    Amend Section 113 Violations to read as follows: 
    Delete Paragraph 113.4 Violation penalties in its entirety. 
    Add Paragraph 113.4 Violation penalties to read as follows: 
    113.4 Violation penalties. Any person who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, install, alter or repair work in violation or the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, in accordance with the applicable sections of the Mobile City Code. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(a)  Violation of the provisions of this code shall be subject to $250.00 fine unless otherwise listed below: 
1.  Occupying a commercial building without a Certificate of Occupancy $500.00 
2.  Working without proper license and certifications $500.00 
3.  Occupying a residential building without a Certificate of Occupancy $300.00 
4.  Signage on all vehicles used by contractor $100.00 
5.  Interference with Code Official $100.00 
    Amend Section 115 Unsafe Buildings and Equipment to read as follows: 
    Amend Paragraph 115.3 Notice to read as follows: 
    Add Paragraph 115.3.1 to read as follows: 
    115.3.1 Procedures. Unsafe Structures and Equipment. All buildings or structures which are unsafe, unsanitary, or not provided with adequate egress or which constitute a fire hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use constitutes a hazard to safety or health by reason of inadequate maintenance, dilapidation, obsolescence, or abandonment, are severally in contempt of this Section, Unsafe Structures and Equipment. All such unsafe buildings are hereby declared illegal and shall be abated by repair and rehabilitation or by demolition in accordance with the Following procedures: 
1.  Whenever the code official shall find any building or structure or portion thereof to be unsafe, as defined in this Section, he/she shall, in accordance with established procedure for legal notice, as required by Alabama Code Section 11-53B-1 enacted on April 17, 2002, and Mobile City Code Section 11-81, Article 5, adopted November 26, 2002, or SECTION 115.3 of this Ordinance, give the mortgagee(s), regulatory boards, the person last assessing the property for state taxes, and the owner, agent, or person in control or such building or structure written notice setting forth the defects thereof. This notice shall require the owner within a stated time either to complete specified repairs or improvements or to demolish and remove the building or structure or portion thereof 
2.  If necessary, such notice shall also require the building, structure, or portion thereof to be vacated forthwith and not re-occupied until the specified repairs and improvements are completed, inspected and approved by the code official. The code official shall cause to be posted at each entrance to such building a notice stating: THIS BUILDING IS UNSAFE AND ITS USE OR OCCUPANCY HAS BEEN PROHIBITED BY THE CODE OFFICIAL. Such notice shall remain posted until the required repairs are made or demolition is completed. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation or their agents, or other servants, to remove such notice without written permission of the code official, or for any person to enter the building except for the purpose of making the required repairs or of demolishing same. 
3.  The mortgagee(s), regulatory boards, last person assessing for state taxation, and if other than those listed, the owner, agent or person in control shall have the right, except in cases of emergency, to appeal from the decision of the code official, as provided thereinafter, and to appear before the Environmental Court at a specified time and place to show cause why he should not comply with said notice. 
4.  In case the mortgagee(s), regulatory boards, last person assessing for state taxation, and the owner, agent or person in control cannot be found within the stated time limit, or if such owner, agent or person in control shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with notice to repair, rehabilitate or to demolish and remove said building or structure or portion thereof, the code official, after having ascertained the cost, shall cause such building or structure or portion thereof, to be secured or required to remain vacant in accordance with SECTION 115 and/or demolished in accord with Alabama Code section 11-53B-1 enacted on April 17, 2002, and Mobile City Code Section 11-81, Article 5, adopted November 26, 2002. 
5.  The decision of the code official shall be final in cases of emergency which, in his/her opinion, involve imminent danger to human life or health. He shall promptly cause such building, structure or portion thereof to be made safe or cause its removal. For this purpose he may at once enter such structure or land on which it stands, or abutting land or structure, with assistance and at such cost as he may deem necessary. He may order the vacation of adjacent structures and if necessary for this purpose may, close a public or private way. 
6.  Costs included under Mobile City Code Section 11-81, Article 5, adopted November 26, 2002, shall be charged to the owner of the premises involved and shall be collected in the manner provided by law. 
7.  The provisions of this code shall not be held to deprive any Federal or State agency, or any applicable governing authority having jurisdiction, of any power or authority. 
    Chapter 2: Definitions of the 2012 International Existing Building Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend section 202 general. Definitions. Add definitions as follows: 
    FLOOD HAZARD AREA. The area designated as a flood hazard area in accordance with the "Storm Water Management and Flood Control Ordinance" adopted and administered by the City of Mobile's Engineering Department. 
    HISTORIC BUILDING. Any building or structure that is listed in the Alabama Register of Landmarks and Heritage or in the National Register of Historic places; designated as a historic property under local or state designation: certified as a contributing resource within a National Register listed or locally designated historic district; or with an opinion or certification that the property is eligible to be listed in the Alabama Register or the National Register of Historic Places either individually or as a contributing building to a historic district: by the State Historic Preservation Officer or the Keeper of the National Register of Historic Places. 
    PEER REVIEW. An alternative assessment for prescriptive code requirements that is performed by a registered or licensed design professional who is independent from the design professional of record. 
    Chapter 3: Compliance Methods of the 2012 International Existing Building Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend Section 301 Compliance Methods to read as follows: 
    Amend Paragraph 301.2 Additional codes to read as follows: 
    301.2 Additional codes. Alterations, repairs, additions and changes of occupancy to, or relocation on existing buildings and structures shall comply with the provisions for alterations, repairs, additions and changes of occupancy or relocation, respectively, in this code and the International Energy Conservation Code, International Fire Code, International Mechanical Code, International Plumbing Code, International Residential Code, National Electrical Code and International Building Code. Where the provisions of other codes conflict with provisions of this code, the provisions of this code shall take precedence. 
    Chapter 7: Alterations-Level 1 of the 2012 International Existing Building Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend Section 702 Building Elements and Materials to read as follows: 
    Delete 702.4.1 International Fuel Gas Code in its entirety. 
    Chapter 14: Performance Compliance Methods of the 2012 International Existing Building Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend Section 1401 General to read as follows: 
    Amend 1401.2 Applicability to read as follows: 
    Amend Paragraph 1401.2 Applicability to read as follows: 
    1401.2 Applicability. Structures existing prior to the effective enforcement date of this code, in which there is work involving additions, alterations or changes of occupancy shall be made to conform to the requirements of this chapter or provisions of Chapters 5 through 13. The provisions of Sections 1401.2.1 through 1401.2.5 shall apply to existing occupancies that will continue to be, or are proposed to be, in Groups A, B, E, F, M, R, and S. These provisions shall not apply to buildings with occupancies in Group H or Group I. 
(Ord. No. 11-004-2011, §§ 8-13, 1-18-11; Ord. No. 11-037-2015 , 3-31-15) 
Chapter 12 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Births and deaths, § 27-21 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definition of "superintendent" and "city sexton." 
    As used in this chapter, "superintendent" and "city sexton" shall mean the parks superintendent. 
(Code 1965, § 12-1; Ord. No. 65-104, § 3, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 12-2. - Map to be kept by revenue officer. 
    The revenue officer of the city shall keep a map showing the location of all lots in any city cemetery which is now or may hereafter be used for interment of the dead, and he shall have such map and the records pertaining to such cemeteries accurately kept. 
(Code 1965, § 12-24) 
Sec. 12-3. - Revenue officer's duty as to purchase money for lots. 
    The money for the purchase of lots for interments shall be paid to the revenue officer. He shall keep a record of such sale, shall charge properly the same on his books and shall countersign the receipt or deed. The money shall be deposited with the general fund of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 12-20) 
Sec. 12-4. - City sexton's bond. 
    The city sexton shall give bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Code 1965, § 12-12) 
Sec. 12-5. - Duty of city sexton as to fees for opening graves; filing monthly account. 
    All fees collected by the city sexton for the opening of graves shall be paid by the city sexton to the city controller. He shall file an account with the city controller of the moneys collected by him before the last day of each month. 
(Code 1965, § 12-11; Ord. No. 65-104, § 5, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 12-6. - Undertakers to obtain burial permits; permit fees. 
    Undertakers, when called upon to bury a person other than an indigent in the city or its police jurisdiction, shall remit an administrative fee in the amount of five dollars ($5.00) to the city sexton to cover the costs of maintaining an accurate record of all deaths and burials which occur in the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 12-16) 
Sec. 12-7. - Permit for disinterment of body; permit fee; duty of superintendent. 
    No disinterment or transfer of bodies from one lot to another, or out of the city, shall be made without first obtaining a permit from the county health department, which may be granted to any undertaker. For this the city sexton shall receive a fee of five dollars ($5.00) from the party applying for the same. The superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, shall see that the grave or vault is properly filled or closed. 
(Code 1965, § 12-17) 
Sec. 12-8. - Work to be done under supervision of superintendent. 
    All work done in any city cemetery by the owners of lots or their representatives shall be performed under the supervision of the superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, and shall be in accordance with all applicable local, state and federal laws. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 12-14; Ord. No. 65-104, § 6, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 12-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-10. - Authority of superintendent to beautify cemetery grounds. 
    The superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, is authorized to adorn and beautify the cemetery grounds. 
(Code 1965, § 12-18) 
Sec. 12-11. - Speculation in cemetery lots; city's assent to transfer. 
    No person shall be interested directly or indirectly, in the purchase or sale of any lot in any city cemetery except for his own family use. No person shall dispose of any such lot, or any part of it, without first reporting to the revenue officer the name of the party to whom such transfer is proposed to be made and receiving the city's assent thereto. 
(Code 1965, § 12-19) 
Sec. 12-12. - Duty of superintendent to protect grounds, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of the superintendent or his duly authorized representative to protect the cemetery grounds and the trees, shrubs, flowers, ornaments, fences, gates, curbing, graves, grave stones, seats and other appendages therein from depredation, to cut the grass as needed, to keep the avenues clean and to maintain good order in the cemetery. 
(Code 1965, § 12-23) 
Sec. 12-13. - Defacing tomb. 
    No one shall destroy, break down, mutilate or deface any tomb, grave, monument, fence or curb erected in any cemetery or pluck any flower or injure any tree or shrub growing therein or in any way violate or profane any cemetery. 
(Code 1965, § 12-21) 
Sec. 12-14. - Burning grass, etc., in cemetery. 
    Any person who burns or sets fire to the grass, shrubbery or undergrowth in any public cemetery in the city shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 12-22) 
Sec. 12-15. - Removal of flowers, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or carry from a cemetery in the city any plants, flowers, trees, shrubs, ornaments, vases, pots, grave stones or grave decorations except with the permission of the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1965, § 12-7) 
Sec. 12-16. - Motorcycles, motorbikes, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person, within the city, or within the police jurisdiction thereof, to ride any motorcycle, motorbike or other two-wheeled vehicle propelled by a motor along the streets, paths or other ways within any cemetery except during and in attendance upon funerals. This section shall not be applied to the operation of such vehicles in cemeteries by officers of the law while in the enforcement of the law. 
(Code 1965, § 12-13) 
Secs. 12-17-12-31. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MAGNOLIA CEMETERY 

Sec. 12-32. - Established. 
    The land lying in the city, known as Magnolia Cemetery, and now being used as a burial place, is established as a public burying ground of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 12-25) 
Sec. 12-33. - Duties of superintendent-Generally. 
    The superintendent or his duly authorized representative shall guard against the introduction of dogs, keep the fences in order, keep the ditches around and in the cemetery free from briars and weeds, keep open all ditches within the cemetery enclosure and keep all streets and alleys therein in good order. 
(Code 1965, § 12-42; Ord. No. 65-104, § 8, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 12-34. - Same-Indigent burial grounds. 
    The superintendent or his duly authorized representative shall keep in order the indigent burial grounds and cut the grass from time to time. He shall be notified of all indigent burials and the time and place thereof, either in Magnolia Cemetery or in the plot adjoining. 
(Code 1965, § 12-43) 
Sec. 12-35. - Same-Prevention from depredation. 
    The superintendent shall protect Magnolia Cemetery and its monuments, walls and fences from depredation and shall prevent the removal or plucking of flowers, shrubbery or designs, except by the owner or on his written authority. 
(Code 1965, § 12-44) 
Sec. 12-36. - Same-Trash or refuse; removal of soil. 
    The superintendent or his duly authorized representative shall remove from the streets and alleys in Magnolia Cemetery all refuse from lots and prevent the depositing of refuse in any of the streets. He shall prevent the use of any of the lots or squares for the deposit of trash or refuse. He shall prevent the removal of soil from the grounds without the consent of the city engineer, who can authorize its removal when necessary for grading or improving the grounds. All material for filling lots shall be brought from without the cemetery enclosure. 
(Code 1965, § 12-45; Ord. No. 65-104, § 9, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 12-37. - Superintendent not to have financial interest in keeping lots in order. 
    The superintendent shall not be directly or indirectly interested financially in keeping any lot in Magnolia Cemetery in order. 
(Code 1965, § 12-55) 
Sec. 12-38. - Finance department to issue deeds and receive money. 
    It shall be the duty of the finance department of the city to execute and issue deeds, or transfers, for burial lots in Magnolia Cemetery and to receive the money for the sale of such lots. Such deeds, or transfers, shall be countersigned by the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 12-26) 
Sec. 12-39. - Finance department's fee. 
    For the services to be rendered by the finance department, a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each deed executed and issued shall be collected from the person purchasing the lot. 
(Code 1965, § 12-27) 
Sec. 12-40. - Erecting monuments-Approval. 
    The erection of a monument or other structure on or about any lot shall require the approval of the owner of the lot or his heirs, transfers or assigns, as well as a permit therefor, issued by the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. The superintendent or his duly authorized representative is authorized to establish reasonable standards and criteria for the erection of a monument with respect to its design, size and placement within the lot. The repair of an existing monument or other structure shall, with the exception of repairs performed by the city or its agent, also require a permit issued by the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. 
(Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-41. - Same-Placement standards. 
    Any monument or other structure shall be placed on a solid concrete foundation of sufficient size and depth and sufficiently reinforced to support the superstructure. The aboveground part of the monument or other structure shall be constructed of natural stone (marble or granite) or of bronze, meeting the specifications of the U.S. Bureau of Standards. Fences may be of cast or wrought iron. Low retaining walls may be of brick but not of concrete block. No artificial stone or soft stone will be permitted, and no cementitious material, other than lime based plaster or stucco, will be permitted above grade. 
(Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-42. - Repair of stones, monuments, etc. 
    The superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, shall have the authority but shall not be required to repair, refurbish, restore or clean any tombstone, mausoleum, monument or other object of funerary art within the cemetery, should the owner of the lot fail to do so. 
(Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-43. - Cleaning stones, monuments, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to clean or refurbish any tombstone, mausoleum or monument within the cemetery, or to do rubbings of any tombstone or monument within the cemetery, without first obtaining the permission of the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. Any person seeking such permission must be able to demonstrate that the cleaning, refurbishing or rubbing will in no way injure or harm the tombstone, monument or mausoleum and meets any standards or criteria set by the superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, with respect thereto. 
(Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-44. - Double deep burials. 
    There shall be no double deep burials allowed in Magnolia Cemetery without first obtaining the written consent of the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. 
(Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-45. - Permit required for work other than general maintenance care. 
    No work, other than general maintenance care, shall be done in, on, under or about any lot in Magnolia Cemetery, or in any division thereof, without the owner of such lot first obtaining a permit from the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 12-49) 
Sec. 12-46. - Work done by lot owners, etc., to be under supervision of superintendent. 
    All work done in Magnolia Cemetery or in any addition or division thereof by the owners of lots or their employees shall be performed under the supervision of the superintendent or his duly authorized representative, and any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 12-50) 
Sec. 12-47. - Fees for opening graves. 
    A reasonable fee for the opening and closing of graves in Magnolia Cemetery shall be established and amended as necessary from time to time by the superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, or the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 12-52; Ord. No. 12-036, 4-7-81; Ord. No. 65-104, § 10, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 12-48. - Exchange of Church Street Cemetery lot for Magnolia Cemetery lot. 
    Whenever a lot in Church Street Cemetery is given in exchange for a lot in Magnolia Cemetery, the size of such lot in Magnolia Cemetery shall be twelve (12) feet by twenty (20) feet. 
(Code 1965, § 12-3) 
Sec. 12-49. - Construction of vaults and tombs. 
    Persons who desire to build vaults or tombs for future use in Magnolia Cemetery shall first get permission from the superintendent or his duly authorized representative to do so and shall, when finished, close the vault or tomb and it shall be opened again only pursuant to a regular burial permit. The contractor for the building of all vaults or tombs in such cemetery, whether for future or immediate use, shall remove all dirt and debris from the lots. 
(Code 1965, § 12-40) 
Sec. 12-50. - Masons working in cemetery. 
    Brick and stone masons and other persons working in Magnolia Cemetery shall not obstruct the streets or gutters therein. Mortar shall be mixed in a box or other vessel and the grounds shall not be defaced in any manner. Upon the completion of such work, the person doing the same shall remove all dirt and debris made by him and leave the grounds clean and in good condition. 
(Code 1965, § 12-53) 
Sec. 12-51. - Lot caretakers to furnish superintendent with list of lots cared for. 
    All persons who contract to keep lots in Magnolia Cemetery in order, by the week or year, shall furnish the superintendent or his duly authorized representative with a list of such lots. 
(Code 1965, § 12-54) 
Sec. 12-52. - Closing. 
    The superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, shall close Magnolia Cemetery to the public during periods of darkness. The entrances on Ann Street and Virginia Street will be opened at 7:00 a.m. Such entrances shall be closed to the public at 5:00 p.m. during the winter and 7:00 p.m. during the summer. The George Street entrance shall be closed to all vehicles at all times, except by special permission from the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1965, § 12-37) 
Sec. 12-53. - Reserved. 
Sec. 12-54. - Automobiles generally. 
    Automobiles are authorized to enter Magnolia Cemetery. The right to use the cemetery by automobiles is authorized solely and exclusively for the purpose of allowing persons so desiring to go to burial lots in the cemetery, and no automobile shall be allowed in the cemetery unless used in transporting persons who desire to visit burial lots. No such vehicle shall be allowed to block the streets in the cemetery. Automobiles while in the cemetery shall not exceed in speed the rate of twelve (12) miles per hour. 
(Code 1965, § 12-35) 
Sec. 12-55. - Reckless driving. 
    Any person who shall, in the confines of Magnolia Cemetery or any division thereof, operate a motor vehicle or drive any beast of burden, bicycle or vehicle of any kind or character recklessly or so as to endanger property or the life or limb of any person shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 12-36) 
Sec. 12-56. - Vehicles; obstructing ditch or drain. 
    No one shall drive or take any vehicles through Magnolia Cemetery or otherwise make it a thoroughfare when not engaged in legitimate duties connected with the cemetery. No one shall drive outside the roadway or use, occupy or obstruct a ditch or drain. 
(Code 1965, § 12-48) 
Sec. 12-57. - Paving of lots. 
    The paving of a lot in Magnolia Cemetery with cementitious or other impervious material, or covering a lot with oyster, clam or other shells or with gravel, is prohibited. 
(Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-58. - Obstructing streets, drains or gutters with dirt, etc. 
    No dirt, grass, manure, trees, shrubbery, bricks, mortar or other article or substance shall be allowed to obstruct any street, drain or gutter in Magnolia Cemetery. 
(Code 1965, § 12-58) 
Cross reference- Drainage, Ch. 17; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 57. 
Sec. 12-59. - Storing building materials. 
    It shall be unlawful to store or put any materials, such as brick, stone, sand, gravel or other materials used for building purposes, upon any of the roadways or alleys of Magnolia Cemetery, unless such materials are placed in tight bins, tight floors or other tight receptacles and, when placed in the roadways, so placed as to leave ample room for the passing of all vehicles and so placed as to not obstruct any of the drains. All persons using any of the roadways of the cemetery for the storing of materials shall, as soon as the work being done is finished, clean up the roadway and leave it in a good and clean condition. 
(Code 1965, § 12-33) 
Sec. 12-60. - Disposal of trash from lots. 
    Trash from lots in Magnolia Cemetery shall be removed by the owner of the lot or his duly authorized representative. All dirt, grass, weeds and other debris from lots shall be disposed of in accordance with Magnolia Cemetery rules and regulations subject to supervision by the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. 
(Code 1965, § 12-56) 
Sec. 12-61. - Manure or fertilizer for lots. 
    Manure or fertilizer for lots in Magnolia Cemetery shall not be placed in the cemetery streets. 
(Code 1965, § 12-57) 
Sec. 12-62. - Lot fencing, plants, improvements, etc. 
(a)  Persons owning lots in Magnolia Cemetery, and their heirs, transfers and assigns, shall be allowed to fence same; plant trees, shrubs and flowers; erect lawn seats, trellises or other outdoor structures; and make other desirable improvements which are not integral parts of the stone monuments, mausoleums or other historic funerary art structures, upon receiving written permission and approval by the superintendent or his duly authorized representative. 
(b)  Flowers, potted plants, wreaths and other floral pieces, whether real or artificial, are permitted in Magnolia Cemetery year-round. The superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, shall have the authority to remove any flowers, real or artificial, if not removed by the lot owner when the same become wilted, dead, faded or soiled. The use of glass or china jars and of tin cans as flower vases or pots is prohibited. 
(Code 1965, § 12-46; Magnolia Cemetery Rules and Regulations) 
Sec. 12-63. - Hitching animals to fences, etc.; defacing monuments, etc.; profane, etc., language or intoxication. 
    No one shall hitch or tie any horse, mule or other animal to any fence, monument, ornamental tree or shrub planted in Magnolia Cemetery or deface any curb, fence, tomb, monument, tree or shrub or commit any profanation of any kind or use any profane, indecent or vulgar language within its enclosure or come within its limits in a state of intoxication. 
(Code 1965, § 12-47) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 7; malicious injury to property, § 39-72. 
Sec. 12-64. - Confederate Soldiers' Rest-Dedication. 
    The piece of ground situated in the graveyard in the northwest corner of square no. 13, fronting north seventy-eight (78) feet six (6) inches and west ninety-three (93) feet six (6) inches shall be laid off as burial ground for Confederate soldiers, to be called the "Soldiers' Rest." 
(Code 1965, § 12-4) 
Sec. 12-65. - Same-Burials in. 
    It shall be the duty of the city sexton to dig the graves at the Soldiers' Rest in line along the west alley, first placing a cedar stake at the head of each grave with a number thereon, corresponding to the number attached to the name of the soldier buried, a separate report of whom shall be made by the superintendent monthly and shall be carefully recorded in a book of record of "deceased patriots." Whenever the first row shall have been filled, then a space of three (3) feet shall be allowed between the feet of the first row and the head of the second row and so on between the rows. 
(Code 1965, § 12-5) 
Sec. 12-66. - Space for monument at Soldiers' Rest. 
    A space of twelve (12) feet square shall be reserved in the center of the Soldiers' Rest for the erection of a suitable monument at a future time, showing that the country honors her sons. 
(Code 1965, § 12-6) 
Chapter 14 - CONTRACTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, adopted December 18, 2018, amended the Code by repealing former ch. 14, §§ 14-1-14-3, and adding a new ch. 14. Former ch. 14 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Code of 1965, § 2-10.1; Ord. No. 65-020, adopted November 6. 1985; Ord. No. 02-80, adopted April 15, 1986; and Ord. No. 01-044, adopted July 6, 1993. 
Cross reference- Public improvements, ch. 50. 

Sec. 14-1. - Findings. 
(a)  The city is an Alabama Class 2 municipality created pursuant to the Zoghby Act, Code of Ala., § 11-44C-1 et seq. and vested with a portion of the state's sovereign power to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
State Law reference- Adoption and enforcement authorized, Code of Ala., § 11-45-1. 
(b)  All powers of the city are "vested in the council, which is authorized to enact ordinances, adopt budgets and determine policies." All powers "shall be exercised in the manner prescribed [by the Zoghby Act] or if the manner be not prescribed, then in such manner as may be prescribed by law or by ordinance." 
State Law reference- City continued as municipal corporation, Code of Ala., § 11-44C-10; Government known as "mayor-council form of government;" powers of city vested in council; manner in which powers exercised, Code of Ala., § 11-44C-11. 
(c)  In addition to the powers enumerated in the Zoghby Act, the council has all of the powers granted to municipal corporations by the constitution and laws of the state, together with "all the implied powers necessary to carry into execution all the powers granted." 
State Law reference- Powers of city generally, Code of Ala., § 11-44C-12. 
(d)  The power to contract is specifically vested in the council by Code of Ala., § 11-40-1: "All municipal organizations are "bodies politic and corporate" with the power to "contract and be contracted with." 
(e)  The council is charged with the "management and control of the finances and all of the property, real and personal, belonging to the City," Code of Ala., § 11-43-56. To be valid, all contracts of the city must be in writing, serve a public purpose, and be executed in the name of the city by the officers authorized by law or ordinance. The council has previously authorized the mayor to execute certain contracts without council approval, see e.g. § 2-66, Mobile City Code. 
State Law reference- Execution of contracts, Code of Ala., § 11-47-5. 
(f)  The purpose of this ordinance is to promote transparency in the contracting process; to adopt reasonable regulations with respect thereto; to require full disclosure of the city's contractual obligations; and to specify the office authorized to contract on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-2. - Disclosure and other requirements. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this chapter, the term "contract" means a written agreement, by whatever name, that imposes a financial obligation on the City; or that affects, or may affect, any property rights of the City. The term does not include deed, contracts, or bonds required in judicial proceedings, as set forth in Code of Ala., § 11-43-83. 
(b)  Disclosure requirements. Not later than 30 days from the effective date of this ordinance, the mayor shall cause to be filed with the city clerk a true and correct copy of the following: 
(1)  Grant agreements that are or will be in effect for the 2018-19 fiscal year; 
(2)  Retainer agreements, engagement letters or other contracts for legal services with attorneys whether hire pursuant to Code of Ala., § 11-44C-38(b) or otherwise; 
(3)  All contracts, letters or other communications setting out or describing the terms of the employment of the city attorney, or any firm with which he is affiliated as city attorney or chief legal advisor to the mayor; or in any other capacity compensated or funded by the city; and 
(4)  Appointment letters or agreements to employ any person who is not in the "classified service" as defined by Act 470, section II (otherwise known as the Mobile County Personnel Law), and any person whom the mayor has appointed to a position pursuant to Code of Ala., § 11-44C-40 or any other authority. Such disclosures shall identify the person's title, department, salary, supervisor, length of service and all other terms of employment. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-3. - Contract procedures. 
(a)  Execution. All contracts shall be in writing, serve a public purpose, and be executed in the name of the city by the officers authorized by law or ordinance. The mayor shall have no authority to execute any contract that has not first been approved by the city council, except for deeds and bonds required in judicial proceedings, and as may be authorized by this chapter. 
(b)  Bid awards. All bids shall be awarded by resolution duly adopted by the council. 
(c)  Settlements. No payment shall be made to settle, adjust, or compromise any litigation, claim, debt, account, dispute, demand for or against the city, unless the agreement is first reduced to writing, presented to and approved by the council, except for settlements with a monetary value of less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and which have been approved by the mayor and the city attorney. All settlements, in any amount, shall be promptly filed with the city clerk. 
(d)  Performance contracts. All commitments to fund organizations, regardless of funding source, shall require a performance contract and resolution of the council finding a public purpose for the expenditure. 
(e)  Budgeted performance contracts. Not later than 30 days after the effective date of this ordinance, the mayor shall prepare performance contracts for all organizations that are itemized in the annual budget, and shall submit such contracts to the council for approval. Thereafter, such performance contracts shall be prepared and submitted to the council for approval not later than 30 days after the effective date of the general fund budget. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-4. - Change orders. 
    The mayor is authorized to approve change orders to city construction contracts subject to at least one (1) of the following criteria. All change orders shall be filed in the clerk's office. 
(1)  Minor changes for a total monetary value less than required for competitive bidding under the state competitive bid laws. 
(2)  Changes for matters relatively minor and incidental to the original contract necessitated by unforeseeable circumstances arising during the course of the work. 
(3)  Emergencies arising during the course of the work on the contract. 
(4)  Changes or alternates provided for in the original bidding where there is no difference in price on the change order from the original best bid on the alternate. 
(5)  Changes of relatively minor items not contemplated when the plans and specifications were prepared and the project was bid which are in the public interest and which do not exceed ten (10) percent of the contract price. This shall mean that the total of all change orders on each contract shall not exceed ten (10) percent of the contract price for each project. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-5. - Leases. 
    If a new lease or lease-purchase requires funding which will overlap into the subsequent budget year, council approval will be required. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-6. - Contracts requiring budget amendments. 
    All contracts requiring a budget amendment for funding must come before the council in order to appropriate funds. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-7. - Contracts implementing major programs. 
    Contracts which implement major programs for the city should come before the council for the purpose of full disclosure. This includes but is not limited to contracts which exceed seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) for construction, consultants, training, lease purchases, privatized services, and other contracts for services. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-8. - Contracts for routine purchases. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, a contract shall be deemed for routine purchases if the total amount of the contract is less than seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00). Pursuant to Code of Ala., § 11-44C-72, the purchasing agent may execute contracts for routine purchases so long as it is pursuant to a written requisition from the head of the office, department or agency whose appropriation will be charged; and no contract or order shall be issued to any vendor unless and until the director of finance certifies that there is a sufficient unencumbered appropriation balance to pay for the supplies, materials, equipment or contractual service for which the contract or order is to be issued. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-9. - Nondiscrimination provisions to be included in municipal contracts. 
    All municipal contracting agencies shall include in every municipal contract hereafter entered into the following provisions: 
"During the performance of this contract the contractor agrees as follows: 
1.  The contractor will not discriminate against any employee or applicant for employment because of race, creed, color, national origin or disability. The contractor will take affirmative action to ensure that applicants are employed, and that employees are treated during employment, without regard to their race, creed, color, national origin or disability. Such action shall include but not be limited to the following: Employment, upgrading, demotion or transfer; recruitment or recruitment advertising; layoff or termination; rates of pay or other forms of compensation; and selection for training, including apprenticeship. The contractor agrees to post in conspicuous places, available to employees and applicants for employment, notices to be provided by the contracting agency of the municipality setting forth the provisions of this nondiscrimination clause. 
2.  The contractor will, in all solicitations or advertisements for employees placed by or on behalf of the contractor, state that all qualifying applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race, creed, color, national origin or disability. 
3.  The contractor will send to each labor union or representative of workers with which he has a collective bargaining agreement or other contract or understanding, a notice to be provided by the municipal contracting agency, advising the labor union or worker's representative of the contractor's commitments under this section, and shall post copies of such notice in conspicuous places available to employees and applicants for employment. 
4.  In the event of the contractor's noncompliance with the nondiscrimination clauses of this contract, this contract may be canceled, terminated or suspended in whole or in part and the contractor may be declared ineligible for further municipal contracts. 
5.  The contractor will include the provisions of this section in every subcontract or purchase order unless exempted by written orders of the governing body of the City of Mobile so that such provisions will be binding upon each subcontractor or vendor. 
6.  Each contractor will agree to the above in writing, including the contractor's commitment to follow the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
Sec. 14-10. - Participation by socially and economically disadvantaged contractors. 
(a)  All contracts or agreements entered into by the city or any entity thereof for any service of any kind, whether by bid or otherwise, including but not limited to professional services and bond issues, shall make every reasonable effort to require that the contractor, firm or company to which any such contract is awarded must have at least fifteen (15) percent participation by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals, or the city shall make every reasonable effort to ensure that at least fifteen (15) percent of the total value of all such contracts or agreements described above shall be awarded to qualified contractors or professionals who are socially and economically disadvantaged. 
(b)  The city will hire a consultant to provide technical assistance and recommend regulations to the city to ensure every reasonable effort is made to implement this section. 
(Ord. No. 14-034-2018 , § 1, 12-18-18)

ARTICLE II. - MOBILE CIVIC CENTER[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Carrying alcoholic beverage container into civic center, § 30-7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 15-31-15-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD 

Sec. 15-41. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the "Mobile Civic Center Advisory Board," referred to herein as the Civic Center Board. 
(Code 1965, § 2-49; Ord. No. 15-047-2009, § 1, 11-24-09) 
Sec. 15-42. - Membership; terms. 
(a)  The civic center board shall consist of fourteen (14) members appointed by the city council. The term of each member of such board shall be for three (3) years, except as hereinafter set forth in this section. 
(b)  The terms of the members of the civic center board shall be divided into three (3) classes and be appointed each year to serve for a three (3) year term. The twelve (12) members presently serving on the civic center board shall continue to serve as members of such board for the terms to which they had been heretofore appointed. The two (2) additional members of the civic center board created by the ordinance amending this section shall be appointed by the city council to serve terms commencing immediately upon their appointment and ending on November 15, 1988. All appointees shall serve the full term for which they are appointed unless removed by the city council for cause. 
(c)  In the event of vacancies caused by death, illness, resignation or for other cause deemed sufficient by the city council, appointments shall be made by the city council to fill the unexpired term of such member of such board. 
(Code 1965, § 2-50; Ord. No. 02-042, 12-24-85) 
Sec. 15-43. - Compensation. 
    Members of the civic center board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 2-51; Ord. No. 02-042, 12-24-85) 
Sec. 15-44. - Powers. 
    The civic center board shall have the power and authority to: 
(1)  Observe the operation, management, affairs, condition and business transactions of the civic center, arena, theater, and appurtenant facilities; to report said observations to the city council; and to make recommendations to the city council for the orderly and efficient operation and maintenance of the civic center. 
(2)  Inasmuch as the city has entered into a management agreement for the operation of the civic center, the civic center board shall have no authority, direct or indirect, to engage in the management, operation, or promotion of the civic center. However, the board members shall have the power and authority to notify the chairman of the board of any grievances or violations of the management agreement. The chairman will bring the subject of any such grievances or violations before the board for discussion, and if the board agrees that a problem exists, then the chairman will notify the council president of the problem. All board members may advise the city council, or any member of the city council, of the problem and make recommendations for resolution. 
(3)  Provide written reports to the council, on a semiannual basis, concerning the operation and maintenance of the civic center and its facilities and the board's recommendations for possible improvements, within the limitations of the board's authority as set out in paragraph (2) of this section 15-44. 
(4)  Receive and review the reports of the civic center's anticipated activities and financial condition and monthly reports of activities and finances that are provided to the city by the management company. The mayor's office should make all such statements available to the city clerk's office and mailed to the advisory board within two weeks upon its receipt by the administration. 
(Code 1965, § 2-52; Ord. No. 02-042, 12-24-85; Ord. No. 15-047-2009, § 2, 11-24-09) 
Secs. 15-45-15-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIBRARY[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Library, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-57-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-51. - Posting of rules. 
    The Mobile public library rules shall be conspicuously posted in all library facilities, including rules for requests of auxiliary aids and services and other accommodations which should be made in advance, when possible, to the library. 
(Ord. No. 33-122, § 2, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 01-044, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 15-52. - Violation of rules. 
(a)  In the event that the Mobile public library rules are violated by any library customer in the presence of the director of the Mobile public library, or his designated representative, such as a library official, he/she shall have the power and authority to direct such customer to immediately leave the premises and/or revoke the customer's library privileges for one (1) year. 
(b)  In the event such a library customer does not immediately leave the premises, the police department should be notified to remove the trespasser. 
(Ord. No. 33-122, § 4, 12-20-88; Ord. No. 15-034, § 1, 5-25-94) 
Sec. 15-53. - Trespassing at the library. 
    Any person violating the posted Mobile public library rules shall, after refusing a directive to leave the library premises, be deemed a "trespasser," and any person who enters any library facility while his or her library privileges are revoked shall be deemed a "trespasser." 
(Ord. No. 33-122, § 5, 12-20-88) 
Sec. 15-54. - Damaging, etc., library property. 
    Any person who maliciously cuts, tears, defaces, breaks or injures any book, newspaper, magazine, video or audio tape, compact disc, or other property owned by or deposited in the Mobile public library or in any of its facilities shall be prosecuted pursuant to section 1-31 et seq., chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 33-10; Ord. No. 15-034, § 1, 5-25-94) 
Sec. 15-55. - Detention of library book, etc., after notice. 
(a)  Any person who is shown to be the holder of a membership card upon the records of the Mobile public library shall be chargeable with all loans or withdrawals made upon such membership card unless such person shall have prior to such loan or withdrawal surrendered his or her card to the Mobile public library or given written notification to the Mobile public library of the loss or theft of same. 
(b)  Any person who willfully detains any book, newspaper, magazine, video or audio tape, compact disc, or other property of the Mobile public library or any of its branches, vehicles or other facilities for thirty (30) days after notice in writing to return the same, given after the expiration of the time which, by the rules of the library, such article or other property may be kept, shall be prosecuted pursuant to section 1-31 et seq., chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(c)  Any such overdue notice shall be perfected when said notice is deposited by certified mail with the United States Postal Service and addressed to such holder at the address shown upon the membership records of the Mobile public library with return receipt requested. 
(Code 1965, § 33-11; Ord. No. 15-034, § 1, 5-25-94) 
Sec. 15-56. - False reporting or criminal impersonation to library officials. 
(a)  A person commits the offense of false reporting to a library official if he or she knowingly makes a false report or causes the transmission of false information in either the library card application process or any procedure of borrowing materials from any branch, vehicle or other facility of the Mobile public library system. 
(b)  A person commits the offense of criminal impersonation to a library official if he or she assumes a false identity to a library official, or does any act in his or her assumed character with an intent to gain an economic benefit for himself, herself or another, or to injure or defraud another. 
(Ord. No. 15-034, § 1, 5-25-94) 
Secs. 15-57-15-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD 

Sec. 15-71. - Government and supervision vested in library board; appointment and number of members of board. 
    The government and supervision of the "Mobile Public Library," hereinafter referred to in this article as the "library," shall be vested in the "Mobile Public Library Board," hereinafter referred to as the "library board," the members of which shall be appointed by the city council from nominations made by the library board at its annual meetings. The library board shall consist of seven (7) or five (5) members, the number to be determined at each annual meeting of the library board at the time nominations are made. Such meetings shall provide for auxiliary aids and services upon request. 
(Code 1965, § 33-1; Ord. No. 01-044, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 15-72. - Terms of members. 
    All appointments to the library board shall be for terms of four (4) years. 
(Code 1965, § 33-2) 
Sec. 15-73. - Vacancies. 
    The city council shall fill all vacancies on the library board, including expired and unexpired terms, from nominations proposed by the library board. 
(Code 1965, § 33-3) 
Sec. 15-74. - Compensation of board members. 
    The members of the library board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 33-4) 
Sec. 15-75. - Officers and bylaws. 
    The library board shall elect its officers and adopt its bylaws. 
(Code 1965, § 33-5) 
Sec. 15-76. - Powers and duties of board. 
    The library board shall be vested with the following powers and perform the following duties: 
(1)  Expenditures. It shall have full power and authority to control the expenditures of all funds received or appropriated for the Mobile public library. 
(2)  Erection, etc., of buildings. It shall have power to erect or rent buildings, with the approval of the city council, to cost not in excess of the funds available to it. 
(3)  Purchase of books and equipment; providing library services. It shall be authorized to purchase books and equipment and to provide a system of library services to be made easily available to all citizens of the city through the central library, branches, stations, book truck service or other appropriate means. 
(4)  Election of director and other employees. It shall be authorized to elect a director and other employees. Such director shall be a professionally trained librarian. 
(5)  Receipt of gifts and trusts. It shall be authorized to receive gifts and administer trusts. 
(6)  Borrowing and lending books to other libraries. It shall be authorized to borrow books from and to lend books to other libraries. 
(7)  Contracts for library service outside the city. It shall be authorized to make contracts with other agencies for the providing of library service outside the city, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 33-6) 
Sec. 15-77. - Rule-making powers. 
(a)  The Mobile library board shall be vested with the power and authority to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the benefit of the Mobile public library system. These rules and regulations shall be known as Mobile public library rules. 
(b)  The Mobile public library board shall be vested with the power and authority to amend the Mobile public library rules from time to time, as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 33-122, §§ 1, 3, 12-20-88) 
Sec. 15-78. - Gifts. 
    Any property donated to the library board shall immediately become the property of the city to be held for the benefit of the library. 
(Code 1965, § 33-7) 
Sec. 15-79. - Records; minutes of board meetings. 
    A careful and complete record and set of books shall be kept by the library board, showing the proceedings of their several meetings and the receipts and disbursements, in detail, of all funds. Records shall be available in Braille, large print, or audio cassette, if requested. 
(Code 1965, § 33-8; Ord. No. 01-044, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 15-80. - Annual report of board. 
    The library board shall prepare a written financial and administrative report at the close of the fiscal year of the city and the same shall be presented to the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 33-9) 
Secs. 15-81-15-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MUSEUM 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-91. - Creation. 
    Pursuant to Code of Alabama, Section 11-47-16, there is hereby created a municipal historic museum called the "Museum of the City of Mobile." 
(Code 1965, § 40-1) 
Secs. 15-92-15-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD 

Sec. 15-101. - Established; composition; appointment of members. 
    There is hereby established a board of twenty-one (21) members to be known as the "Mobile Museum Board," the members of which shall be appointed by the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 40-2; Ord. No. 40-114, 11-29-77) 
Sec. 15-102. - Terms of members; filling vacancies. 
    All appointments made pursuant to the provisions of section 15-101 shall be for terms of three (3) years each. All vacancies on the Mobile museum board shall be filled by appointment of the council, and, in the event of an unexpired term being filled, the member appointed shall serve the balance of the term of the member whose place he is filling. 
(Code 1965, § 40-3) 
Sec. 15-103. - Compensation of members. 
    Members of the Mobile museum board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 40-4) 
Sec. 15-104. - Officers, bylaws, etc. 
    The Mobile museum board shall elect its officers and adopt its bylaws and may become a body corporate for the purpose of promoting a public museum for the city and purposes of a like kind. 
(Code 1965, § 40-5) 
Sec. 15-105. - Powers and duties. 
    The Mobile museum board shall be vested with the following powers and shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  It shall have full power and authority to accept historic items in behalf of the city, to catalogue and keep a record of the same and to determine which items now or hereafter on hand are of an historic value and to dispose of those items which do not have an historic value. 
(2)  It shall have full power and authority to determine which places shall be established in the city museums, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(3)  It shall have full power and authority to control the expenditure of all funds received for the operation of the public museum or museums established in the city. 
(4)  It shall have the power to own real property, to rent the same and to dispose of all property owned by it. It shall be authorized to perform all acts necessary for the operation of a public museum or museums established in the city. 
(5)  It shall be authorized to receive gifts and administer trusts. 
(6)  In the event it becomes incorporated, then it shall have all of the foregoing powers and all powers granted to it by law. 
(Code 1965, § 40-6) 
Sec. 15-106. - Property donated to board. 
    Any property donated to the Mobile museum board shall immediately become the property of the city for the benefit of the museum of the city. However, in the event that the Mobile museum board becomes incorporated, then any property donated to the Mobile museum board shall become the property of the Mobile museum board, but upon the dissolution of the Mobile museum board, then all property owned by the Mobile museum board at the time of the dissolution shall become the property of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 40-7) 
Sec. 15-107. - Records to be kept. 
    An accurate and complete record and set of books shall be kept by the Mobile museum board showing the proceedings of its meetings and detailed statements of all receipts and disbursements. Such records shall be available in Braille, etc. upon request. 
(Code 1965, § 40-8; Ord. No. 01-044, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 15-108. - Annual reports. 
    The Mobile museum board shall prepare and complete written financial and administrative reports at the close of each fiscal year of the city and the same shall be presented to the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 40-9) 
Sec. 15-109. - Created as separate administrative agency, etc. 
    The Mobile museum board established by section 15-101 is created as an administrative agency or instrumentality provided for in Section 11-47-16 of the Code of Alabama, to administer the one or more public museums established in the city and is separate and apart from the Fine Arts Museum of the South at Mobile Board established by section 15-131. 
(Code 1965, § 40-10) 
Secs. 15-110-15-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - MOBILE MUSEUM OF ART[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance Number 09-078, adopted November 1, 1994, changed the name of the "Fine Arts Musuem of the South" to the "Mobile Museum of Art," and the "Fine Arts Musuem of the South Board" to the "Mobile Museum of Art Board." 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-121. - Established. 
    Pursuant to Code of Alabama, Section 11-47-16, there is hereby created a municipal art museum called the "Mobile Museum of Art." 
(Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Secs. 15-122-15-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD 

Sec. 15-131. - Established; composition. 
    There is hereby established a board of twenty-one (21) members to be known as the "Mobile Museum of Art Board," herein referred to as the "board," which shall be appointed by the following entities:The city appoints seven (7) members, the county appoints one (1) member, the Mobile Arts Council appoints one (1) member, the Mobile Art Association appoints one (1) member, the Art Patrons League appoints one (1) member and the Mobile Museum of Art appoints ten (10) members. 
(Code 1965, § 2-42; Ord. No. 65-086, § 1, 11-17-87; Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Sec. 15-132. - Terms; filling vacancies. 
(a)  Members appointed by the Mobile Arts Council, the Mobile Art Association and the Art Patrons League shall each serve for a term of one (1) year. 
(b)  All other appointments shall be for terms of three (3) years each. All vacancies on such board shall be filled by the appointing entity, and the member appointed shall serve the balance of the term of the member whose place he is filling. 
(Code 1965, § 2-43; Ord. No. 65-086, § 1, 11-17-87) 
Sec. 15-133. - Compensation of members. 
    Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1965, § 2-44; Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Sec. 15-134. - Officers, bylaws, etc. 
    The board shall elect its officers and adopt its bylaws and generally operate in a manner to promote the municipal art museum, Mobile Musuem of Art. 
(Code 1965, § 2-45; Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Sec. 15-135. - Powers generally. 
    The board shall have power and authority to perform the following: 
(1)  To receive and display works of art, including oils, watercolors and ceramics. 
(2)  To conduct an instructional program in the arts for citizens of all ages. 
(3)  To administratively operate the Mobile Museum of Art in cooperation with the city. 
(4)  To receive gifts of money or art bequeathed to the city in behalf of the city. 
(5)  To administer moneys received whether from the city or other sources, subject to audit of the city or its agents. 
(6)  To perform all acts necessary to the operation of a municipal art museum. 
(7)  To incorporate as a nonprofit corporation under the laws of the state with the above powers and such powers as are provided by law. 
(Code 1965, § 2-46; Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Sec. 15-136. - Property donated to board. 
    Any property of every kind and nature donated to the board shall immediately become the property of the city to be held for the benefit of the Mobile Museum of Art. However, in the event that the board becomes incorporated, then any property donated to the board shall become the property of the board, but upon the dissolution of the board, then all property owned by the board at the time of the dissolution shall become the property of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 2-47; Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Sec. 15-137. - Records generally; annual financial statement. 
    An accurate and complete record and set of books shall be kept by the board showing the proceedings of its meetings and a detailed statement of all receipts and disbursements. The board shall cause a copy of its minutes to be filed with the city clerk and shall by its proper officer render an annual financial statement to the city council at the conclusion of the fiscal year, which shall be the same as that of the city. Such records shall be made available in Braille, etc. upon request. 
(Code 1965, § 2-48; Ord. No. 01-044, § 1, 7-6-93; Ord. No. 09-078, § 1, 11-1-94) 
Chapter 17 - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND FLOOD CONTROL[1]

ARTICLE I. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT AND FLOOD CONTROL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-025-2014 , amended the Code by repealing former div. 1, §§ 17-1-17-9, 17-11-17-16, and adding a new div. 1. Former div. 1 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 65-007-2009, adopted March 10, 2009. 

Subpart A. - General Provisions 

Sec. 17-1. - Purpose; applicability; manual; jurisdiction; compliance; abrogration; interpretation; severability. 
(a)  Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this article to control land disturbance activities and stormwater drainage facilities within the corporate limits of the city in order to promote the public health, safety and general welfare, and to comply with the Federal Clean Water Act, the Alabama Water Pollution Control Act, as amended, Alabama Code (1975), § 22-21-1, et seq., the Alabama Environmental Management Act, as amended, Alabama Code (1975), § 22-22A-1, et seq., and rules and regulations adopted thereunder, the national pollution discharge elimination system (NPDES) program to meet its stormwater discharge permit requirements, and Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) requirements to reduce flooding through provisions designed to: 
(1)  Protect human life and health; 
(2)  Protect the natural assets and resources of the city; 
(3)  Protect the lands and waters of the city from the effects of soil erosion, sedimentation, and illicit discharges into its municipal separate storm sewer system; 
(4)  Prevent and reduce degradation of streams and lakes from the effects of siltation and illicit discharges; 
(5)  Prevent obstruction of drainage channels, reduce flood damage and prevent damage to the property of adjacent land owners; 
(6)  Enforce the city's stormwater management program; 
(7)  Reduce the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding; 
(8)  Provide for the sound use and development of flood-prone areas so as to maximize beneficial use without increasing flood hazard potential; 
(9)  Reduce damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and sewer lines, electric, telephone and gas facilities, and streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(10)  Ensure a functional stormwater drainage system that will not result in excessive maintenance costs; 
(11)  Encourage the improvement of existing flooding problems in conjunction with new development that enhances and does not impair the city's stormwater drainage system; 
(12)  Encourage the use of natural and aesthetically pleasing design; 
(13)  Reduce the impact on public and private lands caused by the accumulation of mud, dirt, water, debris and construction materials. 
(b)  Applicability. This article shall apply to all areas within the city limits. 
(c)  Stormwater design manual. The city may furnish additional policy, criteria and information including specifications and standards, for the proper implementation of the requirements of this division and may provide such information in the city floodplain management plan, which is available for review and copying at the office of the city clerk and on the city website, or in the form of a stormwater design manual. 
This manual will include a list of acceptable stormwater treatment practices, including the specific design criteria and operation and maintenance requirements for each stormwater practice. The manual may be updated and expanded from time to time, at the discretion of the city engineer, based on improvements in engineering, science, monitoring and experience. Stormwater treatment practices that are designed and constructed in accordance with these design and sizing criteria will be presumed to meet the minimum water quality performance standards. 
(d)  Jurisdiction. The regulations and requirements set forth in this article shall apply to all property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(e)  Compliance. No structure or land shall hereafter be located, extended, converted or structurally altered without full compliance with the terms of this article and other applicable regulations. 
(f)  Abrogation and greater restrictions. This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. However, where this article and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(g)  Interpretation. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall constitute minimum requirements and shall be liberally construed in favor of the governing body and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other powers granted by city ordinances. Whenever the provisions of this article impose more restrictive standards than are required in or under any other law, regulation, or ordinance, the requirements herein contained shall prevail. Whenever the provisions of any other law, regulation, or ordinance require more restrictive standards than are required herein, the requirements of such law, regulation, or ordinance shall prevail. 
(h)  Severability. If any section, clause, provision or portion of this article is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this article shall not be affected thereby. 
( Ord. No. 17-025-2014, 7-8-14 ) 
Sec. 17-2. - Definitions. 
    Words used in this article shall have their customary meanings as determined by the standard dictionary definition except for the purposes of this chapter, the following specific words and terms used herein shall be interpreted as follows: 
    ADEM means the Alabama Department of Environmental Management or its successor agency. 
    Accelerated erosion means erosion caused by development activities that exceeds the natural processes by which the surface of the land is worn away by the action of water, wind, or chemical action. 
    Adverse impact means a negative effect to land, water and associated resources resulting from any land-disturbing activity. Negative effects include, but are not limited to, increased risk of flooding, degradation of water quality, increased sedimentation, reduced groundwater recharge, harm to aquatic organisms, wildlife or other resources and/or threatened public health. 
    Applicant means a property owner or agent of a property owner who has filed an application for a stormwater management or other permit required by chapter 17. 
    Approved drainage system means a system that was approved for construction and permitted by the city; provided, however, the term does not include stormwater piping within the city's right-of-way. 
    As-built plans or record documents means a set of engineering site drawings that delineate a specific permitted stormwater management facility or system as actually constructed. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one (1) percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Best management practices (BMPs) means schedules of activities, prohibitions of practices, general good housekeeping practices, pollution prevention, educational practices, maintenance procedures, and other management practices to prevent or reduce the discharge of pollutants directly or indirectly into stormwater, receiving waters, or stormwater conveyance systems. BMPs also include treatment practices, operating procedures, and practices to control facility site runoff, spillage or leaks, sludge or water disposal, or drainage from raw materials storage and construction sites, or such other practices approved by EPA, see National Menu of Best Management Practices. 
    Building means any structure, either temporary or permanent, having walls and a roof, designed for the shelter of any person, animal, or property, and occupying more than one hundred (100) square feet of area. 
    Building permit means an official document or certificate issued by the city urban development department that authorizes performance of a specific activity relating to constructing, reconstructing, enlarging, extending, or structurally altering any building or structure, including interior alterations. 
    Certificate of occupancy means an official document, issued by the city urban development department, that certifies completion of a permitted structure in accordance with the provisions of established codes and other laws. 
    Channel means a natural or artificial watercourse with a definite bed and banks that conducts continuously or periodically flowing water. 
    City means the City of Mobile, Alabama. 
    City council means the city council of the City of Mobile, Alabama. 
    City engineer means the director of stormwater and floodplain management, and city engineering, or his designee. 
    Clean Water Act means the federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.), and any subsequent amendments thereto. 
    Clearing means those operations where trees and vegetation are removed (cut) and stumps left in place, but not including grading or any other activity that would alter the existing elevation contours of the cleared property. 
    Construction best management practice plan ("CBMP plan") means a set of drawings and/or other documents submitted by a person as a prerequisite to obtaining a land disturbance permit, which contains all of the information and specifications pertaining to BMP. 
    Consultant means a licensed or registered professional who provides technical services. 
    Contractor means a person or his designee who is responsible for construction activities. 
    Dedication means the deliberate appropriation of property by its owner for general public use. 
    Detention means the temporary storage of storm runoff in a stormwater management practice with the goals of controlling peak discharge rates and providing gravity settling of pollutants. 
    Detention facility means a detention basin or alternative structure designed for the purpose of temporary storage of stream flow or surface runoff and gradual release of stored water at controlled rates. 
    Developer means a person who undertakes land disturbance activities or undertakes other development. 
    Development means any manmade change to improved or unimproved real estate, including, but not limited to, buildings or other structures, mining, dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation, drilling operations and storage of equipment or materials. 
    Diameter at breast height (DBH) means the measurement of the width of the trunk of the tree at four and one-half (41/2) feet above the existing grade. For multitrunk trees the DBH shall be the sum of the diameter of the trunks. 
    Director of urban development means the director of the city department responsible for administration of building, zoning, subdivision regulations, forestry and other land use codes of the city or his/her designee. 
    Drainage area means that area contributing runoff to a single point. 
    Dwelling, one-family means a non-commercial, individual and separately built structure designed and constructed exclusively for use by one (1) family for residential purposes. 
    Easement means an interest in land granted by the owner or his predecessor for a specific limited use, purpose or purposes, (which is described in the conveyance of the land affected by such easement), but not conveying title to real property. 
    Engineer means a person licensed under Alabama Code, Section 34-11-1 et seq. (1975), as amended. 
    EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    Erosion means the wearing away of land surface by the action of wind, water, gravity, ice, or any combination of those forces. 
    Erosion and sediment control means the control of solid material, both mineral and organic, during a land-disturbing activity to prevent its transport out of the disturbed area by means of air, water, ice, gravity or mechanical means (see best management practices, "BMPs" ). 
    Fee in lieu means a payment of money in place of meeting all or part of the stormwater performance standards required by this division. 
    FEMA means the Federal Emergency Management Agency, or its successor agency. 
    Floodway (regulatory floodway) means the channel of a river or other watercourse and the adjacent land areas that must be reserved in order to discharge the base flood without cumulatively increasing the water surface elevation more than one (1) foot. 
    Floodplain means any land area susceptible to being inundated by floodwaters from any source. 
    Grading means excavating, filling (including hydraulic fill) or stockpiling of earth material, (or any combination thereof), including the land in its excavated or filled condition. 
    Grubbing means the effective removal of understory vegetation such as, but not limited to, palmetto from the site and/or the removal of stumps and roots from a cleared parcel of land. 
    Hazardous materials means any material, including any substance, waste, or combination thereof, which because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause, or significantly contribute to, a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, safety, property, or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Heritage live oak tree means a live oak tree which is at least twenty-four (24) inches DBH. 
    High-risk facility means municipal landfills; other treatment, storage or disposal facilities for municipal waste; hazardous waste treatment, storage, disposal and recover facilities; facilities subject to Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-know Act (EPCRA), title III, section 313, and any other industrial or commercial facility that the city engineer determines may make or has made a substantial pollutant contribution to the MS4. The city engineer shall publish a list of high-risk facilities on the city's web site, the city floodplain management plan, and such other publications as appropriate. 
    Heritage tree means any of the following list of trees which is at least twelve (12) inches DBH: oak (excluding water oak and scrub oak), hickory, sycamore, yellow poplar, sweet gum, magnolia, cypress and new trees required by section 64-4.E. or section 64-4.H.4.f. of chapter 64, Mobile City Code. 
    Historic structure means any structure that is: 
(1)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places (a listing maintained by the department of interior) or preliminary determined by the secretary of the interior as meeting the requirements for individual listing on the National Register. 
(2)  Certified or preliminarily determined by the secretary of the interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the secretary to qualify as a registered historic district. 
(3)  Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places in states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the secretary to qualify as a registered historic district. 
(4)  Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places in communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified either: 
a.  By an approved state program as determined by the secretary of the interior, or 
b.  Directly by the secretary of the interior in states without approved programs. 
    Illicit connections means an illicit connection is defined as either of the following: 
Any drain or conveyance, whether on the surface or subsurface, which allows an illegal discharge to enter the storm drain system including but not limited to any conveyances which allow any non-stormwater discharge including sewage, process wastewater, and wash water to enter the storm drain system and any connections to the storm drain system from indoor drains and sinks, regardless of whether said drain or connection had been previously allowed, permitted, or approved by an authorized enforcement agency; or 
Any drain or conveyance connected from a commercial or industrial land use to the storm drain system which has not been documented in plans, maps, or equivalent records and approved by an authorized enforcement agency. 
    Illicit or illegal discharge means any discharge to a municipal separate storm sewer that is not composed entirely of stormwater except discharges pursuant to a NPDES permit (other than the NPDES permit for discharges from the municipal separate storm sewer) and discharges resulting from fire fighting activities. 
    Impervious cover means those surfaces that cannot effectively infiltrate rainfall (e.g., building rooftops, pavement, sidewalks, driveways, etc). 
    Industrial stormwater permit means a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System permit issued to a commercial industry or group of industries which regulates the pollutant levels associated with industrial stormwater discharges or specifies on-site pollution control strategies.
