Secs. 19-8-19-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-11. - Injuring or interfering with property of electrical company. 
    Any person who shall maliciously destroy, cut, injure, remove, break, deface or interfere with any of the poles, wires, fixtures, instruments or other property of any electrical company used in connection with its circuit within the city shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 15-20) 
Sec. 19-12. - Injuring or interfering with street or park lighting system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, dig into, injure, displace, disconnect, remove or interfere with the insulation on any of the cables, wires, lighting standards or poles or to remove, destroy, injure or deface any of the globes, lamps, receptacles or any part of the equipment constituting a part of the public street or park lighting system of the city. 
Sec. 19-13. - Electrical contractors. 
(a)  "Electrical contractor" defined. The words "electrical contractor," as used in this chapter, shall include any person doing any electrical construction, installing any electrical wiring or apparatus for electric lights, heat or power or altering, changing or repairing any electrical wiring or apparatus but shall not include a workman employed by any such electrical contractor when such work is done under the personal supervision of such electrical contractor. 
(b)  Improper use of contractor's name. No licensed contractor shall allow his name to be improperly used by any person, directly or indirectly, either for the purpose of obtaining a permit or to do any work under his license. 
(Code 1965, §§ 15-38, 15-39) 
Sec. 19-14. - Indemnification of city. 
    All persons who now or may hereafter enjoy any of the rights or perform any of the duties imposed upon them by this chapter shall, before entering upon the work covered by this chapter, bind themselves, their successors and assigns to hold the city harmless from any liability for any damage that may accrue from the default of such obligor respecting the construction of overhead or underground electrical transmission of any kind, purpose, class or description. 
(Code 1965, § 15-26) 
Sec. 19-15. - Reserved privileges, etc., of city not affected. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abrogate or affect any privilege heretofore reserved by the city by ordinance or otherwise and nothing in this chapter shall be held or construed to limit the authority or power of the city to require all electrical wires to be placed underground. 
(Code 1965, § 15-27) 
Sec. 19-16. - Powers of council as to materials, etc. 
    The city council, or its authorized representative, shall have the power to compel any person who may be authorized to use the streets and public places of the city, under this chapter, to use in all works thereunder material and apparatus, of any and every description, of the best quality and shall have the right to condemn any material that shall be defective or improper for such purpose or that may be required to be condemned for the purpose of protection to the general public. 
(Code 1965, § 15-50) 
Sec. 19-17. - Meter deposits-Interest. 
    Electric companies requiring meter deposits shall pay interest thereon at the rate of six (6) percent per annum. Such payment of interest shall be made on the fifteenth day of June of each year or at the time such deposit certificate is cashed or turned in for payment. 
(Code 1965, § 15-23) 
Sec. 19-18. - Same-Used as guarantee; nonallowable deductions. 
    Meter deposits shall be used as a guarantee for payment of all accounts justly due and for the same return of the meter; provided, that no deductions shall be made from the amount deposited for any loss due to wear and tear or destruction of the meter by electric current or by fire from any cause. 
(Code 1965, § 15-24) 
Sec. 19-19. - Same-Return after two years. 
    All amounts deposited shall be returned to the depositor after the expiration of two (2) years, if such depositor has paid in full, when due, all accounts justly rendered against him. 
(Code 1965, § 15-25) 
Sec. 19-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITY ELECTRICIAN 

Sec. 19-21. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The city electrician shall superintend and determine the proper placing and adjustment of all wires or appliances for the transmission of electrical currents, in accordance with the provisions of the following sections of this chapter and in such manner as shall minimize the liability of accident, fire or damage to life or property. 
(b)  The city electrician shall further be required to superintend, manage and operate the traffic signal, street and park lighting systems of the city and such other lawful duties as required by the city council. 
(c)  When requested by the fire department, the city electrician shall attend or cause an employee to attend all fires which occur in the city, with proper appliances for cutting wires and moving the same to afford protection as far as possible to property and lives of persons. 
(Code 1965, § 15-28) 
Sec. 19-22. - Right of entry; removal of defective wire or appliance. 
    The city electrician shall have the right, in the discharge of his duty, to enter any building, manhole or subway or to climb any pole for the purpose of examining and testing the electrical appliances therein or thereon contained. For that purpose he shall be given prompt access to all buildings, both public and private, and to all manholes, subways and poles, on application to the company owning or the individual in charge of the same. Whenever an electric wire or appliance shall be defective through improper or insufficient insulation, or for any other reason, he shall at once cause the removal of such defects at the expense of the owners of such wires or appliances. 
(Code 1965, § 15-29) 
Sec. 19-23. - Authority to cut off current. 
    In case of failure to comply with this chapter, the city electrician shall have authority, after ten (10) days' notice, to cut off lights or current in any locality concerned and to enforce discontinuance of the same until such requirements are complied with. 
(Code 1965, § 15-34) 
Sec. 19-24. - Duty in directing placing of poles and wires; removal of superfluous poles. 
    It shall be the duty of the city electrician to so direct the placing of poles and wires in the streets, alleys and public places of the city that the same shall cause as little obstruction as possible, either to public travel in such thoroughfares or to the private use and enjoyment of adjacent property. It shall also be his duty, and he shall have authority, to compel the removal of superfluous poles. 
(Code 1965, § 15-30) 
Sec. 19-25. - Record; reports. 
    The city electrician shall keep a full and complete record of all work done, examinations made and other official work performed as required by this chapter. 
(Code 1965, § 15-33) 
Secs. 19-26-19-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - POLES AND WIRES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Posting signs on fence, pole, tree, etc., § 54-5; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 57. 

Sec. 19-31. - Poles, wires, etc., under supervision of city electrician. 
    All poles, posts, crossarms, wires and other fixtures placed, owned or used in any street, alley or public place in the city by any telegraph, telephone, signal, electric light or power company shall be placed, owned or used under the supervision and direction of the city electrician, and the city electrician shall have the right and authority at any time to fix the size, height and designation of poles and to locate and change the location of poles, wires, etc. 
(Code 1965, § 15-1) 
Sec. 19-32. - Rights reserved to city in granting permits to erect poles. 
    In granting permits to erect poles, the city council reserves the right, if in its opinion the interest of the public so demands, to authorize other persons to use the same poles for like or similar purposes, upon the payment to the owner thereof of proper compensation, to be determined by the parties concerned or by a board of arbitration in default of their agreement. The city may make use of all poles in the streets for municipal purposes without compensation, so far as it does not compete, or materially interfere, with the use by the owners thereof. All grants shall be subject to these implied conditions. 
(Code 1965, § 15-9) 
Sec. 19-33. - Material for poles. 
    All poles shall be of metal, combination wood and metal, cedar, juniper, cypress, yellow pine or other equally durable timber and, if of pine, shall be pressure treated with creosote or equal preservative. Poles used within the city shall be what is known as commercially straight. 
(Code 1965, § 15-4) 
Sec. 19-34. - Setting poles; crossarms. 
    All poles shall be set in the ground a depth of not less than five (5) feet and the earth around the same shall be firmly tamped. The height of the lowest crossarm shall be not less than twenty-three (23) feet above the ground, and all crossarms shall be securely braced. 
(Code 1965, § 15-7) 
Sec. 19-35. - Replacement of sidewalk after erection of pole. 
    In erecting poles for electric wires, sidewalks shall always be replaced in good condition, shall be repaved with the same kind of material as originally paved and shall be fitted neatly to the poles. 
(Code 1965, § 15-8) 
Sec. 19-36. - Painting and marking poles. 
    All poles, except creosoted poles, shall be painted by the owners at such intervals and of such color as may be designated by the city council, and each pole shall be marked or branded, at a point where it will be in plain sight from the ground, with the initials of the company owning the same or with some other plain symbol indicating ownership, satisfactory to the city electrician. 
(Code 1965, § 15-5) 
Sec. 19-37. - Directing stringing of wires; joint use of poles. 
    It shall be the duty of the city electrician to so direct the placing, stringing and attaching of wires upon poles erected in the streets and alleys of the city that the same shall cause as little obstruction, either to travel in the streets or to the use and enjoyment of private property, as possible, and to compel the joint use of poles wherever practicable. In case the joint users of any such pole are unable to agree on such joint use or the rental to be paid the owner of such pole for such use, the city electrician shall fix such rate, which shall be binding upon the parties and companies interested; provided, that either party may appeal from the decision of the city electrician as to such joint use or the amount of rental to be paid for the use of such pole for the privilege of attaching wires thereto, to the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 15-32) 
Sec. 19-38. - Zones on poles used jointly; free zone for city's use. 
    On any pole of any electric light, power, telephone or telegraph company used jointly by two (2) or more such companies, each company shall be allotted a special zone and shall confine its wires to that zone. Spaces shall be measured from the tops of poles downward and the uppermost zone on every telephone or telegraph pole and the lower zone on every electric light and power pole shall at all times be reserved for the free use of the city in stringing its traffic signal wiring. No employee of any company operating in the city shall interfere with, move or change any wire connected with the traffic signal wiring without first notifying the city electrician and obtaining permission from him to do so, except in a case of urgent necessity. 
(Code 1965, § 15-3) 
Sec. 19-39. - Stringing and insulating wires. 
    All overhead wires shall be strung in a neat and workmanlike manner, drawn taut and firmly tied to approved insulators. They shall not be attached to a building or trees without the consent of the owners thereof, and they shall be so placed as to interfere as little as possible with the work of the firefighters in case of fire. All strong current wires shall be insulated with coatings of material as nearly as practicable proof against leakage, moisture and fraying. They shall be fastened to insulated supports by insulated wire which shall have an insulation equal to that of the conducting wire. 
(Code 1965, § 15-12) 
Sec. 19-40. - Taps to be made at right angles. 
    All taps from pole lines to a building or crossing streets shall advisedly be made at right angles to a pole line and no wires shall be strung obliquely across the face or sides of any building. 
(Code 1965, § 15-13) 
Sec. 19-41. - Crossing wires of different system. 
    At points where it is necessary that wires of different systems cross each other, no telephone, telegraph, fire or police alarm or call box wires shall be placed less than four (4) feet above or below an electric light or high tension wire, except when entering or attached to buildings. 
(Code 1965, § 15-14) 
Sec. 19-42. - Wires of different systems on same crossarm. 
    Telegraph, telephone and similar wires shall not be placed on the same crossarm with electric light or power wires. When placed on the same pole with such wires, the distance between the two (2) inside pins of each crossarm shall not be less than sixteen (16) inches. 
(Code 1965, § 15-15) 
Sec. 19-43. - Builders, etc., to notify electrical inspector when necessary to remove wires. 
    Whenever builders or persons engaged in repairing, painting, etc., find it necessary to remove wires from any building in prosecuting their work, the owner or agent of such building or the contractor engaged thereon shall serve the electrical inspector with written notice twenty-four (24) hours before such contemplated work is begun and it shall be the immediate duty of the electrical inspector to notify the persons owning wires to remove same at once. 
(Code 1965, § 15-17) 
Sec. 19-44. - Clock, alarm and call box wires. 
    All clock, burglar alarm, fire alarm and call box wires carrying current of low tension shall be fastened or attached to poles set in the streets, alleys or other public places of the city and shall be permitted to remain overhead; provided, that all such wires shall not be less than twenty-three (23) feet above the surface of the street where they cross any open space of more than ten (10) feet and shall be securely fastened; and provided further, that each wire or cable shall be covered thoroughly with insulating material satisfactory to the city electrician and shall be tagged with lead tags, in such manner that it will be impossible to remove the tag without destroying the wire or the fixture to which it is attached, plainly marked with the owner's name. 
(Code 1965, § 15-18) 
Cross reference- Alarms connected to communications center, § 46-71 et seq. 
Sec. 19-45. - Duty of company in case of fire; badges of linemen, etc. 
    On the occurrence of a fire in any district in which any person or electric light or power company has wires, such person or company shall forthwith send a man prepared to remove them at once, under the direction of the chief of the fire department or his assistant or the city electrician. Every lineman and electrician shall wear an ID in plain sight, indicating his number and the company by which he is employed, and in case of fire his ID shall serve as a pass to admit the wearer inside the fire lines. 
(Code 1965, § 15-19) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, Ch. 22; alarms connected to communications center, § 46-71 et seq. 
Sec. 19-46. - Excavating near underground wires of street or park lighting system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any digging or make any excavation in any of the streets or sidewalks of the city at, under, over, around or so near the location of any underground wire, cable, cable case or cable carrier constituting a part of the public street or park lighting system, as to be likely to do injury or damage to the same or to the armor or insulation thereof, without first notifying the city electrician and securing a permit from him to do such digging or make such excavation. All such digging or excavation work shall be done under the supervision of the city electrician and so as not to injure or damage such cables and wires or the insulation or armor thereon. Any person who shall cause any damage to any such wire, cable, the insulation thereof or the armor case or receptacle covering or carrying the same shall be guilty of a violation of this chapter and, in addition to the penalty provided by section 1-21 of this Code, shall be liable in damages to the city for the damage done. 
(Code 1965, § 15-22) 
Cross reference- Excavations, § 57-141 et seq. 
Sec. 19-47. - Removal of dead wires. 
    The city electrician shall cause all wires leading to buildings that have not been used for thirty (30) days, and which are known as dead wires, to be removed at once at the expense of the owners of such wires. All dead wires of telephone, messenger call and telegraph companies shall be detached from the buildings with which they have been connected, when the instrument is removed from the building. 
(Code 1965, § 15-31) 
Sec. 19-48. - Failure or refusal to remove pole on notice from city electrician; use of condemned pole; removal of poles by city electrician. 
    Any person owning and using any poles in any street or public place who shall fail or refuse, after five (5) days' notice from the city electrician, to remove any pole deemed by him unsuitable, unsafe or improperly located, or the location of which he shall require to be changed, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). The erection or use of any poles rejected or condemned by the city electrician shall subject the offender to a like penalty. Any such poles for which ownership cannot be established shall be removed by the city electrician at the city's expense. 
(Code 1965, § 15-2) 
Sec. 19-49. - Injuring wire or pole. 
    No person shall injure any electric wire or pole in use by the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-11) 
Cross reference- Malicious injury to property, § 39-72. 
Sec. 19-50. - Interfering, etc., with wires. 
    It shall be unlawful, except as otherwise provided in this article, for any person, in erecting scaffolding, putting up signs, repairing or painting buildings or in any other way, to cut, break or in any manner interfere with the arrangement of telegraph, telephone, light, power or other electric wires. 
(Code 1965, § 15-16) 
Sec. 19-51. - Advertising on poles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or allow to be placed, any advertising cards or posters or other like material on any of the poles within the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-6) 
Cross reference- Signs and advertising, Ch. 54. 
Sec. 19-52. - Hitching animal to pole; intercepting electrical circuit. 
    Any person who shall hitch any animal to any street pole used in connection with any electrical circuit or shall intercept such circuit shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 15-10) 
Secs. 19-53-19-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - UNDERGROUND CONDUITS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Excavations, § 57-141 et seq. 

Sec. 19-61. - Authorized; permit required. 
    All persons owning, using or operating electric wires or other electrical conductors, under proper authority, along or across any street, alley or public place in the city, strung on poles or attached to buildings or other structures, are authorized to construct, alter and repair underground conduits and to place their electric wires and other electrical conductors therein, to construct, alter and repair such ducts, manholes and other appurtenances as may be required for placing such electric wires and other electrical conductors underground and to operate and use the same, if they first obtain therefor a permit from the city. 
(Code 1965, § 15-40) 
Sec. 19-62. - When city to act on application; size of ducts. 
    It shall be the duty of the city to pass upon the application, statements, plans and details presented to it in accordance with sections 19-61 and 19-65 within thirty (30) days from the filing thereof. All conduits shall be provided with ducts fifty (50) percent in excess of those required to carry the wires in use in the streets, alleys and public grounds at the time of the construction of the conduits. 
(Code 1965, § 15-42) 
Sec. 19-63. - Bonds. 
(a)  Any person required or permitted to place conduits under the streets and public places of the city shall, after first obtaining from the city council the permit required by section 19-61, file a bond with the city clerk, to be approved by the city council, in the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), for two (2) years, dating from the commencement of the construction of the underground subways or conduits, conditioned to pay the city any sum of money for which the city may become liable, for and by reason of any damage which may occur and accrue to the city from any injury to person or property during any of the work authorized or which may accrue to the city from any cause growing out of doing the work authorized. 
(b)  Any person who may be authorized to place conduits under the streets or public places of the city shall file a bond with the city clerk, to be approved by the city council, in the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), conditioned to properly replace any paved sidewalks or streets or the surface of any unpaved sidewalks or streets that may be displaced in doing the work authorized. 
(Code 1965, § 15-43) 
Sec. 19-64. - Maps and plans. 
    Any person who may be authorized to place conduits under the streets or public places of the city shall, before commencing the work, file with the city engineer maps and plans showing the location, elevation and grades of all underground conduits, pipes, tubes, manholes, etc., which plans shall be subject to amendment or change as the public interest may demand. 
(Code 1965, § 15-44) 
Sec. 19-65. - Specifications. 
    All conduits, ducts, manholes and other appurtenances for the use or operation of electrical wires and other electrical conductors shall be constructed and maintained in strict accordance with such plans and specifications as shall be approved by the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 15-45) 
Sec. 19-66. - Excavations. 
(a)  The method employed in laying underground conduits shall be such that it will at no time be necessary to remove so much of the pavement or to make such excavations as to materially impede traffic or passage upon sidewalks or streets during the operation of laying or repairing such conduits, except when in crossing streets transversely, where removal of the pavement in the nearest straight line from corner to corner shall be permitted. 
(b)  The work of removal and replacement of the pavements in any and all streets and public places in and through which the wire of any company shall be laid shall be subject to the control and supervision of the city engineer and excavations in all the unpaved streets or public places shall also be subject to like control and supervision. 
(Code 1965, § 15-41) 
Sec. 19-67. - Work under supervision of city engineer and city electrician. 
    All work done under this article shall be done under the direction and supervision of the city engineer and city electrician and to the satisfaction of such officers. 
(Code 1965, § 15-46) 
Sec. 19-68. - Poles for distributing purposes from underground system. 
(a)  All poles set for distributing purposes from an underground system shall be either creosoted pine, red cedar or other approved material, not less than fifty (50) feet long, and shall be placed inside of the property line of the blocks as far as practicable. When it is impracticable to distribute from the inside of a block then the distributing poles may be placed on the street, the location to be determined by the city, provided, that there shall not be more than one (1) pole to each block, except where the blocks exceed five hundred (500) feet in length. 
(b)  Distributing and all other poles shall be located by the city electrician and any pole shall be subject to removal by the city electrician, his decision, however, being subject to an appeal to the city. All such work shall be done at the expense of the person owning such poles. 
(Code 1965, § 15-47) 
Sec. 19-69. - Work done by city. 
    In case of failure on the part of any person exercising any of the powers granted by this article or in case of the failure of any such person to lower or raise or move any subways, underground conduits, pipes or tubes, when lawfully required to do so under the provisions of section 19-71, the city shall have power to cause such work to be done at the expense of such person and such person, by the acceptance of the terms of this article or doing any work thereunder, promises to repay to any other person performing such work under the authority of the city all reasonable costs and expenses incurred in doing such work, which may be recovered in any appropriate legal action or by execution at law. 
(Code 1965, § 15-48) 
Sec. 19-70. - Access by city electrician. 
    The city electrician shall have full and free access, at all times, to all the poles, manholes and conduits, for the purpose of inspecting the same and for the purpose of maintaining and operating any wires belonging to the city that may be placed thereon or therein. 
(Code 1965, § 15-49) 
Sec. 19-71. - Right to require conduits, etc., to be lowered, raised or moved. 
    In the event of the necessity for elevating or lowering the grade of any street or alley of the city, or in the construction or repair of sewers, water or other pipes belonging to the city, the city reserves the right to require subways, conduits, pipes or tubes to be lowered, raised or moved and the cost and expense of changing such subways, underground conduits, pipes or tubes so as to conform to the altered grade of such street or alley or the construction, maintenance or repair of such sewers or other pipes shall be borne by the person owning or operating such underground conduits, pipes or tubes. 
(Code 1965, § 15-51) 
Sec. 19-72. - Subleasing space in conduit, etc. 
    No person building conduits under this article shall have the right, without the consent of the city council, to lease or sublease space within such conduits or to use such conduits for purposes other than required by the individual needs of the person so building such conduit. Any violation of this section shall cause a forfeiture of all the rights and privileges granted under this article. 
(Code 1965, § 15-52) 
Chapter 21 - FENCES, BARRICADES AND SIMILAR STRUCTURES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Building, Ch. 11; posting signs on fence, pole, tree, etc., § 54-5; fences and walls, § 64-4.D.6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Barbed wire fences. 
    No person shall erect or maintain along or adjacent to any building line any fence constructed of barbed wire or other material that may be considered by the director of inspection services unsafe nor shall any part of any such fence be constructed of such materials. The provisions of this section shall not be deemed to apply to any fencing around public property when the chief of the police department has advised the city governing body that for the protection of the public property to be enclosed within the fence he recommends barbed wire be made a part of the fence. 
(Code 1965, § 18-1; Ord. No. 18-050, 2-29-72) 
Sec. 21-2. - Partition fences-Authority of director of inspection services. 
    The director of inspection services may order any partition fence repaired upon application of the owner on either side and he shall require an equitable division of the expense between the parties. Any person failing or refusing to pay the sum so designated shall be guilty of a violation of this section and punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 18-2) 
Sec. 21-3. - Same-Joint expense of adjacent owners. 
    Every partition fence and wall in the city shall be erected, built and kept in repair at the joint expense and cost of the persons whose grounds shall be enclosed or separated thereby. If the parties cannot agree, either may have the fence or wall built or necessary repairs made. 
(Code 1965, § 18-3) 
Sec. 21-4. - Same-Procedure in case of dispute. 
    In all cases where any dispute shall arise as to the necessity for repair or its extent or the sum of money to be paid by either party for the erection, building or repairing of any partition fence or wall, the party aggrieved may complain to the judge of the municipal court and thereupon the judge of the municipal court shall appoint three (3) disinterested freeholders of the city as inspectors, whose duty it shall be forthwith to examine into the matter and report to the judge of the municipal court the sum to be paid and to and by whom. 
(Code 1965, § 18-4) 
Sec. 21-5. - Same-Order to pay. 
    Upon receiving the report made under section 21-4, the judge of the municipal court shall make an order requiring the delinquent within the term of ten (10) days to pay to the person to whom the same may be due the sum so reported by a majority of the inspectors and two dollars ($2.00) to each inspector. If the delinquent shall neglect or refuse after due notice of this order to pay such sum of money, he shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 18-5) 
Secs. 21-6-21-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ENCLOSURE OF SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 21-21. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Building department shall mean the building department of the city. 
    City shall mean the city and its police jurisdiction. 
    Swimming pool shall mean a body of water in an artificial or semiartificial receptacle or other container whether located indoors or outdoors, used or intended to be used for public, semipublic or private swimming by adults or children, or both adults and children, whether or not any charge or fee is imposed upon such adults or children, operated and maintained by any person whether he be an owner, lessee, operator, licensee or concessionaire, and shall include all structures, appurtenances, equipment, appliances and other facilities appurtenant to and intended for the operation and maintenance of a swimming pool, and also all swimming pools operated and maintained in conjunction with or by clubs, motels, hotels and community associations. It shall also include a swimming pool used or intended to be used solely by the owner, operator or lessee thereof and his family, and by friends invited to use it without payment of any fee, in general being what is commonly understood to be a private residential swimming pool. 
(Code 1965, § 56-1) 
Sec. 21-22. - Fence or wall-Generally. 
(a)  Every outdoor swimming pool shall be completely surrounded by a fence or wall not less than four (4) feet in height, which shall be so constructed as not to have openings, holes or gaps larger than four (4) inches in any dimension except for doors and gates; and, if a picket fence is erected or maintained, the horizontal dimension shall not exceed four (4) inches. A dwelling house or accessory building may be used as part of such enclosure. 
(b)  All gates or doors opening through such enclosure shall be equipped with a self-closing and self-latching device for keeping the gate or door securely closed at all times when not in actual use; except, that the door of any dwelling which forms a part of the enclosure need not be so equipped. 
(c)  This requirement shall be applicable to all new swimming pools hereafter constructed, other than indoor pools, and shall apply to all existing pools which have a minimum depth of eighteen (18) inches of water. No person in possession of land within the city, either as owner, purchaser, lessee, tenant or a licensee, upon which is situated a swimming pool having a minimum depth of eighteen (18) inches shall fail to provide and maintain such fence or wall as herein provided. 
(Code 1965, § 56-2) 
Sec. 21-23. - Same-Modifications by building department in certain cases. 
    The building department may make modifications in individual cases, upon a showing of good cause, with respect to the height, nature or location of the fence, wall, gates or latches, or the necessity therefor, provided the protection as sought under this article is not reduced thereby. The building department may permit other protective devices or structures to be used so long as the degree of protection afforded by the substitute devices or structures is not less than the protection afforded by the wall, fence, gate and latch described in this article. The building department shall allow a reasonable time within which compliance shall be had with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1965, § 56-3) 
Secs. 21-24-21-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BARRICADES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-31. - Location. 
    The location of any and all barricades erected within the city on public streets including dead-end streets shall be approved by the city engineer prior to construction of any such barricade. 
(Ord. No. 18-074, § 1, 7-29-75) 
Sec. 21-32. - Construction standards. 
    All barricades shall be constructed of and referred to as 630-A, steel beam guard rail, class I, type A per lineal foot as listed in Standard Specifications for Highways and Bridges, 1975 Edition. 
(Ord. No. 18-074, § 2, 7-29-75) 
Sec. 21-33. - City property. 
    After erection the barricades shall become the property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 18-074, § 3, 7-29-75) 
Sec. 21-34. - Removal and storage. 
    Barricades once erected shall not be removed except by the city or through written consent of the city engineering department. Any such barricades removed shall be stored at the city consolidated garage. 
(Ord. No. 18-074, § 4, 7-29-75) 
Secs. 21-35-21-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DURING MARDI GRAS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Mardi Gras, § 39-201 et seq. 

Sec. 21-41. - Definitions. 
    Whenever used in this division, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context, "crowd restraint device" shall mean any barricade, cable or other device erected on or along the streets of Mobile for the purpose of keeping crowds out of the street during a Mardi Gras parade. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 1, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 21-42. - Authorized placement. 
    The city traffic engineering department is hereby authorized to place crowd restraint devices along any Mardi Gras parade route for the purpose of crowd restraint. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 2, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 21-43. - Unlawful to cross crowd restraint device. 
    During the period of time beginning five (5) minutes prior to the commencement of a Mardi Gras parade and ending five (5) minutes after the end of such Mardi Gras parade, it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to disregard a crowd restraint device by going over, under or through the crowd restraint device for the purpose of gaining access to the street in front of the crowd restraint device. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 3, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 21-44. - Penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this ordinance shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991) of the Mobile City Code. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 4, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 21-45. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division shall not apply to: 
(1)  Emergency situations when it is necessary to disregard a crowd restraint device and such movement is authorized by a member of the police department; 
(2)  Officials; officers; agents or employees of the city, county, state or federal government in the course of performing their official duties; 
(3)  Emergency medical personnel in the course of performing their official duties. 
(Ord. No. 18-014, § 5, 2-13-79) 
Chapter 22 - FIRE PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Codes advisory committee, § 9-21 et seq.; building, ch. 11; electricity, ch. 19; fire alarm indicators in offices of electric companies. § 19-45; false fire alarm, § 39-62; certain explosive chemicals, § 39-181 et seq.; fireworks during Mardi Gras, § 39-201; burning grass in parks, § 41-4; unauthorized uses of water from fire hydrants, § 45-72; alarms connected to communications center, § 46-71 et seq.; false alarms with alarms connected to communications center, § 46-78. 

ARTICLE I. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 22-1. - Code and appendices. 
    Pursuant to Alabama Code Section 11-45-8 (1975), the 2012 Edition of the International Fire Code and Appendices B, C, and D, along with the amendments to the same contained in this ordinance, which has been on file in the office of the city clerk, pursuant to a resolution adopted by the city council, on March 3, 2015, is hereby adopted as the "Fire Code of the City of Mobile." 
(Ord. No. 19-063, § 1, 2-25-86; Ord. No. 20-003, § 1, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 22-034, § 1, 4-14-92; Ord. No. 22-084, 12-28-93; Ord. No. 22-055, §§ 3, 10, 11, 11-7-95; Ord. No. 22-058, §§ 3, 11, 12, 8-25-98; Ord. No. 22-033, §§ 1, 10, 7-6-04; Ord. No. 22-006-2011, § 1, 1-18-11; Ord. No. 22-034-2015 , 3-31-15) 
Sec. 22-2. - Amendments. 
    Chapter 1 Scope and Administration of the 2012 International Fire Code shall be amended as follows. 
    Amend Section 101 Scope and General Requirements as follows: 
    Amend 101.1 Title to read as follows: 
    101.1 Title. These regulations shall be known as the Fire Code of the City of Mobile, Alabama, and shall be cited as such and will be referred to herein as, "this Code." 
    Amend Section 102 Applicability to read as follows: 
    Add 102.4.1 Application of the Properly Maintenance Code to read as follows: 
    102.4.1 Application of the Property Maintenance Code. The provisions of the 2012 International Property Maintenance Code and adopted ordinances shall apply to existing structures and premises: equipment and facilities; light, ventilation, space, heating, sanitation, life and fire safety hazards; responsibilities of owners, operators and occupants; and occupancy of existing structures and premises. 
    Add 102.4.2 Application of the Electrical Code to read as follows: 
    102.4.2 Application of the Electrical Code. The provisions of the 2014 National Electrical Code and adopted ordinances shall apply to the installation, alterations, repairs and replacement of electrical systems, including equipment, fixtures, fittings and/or appurtenances. 
    Add 102.4.3 Application of the Mechanical Code to read as follows: 
    102.4.3 Application of the Mechanical Code. The provisions of the 2012 International Mechanical Code and adopted ordinances shall apply to the installation, alterations, repairs and replacement of mechanical systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fittings and/or appurtenances, including ventilating, heating, cooling, air-conditioning and refrigeration systems, incinerators and other related systems. 
    Add 102.4.4 Application of the Plumbing Code to read as follows: 
    102.4.4 Application of the Plumbing Code. The provisions of the 2012 International Plumbing Code and adopted ordinances shall apply to the installation, alteration, repair and replacement of plumbing systems, including equipment, appliances, fixtures, fitting and appurtenances, and where connected to a water or sewage system. 
    Amend 102.13 Appendices to read as follows: 
    102.13 Appendices. The following appendices shall be adopted: 
1.  Appendix B - Fire Flow Requirements for Buildings. 
2.  Appendix C - Fire Hydrant Locations and Distribution. 
3.  Appendix D - Fire Apparatus Access Roads, except for section D107 which is not adopted. 
    Amend Section 108 Board of Appeals as follows: 
    Delete articles 108.1 through 108.3 . Add to read as follows: 
    108.1 Construction Board of Appeals. The Board of Appeals, herein called the Construction Board of Appeals, shall be in accordance with the applicable sections of the International Building Code and the Ordinance Adopting the International Building Code. 
    Amend Section 109 Violations as follows: 
    Amend 109.3 Violation penalties to read as follows: 
    109.3 Violation penalties. Any person who violates a provision of this code or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who erects, constructs, alters, or repairs a building or structure in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this code, shall be subject to penalties in accordance with Chapter 1 of the Mobile City Code. 
    Violation of the provisions of the 2012 International Fire Code shall be subject to $250.00 fine unless otherwise listed below: 
1.  Working without proper license, certifications or permit. $500.00 
2.  Signage on all vehicles used by contractor. $100.00 
3.  Interference with a Fire Code Official. $100.00 
    Amend Section 113 Fees to read as follows: 
    Amend 113.2 Schedule of Permit Fees to read as follows: 
    Amend Paragraph 113.2 to read as follows: 
    113.2 Schedule of Permit Fees. On all buildings, structures, facilities and operations requiring a permit, a fee for each permit shall be paid as required at the time of filing the application, in accordance with the Fire Code Permit Fee Schedule Ordinance as established by the City of Mobile and adopted in a separate ordinance. 
    Amend Section 113.5 Refund to read as follows: 
    Amend Paragraph 113.5 to read as follows: 
    113.5 Refunds. Refunds shall be in accordance with the Fire Code Permit Fee Schedule Ordinance. 
    Chapter 2 Definitions of the 2012 International Fire Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend Section 202 General Definitions as follows: 
    Add 202 Historic Building to read as follows: 
    202 Historic Building. Any building or structure that is listed in the Alabama Register of Landmarks and Heritage or in the National Register of Historic Places; designated as a historic property under local or state designation; certified as a contributing resource within a National Register listed or locally designated historic district; or with an opinion or certification that the property is eligible to be listed in the Alabama Register or the National Register of Historic Places either individually or as a contributing building to a historic district by the State Historic Preservation Officer or the Keeper of the National Register of Historic Places. 
    Chapter 3 General Requirements of the 2012 International Fire Code shall be amended as follows. 
    Amend Section 308 Open Flames as follows: 
    Amend 308.1.4 Open flame cooking devices to read as follows: 
    308.1.4 Open flame cooking devices. Charcoal burners and other open-flame cooking devices shall not be operated on balconies or within 10 feet of combustible construction. The management of multi-family residential occupancies which have balconies, decks, or patios shall notify their tenants in writing of the prohibitions of open flame cooking devices on balconies as outlined in 308.1.4 of the fire code when the tenant or occupant initially occupies the building and periodically thereafter as may be necessary to ensure compliance. 
    Amend 308.1.4 Exceptions to read as follows: 
    Delete Item Number 4 308.1.4 Exceptions. - Where buildings, balconies and decks are protected by an automatic sprinkler system.

    503.2.3 Surface. Fire apparatus access roads shall be surfaced with asphalt or concrete and designed and maintained in accordance with Section 503 and Appendix 14 FIRE APPARATUS ACCESS ROADS Section D102.1 Access and loading. 
    Amend Section 506 Key Boxes to read as follows: 
    Amend 506.1 Where required to read as follows: 
    506.1 Where required. All buildings with fire alarm and automatic sprinkler systems and any building requiring a fire department inspection for Certificate of Occupancy will require an approved Knox key box for rapid fire department entry into the building. Entry keys/cards to all parts of the building arc required to be placed in the key box and shall be maintained in accordance to 506.2.

    Amend 507.5.1.1 Hydrant for standpipe systems to read as follows: 
    507.5.1.1 Hydrant for automatic sprinkler systems and standpipe systems. Buildings equipped with an automatic sprinkler system or standpipe system shall have a fire hydrant located within 100 feet of the fire department connections. 
    Chapter 9 Fire Protection Systems of the 2012 International Fire Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend Section 901 General to read as follows: 
    Add 901.2.2 Professional certification to read as follows: 
    901.2.2 Professional certification. Automatic sprinkler system, standpipe systems and fire alarm system contractors shall be certified by the Alabama State Fire Marshal's Office before applying for permission to perform work on these systems within the City of Mobile. All other fire protection system contractors shall submit proof of certification from the fire protection system's manufacturer to perform work on those systems. The fire protection system permit requirements does not relieve the permitted of additional qualifications and permits required from other adopted codes and ordinances. 
    Amend 901.9 Termination of monitoring service to read as follows: 
    901.9 Termination of monitoring service. For fire alarm systems required to be monitored by this code, notice shall be given to the fire code official whenever alarm monitoring services are terminated. The owner or owner designated representative shall be responsible for sending a notice of termination of service in writing to the following mail address and fax number. 
Attention To: 
Fire Code Official Bureau of Fire Prevention 
2851 Old Shell Road Mobile, AL 36607 
Fax: (251) 208-7162. 
    Amend Section 904 Alternative Automatic Fire-Extinguishing Systems to read as follows: 
    Amend 904.11 Commercial cooking systems to read as follows:

    Amend Section 912 Fire Department Connections to read as follows: 
    Amend 912.3.1 Locking Fire Department connection caps to read as follows: 
    912.3.1 Locking fire department connection caps. Locking caps are required on fire department connections for water-based fire protection systems unless the connection is located inside a security guard-maintained, fenced facility and the fire code official has approved the site. 
    Amend 912.5 Backflow protection to read as follows: 
    912.5 Backflow protection. The potable water supply to fire protection systems shall be protected against backflow as required by the International Fire Code and the Mobile Area Water and Sewer Service. Backflow preventers shall be protected from freezing by being insulated. 
    Amend 913 Fire Pumps to read as follows: 
    Amend 913.2 Protection against interruption of service to read as follows: 
    913.2 Protection against interruption of service. As required by the AHJ, occupancies where life safety is at risk such as residential, institutions, etc. An emergency generator shall be required as an alternate source of power. 
    Occupancies where life safety is at low risk, such as business, mercantile, etc. An emergency generator will not be required. 
    Chapter 50 Hazardous Materials-General Provisions of the 2012 International Fire Code shall be amended as follows: 
    Amend Section 5001.1.1 Waiver to read as follows: 
    5001.1.1 Waiver. The provisions of this chapter and any other chapter are waived when the fire code official determines that such enforcement is preempted by other codes, statutes or ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 19-063, §§ 4-7, 2-25-86; Ord. No. 20-003, §§ 4, 5, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 20-039, § 1, 6-5-90; Ord. No. 22-034, §§ 4-9, 4-14-92; Ord. No. 22-056, § 1, 8-25-93; Ord. No. 22-055, §§ 4-9, 11-7-95; Ord. No. 22-001, §§ 1, 2, 1-6-98; Ord. No. 22-058, §§ 4-10, 8-25-98; Ord. No. 22-087, § 2, 12-22-98; Ord. No. 22-014, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 22-033, §§ 2-9, 7-6-04; Ord. No. 22-071-2005, § 1, 11-1-05; Ord. No. 22-006-2011, § 6-15, 1-18-11; Ord. No. 22-034-2015 , 3-31-15; Ord. No. 22-017-2017 , § 1, 4-25-17) 
Sec. 22-3. - Contractors criteria and qualifications. 
    Criteria and qualifications for fire protection system contractors shall be set forth herein. 
    Contractor's responsibilities. It shall be the duty of every contractor who shall make contracts for the design, installation and/or replacement of components of fire protection systems, for which a permit is required, to be properly certified, licensed and bonded in accordance with all of the city and state requirements. 
(Ord. No. 22-006-2011, § 4, 1-18-11; Ord. No. 22-034-2015 , 3-31-15) 
Sec. 22-4. - Surety bond. 
    In addition to the requirements as set forth herein, it shall be the duty of every contractor and sub-contractor to provide and have on file a current license and permit bond for ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The bond is subject to the approval of the city legal department and shall be provided by a surety company qualified to do business in the state and from an agent thereof with an office in the city. 
    Such bond shall insure that the licensee complies with laws, ordinances and regulations of the applicable governing body. The local governing body shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damage of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person, firm, or corporation engaged in business or by any other unfaithful, inadequate work done either by themselves or their agents or employees. 
(Ord. No. 22-034-2015 , 3-31-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 22-034-2015 , adopted March 31, 2015, has been treated by the editor as amending the Code by repealing former § 22-4, and adding a new § 22-4. Former § 22-4 pertained to liability insurance, and derived from Ord. No. 22-006-2011, adopted January 18, 2011. 
Sec. 22-5. - Vehicular sign. 
    All trucks and similar vehicles used by contractors and subcontractors shall have signs on both sides of said vehicles indicating the full name. address, and telephone number of the firm to which it belongs. Lettering may be any color in contrast to the color of the body and be at least one and one-quarter (11/4) inches tall. 
(Ord. No. 22-034-2015 , 3-31-15) 
Sec. 22-6. - Schedule of permit fees. 
(a)  Applicability. This section applies to permit fees charged by the city for compliance with the fire code adopted by the city listed herein unless otherwise exempted. Permits may be required by other departments and agencies including but not limited to the following: 
City engineering; 
Urban forestry; 
Historic development; 
Alabama Power Company; 
Urban development; 
Mobile Area Water & Sewer Service; 
City revenue; 
Mobile Gas Corporation; 
Right-of-way; 
Mobile County Health Department; 
Traffic engineering. 
(b)  Violation penalties. Any person who violates a provision of this article or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof shall be subject to penalties in accordance with chapter 1 of the Mobile City Code. 
(c)  Schedule of fire code permit fees. On conducting an operation or business, or installation or modification of any fire protection system and equipment which is regulated by the fire code, a permit fee for each required permit shall be paid at the time of receiving the permit. The applicable permit fees required by the city shall be determined in accordance with the schedule of fees as listed and do not include fees required by other departments or agencies (see subsection (a) applicability). 
Work exempt from permit. Any exemptions from permit requirements of this code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction. 
Fire code permit fees. The fees established by the city fire code must be collected at time the permit is received. A one dollar ($1.00) permit issuance fee shall be assessed to all permits issued. 
Other permit fees. Where no permit fees are listed the city shall determine the required permit fee. 
Operational and business permit fees. These fees are based on the operation or business conducted and the prescribed period before permit is renewed or revoked.
