ARTICLE VI. - SEPTAGE AND GREASE HAULER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 25-121. - Title. 
    This body of regulations shall be known as the septage and grease hauler regulations. 
(Ord. No. 25-086, § 1, 11-26-02) 
Sec. 25-122. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  The United States District for the Southern District of Alabama, Southern Division, entered a consent decree in a civil action styled United States of America, the State of Alabama, and Mobile Bay Watch, Inc. versus the Board of Water and Sewer Commissioners of the City of Mobile, Alabama, Case No. CV-99-0595-CB-S and 2002-58-CB-S. 
(b)  The consent decree requires the board of water and sewer commissioners (hereafter the "board") to develop, among other things, a grease control program. 
(c)  In order to comply with the court's consent decree, the board has asked the city to cooperate by imposing reasonable regulations upon companies that are licensed by the city to operate a septage and grease hauling business. 
(d)  The city believes that the board's request is reasonable and desires to accommodate the board; and the city further finds that such a policy is desirable and promotes the public health, safety and welfare as it will prevent unlicensed operation of such companies and will reduce illegal discharges of septage and grease. 
(Ord. No. 25-086, § 2, 11-26-02) 
Sec. 25-123. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions apply in this chapter: 
    Domestic waste: Any waste capable of entering into or passing through a plumbing system. Such waste includes but is not limited to human excrement, bath water, kitchen and bathroom waste and waste from septic tanks, sumps, outhouses, or any other waste collection point. The term "domestic waste" does not include waste from any commercial or industrial process that is authorized by Mobile Area Water and Sewer System to be discharged into a sewage collection system. 
    Food service facility: Any establishment, retail food store, public or private school, correctional facility, hospital, food processing or preparing establishment, or other establishment where food is prepared for sale or offered for sale, including any establishment that slaughters, fabricates, bones, or processes animals, poultry, or fish whether or not required by law to be licensed or permitted by an agency of the state. 
    Grease hauler: Any person (natural or legal) who removes fat, oil, or grease waste of any form from a premises by means of transporting the waste over a public road. This includes waste from grease traps, grease interceptors, grease collection bins, or any other fats, oils, or grease collection point. 
    Septage hauler: Any person (natural or legal) who removes domestic waste from a premises and transports the waste over a public road. 
(Ord. No. 25-086, § 3, 11-26-02) 
Sec. 25-124. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business as a septage or grease hauler within the city or its police jurisdiction without first obtaining a business license in accordance with chapter 34 of the Mobile City Code. 
(Ord. No. 25-086, § 4, 11-26-02) 
Sec. 25-125. - Operating requirements. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this code for any grease hauler or septage hauler to dispose of any waste at any location other than a disposal site permitted to accept such waste by the Alabama Department of Environmental Management (ADEM), the Alabama State Board of Health, the state department of agriculture, or another governmental agency with authority to permit such activity. 
(b)  Every vehicle used by any septage or grease hauler must prominently display on the exterior of the vehicle in at least four-inch lettering the following information: company name, business license number and business telephone number. 
(c)  Every vehicle used by any septage or grease hauler must maintain a chain of custody or manifest for each pick up, disposal or other service provided for each customer. Such document must identify the source of waste hauled, the type of waste hauled, date and time waste was accepted by the hauling company, amount of waste accepted, disposal location for waste, and any applicable permit numbers associated with the process. When waste is removed from a food service facility, a copy of the completed manifest must be returned to the originating facility. 
(Ord. No. 25-086, § 5, 11-26-02) 
Sec. 25-126. - Current licensees. 
    Any person who currently holds a license to dispose of any septage and/or grease under any revenue classification as of the effective date of this article shall be allowed to continue to hold such license in accordance with its terms. However, said companies must comply not later than October 1, 2002 with all of the operating requirements set out in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 25-086, § 6, 11-26-02) 
Chapter 26 - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Certain explosive chemicals, § 39-181 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 26-1-26-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRANSPORTING HAZARDOUS MATERIALS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch.61. 

Sec. 26-21. - Statement of findings. 
    The city council hereby makes the following findings: 
(1)  The release of hazardous materials into the environment is injurious to the public health, safety and welfare and is hereby found to constitute a nuisance. 
(2)  The city may incur substantial expense for emergency actions to mitigate injury to the public health, safety and welfare from the release or threatened release of hazardous materials. 
(3)  Such expenses should properly be borne by those that profit from the activities that resulted in the release or threatened release of hazardous materials into the environment. 
Ord. No. 37-017, Art. I, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-22. - Scope. 
    This article shall pertain to all modes of transportation as defined in the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 49, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. II, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-23. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation of this article: 
    Emergency action shall mean all of the concerted activities conducted in order to prevent or mitigate injury to human health or the environment from a release or threatened release of any hazardous material into the environment. 
    Fire code shall mean the fire code of the city as may be amended from time to time. 
    Hazardous material shall mean a substance or material, including a hazardous substance, which has been determined by the secretary of transportation, or other state or federal agency, to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health, safety and property when transported in commerce, and which has been so designated, including any residue, vapors or fumes from such substance. The above definition of hazardous materials shall include any material defined as hazardous material by the United States Department of Transportation, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Alabama Public Service Commission or any other federal or state agency, including but not limited to the definitions and illustrations given in the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Sections 261.31 through 261.33 and Title 49, Section 171.8, as may be amended from time to time. 
    Motor vehicle shall be defined as is defined by state law and in the federal Motor Carriers Safety Regulations, as may be amended from time to time. For the purposes of this article, the above definitions shall also include railroad trains and cars. 
    Person shall mean any individual, corporation, association, partnership, firm, trustee or legal representative. 
    Recoverable expenses are all those expenses that are reasonable and necessary for the emergency action, except as hereinafter provided. Recoverable expenses include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Disposable materials and supplies acquired, consumed and expended specifically for the purpose of the emergency action. 
(2)  Any compensation payable to employees, consultants and contractors for time and effort devoted to the emergency action. 
(3)  Rental or leasing of equipment used specifically for the emergency action. 
(4)  Replacement costs for city equipment that is contaminated beyond reuse or repair. 
(5)  Decontamination of equipment contaminated during the emergency action. 
(6)  Other special services specifically required for the emergency action. 
(7)  Any costs of cleanup, storage or disposal of the released material. 
(8)  Costs associated with the services, supplies and equipment procured for a specific evacuation. 
(9)  Laboratory costs of analyzing samples taken during the emergency action. 
(10)  Medical expenses incurred as a result of response activities. 
(11)  Legal expenses that may be incurred as a result of the emergency action. 
    Threatened release of hazardous material shall mean a condition which exists when a release of hazardous materials is likely to occur unless preventive measures are immediately taken to prevent such release. 
    Transportation operations shall mean any movement, driving or otherwise operating a motor vehicle; transportation, conveying, storing, parking or offering for transportation any hazardous material; all activities connected with the operation of a motor vehicle or the transportation of hazardous material, including but not limited to the proper placarding, packaging, marking, labelling; proper shipping papers and any other requirements concerning the operation of a motor vehicle or the transportation of hazardous material. 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. II, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-24. - Criminal penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. IV, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-25. - Release or threatened release a nuisance. 
    The release or threatened release of hazardous materials into the environment in violation of the city's fire code is a nuisance. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, cause, keep or maintain any such nuisance within the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. V, § 1, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-26. - Compliance required. 
    All persons, companies, other legal entities and all motor vehicles engaged in transportation operations for commercial purposes as defined in this article shall comply with all federal and state laws and regulations pertaining to same; these laws and regulations shall include but not be limited to regulations enacted by the U.S. Department of Transportation, federal Highway Administration, Environmental Protection Agency and the Alabama Public Service Commission, as if fully set out and incorporated herein. Any violation of the above laws or regulations shall be a violation of this article. The city police department is hereby authorized to stop and inspect any vehicles suspected of engaging in improper transportation operations, which is operating within the city limits or police jurisdiction of the city in order to ensure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. V, § 8, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-27. - Unlawful acts enumerated. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move, drive or otherwise operate a motor vehicle for commercial purposes, as defined herein, unless such vehicle shall comply with the most current regulations of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations and the Alabama Public Service Commission Motor Carrier General Orders, Rules and Regulations. This section shall apply to all motor vehicles when engaged in any transportation operations of passengers and/or property both public and private for commercial purposes. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person or other legal entity to transport, convey, store or offer for transportation any hazardous material as defined herein, unless such material is properly packaged, marked, labelled and accompanied by the proper documentation as required by Title 49 of the Code of Federal Regulations. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person or other legal entity to move, drive or otherwise operate any motor vehicle past the point of the entrance into a vehicular tunnel, when such vehicle is loaded in such a manner, or with such materials or is so construed, operated or equipped as to be likely to endanger persons or property therein or is likely to render the use of such tunnel unsafe or unclean. Without limiting the foregoing, the following described vehicles or types of vehicles are hereby declared to be of the type which is likely to endanger persons or property or which is likely to render the use of the tunnel unsafe or unclean; however, subsections (9), (10) and (11) shall not apply to recreational or private pleasure vehicles: 
(1)  Vehicles with persons standing or sitting on the outside thereof, or trucks with persons sitting on the rear with feet dangling, or which are overcrowded with persons. 
(2)  Pushcarts, wheelbarrows and similar vehicles which must be pushed to be propelled. 
(3)  With the exception of Mardi Gras floats, no self-propelled vehicles or trailers with metal tires, steamrollers or tractors of caterpillar types. 
(4)  Vehicles with flat tires. 
(5)  Vehicles loaded with earth, garbage, manure, loose hay, straw or similar material not covered or contained. 
(6)  Vehicles overloaded to such an extent that the means of propulsion is insufficient. 
(7)  Vehicles with inadequate brakes. 
(8)  Slow moving vehicles which are likely to cause undue delay or interference with traffic. 
(9)  Any gasoline tank truck or any other type truck, portable tanker or container with a capacity of fifty (50) gallons or more containing hazardous material in any quantity, including residue, fumes or vapor from hazardous materials that have not been steamed, cleaned, purged or reloaded with a nonhazardous material, as these terms are defined by the department of transportation; this subsection does not apply to vehicle fuel tanks. 
(10)  Any motor vehicle transporting any quantity of those hazard classes listed in the Code of Federal Regulations, Title 49, Section 172.504, Table 1, as may be amended from time to time. 
(11)  Any motor vehicle transporting any hazard class not identified in paragraph (10) of this section when the gross weight of all hazardous material is over one hundred (100) pounds. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle used for commercial purposes which contains hazardous material to park under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  A motor vehicle which contains hazardous material parked on or within five (5) feet of the travelled portion of a public street or highway, except for brief periods when the necessities of operation require the vehicle to be parked and make it impracticable to park the vehicle in any other place. 
(2)  On public or private property, including but not limited to premises of a fueling facility, an eating facility, a motel, hotel, truckstop or parking lot, without the knowledge and consent of the person who is in charge of the property. 
(3)  Notwithstanding any other provisions in this section, a motor vehicle which contains hazardous material shall not be parked within three hundred (300) feet of a bridge, tunnel, dwelling, building or other place where people work, congregate or assemble, except for brief periods when the necessities of operation require the vehicle to be parked and make it impracticable to park the vehicle in any other place. 
The police department is hereby authorized to cause the removal of any vehicle that is found in violation of this subsection. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to move, drive or otherwise operate past the point of entrance into the Bankhead Tunnel any motor vehicle which is of a height of twelve (12) feet or more. For the purpose of this section, the entrance to the Bankhead Tunnel shall be deemed to be that point immediately past the last possible exit prior to entering the Bankhead Tunnel. 
(f)  For the purposes of this article, the entrance to the Wallace Twin Tunnels on Interstate 10 shall be deemed to be that point immediately past the last possible exit off of Interstate 10, prior to actually entering the tunnels. This definition of the tunnel entrance shall be applicable whether the vehicular approach is towards the eastbound entrance of the Wallace Tunnel or the westbound entrance to the Wallace Tunnel. It shall be a prima facie violation of this subsection for any prohibited vehicle described in this article to proceed past the entrance of the Wallace Twin Tunnel. 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. III, §§ 1-7, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 26-28. - Recovery of expenses. 
(a)  Any person responsible for a release or threatened release of hazardous materials into the environment which results in an emergency action shall be liable to the city for the city's recoverable expenses resulting from such action. 
(b)  The staffs of each city department involved in an emergency action to stabilize the situations shall keep a detailed record of its recoverable expenses resulting from the emergency action. Promptly after completion of the emergency action, the staffs shall certify those expenses to the fire chief. The fire chief, or a duly authorized designee, shall forward the city's total claim to the accounts receivable department to be mailed to any and all persons responsible for the emergency action. The claim shall be a written, itemized statement of the total recoverable expenses incurred by the city for the emergency actions, along with an assessment detailed further in subsection (c) and shall include a notice that if such claim is not paid in full within thirty (30) days, the city may initiate a civil action for the collection of the claim. 
(c)  The city's claim for emergency response shall include in addition to the city's recoverable expenses a hazardous materials special assessment in the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00). Appeal of this amount shall be to the city council. A written notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within thirty (30) days from the date of the invoice. Notice of such appeal shall be forwarded to the fire chief, the accounts receivable office and the legal department by the city clerk's office. 
(d)  The accounts receivable department is hereby authorized to have an action brought by the legal department on behalf of the city to recover any such claim which has not been paid or appealed within the specified thirty (30) days. 
(e)  This civil remedy shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any criminal prosecution or penalty. 
(f)  The recoverable expenses and the hazardous materials special assessment resulting from an emergency response to any spill, or release of a hazardous substance, as defined herein which poses a significant present threat or potential hazard to human life, property or environment, shall be a charge against the person or entity whose conduct, or conduct of its employees, agents or contractors, caused or permitted the incident resulting in the emergency response. 
(Ord. No. 37-017, Art. V, §§ 2-7, 3-19-91; Ord. No. 26-059, 10-1-02) 
Chapter 27 - HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals having glanders or other dangerous disease, § 7-11; rabies control, § 7-31 et seq.; barbers, masseurs and similar personal service establishments, Ch. 8; drainage, Ch. 17; pest control, Ch. 43; sewers, sewage disposal and water supply, Ch. 53.5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 27-1. - Enforcement [of] Mobile County Health Department Rules. 
(a)  The Mobile County Health Department Rules as defined by the Alabama Department of Public Health pursuant to Title 22, Health and Environmental, Code of Alabama (1975), as amended, are the health regulations of the City of Mobile. 
(b)  The Mobile County Health Officer is the health officer of the city, pursuant to Title 22, Health and Environmental, Code of Alabama (1975), as amended. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of violating any provision of the Rules of Mobile County Health Department, as adopted pursuant to state law, within the city limits or its police jurisdiction of the city, shall be prosecuted in accordance with the jurisdiction of the Environmental Court Division of the Mobile Municipal Court and shall be fined or punished as set out in Chapter 1, Article II of the City Code of the City of Mobile. 
(Ord. No. 29-074, 11-24-92) 
Secs. 27-2-27-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BIRTHS AND DEATHS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Cemeteries, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 27-21. - Report and registration of births. 
    Every physician, midwife or other person who may attend any case of midwifery within the city shall make to the health officer a report of such case within one (1) week after the date of its occurrence, specifying the names of the parents, the date of the birth and the sex and color of the child. Such reports shall be recorded by the health officer in a book to be kept for that purpose, entitled "the register of births." 
(Code 1965, § 9-1) 
Sec. 27-22. - Registration of deaths. 
    The health officer shall keep a book, to be entitled "the register of deaths," in which he shall make a registration of all deaths occurring in the city, under such regulations as may be prescribed by the county health department, designating such as are indigents. 
(Code 1965, § 9-2) 
Sec. 27-23. - Certificate of death-Generally. 
(a)  The health officer shall supervise all certificates of death and see that they are properly made out. The form of the certificate and the nomenclature of the disease shall be such as may be prescribed by the county health department. If the certificate of death is in any way defective, the health officer shall return it to the physician signing the same for correction. Any physician failing or refusing to give such certificate in proper form shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(b)  In all cases of death in which no adequate certificate can be obtained from a physician, the coroner shall investigate the circumstances and make out the certificate. 
(Code 1965, § 9-3) 
Sec. 27-24. - Same-Filing. 
    All certificates of deaths occurring in the city shall be filed in the office of the county health department within twenty-four (24) hours after the death has occurred. Any undertaker who shall be employed in or about the funeral or burial of any person, or in or about the preparation of the body of any person for burial, who shall fail to file the certificate of the death of such person in the office of the county health department within twenty-four (24) hours shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 9-4) 
Sec. 27-25. - Where burial permitted. 
    The bodies of deceased persons shall not be buried in any cemetery or in any other place within the city limits, except where authorized by the city council in compliance with all state laws, rules and regulations. 
(Code 1965, § 12-2; Ord. No. 12-075, 8-5-80; Ord. No. 65-104, § 4, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 27-26. - Burial or removal permit-Generally. 
    If the certificate of death required by this article is in proper form, the health officer shall issue a permit authorizing the removal or burial of the body of the dead person. Without such permit, no person who may die in the city shall be removed or buried by any sexton, undertaker or other person. 
(Code 1965, § 9-5) 
Sec. 27-27. - Same-Issued only to licensed undertakers. 
    The health officer shall not issue any permit for the removal or burial of any body to any undertaker who has not obtained a license from the state to engage in business as an undertaker. 
(Code 1965, § 9-6) 
Sec. 27-28. - Bringing dead bodies into city. 
    No dead body of any diseased person shall be brought into the city from any other place unless it is accompanied by a proper certificate of the cause of death. If the death was caused by smallpox, yellow fever or any other infectious or pestilent disease, no dead body shall be brought into the city unless a permit from the county health department has been first obtained. 
(Code 1965, § 9-7) 
Sec. 27-29. - Morgue (department of forensic science of the University of South Alabama). 
    The department of forensic science of the University of South Alabama shall provide and maintain the city morgue. The body of any person found dead in any public place or who shall die in any public place in the city, other than an infirmary or hospital, shall be removed to the city morgue, unless some member of the immediate family of such deceased person shall request removal of the body to the residence of the deceased or that of his family or to the place of business or undertaking parlor of some licensed undertaker in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 9-8; Ord. No. 65-104, § 2, 10-6-88) 
Secs. 27-30-27-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABORTIONS 

Sec. 27-41. - Definitions. 
    Definitions as used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Abortion means a purposeful termination of a human pregnancy after implantation of a fertilized ovum, by any person, including the pregnant woman herself, with an intention other than to necessarily produce a live birth or to remove a dead unborn child. 
    Hospital means a general hospital or special hospital devoted to gynecology or obstetrics which is accredited by the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals or by the American Osteopathic Association. 
    Physician means a person licensed to practice medicine in the State of Alabama. 
    Registered nurse means a person licensed as a registered nurse in the State of Alabama. 
    Viable means potentially able to live outside of the womb of the mother upon premature birth whether resulting from natural causes or an abortion, or otherwise, and whether that potentiality exists in part due to the provisions or availability of natural or artificial life support systems. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 1, 10-19-82) 
Sec. 27-42. - Abortion counseling. 
    No abortion facility or physician's office shall advertise or hold itself out as also providing counseling to pregnant women, unless: 
(1)  The counseling is done by a licensed physician, a licensed registered nurse or other person holding at least a bachelor's degree from an accredited college or university in psychology or some similarly appropriate field or special training in counseling (including instruction in the following subjects: sexual and reproductive health, abortion technology, contraceptive technology, short-term counseling skills, community resources and referrals, and informed consent); 
(2)  The counseling includes factual information given in such a manner as to not be misleading, including discussion of the development of the unborn child; 
(3)  The counseling includes a thorough discussion of the alternative to abortion and the availability of agencies and services to assist her if she chooses not to have an abortion; and 
(4)  The type of counseling provided (individual or group) is clearly indicated in the advertisement. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 3, 10-19-82; Ord. No. 27-120, § 3, 12-13-83) 
Sec. 27-43. - Informed consent for abortion. 
(a)  No abortion shall be performed except with the voluntary and informed consent of the woman upon whom the abortion is to be performed. 
(b)  A statement indicating such consent in writing and a signed authorization for the performance of an abortion shall be obtained from each patient prior to the procedure. 
(c)  Consent to an abortion will be considered to be voluntary and informed if, and only if, the physician who is to perform the abortion, or his designated agent, provides the woman upon whom the abortion is to be performed with the following information: 
(1)  The name of the physician who will perform the abortion. 
(2)  The particular medical risks associated with the woman's own pregnancy and the particular abortion procedure to be employed in the best medical judgment of the physician based on the particular facts of the case before him. 
(3)  The possibility of unforeseeable and harmful physical and psychological effects of the abortion and harmful physical and psychological effects of the abortion procedure to be used. 
(4)  A general description of the method and instructions to be followed subsequent to the abortion in order to ensure her safe recovery. 
(5)  That alternatives to abortion include childbirth and adoption, and a comprehensive list, prepared by the county health department, of public and private agencies and services available to assist a woman during pregnancy, upon childbirth, and while the child is dependent, including adoption agencies, and a description of the manner in which they may be contacted along with their addresses. 
(d)  Paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) of this section shall not apply when in the best medical judgment of the attending physician based on the particular facts of the case before him, there exists a medical emergency which warrants nullification of the requirements that the woman be provided with the information prescribed by paragraph (c) of this section and that the woman certify her consent as prescribed by paragraph (b) of this section. In such a case, the physician shall describe in writing the basis of his best medical judgment that such an emergency exists and, if the woman survives the abortion, the physician shall inform her of the medical indications for his judgment that a medical emergency existed and of the particular medical risks associated with the particular abortion procedure employed, the symptoms of which might become manifest in the future. 
(e)  The attending physician or designated agent shall provide the woman with a duplicate copy of the consent form signed by her in accordance with paragraph (b) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 4, 10-19-82; Ord. No. 27-120, § 8, 12-13-83) 
Sec. 27-44. - Parental notice and consent for abortion for unemancipated minors. 
(a)  No physician shall perform or induce an abortion upon an unmarried pregnant woman under the age of eighteen (18) years without first having given at least twenty-four (24) hours' actual notice to one (1) of the parents or the legal guardian of the minor pregnant woman as to the intention to perform such abortion, or if such parent or guardian cannot be reached after a reasonable effort to find him or her, without first having given at least seventy-two (72) hours' constructive notice to one (1) of the parents or the legal guardian of the minor pregnant woman by certified mail to the last known address of one (1) of the parents or guardian, computed from the time of mailing. 
(b)  The provisions of paragraph (a) do not apply if: 
(1)  One (1) of the parents personally appears and waives in writing the opportunity for consultation, or 
(2)  One (1) of the parents or the legal guardian of the minor pregnant woman gives his or her notarized written consent to performance of the abortion. 
(c)  To the extent required by the Constitution of the United States, the abortion may be performed on the unmarried pregnant woman without compliance with paragraph (a) where a judge of the municipal court waives the application of paragraph (a), or where the abortion is ordered by a court otherwise having jurisdiction over such minor pregnant woman. The municipal court judge shall, upon petition, motion or other appropriate pleading, and after appropriate hearing and consideration of any relevant evidence (including but not limited to the emotional development, maturity, intellect and understanding of the minor), issue an order waiving application of paragraph (a) if such judge determines that: 
(1)  The woman is sufficiently mature to make the abortion decision herself; or 
(2)  The abortion would be in the best interests of the woman. 
(d)  The requirements and procedures under this section apply and are available whether or not the woman for whom waiver is sought is a resident of Mobile. 
(e)  The woman may participate in the proceedings in the municipal court on her own behalf, or the court may appoint a guardian ad litem for her. The court shall advise her that it will, upon her request, provide her with a guardian ad litem, at the city's expense, to counsel her for the hearing. 
(f)  All proceedings and papers filed under this section in the municipal court and the name of the woman involved shall be confidential to protect the privacy of the woman. However, nothing herein shall prevent the records of these proceedings from being deemed public for statistical or other purposes, except to the extent necessary to protect the privacy of the woman involved. 
(g)  Completion of these proceedings shall be given precedence over other pending matters so that the court may reach a decision promptly and without delay so as to serve the best interests of the woman, but in no case shall the court fail to rule within forty-eight (48) hours of the time of application. 
(h)  A judge of the municipal court who conducts proceedings under this section shall make in writing specific factual findings and conclusions of law supporting his decision and shall order a record of the evidence to be maintained including his own findings and conclusions of law supporting his decision. 
(i)  The clerk of the municipal court shall develop a form pleading which will be available at any time to convene and may be filed for the purpose of convening the judicial hearing prescribed by this section. Under no circumstances shall financial indigence of the woman preclude the judicial consideration prescribed by this section or on the appeal hereinafter prescribed by this section. All costs and fees associated with consideration of the petition, motion, other appropriate pleading and any appeals under this section may be waived if the petitioner so requests. 
(j)  A confidential expedited de novo appeal shall lie to any other municipal judge, and the municipal court shall take such steps as are necessary to make the petitioner aware of the right to seek appeal and the manner in which such appeal shall be taken in the event the municipal court refuses to issue the order requested. 
(k)  The municipal court shall take such steps as are necessary to provide for the effective implementation of the provisions of this subsection within sixty (60) days after its passage. 
(l)  The requirements of paragraphs (a) through (k) of this section shall not apply when, in the medical judgment of the attending physician based on the particular facts of the case before him, there exists a medical emergency. In such a case, the physician shall describe in writing the basis of his medical judgment that such an emergency exists and the physician or his designated agent shall provide the parent or guardian with the following information within seven (7) days of the time the abortion is performed, either in person or by sending it by certified mail to their last known address: 
(1)  That an abortion has been performed upon the minor pregnant woman and the medical indications for the physician's medical judgment that a medical emergency exists or existed, 
(2)  The name of the physician who performed the abortion, and 
(3)  In the best medical judgment of the physician based on the particular medical facts of the case before him, any particular medical risks associated with the particular abortion procedure employed, the symptoms of which might become manifest in the future. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 6, 10-19-82; Ord. No. 27-120, §§ 4-6, 12-13-83) 
Sec. 27-45. - Abortion by licensed physician in licensed facility. 
    No person shall perform or induce an abortion upon a pregnant woman unless that person is a physician licensed to practice medicine in the State of Alabama and such abortion is performed in a hospital or in an abortion facility. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 2, 10-19-82) 
Sec. 27-46. - Standard of care. 
    No person who performs or induces an abortion, after the fetus has become viable, shall fail to exercise that degree of professional skill, care and diligence to preserve the life and health of the fetus which the person would be required to exercise in order to preserve the life and health of any fetus intended to be born and not aborted. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 11, 10-19-82) 
Sec. 27-47. - Abortion after viability. 
(a)  No physician shall perform or induce an abortion upon a pregnant woman after such time as her unborn child has become viable, unless such abortion is necessary to prevent the death of a pregnant woman or to prevent impairment to her health. Before a physician may perform or induce an abortion upon a pregnant woman after such time as her unborn child has become viable, such physician shall first certify in writing that the abortion is necessary to prevent the death of a pregnant woman or to prevent impairment to her health and shall further certify in writing the medical indications for such abortion and the probable health consequence if the abortion is not performed or induced. 
(b)  An unborn child shall be presumed to be viable if more than twenty-four (24) weeks have elapsed from the probable beginning of the last menstrual period of the pregnant woman, based upon either information provided by her or through examination by her attending physician. If it is the judgment of the attending physician that the particular unborn child is not viable where the presumption of viability exists, then before such physician may perform or induce an abortion upon the pregnant woman, he shall first certify in writing that the particular unborn child is not viable, in his opinion, and shall further certify the precise medical findings upon which he based his judgment. 
(c)  Any physician who shall perform or induce an abortion upon a pregnant woman where the presumption of viability exists shall utilize the available method or technique of abortion most likely to preserve the life and health of the unborn child, unless that method or technique would present a significantly greater risk to the life or health of the pregnant woman, than other available method or technique to be actually utilized, and the physician so certifies in writing. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 10, 10-19-82) 
Sec. 27-48. - Abortion report. 
(a)  A report of each abortion performed shall be made to the county health department on forms prescribed by the board. Such report shall not identify the patient by name, but by an individual number to be noted in the patient's permanent record in the possession of the physician and shall include the following information: 
(1)  Identification of the physician who performed the abortion; 
(2)  Identification of the abortion facility or hospital where the abortion was performed; 
(3)  The political subdivision in which the patient resides; 
(4)  The patient's age; 
(5)  The patient's race; 
(6)  The patient's marital status; 
(7)  The patient's years of education; 
(8)  The patient's number of prior pregnancies; 
(9)  The patient's number of living children; 
(10)  The patient's number of previous induced abortions; 
(11)  The date of the patient's last induced abortion; 
(12)  The date of the patient's last live birth; 
(13)  The date of the patient's last menstrual period; 
(14)  The type of abortion procedure utilized; 
(15)  Any complications with the abortion; 
(16)  The type of procedure done after the abortion; 
(17)  The medical condition of the patient at the time of the abortion; 
(18)  Any medical or counseling assistance given to the patient after the abortion; 
(19)  The date that the abortion was performed; 
(20)  The type of family planning recommended; 
(21)  The basis for any medical judgment that a medical emergency existed as required by any provision of this article; 
(22)  The Rh type of the patient; and, if the patient is Rh negative, whether or not anti-Rh immune globulin therapy with required laboratory procedures was given to the patient; and 
(23)  The signature of the attending physician. 
(b)  An individual complication report for any post-abortion care performed upon a woman shall be completed by the physician providing such post-abortion care. This report shall include: 
(1)  The date of the abortion; 
(2)  The name and address of the abortion facility or hospital where the abortion was performed; 
(3)  The nature of the abortion complication diagnosed or treated. 
(c)  All of the abortion reports shall be signed by the attending physician and submitted to the county health department within thirty (30) days from the date of the abortion. All complication reports shall be signed by the physician providing the post-abortion care and submitted to the county health department within thirty (30) days from the date of the post-abortion care. 
(d)  A copy of the abortion report shall be made a part of the medical record of the patient of the facility or hospital in which the abortion was performed. 
(e)  All information obtained by a physician, hospital or abortion facility from a patient for the purpose of preparing reports under this article, and all reports made under this article shall be confidential (but may be used for statistical purposes) except to the extent necessary to secure the rights or interests of a person or the state pursuant to a court order in civil or criminal actions or proceedings to grant or revoke licenses. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 7, 10-19-82; Ord. No. 27-120, § 7, 12-13-83) 
Sec. 27-49. - Records. 
    All abortion facilities and hospitals in which abortions are performed or induced shall keep records, including admission and discharge notes, histories, results of tests and examinations, nurse worksheets, social service records and progress notes, and shall further keep a copy of all written certifications provided for in this section as well as a copy of records of constructive work consent forms, abortion reports and complication reports provided for in this article. Such records shall be maintained in the permanent files of the hospital or abortion facility for a period of not less than six (6) years. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 8, 10-19-82; Ord. No. 27-120, § 9, 12-13-83) 
Sec. 27-50. - Prohibition of fetal research. 
    No person shall use any fetus or premature infant aborted alive for any type of scientific research, laboratory or other kind of experimentation either prior or subsequent to any abortion procedure except as necessary to protect or preserve the life and health of such premature infant aborted alive. 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 12, 10-19-82) 
Sec. 27-51. - Abortion funding restrictions. 
(a)  No city funds shall be used to provide abortions, to advertise or promote abortions, or for abortion referral. 
(b)  Any person or organization which intentionally, knowingly or recklessly fails to conform to the requirements of paragraph (a) of this section shall not be eligible to receive any city funds for a period of at least two (2) years after the person or organization has been found to have violated the provisions of paragraph (a). 
(Ord. No. 27-111, § 13, 10-19-82) 
Secs. 27-52-27-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SMOKING[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 17, adopted August 21, 2012, amended the Code by repealing former art. IV, §§ 27-61-27-73, and §§ 1-14 and 16 added a new art. IV. Former art. IV pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 27-40, adopted June 21, 1994. Subsequently, Ord. No. 27-026-2014 added new provisions regarding minors and tobacco. Therefore, the editor has designated the new provisions div. 2, §§ 27-91-27-96, retitled the art. IV, and added the designation div. 1 for §§ 27-61-27-75. 
Cross reference- Smoking in theaters, § 60-2. 

DIVISION 1. - SMOKING GENERALLY 

Sec. 27-61. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms and words shall have the meaning ascribed to them: 
    Bar means an establishment that: 
(1)  Is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for consumption by guests on the premises and in which the serving of food is only incidental to the consumption of those beverages, and 
(2)  That is licensed for "on premises" retail sales of alcoholic beverages by the Alabama Alcohol Beverage Control Board, including but not limited to any establishment that holds a valid and duly issued club liquor license. 
For purposes of this article, the serving of food shall be considered incidental to the consumption of alcoholic beverages only if food sales make up less than ten (10) percent of the total revenue of the establishment. 
    Business means a sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other business entity, either for-profit or not-for-profit, including retail establishments where goods or services are sold; professional corporations and other entities where legal, medical, dental, engineering, architectural, or other professional services are delivered; and private clubs. 
    City means the City of Mobile, Alabama. 
    Common area means a hallway, corridor, lobby, aisle, water fountain area, restroom, stairwell, interior and/or exterior general public entryway or exit, refreshment area, or restroom. 
    Employee means any person who is employed for compensation, profit or who volunteers his or her services for an employer. 
    Employer means any person, partnership, corporation, association or other entity that employs one (1) or more persons. 
    Enclosed area means all space between a floor and ceiling that is bounded on at least fifty (50) percent of its sides by walls, doorways, or windows, whether open or closed. A wall includes any retractable divider, garage door, or other physical barrier, whether temporary or permanent. 
    Health care facility means any office, institution, or business providing individual care or medical treatment of diseases, whether physical, mental, emotional, psychological or physiological conditions, including but not limited to hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals or clinics, weight control clinics, nursing homes, homes for the aging or chronically ill, and offices of surgeons, chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, doctors, dentists, and all specialists within these professions. This definition shall include all waiting rooms, hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, wards, and common areas. 
    Place of employment means any enclosed indoor area under the control of an employer to which employees have access during the course of employment, including but not limited to work areas, private offices, employee lounges, employee restrooms, conference rooms, meeting rooms, classrooms, employee cafeterias, hallways, constructions sites, temporary offices, and vehicles. A private residence is a place of employment, if it contains certain places of business, such as child care, adult day care centers, or health care facilities. 
    Playground means any park or recreational area designed in part to be used by children that has play or sports equipment installed or that has been designated or landscaped for play or sports activities, or any similar facility located on public or private school grounds or on city grounds. 
    Private club means an organization or entity, whether incorporated or not, which is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, which is operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and which only sells alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. The affairs and management of the organization or entity are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an annual meeting. The organization or entity has established bylaws and/or a constitution to govern its activities. The organization or entity has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal income tax as a club under 26 U.S.C. Section 501. For purposes of this article, the serving or sale of alcoholic beverages shall be considered incidental to the operation of such organization or entity only if the sale of alcoholic beverages makes up less than ten (10) percent of the total revenue of the establishment. 
    Public place means any area, to which the public is invited or permitted, including but not limited to retail stores, retail service establishments, retail food production and marketing establishments, restaurants, theaters, stadiums, sports facilities, waiting areas for any business, establishment, etc., restrooms, elevators, government or civic buildings, educational facilities, medical or health facilities, public transportation, and hotels and motels. A private residence does not constitute a "public place," unless it is used as a child care, day care or health care facility. 
    Restaurant means an eating establishment, including but not limited to coffee shops, cafeterias, sandwich stands and private and public school cafeterias, which gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, as well as kitchens and catering facilities in which food is prepared on the premises for serving elsewhere. The term "restaurant" shall include a bar area attached to or within the restaurant. 
    Retail tobacco store means a retail store which is the sole occupant of the building in which it is located and derives at least ninety (90) percent of its gross quarterly revenue from the sale of tobacco, tobacco products and accessories, such as pipes, matches, lighters and ashtrays. Revenue generated from cigarette vending machine sales shall not be used to determine whether a retail store satisfies this definition. "Retail tobacco store" does not include a tobacco department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any establishment with any type of on-premises liquor, food, or restaurant license. 
    Service line means any indoor line at which one (1) or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not such service involves the exchange of money, including but not limited to, ATM lines, concert lines, food vendor lines, ticket lines, and sporting event lines. 
    Shopping mall means an enclosed public walkway, corridor, or hall area that serves to connect retail or professional establishments. 
    Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted or heated cigar, cigarette or pipe, or any other lighted or heated tobacco or plant product intended for inhalation, in any manner or form. 
    Sports area means sports pavilions, stadiums, gymnasiums, health spas, boxing arenas, swimming pools, roller and ice rinks, bowling alleys, and other similar places where members of the general public assemble to engage in physical exercise, participate in athletic completion, or witness sports or other events. 
    Tobacco bar means an establishment whose business is the sole occupant of the building and is devoted to the serving of tobacco products, and which serves only complimentary snacks. The tobacco bar contains no kitchen facilities and has no access to kitchen facilities, catering, or food, other than the complimentary snacks. A tobacco bar derives ninety (90) percent or greater of its revenue from the sale of tobacco products and devotes a minimum of fifty (50) percent of net floor space to the display, storage, and sale of actual tobacco products, and does not permit the on-premises use of tobacco products not purchased on the premises. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years is allowed in a tobacco bar. "Tobacco bar" does not include a department or section of a larger commercial establishment. 
    Tobacco retailer means any person, government, or entity who sells tobacco products to individuals for personal consumption, or who operates a facility where self- service displays of tobacco products are permitted. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 1, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-62. - Prohibition of smoking in public places. 
    Smoking is and shall be prohibited in all enclosed public places within the city, including, but not limited to, the following places: 
(1)  Aquariums, galleries, libraries and museums. 
(2)  Areas available to and customarily used by the general public in business and nonprofit entities patronized by the public, including but not limited to professional and commercial offices and office buildings of all types, banks, grocery stores/supermarkets, convenience stores, and retail establishments of all types, hotels and motels. 
(3)  Bingo facilities. 
(4)  Convention and meeting facilities of all types. 
(5)  Educational facilities, both public and private. 
(6)  Elevators. 
(7)  Theaters and facilities primarily used for exhibiting a motion picture, stage, drama, lecture, musical recital, or other similar performance. 
(8)  Health care facilities and offices. 
(9)  Child care and adult care facilities. 
(10)  Polling places. 
(11)  Public transportation facilities, including buses, taxicabs, limousines, and ticket, boarding and waiting areas of public transit depots. 
(12)  Restaurants. 
(13)  Restrooms, lobbies, reception areas, hallways, and other common-use areas. 
(14)  Rooms, chambers, places of meeting or public assembly, including school buildings under the control of an agency, board, commission, committee or the council of the city, to the extent the place is subject to the jurisdiction of the city. 
(15)  Service lines. 
(16)  Shopping malls. 
(17)  Any property owned or leased by the city. 
(18)  Sports arenas, including enclosed places in outdoor arenas. 
(19)  Public sidewalks located within the Downtown Mobile Business Improvement District as that district is defined in Ordinance 50-039, adopted May 10, 2005. 
(20)  All other indoor locations where the public may gather. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 2, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-63. - Prohibition of smoking and the use of tobacco or tobacco products in public parks, playgrounds, and recreational areas. 
(a)  Smoking is and shall be prohibited in all areas of municipally owned or operated parks, playgrounds, or public use lands where the general public congregates, including but not limited to public bleacher areas, pavilions, concession areas, playgrounds, outdoor cooking areas, gazebos, tennis courts, pools, playing fields, dugouts, skate parks, parking lots, and walking/running trails or track areas, and other outdoor locations where the public may gather. It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any of these areas. 
(b)  The use of tobacco or tobacco products is not permitted in all areas of municipally owned or operated parks, playgrounds, or public use lands where the general public congregates, including but not limited to public bleacher areas, pavilions, concession areas, playgrounds, outdoor cooking areas, gazebos, tennis courts, pools, playing fields, dugouts, skate parks, parking lots, and walking/running trails or track areas, and other outdoor locations where the public may gather. It shall be unlawful for any person to use tobacco or tobacco products in any of these areas. For purposes of this section, the term "tobacco or tobacco products" shall mean any tobacco or any product containing tobacco, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Cigarettes; 
(2)  Cigars; 
(3)  Chewing tobacco; 
(4)  Snuff; 
(5)  Pipe tobacco; 
(6)  Smokeless tobacco. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 3, 8-21-12; Ord. No. 27-084-2015 , § 2, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 27-64. - Exemptions. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article to the contrary, the following areas shall be exempted from the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Private residences, except smoking is prohibited at all times within any private residence that is a licensed childcare, adult day care, or health care facility. 
(2)  Retail tobacco stores; provided that smoke from these places does not infiltrate into areas where smoking is prohibited under the provisions of this section, and provided that the store operated as a tobacco retail shop for at least sixty (60) days prior to the passage of this article. 
(3)  Bars, so long as they comply with the requirements of section 27-65 of this article. 
(4)  Outdoor areas of restaurants including but not limited to decks, verandas, and porches, but only after 8:00 p.m. on each day. Smoking shall be prohibited in such areas prior to 8:00 p.m. on each day. 
(5)  Private clubs, including veterans associations. 
(6)  Tobacco bars. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 4, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-65. - Bars. 
(a)  For bars that allow smoking, smoking by patrons and customers shall be allowed throughout all areas generally occupied by patrons and customers. No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall be admitted as a patron or a customer on the premises of a bar that allows smoking; and it shall be unlawful for the owner, business agent, manager, or other person having control of any such establishment to admit any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years on the premises as a patron, customer, or employee. 
(b)  For bars that allow smoking, signage shall be posted on or adjacent to each and every exterior door to the establishment that is generally accessed by patrons or employees, plainly visible to persons entering through the door. Signage shall be no smaller than eight and one-half (8.5) inches by eleven (11) inches, with white lettering on a red or black background, and including at least one (1) of the following statements: "This establishment is a smoking facility" with letters no smaller than five-eighths ( 5/8 ) of an inch tall; or "Smoking is allowed throughout this facility at all times" with letters no smaller than five-eighths ( 5/8 ) of an inch tall. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 5, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-66. - Tobacco bars. 
    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years is or shall be allowed in a tobacco bar. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 6, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-67. - Prohibition of smoking in enclosed work places. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited in all enclosed facilities within places of employment without exception. This includes common work areas, auditoriums, classrooms, conference and meeting rooms, private offices, elevators, hallways, medical facilities, cafeterias, employee lounges, stairs, restrooms, vehicles, and all other enclosed facilities. This prohibition on smoking shall be communicated to all existing employees by the effective date of this article and to all prospective employees upon their application for employment. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 7, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-68. - Offenses. 
    A person violates this section and commits an offense if he or she: 
(1)  Smokes in a public place, taxicab, bus or public passenger carrier, that is not engaged in interstate commerce. 
(2)  Is the owner, lessee, or other person in charge of a public place, and fails to make a reasonable effort to inform those on the premises that smoking in a public place which is not designated as a smoking area under this section is proscribed behavior. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 8, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-69. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the municipal code enforcement officer, police officer, fire department official, or by the employees of the county health department, or an authorized designee. 
(b)  Notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to all applicants for a business license in the city. 
(c)  Any citizen who desires to register a complaint under this article may initiate enforcement with the county health department. 
(d)  The health department, fire department, or their designees shall, while an establishment is undergoing inspections, inspect for compliance with this article. 
(e)  An owner, manager, operator, or employee of an area regulated by this article shall direct a person who is smoking in violation of this article to extinguish the product being smoked. If the person does not stop smoking, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall refuse service and shall immediately ask the person to leave the premises. If the person in violation refuses to leave the premises, the owner, manager, operator, or employee shall contact law enforcement. 
(f)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an employee or private citizen may bring legal action to enforce this article. 
(g)  In addition to the remedies provided by the provisions of this section, the county health department, or any person aggrieved by the failure of the owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of a public place or a place of employment to comply with the provisions of this article may apply for injunctive relief to enforce those provisions in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(h)  Violation of this article by a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 9, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-70. - Violation; penalty. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished with a fine of seventy dollars ($70.00) plus court costs, or by community service for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or by both fine and imprisonment and/or community service at the discretion of the judge. 
(b)  A person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment and who fails to comply with the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an infraction, punishable by: 
(1)  A fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first violation. 
(2)  A fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a second violation occurring within one (1) year of any previous violations. 
(3)  A fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each additional violation occurring within one (1) year of any previous violations. 
(c)  Each day on which a violation of this article occurs shall be considered a separate and distinct violation. 
(d)  Violation of this article by a person who owns, manages, operates, or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment may result in the suspension or revocation of any permit or license issued to the person or for the premises on which the violation occurred. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 10, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-71. - Miscellaneous. 
    Nothing in this section excuses noncompliance with any federal or state law, city ordinance, or any rule or regulation which prohibits smoking. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, an owner, operator, or other person in control of an establishment, facility, or business may declare that entire establishment, facility, or business as a nonsmoking place. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 11, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-72. - City buildings and vehicles. 
(a)  Smoking is not permitted in any city-owned or operated building or facility, on the premises of any city-owned or operated building or facility, in any public library, or on the premises of any public library. The provisions of section 27-74 shall not be applicable to any city-owned or operated buildings, facilities, or premises, or to the buildings or premises of any public library, it being the intent of this section to make the campus of all city owned or operated premises and libraries to be smoke free. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any city-owned or operated building or facility, on the premises of any city-owned or operated building or facility, in any public library, or on the premises of any public library. 
(c)  The use of tobacco or tobacco products is not permitted in any city-owned building or facility, on the premises of any city-owned or operated building or facility, in any public library, or on the premises of any public library. It shall be unlawful for any person to use tobacco or tobacco products in any city-owned or operated building or facility, on the premises of any city-owned or operated building or facility, in any public library, or on the premises of any public library. For purposes of this section, the term "tobacco or tobacco products" shall mean any tobacco or any product containing tobacco, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Cigarettes; 
(2)  Cigars; 
(3)  Chewing tobacco; 
(4)  Snuff; 
(5)  Pipe tobacco; 
(6)  Smokeless tobacco. 
(d)  A sign stating that smoking and the use of tobacco products is not permitted on the premises shall be conspicuously posted at or near each entrance to any city-owned or operated building or public library. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in any city-owned vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 12, 8-21-12; Ord. No. 27-084-2015 , § 1, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 27-73. - Vending machines. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against this city for any business owner or manager of any retail establishment within the jurisdiction of this city, to allow the existence of a vending machine containing tobacco products in any area where minors are allowed. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 13, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-74. - Reasonable distance. 
    Smoking is and shall be prohibited within a reasonable distance of fifteen (15) feet, when attainable, outside an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited, including a reasonable distance of fifteen (15) feet, when attainable, from each and every exterior door to the establishment that is generally accessed by patrons or employees, so as to insure that tobacco smoke does not enter the area through entrances, windows, ventilation systems or other means. (If fifteen (15) feet is not achievable, no less than seven (7) feet is required.) 
    The owner, operator, manager, or other person in control of an establishment may declare that smoking is prohibited within a distance greater than fifteen (15) feet, when attainable, outside an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited. If smoking is prohibited outside the establishment within a distance greater than fifteen (15) feet, when attainable, a conspicuous sign shall be posted at every entrance stating that smoking is prohibited within a specified distance (in feet) from the building. Smoking shall be prohibited in any place in which a sign conforming to the requirements of this section is posted. (If fifteen (15) feet is not achievable, no less than seven (7) feet is required.) 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 14, 8-21-12) 
Sec. 27-75. - Non-retaliation and non-waiver of employee rights. 
(a)  No person or employer shall discharge, refuse to hire, or in any manner retaliate against an employee, applicant for employment, customer, or resident of a multiple-unit residential facility because that employee, applicant, customer, or resident exercises any rights afforded by this article or reports or attempts to prosecute a violation of this article. Notwithstanding section 27-70, violation of this subsection shall be a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
(b)  An employee who works in a setting where an employer allows smoking does not waive or otherwise surrender any legal rights the employee may have against the employer or any other party. 
(Ord. No. 27-022-2012, § 16, 8-21-12; Ord. No. 27-024, § 1, 8-28-2012) 
Secs. 27-76-27-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SALE OF TOBACCO, TOBACCO PRODUCTS OR ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCTS TO MINORS 

Sec. 27-91. - Prohibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either directly or indirectly by an agent or employee, or by a vending machine owned by the person or located in the person's establishment or business, to sell, furnish, give to or purchase for any person under the age of nineteen (19) years any tobacco, tobacco product, or alternative nicotine product; or to attempt to sell, furnish, give to or purchase any tobacco, tobacco product, or alternative nicotine product for a person under the age of nineteen (19) years. 
( Ord. No. 27-026-2014, § 1, 7-22-14 ) 
Sec. 27-92. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Alternative nicotine product means: 
(1)  An electronic cigarette; or 
(2)  Any other product that consists of or contains nicotine that can be ingested into the body by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling or by any other means. The term "alternative nicotine product" does not include the following: 
a.  A cigarette or other tobacco product as defined in section 28-11-2 of the Code of Alabama. 
b.  A product that is a drug under 21 U.S.C. §321(g)(1). 
c.  A product that is a device under 21 U.S.C. §321(h). 
d.  A combination product that is a device under 21 U.S.C. §353(g). 
    Electronic cigarette shall mean an electronic product or device that produces vapor that delivers nicotine or other substances to the person inhaling from the device to simulate smoking, and is likely to be offered to, or purchased by, consumers as an electronic cigarette, electronic cigar, electronic cigarillo, or electronic pipe. The term "electronic cigarette" does not include any of the following: 
(1)  A cigarette or other tobacco product as defined in section 28-11-2 of the Code of Alabama. 
(2)  A product that is a drug under 21 U.S.C. §321(g)(1). 
(3)  A product that is a device under 21 U.S.C. §321(h). 
(4)  A combination product that is a device under 21 U.S.C. §353(g). 
    Tobacco or tobacco products shall mean any tobacco or any product containing tobacco, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Cigarettes. 
(2)  Cigars. 
(3)  Chewing tobacco. 
(4)  Snuff. 
(5)  Pipe tobacco. 
(6)  Smokeless tobacco. 
( Ord. No. 27-026-2014, § 2, 7-22-14 ) 
Sec. 27-93. - Proof of age. 
    Before selling, offering for sale, giving or furnishing any tobacco, tobacco product, or alternative nicotine product to an individual, a person shall verify that the individual is over the age of nineteen (19) years by examining from any individual that appears to be under the age of twenty-seven (27) years of age the individual's proof of age. It shall be unlawful for any person to accept any proof of age from a person purchasing or attempting to purchase any tobacco, tobacco product, or alternative nicotine product except for the following: 
(1)  A valid driver's license issued by any state and bearing the photograph of the presenting person. 
(2)  A valid United States Uniform Service Identification. 
(3)  A valid passport, bearing a photograph and date of birth of the presenting person. 
(4)  A valid identification issued by an agency of a state for the purpose of identification, bearing a photograph and date of birth of the presenting person. 
( Ord. No. 27-026-2014, § 3, 7-22-14 ) 
Sec. 27-94. - Citation. 
    A city police officer may choose to cite and release a person that violates this division. The uniform non-traffic citation and complaint ("UNTCC") shall serve as the charging instrument and shall be issued in accordance with Rule 20 of the Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. 
( Ord. No. 27-026-2014, § 4, 7-22-14 ) 
Sec. 27-95. - Municipal offense ticket. 
    A person designated as an enforcement officer may issue a municipal offense ticket ("MOT") for a violation of this division. The person charged with a violation must, within the time period specified on the MOT, or within seventy-two (72) hours before the court date shown on the MOT: 
(1)  Appear in person before a magistrate, sign the plea of guilty/waiver of rights provision on the MOT, and pay the fine and applicable court costs; or 
(2)  Sign the plea of guilty/waiver of rights provision on the MOT and mail or hand deliver to the clerk of the municipal court the signed page and payment for the amount of the fine and applicable court costs. Remittance by mail or hand delivery of the fine and costs constitutes a guilty plea and waiver of trial, even if the "plea of guilty/waiver of rights" provision on the MOT has not been signed by the defendant. If the amount sent is insufficient, then the money received by the clerk shall be considered to be a partial payment of the fine and costs, and it shall be applied by the clerk to the fine and costs and deposited as required by law. The clerk shall give notice of the insufficiency, and a supplemental summons or warrant of arrest may be issued for the defendant's arrest; or 
(3)  Sign the MOT and agree to appear in court on the date and at the time shown on the MOT to contest the charge. If the defendant fails to appear, the municipal court may, in its discretion, issue further notice or issue a supplemental summons or warrant of arrest. 
( Ord. No. 27-026-2014, § 5, 7-22-14 ) 
Sec. 27-96. - Penalties. 
    Any person who pleads guilty or is found guilty of a violation of this division may be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), by imprisonment for not more than six (6) months, or may be sentenced to perform community service as directed by the judge. 
( Ord. No. 27-026-2014, § 6, 7-22-14 ) 
Chapter 28 - HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - HOUSING CODE 

Sec. 28-1. - Adopted. 
    The Standard Housing Code, being particularly the 1994 edition thereof and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as may hereinafter be amended, of which not less than three (3) copies have been and are now filed in the office of the city clerk, and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set forth at length herein, and from the date on which this article shall take effect, the provisions therein shall be controlling in the use, maintenance and occupancy of all dwellings, dwelling units and/or structures within the area of jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 28-036, § 1, 6-23-87; Ord. No. 28-025, § 1, 5-6-97) 
Sec. 28-2. - Amendments. 
    Subsection 101.4 of section 101 of the Standard Housing Code is amended to read as follows: 
101.4. Existing buildings. 
    (a) If, within any twelve-month period, alterations or repairs costing in excess of fifty (50) percent of the then physical value of the building are made to an existing building, such building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings, provided also that for buildings located in fire districts the provisions of sections 303.1 and 303.2 shall apply. 
    (b) If an existing building is damaged by fire or otherwise in excess of fifty (50) percent of its then physical value before such damage is repaired, it shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
    (c) If the cost of such alterations or repairs within any twelve-month period or the amount of such damage as referred to in section 101.5 is more than twenty-five (25) but not more than fifty (50) percent of the then physical value of the building, the portions to be altered or repaired shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for new buildings to such extent as the director of inspection services may determine. 
    (d) For the purpose of this section physical value of the building shall be determined by the director of inspection services. 
    (e) If the occupancy of an existing building is entirely changed the building shall be made to conform to the requirements of this code for the new occupancy. If the occupancy of only a portion of an existing building is changed and that portion is separated from the remainder as stipulated in section 403, then only such portion need be made to conform. 
    (f) Repairs and alterations, not covered by the preceding paragraphs of this section, restoring a building to its condition previous to damage or deterioration, or altering it in conformity with the provisions of this code or in such manner as will not extend or increase an existing nonconformity or hazard, may be made with the same kind of materials as those of which the building is constructed; but not more than twenty-five (25) percent of the roof covering of a building shall be replaced in any period of twelve (12) months unless the entire roof covering is made to conform with the requirements of this code for new buildings. 
    Subsection 102.1 of section 102 of the Standard Housing Code is amended to read as follows: 
102.1. Enforcement officer. 
    There is hereby established by the applicable governing body provisions for the enforcement of this code by the director of inspection services. 
    Section 104 of the Standard Housing Code is amended to read as follows: 
104. Inspections. 
    (a) The director of inspection services shall of his own volition or upon receipt of complaints cause to be made such inspections as are necessary to determine the fitness of a dwelling unit for human occupancy. He shall make a record of every such inspection and of all violations of this code. 
    (b) The director of inspection services shall make, or cause to be made by his duly authorized representative, the inspections called for by these requirements. 
    (c) The applicable governing body shall not provide, nor permit another to provide either public or private utility services such as water, gas, electricity, sewer, etc., to any substandard dwelling unit becoming vacant until such dwelling unit has been inspected and brought into compliance with this code and the building code, and a valid certificate of occupancy as required has been issued. This requirement shall not preclude the temporary use of such utility services as may be deemed necessary during construction, repair or alteration. The director of inspection services shall be responsible for making the determination as to when such "temporary services" may be necessary. 
    (d) No building, plumbing, electrical, gas or other permit, as may be required for an addition, alteration or repair of an existing substandard dwelling unit shall be issued until such time as an inspection of the property has been made to determine the feasibility of rehabilitation of such dwelling unit. 
    Section 108 of the Standard Housing Code is amended to read as follows: 
108. Violations and penalties 
    Any person, firm, corporation or agent, who shall violate a provision of this code, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, construct, alter, demolish or move any structure, or has erected, constructed, altered, repaired, moved or demolished a building or structure in violation of this code shall be guilty of an offense against the city. Each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense per each and every day, or portion thereof, during which any violation of any provision of this code is committed, or continued, and upon conviction of such violation such person shall be punished as prescribed in Chapter 1, Article II, City Code (1991). 
    All references to the housing board of adjustments and appeals, and all text making reference to or in any way concerning the housing board of adjustments and appeals appearing in the Standard Building Code as adopted by and incorporated in Ordinance 28-036 are hereby deleted in their entirety. Specifically, reference to the housing board of adjustments and appeals and all text pertaining to said board found in the following sections is deleted: 101.4.1, 103.2.4, 103.4, 103.5, 105, 106, and 107. 
(Ord. No. 28-036, §§ 2-6, 6-23-87; Ord. No. 28-008; §§ 1, 2, 2-13-96) 
Secs. 28-3-28-9. - Reserved.
