No. 34-038-2012, § 1, 11-27-12; Ord. No. 34-008-2014, § 1, 4-8-14 ) 
Sec. 34-65. - Exemptions. 
(a)  There are exempted from the computation of the amount of the privilege license tax levied, assessed or payable under this article: 
(1)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property which the city is prohibited from taxing under the Constitution or laws of the United States, or under the Constitution and laws of the state. 
(2)  The gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or renting of a rental motor vehicle reported under Ordinance 34-034, adopted June 24, 2003, which is codified herein as art. IV of this chapter. 
(b)  Any business, trace or other activity in the city or its police jurisdiction that is exempt from this municipal annual license tax under state or federal law is hereby exempt from the annual privilege license tax levied, assessed or payable under this article. 
(Ord. 34-035, § 1, 6-24-03; Ord. No. 34-058-2007, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 34-66. - Exchange of information. 
    The revenue director may exchange tax returns, information, records, and other documents secured by the city, with other cities adopting similar ordinances for the exchange of taxpayer information, or with county or state authorities. The revenue director may charge a reasonable fee for providing such information or documents. Any tax returns, information, records, or other documents so exchanged shall remain subject to the confidentiality provisions, restrictions, and criminal penalties for unauthorized disclosure as provided under state or municipal law. 
(a)  Any such exchange shall be for one or more of the following purposes: 
(1)  Collecting taxes due. 
(2)  Ascertaining the amount of taxes due from any person. 
(3)  Determining whether a person is liable for, or whether there is probable cause for believing a person might be liable for, the payment of any tax to a state, county, or municipal agency. 
(b)  Nothing herein shall prohibit the use of tax returns or tax information by the city in the proper administration of any matter administered by the revenue director. The revenue director may also divulge to a purchaser, prospective purchaser as defined pursuant to the regulations of the state department of revenue, or successor of a business or stock of goods the outstanding sales, use, or rental tax liability of the seller for which the purchaser, prospective purchaser as defined pursuant to the regulations of the state department of revenue, or successor may be liable pursuant to Code of Ala. §§ 40-23-25, 40-23-82, or 40-12-224. 
(Ord. No. 34-058-2007, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 34-67. - Waiver of penalty. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, no fine or penalty under this section shall be assessed, or if assessed, shall be waived, if reasonable cause exists. "Reasonable cause" shall mean: The death or major illness of or an accident involving a sole proprietor causing serious bodily injury that in either case resulted in the sole proprietor being unable to purchase the license or operate his or her business during the ten (10) days preceding the due date for the license; natural disaster, fire, explosion, or accident that caused the closing or temporary cessation of the business of the taxpayer during the ten (10) days preceding the due date for the license; or reasonable reliance on the erroneous written advice of an employee or agent of the city's revenue department given in good faith while acting in his or her official capacity in response to a specific written request of the taxpayer or its representative provided the penalty did not result from the taxpayer's or its representative's failure to provide complete and accurate information or from a change in law or a new judicial interpretation of an existing law. Written advice or requests includes those transmitted by electronic mail. 
(Ord. No. 34-058-2007, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 34-68. - Refunds on overpayments. 
(a)  Any taxpayer may file a petition for refund with the city for any overpayment of business license tax erroneously paid to the city. If a final assessment for the tax has been entered by the city, a petition for refund of all or a portion of the tax may be filed only if the final assessment has been paid in full prior to or simultaneously with the filing of the petition for refund. 
(b)  A petition for refund shall be filed with the city within two years from the date of payment of the business license tax, which is the subject of the petition. 
(c)  The city shall either grant or deny a petition for refund within six months from the date the petition is filed, unless the period is extended by written agreement of the taxpayer and the city. The taxpayer shall be notified of the city's decision concerning the petition for refund by first class U.S. mail or by certified U.S. mail, return receipt requested, sent to the taxpayer's last known address. If the city fails to grant a full refund within the time provided herein, the refund petition shall be deemed to be denied. 
(d)  If the petition is granted or the city or a court otherwise determines that a refund is due, the overpayment shall be promptly refunded to the taxpayer, together with interest to the extent provided for in section 11-51-92. If the city determines that a refund is due, the amount of overpayment plus any interest due thereon may first be credited by the city against any outstanding tax liabilities due and owing by the taxpayer to the city, and the balance of any overpayment shall be promptly refunded to the taxpayer. If any refund or part thereof is credited to any other tax by the city the taxpayer shall be provided with a written detailed statement showing the amount of overpayment, the amount credited for payment to other taxes, and the resulting amount of the refund. 
(e)  A taxpayer may appeal from the denial in whole or in part of a petition for refund by filing a notice of appeal with the clerk of the county circuit court. Said notice of appeal must be filed within two (2) years from the date the petition was denied. The circuit court shall hear the appeal according to its own rules and procedures and shall determine the correct amount of refund due, if any. If an appeal is not filed with the appropriate circuit court within two (2) years of the date the petition was denied, then the appeal shall be dismissed for lack of jurisdiction 
(Ord. No. 34-058-2007, 11-27-07) 
Secs. 34-69, 34-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RENTAL MOTOR VEHICLE TAX 

Sec. 34-71. - Levy of tax. 
    This is hereby levied in addition to all privilege license taxes of every kind now imposed by law, and shall be collected as herein provided, a privilege or license tax against the lessors of certain rental motor vehicles from locations within the city and its police jurisdiction, as provided herein. 
    The rental motor vehicle tax shall be levied and twenty-eight (28) percent of the revenue collected pursuant to this ordinance shall be dedicated and used for the purpose of making capital improvements in city parks; promoting tourism, trade, commerce and industry; for the provision of convention, trade, sports, and recreational facilities; and for public safety purposes. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-72. - Rate. 
    The rental motor vehicle tax rate shall be five and one-half (5.5) percent of taxable charges to the public for the rental of motor vehicles within the city and two and three-quarters (2.75) percent of taxable charges to the public for the rental of motor vehicles within the police jurisdiction. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-73. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms shall have the meanings shown below when used in this article: 
(1)  Rental motor vehicle. A motor vehicle designed to carry fifteen (15) or fewer passengers, and used primarily for the transportation of persons that is rented or leased without a driver, regardless of whether such vehicle is licensed in this state. 
(2)  Taxable charges. The total charges received by a rental motor vehicle business for the rental or lease of a motor vehicle for sixty (60) or fewer consecutive days, including the total cash and nonmonetary consideration for the rental or lease including, but not limited to, charges based on time or mileage, and charges for insurance coverage or collision damage waiver, but excluding all charges for motor fuel taxes and sales taxes. Taxable charges shall not include rental charges associated with the rental or lease of a rental motor vehicle if the customer picks up the rental motor vehicle outside this state and returns it in this state. 
(3)  Rental motor vehicle business. A person or legal entity, which owns or leases five or more rental motor vehicles, and which regularly rents or leases such vehicles to the public for value. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-74. - Return; payment of tax. 
(a)  Each rental motor vehicle business shall remit the tax to the city revenue department, and the tax remitted shall not be a credit against the tax imposed by the city's general lease tax Ordinance Number 34-113 adopted September 21, 1971. 
(b)  Every rental motor vehicle business subject to the tax levy pursuant to this article shall be liable for the tax at the applicable rate on the rental charges actually collected, or the amount of taxes collected from the customers, whichever is greater. 
(c)  All persons subject to the provisions of this article may add the tax herein levied to the rental price and collect the same from the purchasers but this section is not mandatory. 
(d)  Each rental motor vehicle business shall, on or before the twentieth day of each month, transmit to the revenue department a return showing the total automotive rental charges collected during the preceding calendar month, the amounts of the various exclusions as provided by this article, and the tax amount due. 
(e)  Said rental motor vehicle business shall remit the tax to the city with its monthly tax return. Such return shall be submitted on a form prescribed by the revenue department. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-75. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person liable hereunder for city rental motor vehicle tax who fails to file a return, fails to timely file a return, fails to pay taxes due or fails to timely pay taxes due, shall, in addition to the taxes due, owe the city the penalties due under section 34-22 of this Code. 
(b)  In addition to all other penalties, if a taxpayer fails to timely pay the city and rental motor vehicle tax due under the city's rental motor vehicle tax code, there shall be added as interest one (1) percent of the total amount due if the delinquency is not for more than one (1) month, with an additional one (1) percent for each additional month or fraction thereof during which the delinquency continues. 
(c)  Criminal penalties. In addition to the above penalties, any person convicted of a violation of the city's rental motor vehicle tax code shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense and by a fine of no more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a prison sentence of no more than six (6) months upon conviction of a second offense and all additional offenses within a calendar year. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03; Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 4, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-76. - Failure to file; assessment. 
(a)  In any case where a person or firm liable for paying rental motor vehicle taxes as provided herein fails to do so, the revenue department shall be authorized to determine the amount of taxes due using the best information available either by return filed or by other means. The taxpayer shall be notified by registered or certified mail or by personal service, of the amount of any such assessment, and of his right to appear before the revenue director on a day named not less twenty (20) days from the date of notice and show cause why such assessment shall not be made final. Such appearance may be made by agent or attorney. 
(b)  If no showing is made on or before the date fixed in such notice, or if such showing is not sufficient in the judgment of the city revenue director, such assessment shall be made final in the amount originally fixed, or in such other amount as is determined by the revenue department to be correct. 
(c)  If upon such hearing the revenue department finds the amount due to be different from that originally assessed, he/she shall make the assessment final in the correct amount and in all cases shall notify the taxpayer of the assessment as finally fixed. 
(d)  A notice by the United States mail, addressed to the taxpayer's last known place of business, shall be sufficient. Any assessment made by the city revenue department shall be prima facie correct upon appeal. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-77. - Maintenance of books and records. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaging, or continuing in this city in any business for which a privilege tax is imposed by this article to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross rental charges, taxable charges, and such other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable under the provisions of this article. And it shall be the duty of every person to keep and preserve these records for a period of five (5) years. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-78. - Examination of books and records. 
    The books, records and accounts mentioned in the preceding section shall at all times be open to examination by the revenue department or any person designated. Any person who shall fail to keep such records or who shall refuse to permit such examination thereof or who violates any other provision hereof shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in chapter 1 of the Mobile City Code. 
(Ord. 34-034, § 1, 6-24-03) 
Sec. 34-79-34-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TOBACCO PRODUCTS TAX 

Sec. 34-91. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the "tobacco products tax." 
(Ord. No. 34-058, § 1, 10-7-03) 
Sec. 34-92. - Cigarettes. 
(a)  Definitions. Unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning, the following definitions shall apply in this article whether capitalized or not; the masculine gender shall include the feminine; the plural shall include the singular, and the singular shall include the plural. 
    Cigarettes means any cigarette made from tobacco or any substitute therefore. 
    City means the City of Mobile, Alabama. 
    Collector means the person designated by the city revenue director to collect or enforce the tobacco products tax. 
    Consumer means any person who purchases or otherwise consumes cigarettes or other tobacco products, irrespective of the manner or the source acquired, for any purpose other than resale. 
    Dealer means any wholesale or retail dealer, as herein defined. 
    Person means a natural person, firm, corporation, club, association, joint stock company, receiver, estate, trustee or any other person acting in a fiduciary capacity, or other legal entity. 
    Retail dealer means every person, other than a wholesale dealer, who sells or delivers to consumers within the city or its police jurisdiction, cigarettes or other tobacco products, and all persons operating under a retail dealer's license. 
    Stamps means the city revenue stamps that wholesalers must, by this article, affix to each package of cigarettes. 
    Storer means any person who ships or causes to be shipped or receives cigarettes or other tobacco products into the city or its police jurisdiction, and stores the same in any manner and/or withdraws or uses the same for any purpose, other than for resale or reshipment outside of the limits of the city or its police jurisdiction. 
    Wholesale dealer and jobber mean any person who sells, stores or delivers cigarettes within the city or its police jurisdiction to retail dealers for the purpose of resale. 
(b)  Levy of tax-City. In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every wholesale dealer who sells, stores or delivers cigarettes in the city shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied, for the sale, storage, or delivery of cigarettes in the city. The license tax shall be in an amount equal to fifteen cents ($0.15) for each package of cigarettes so sold, stored or delivered. 
(c)  Levy of tax-Police jurisdiction. In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every wholesale dealer who sells, stores or delivers cigarettes in the police jurisdiction shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied, for the sale, storage, or delivery of cigarettes in the police jurisdiction of the city. The license tax shall be in an amount equal to seven and one half cents ($0.075) for each package of cigarettes so sold, stored or delivered. 
(d)  Stamps. The collector shall keep on hand, for sale, an adequate quantity of stamps to be affixed to each package of such cigarettes, in the denomination required by this article. Each such stamp shall have inscribed thereon the words "City of Mobile - Cigarette Tax", but such words need not be arranged in the foregoing order and may be abbreviated. 
(e)  Discounts. Said stamps may be sold to the wholesale dealer only by the collector, at the following discounts: 
(1)  On a sale of one hundred dollars ($100.00) or over, and less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), a discount of one (1) percent on the entire amount of the sale. 
(2)  On a sale of two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more, a discount of three and three-tenths (3.3) percent on the entire amount of the sale. 
The discounts allowed hereby represent compensation to the wholesale dealer for the labor of affixing the said stamps to the cigarettes enumerated herein. All other persons, except such wholesale dealer, must pay the full face of the amount of the stamps, but no person or dealer shall be entitled to purchase any such number of said stamps as would cause the purchase price to include the fraction of a cent. 
(f)  Stamps held in inventory. Any city cigarette stamps held in inventory on the effective date of this article shall be revalued to reflect the increased amount of tax imposed by this article. For the first month this article is in effect, each wholesale dealer or jobber shall attach to the monthly report required herein a revaluation statement setting forth: 
(1)  The number of city cigarette stamps on hand as of the end of the last day of the month immediately preceding the effective date of this article; 
(2)  The monetary revaluation of the cigarette stamps at fifteen cents ($0.15) each within the city or at seven and one-half cents ($0.075) within the police jurisdiction; 
(3)  The monetary valuation of the city cigarette stamps at five cents ($0.05) each within the city or at two and one-half cents ($0.025) within the police jurisdiction; and 
(4)  The difference between the monetary revaluation in (2) and the monetary valuation in (3). 
(g)  Dedication of revenues. Two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the cigarette tax revenue collected pursuant to this section shall be used exclusively for the purpose of funding of blanket raises for the city's merit system employees. 
(h)  Dealers. Before any cigarettes shall be sold or delivered within the limits of the city or its police jurisdiction by any dealer, such dealer shall affix to each package of said cigarettes a stamp or stamps, obtained from the collector, in the amount set out in this article, in payment of the license taxes imposed by this article. 
(i)  Time for affixing stamps. Every dealer shall, within one (1) hour after the receipt of any such cigarettes within the city or its police jurisdiction, unless sooner offered for sale, cause stamps to the requisite amount of the tax to be affixed as hereinabove stated, and to cause the same to be cancelled by writing or stamping with waterproof ink across the face of each stamp, the registered number furnished such dealer by the state department of revenue. After such stamping has begun, it shall be continued with reasonable diligence by such dealer until all cigarettes have been stamped and the stamps cancelled as provided, but no stamps required to be affixed to any package of cigarettes shall, after the same has been affixed as herein provided, be again used in payment of any part of the tax levied under this article. 
(j)  Manner of affixing stamps. Such stamps shall be affixed in such a manner that their removal will require continued application of water or steam. In the case of cigarettes sold by retail in packages, the stamps shall be affixed to each individual package in such a way that such stamps shall be torn in two (2) or mutilated when such package is opened. 
(k)  Records. Every wholesale dealer shall, at the time of selling and/or delivering any cigarettes enumerated herein within the city or its police jurisdiction, make a true duplicate invoice of the same, which shall show full and complete detail of the sale and/or delivery of said cigarettes, and shall retain the same, subject to the use and inspection of the collector or his duly authorized deputy, for a period of three (3) years. Wholesale and retail dealers shall also keep a record of the purchase, sale, exchange and/or receipt of all the aforesaid cigarettes, and hold all books, records, cancelled checks and all other memoranda pertaining to such purchase, sales, exchange and/or receipt for three (3) years, subject to the inspection of the collector or his duly authorized deputy, shall have the power and authority to enter upon the premises and to examine such books, records and memoranda at all reasonable times. Wholesale and retail dealers shall also keep a record of the purchases of all cigarettes enumerated herein and hold all books, records and memoranda pertaining to the purchase of such cigarettes open to the inspection of the collector or his deputy, at any reasonable time. 
(l)  Reports/wholesale dealer. Every wholesale dealer shall furnish to the collector a monthly report, between the first and tenth of each month, showing: 
(1)  The total amount of cigarettes sold or delivered the preceding month in the city or its police jurisdiction; and 
(2)  All orders for cigarettes purchased from without the city or its police jurisdiction on a drop shipment and consigned direct to the person ordering such cigarettes. 
(m)  Reports/retail dealers. Every retail dealer purchasing or receiving cigarettes from without the city or its police jurisdiction whether the same shall have been ordered or purchased through a wholesaler or jobber in this city or police jurisdiction, or by drop shipment or otherwise, shall within thirty (30) days of receipt of such cigarettes, mail by registered mail a true duplicate of invoice of all such purchases or receipts to the collector, said invoice carrying the name of the person or firm from whom or through whom such purchase or shipments of such cigarettes so received, showing kinds and quantities. 
(n)  Reports/others. Any person who purchases and/or receives in any manner whatsoever, any of the cigarettes enumerated herein which do not have city revenue stamps affixed as required by this article shall, within three (3) days after receipt of such cigarettes, report the receipt and purchase of said cigarettes to the collector, giving the date of purchase or receipt, the name and address of the person or firm from whom purchased or received, and a list describing the cigarettes purchased or received. Such report must be made by registered mail or in person. 
(o)  Interference with the collector. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with or obstruct the collector or his deputy or agent, in the exercise of the power and authority conferred by this article. 
(p)  Cigarettes subject to confiscation. Any cigarettes taxable under the provisions of this article, found at any point within the city or its police jurisdiction, which have been within the city or its police jurisdiction for a period of two (2) hours or longer in the possession of any retailer or semi-jobber, or for a period of thirty-six (36) hours or longer in the possession of any wholesaler or jobber, not having affixed to the package the stamps as provided, are hereby declared to be contraband goods and may be seized by the collector, his deputy or agent, or by any peace officer of the city, without a warrant, and the said goods shall be delivered to the collector for sale at public auction to the highest bidder, but the collector, before delivering any cigarettes so seized, shall require the purchaser to affix the proper amount of stamps to the individual package. 
(q)  Proceeds. The proceeds of sale for any cigarettes so sold shall be accounted for by the collector, as are the funds collected by him. Provided, further that any of the cigarettes herein enumerated when offered for sale, either at wholesale or retail, without the stamps having been first affixed, shall be subject to confiscation as hereinabove provided. 
(r)  Procedure when cigarettes are confiscated. In all cases where cigarettes are seized or confiscated by the collector, under the provisions of this article, he shall follow the procedure set forth in Code of Ala., § 40-25-9, which procedure is hereby adopted, all advertisements provided for therein to be made in the city. 
(s)  Illegal acts. Among others, the following acts and omissions shall be unlawful: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person required by this article to affix stamps to cigarettes, to fail to affix such stamps, or to fail to cancel such stamps in the manner or within the time required by this article. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, deliver or consume, within the city or its police jurisdiction, any cigarettes to which stamps have not been affixed and cancelled as provided by this article. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any dealer to have in his possession, or under his control, any cigarettes not properly stamped, as required by this article, for more than six (6) hours after receipt of such cigarettes on the premises of such person, provided that this subsection shall not apply to cigarettes in the possession of wholesale dealers or jobbers, kept for the purpose of resale or reshipment outside of the city or its police jurisdiction and which products are actually so resold or reshipped. The possession of each article not having the proper stamps affixed thereto, as required by this article, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful to manufacture, buy, sell, offer for sale, or possess, or attempt to do so, any reproduction or counterfeit of the stamps provided for in this article, or to possess tools, implements, instruments or material of any kind necessary or appropriate to reproduce or counterfeit such stamps, or to alter or cause to be altered any stamp herein provided for. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful to remove from a package or otherwise prepare any stamp with intent to use or cause the same to be used, after it has already been used, or to buy, sell, offer for sale, or give away, any washed, removed, altered or restored stamp to any person, or to possess any washed or removed or restored or altered stamp, or for the purpose of indicating the payment of any tax hereunder, to reuse any stamp which has been used for the payment of any tax provided in this article, or, except as to the collector, to sell any stamp provided for herein. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful to reuse or refill with cigarettes, any packages from which such tax paid cigarettes have been removed. 
(t)  Application. This article shall not be applied: 
(1)  To impose any unlawful tax or unlawful burden on interstate commerce or any business of the United States Government or of any branch or agency thereof, or to any cigarettes exempted from the payment of the State Tobacco Tax by Code of Ala. § 40-25-15, as last amended; 
(2)  To apply to cigarettes stored by any wholesale dealer for the purpose of resale or reshipment outside of the city, and which are actually so resold or reshipped; 
(3)  Whenever the requisite amount of stamps has been affixed to the cigarettes, as required, this article shall not require additional stamps to be affixed in case of subsequent sales, deliveries or storages. 
(4)  All of the provisions of this article, other than the rate of taxation, which apply to persons within the corporate limits of the city shall apply to and govern and be binding upon persons engaging in such business within the police jurisdiction. 
(u)  Penalty. Persons failing to properly affix the stamps required by this section shall be required to pay, as a part of the tax, a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and shall be shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or both, in the discretion of the judge trying the case. 
(Ord. No. 34-058, § 2, 10-7-03) 
Sec. 34-93. - Other tobacco products. 
(a)  Levy of tax-City. In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every wholesale dealer who sells, stores or delivers tobacco products, other than cigarettes, in the city shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied, in the following amounts: 
(1)  Ten cents ($0.10) on each package of little cigars, including cigarette-sized or near cigarette-sized cigars made of tobacco or any substitute therefor. 
(2)  Ten cents ($0.10) on each cigar, excluding those described in subdivision (1) of any description made of tobacco or any substitute therefor. 
(3)  Ten cents ($0.10) on each sack, can, or other container of smoking tobacco, including granulated, plug-cut, crimp-cut, ready-rubbed, and other kinds and forms of tobacco which are prepared in such manner as to be suitable for smoking in a pipe or cigarette. 
(4)  Ten cents ($0.10) on each sack, plug, package, or other container of chewing tobacco, which tobacco is prepared in such manner as to be suitable for chewing only and not suitable for smoking. 
(5)  Ten cents ($0.10) on each can, bottle, glass, tumbler, package, or other container of snuff made of tobacco or any substitute therefor. 
(6)  Ten cents ($0.10) on each package of tobacco paper, whether gummed or not. 
(b)  Levy of tax-Police jurisdiction. In addition to all other taxes now imposed by law, every wholesale dealer who sells, stores or delivers tobacco products, other than cigarettes, in the city's police jurisdiction shall pay a license tax to the city, and a license tax is hereby fixed and levied, in the following amounts: 
(1)  Five cents ($0.05) on each package of little cigars, cigarette-sized or near cigarette-sized cigars made of tobacco or any substitute therefor. 
(2)  Five cents ($0.05) on each cigar, excluding those described in subdivision (1) of any description made of tobacco or any substitute therefor. 
(3)  Five cents ($0.05) on each sack, can package or other container of smoking tobacco, including granulated, plug-cut, crimp-cut, ready-rubbed, and other kinds and forms of tobacco which are prepared in such manner as to be suitable for smoking in a pipe or cigarette. 
(4)  Five cents ($0.05) on each sack, plug, package, or other container of chewing tobacco, which tobacco is prepared in such manner as to be suitable for chewing only and not suitable for smoking. 
(5)  Five cents ($0.05) on each can, bottle, glass, tumbler, package, or other container of snuff made of tobacco or any substitute therefor. 
(6)  Five cents ($0.05) on each package of tobacco paper, whether gummed or not. 
(c)  Reports. Each person subject to the payment of the tax levied by this section shall furnish to the collector, not later than the twentieth day of each month, a copy of each invoice showing the total sales to retailers for the previous month. The collector shall then use said invoices to prepare and send a tax bill for the amount due under this section. Payments shall be due not later than the first day of the month following receipt of the tax bill from the collector. 
(d)  Penalties. Persons failing to timely report and/or pay the tax due under this section shall be required to pay, as a part of the tax, a penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition, persons failing to timely report and/or pay the tax due under this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be imprisoned for not more than six (6) months, or shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or both, in the discretion of the judge trying the case. 
(Ord. No. 34-058, § 3, 10-7-03) 
Secs. 34-94-34-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - LODGING TAX 

Sec. 34-101. - Levy of tax-City. 
    There is hereby imposed, levied and assessed against every person engaged in the business of operating hotels, motels, tourist courts, tourist cabins, lodging houses and rooming houses renting to transients, in addition to all license taxes heretofore imposed, and now existing against them, a license tax equal to eight (8) percent of the gross receipts received by each such person from the renting of rooms within the city, including the charge for use or rental of personal property and services furnished in such room. 
(Ord. No. 34-055-2004, § 1, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 34-102. - Levy of tax-Police jurisdiction. 
    There is hereby imposed, levied and assessed against every person engaged in the business of operating hotels, motels, tourist courts, tourist cabins, lodging houses and rooming houses renting to transients, in addition to all license taxes heretofore imposed, and now existing against them, a license tax equal to three (3) percent of the gross receipts received by each such person from the renting of rooms within the police jurisdiction, including the charge for use or rental of personal property and services furnished in such room. 
(Ord. No. 34-055-2004, § 2, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 34-103. - Exemptions. 
    The exemptions levied by this article shall be parallel to exemptions of the state lodging tax rules including but not limited to: 
(1)  Charges for rooms, lodgings, or accommodations supplied for a period of one hundred eighty (180) continuous days or more in any place; 
(2)  Charges for certain rooms, lodgings, or accommodations supplied by camps, conference centers, or similar facilities operated by nonprofit organizations primarily for the benefit of, and in connection with, recreational or educational programs for children, students, or members or guests of other nonprofit organizations during any calendar year; 
(3)  Charges for rooms, lodgings, or other accommodations in connection with the production of an approved project authorized by the Alabama Film Office and which meets criteria established by the Alabama Film Office through the Alabama Administrative Procedure Act; 
(4)  By privately operated camps, conference centers, or similar facilities that provide lodging and recreational or educational programs exclusively for the benefit of children, students, or members or guests of nonprofit organizations during any calendar year. 
(5)  For purposes of this section: "Children" means individuals under age 21; "student" is defined in accordance with 26 U.S.C. section 151(c) (4), as in effect from time to time or by any successor law; "nonprofit organization" is an organization exempt from federal income tax under 26 U.S.C. section 501 (c) (3), as in effect from time to time or any successor law; and "privately operated" refers to any camp, conference center, or similar facility other than those operated by a nonprofit organization as herein defined; 
(6)  Charges for rooms, lodgings, or other accommodations furnished to the United States Government, its departments, or its agencies are exempt provided the charges are billed directly to, and paid directly by, the United States Government. 
(7)  Charges for rooms, lodgings, or other accommodations furnished to federal credit unions are exempt provided the charges are billed directly to the federal credit union and paid for by the federal credit union with the federal credit union funds. 
(8)  Charges for rooms, lodgings, or other accommodations furnished to entities that are exempted from the payment of any and all state, county and municipal taxes by special act of the legislature provided the charges are billed directly to the exempt entity and paid for by the exempt entity with the exempt entity's funds. 
(Ord. No. 34-055-2004, § 3, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 34-104. - Monthly report; payment of tax. 
    All persons against whom the license tax imposed by this article is assessed shall, on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the business is carried on, make a verified report to the revenue department of the city showing the total receipts derived from the renting of rooms and the furnishing of personal property and services in such room during the preceding month, and shall, at the time of making such report, pay to the revenue department the amount of the license tax assessed in this article covering such preceding month. 
(Ord. No. 34-055-2004, § 4, 12-7-04) 
Sec. 34-105. - Provisions of state lodging tax statutes applicable to article; penalties. 
(a)  Lodging taxes levied by this article shall be subject to all penalties and interest applicable to taxes levied by the state lodging tax statutes, except where inapplicable or where herein otherwise provided, including provisions of the state tax statutes for enforcement and collection of taxes. 
(b)  In addition to other penalties, if a taxpayer fails to timely pay the city any lodging tax due under the city's lodging tax code, there shall be added as interest one (1) percent of the total amount due if the delinquency is not for more than one (1) month, with an additional one (1) percent for each additional month or fraction thereof under which the delinquency continues. 
(c)  Criminal penalties. In addition to the penalties provided under state law, any person convicted of a violation of the city's lodging tax code shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense and by a fine of no more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a prison sentence of no more than six (6) months upon conviction of a second offense and all additional offenses within a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 34-055-2004, § 5, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 5, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-106. - Allocation of revenues. 
(a)  Convention facility. Two (2) percent of the revenues derived from the lodging tax imposed by section 34-101 shall be designated for the expense incurred in building, marketing, operating and financing the convention facility, and for payments of any amounts by the city due under any lease with respect to the convention facility. 
(b)  Capital improvement fund. Two (2) percent of the revenues derived from the lodging tax imposed by section 34-101 and one (1) percent of the revenues derived from the lodging tax imposed by section 34-102 shall be designated to the capital improvement fund. 
(Ord. No. 34-055-2004, § 6, 12-7-04; Ord. No. 34-034-2016 , § 1, 7-26-16) 
Secs. 34-107-34-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TAX ON LEASE OF TANGIBLE PERSONAL PROPERTY 

Sec. 34-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  The term "person" or the term "company" herein used interchangeably, includes any individual, firm, co-partnership, association, corporation, receiver, trustee, entity, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, and the plural as well as the singular number, unless the intention to give a more limited meaning is disclosed by the context. 
(2)  The term "city" means the City of Mobile. 
(3)  The term "city license officer" shall mean the license officer of the City of Mobile. 
(4)  The term "business" means and shall include all activities engaged in, or caused to be engaged in, by any person with the object of gain, profit, benefit or advantage, either direct or indirect, to such person. 
(5)  The term "gross proceeds" means the value proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property, without any deduction on account of the cost of the property so leased or rented, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, interest paid or any other expenses whatsoever, and without any deductions on account of loss, but shall not include the gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or renting to another of the same property which is to be leased or rented in a transaction subject to the provisions of this article as long as the lessee in such excluded transaction (who has leased to re-lease) shall not use the same property to its own use; nor shall it include the gross proceeds accruing from any charge in respect to the use of docks and docking facilities furnished for vessels, barges, ships, and other watercraft operated on waterways; nor shall it include a transaction whereunder the lessor leases a truck or tractor-trailer or semi-trailer with driver furnished for operation over the public roads and highways (such transaction being deemed to constitute the rendition of service and not a "leasing or rental"); nor shall it include the gross proceeds accruing from charges made by operators of hotels, motels, tourist courts, tourist cabins, lodging houses, and rooming houses renting furnished rooms to transients, on which there is levied a lodging tax under article VI of chapter 34 of the City Code. 
(6)  The term "leasing or rental" means and includes a transaction whereunder the person who owns, or controls the possession of, tangible personal property permits another person in the city and its police jurisdiction to have the possession or use thereof for a consideration and for the duration of a definite or indefinite period of time, without transfer of the title of such property. The detention by the user thereof of freight cars, oxygen and acetylene tanks, and similar property, in respect of which detention a demurrage or per diem charge is made against the user of such property, shall not be deemed to constitute a transaction whereunder property is leased or rented to another within the meaning of this article. 
(7)  The term "tangible personal property" means and includes personal property which may be seen, weighed, measured, felt, or touched, or is in any other manner perceptible to the senses. The term "tangible personal property" shall not include stocks, bonds, notes, insurance, or other contracts, or securities. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-132. - Levy of tax. 
    There is hereby levied in addition to all privilege license taxes of every kind now imposed by law, and shall be collected as herein provided, a privilege or license tax against persons on account of the business activities and in the amounts to be determined by the application of rates against gross proceeds as follows: 
(1)  Upon each person engaging or continuing in the business of leasing or renting tangible personal property within the city at the rate of five (5) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor therefrom; provided that the privilege license tax levied in this article shall not apply to any leasing or rental, as lessor, by the United States of America, the state, or any municipality or county in the state. 
(2)  Upon each person engaging or continuing in the business of leasing or renting tangible personal property beyond the corporate limits and within the police jurisdiction of the city at the rate of two and one-half (21/2) percent of the gross proceeds derived by the lessor therefrom; provided, that the privilege tax levied in this article shall not apply to any leasing or rental, as lessor, by the United States of America, this state or any municipality or county in this state. 
    All of the provisions of this article, other than the rate of taxation, which apply to persons engaging in business within the corporate limits of the city, shall apply to and govern and be binding upon all persons engaging in such business beyond the corporate limits and within the police jurisdiction of the city. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09; Ord. No. 34-011-2010, § 3, 5-4-10; Ord. No. 34-028-2012, § 3, 10-2-12) 
Editor's note- The additional tax imposed by Ord. No. 34-028-2012 and amended by Ord. No. 34-039-2014 , adopted September 16, 2014, shall sunset effective September 30, 2018. 
Sec. 34-133. - Exemptions. 
    There are exempted from the computation of the amount of the privilege license tax levied, assessed or payable under this article the gross proceeds accruing from the leasing or rental of tangible personal property which the city is prohibited from taking under the Constitution or laws of the United States, or under the Constitution and laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-134. - When due and payable. 
    The privilege license tax levied under the provisions of this article, except as otherwise provided, shall be due and payable in monthly installments on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding the month in which the privilege license tax accrues. On or before the twentieth day of each month after this article shall have taken effect, every person on whom the amounts levied by this article are imposed, shall render to the city, on a form prescribed by the city, a true and correct statement showing the gross proceeds of his business, for the next preceding month, the amount of gross proceeds which are not subject to the privilege license tax, or are not to be used as measurement of the amounts due by such person and the nature thereof, together with such other information as the city may require, and at the time of making such monthly report such person shall compute the privilege license taxes due and shall pay to the city the amounts shown to be due. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-135. - Option for persons making cash and credit leases or rentals. 
    Any person taxable under this article, making cash and credit leases or rentals, may if he desires, report such cash leases or rentals only, and he shall thereafter include in each monthly report all credit collections made during the month preceding, and shall pay the privilege license tax due thereon at the time of filing such report. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-136. - Records. 
    It shall be the duty of every person engaging or continuing in any business for which a privilege tax is imposed by this article to keep and preserve suitable records of the gross proceeds of any such business and such other books and accounts as may be necessary to determine the amount of tax for which he is liable, under the provisions of this article. And it shall be the duty of every person to keep and preserve for a period of three years, all invoices of gross proceeds, proceeding or accruing from the leasing or rental herein taxed and all such books, invoices and other records shall be open for examination, at any time by the city or its agent. Any person leasing, who in addition for re-leasing, shall keep his books so as to show separately the gross proceeds of leasing and the gross proceeds of leasing and the gross proceeds of leasing for re-leasing. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09) 
Sec. 34-137. - Penalties. 
(a)  Leasing of personal property taxes levied by this article shall be subject to all penalties applicable to taxes levied by the state leasing of tangible personal property statutes, except where inapplicable or where herein otherwise provided, including provisions of those tax statutes for enforcement and collection of taxes. 
(b)  In addition to all other penalties, if a taxpayer fails to timely pay the city any lease tax due under the city's tax on lease of tangible personal property code, there shall be added as interest one (1) percent of the total amount due if the delinquency is not for more than one (1) month, with an additional one (1) percent for each additional month or fraction thereof during which the delinquency continues. 
(c)  Criminal penalties. In addition to the penalties provided under state law, any person convicted of a violation of the city's leasing of tangible personal property tax code shall be guilty of a class C misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a first offense and by a fine of no more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and a prison sentence of no more than six (6) months upon conviction of a second offense and all additional offenses within a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 34-048-2009, § 6, 12-15-09) 
Secs. 34-138-34-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - AD VALOREM TAX ON REAL AND PERSONAL PROPERTY AND INTANGIBLES 

Sec. 34-151. - Levy of tax; description of area. 
    For the purpose of paying the expenses of the city government, the council of the city does hereby lay, levy, and assess for the municipal tax year, beginning October 1, 2018, and for successive tax years, ad valorem taxes on all real and personal property and intangibles located within the corporate limits of the city, including, without limitations, property situated in the following described areas within the corporate limits of the city, and which may be subjected to municipal ad valorem taxes under the Constitution and Laws of the State of Alabama, viz.: 
"A" 
Commencing at the intersection of the west harbor line of Mobile River and the township line between Township 3 south and Township 4 south; thence eastwardly along said township line to the point where the same intersects the east shore line of Blakely Island on Polecat Bay; thence southwardly along the meanders of the said east shore line of Blakely Island and the north shore line of the Mobile Bay Bridge Causeway to a point on said north shore line of said Causeway where said shore line is intersected by the north-south Coordinate Line 336,000 of the Transverse Mercator Projection for Alabama West Zone as used officially on maps of the Mobile Bay area by the United States Corps of Engineers; thence south along said coordinate line to the point of its intersection with the south boundary line of Township 4 south, thence westwardly along said township line between Township 4 south and Township 5 south to the point where the same intersects the north right-of-way line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad; thence southwestwardly along the north right-of-way line of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad to the west bank of Dog River; thence northwestwardly along the west bank of Dog River to the north bank of Bolton Branch; thence northwestwardly along the north bank of Bolton Branch to the range line between Range 1 west and Range 2 west of the St. Stephens Meridian; thence due north along said range line to the southwest corner of Section 6, Township 4 south, Range 1 west of the St. Stephens Meridian; thence east along the south line of Section 6, and continue east along the south line of Section 5 of said Township 4 south, Range 1 west in a straight line to the southeast line of Alley No. 1 (Prichard Lane); thence northeastwardly along the south property line of Alley No. 1 (Prichard Lane) to the point where the same intersects the east property line of College Avenue; thence southeastwardly along the east and north property lines of College Avenue to the north property line of Sweeney's Lane; thence southwestwardly along the north property line of Sweeney's Lane to the west bank of Toulmin's Branch; thence southeastwardly along the west bank of Toulmin's Branch to a point directly west of the south boundary line to the City of Prichard; thence eastwardly, northwardly and eastwardly, along the boundary line of the City of Prichard to the southeast corner of the Craftview Court Subdivisions; thence directly eastwardly to the point of intersection of the west boundary line of West Highlands Subdivision; thence northwardly along the west boundary line of West Highlands Subdivision to the north boundary line of said subdivision; thence eastwardly along the north boundary line of said subdivision to the west right-of-way line of Telegraph Road;     Pursuant to the provisions of Act No. 18, General Acts of Alabama, 1956, Second Special Session, Page 279, the area described in said Act No. 18 but outside of that area described in sections 34-151 and 34-152 of this article is hereby exempted from city ad valorem taxes for the municipal tax year beginning October 1, 2018.

Sec. 34-154. - Rate. 
    The annual rate of each levy provided in sections 34-151 and 34-152 of this article shall be 0.70 of one per centum as authorized by law, of the value of such property as assessed for state taxation during the preceding year.

Chapter 37 - MOBILE HOMES AND MANUFACTURED HOMES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Housing, Ch. 28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 37-1-37-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME PARKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 37-21. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section unless a contrary intent clearly appears from the context: 
    City shall mean the city and its police jurisdiction. 
    Combination mobile home park shall mean a mobile home park for both dependent and independent mobile homes. 
    Dependent mobile home shall mean a mobile home which does not have a toilet and a bathtub or shower. 
    Dependent mobile home park shall mean a mobile home park for dependent mobile homes only. 
    Dependent mobile home space shall mean a mobile home space intended to accommodate a dependent mobile home only. 
    Independent mobile home shall mean a mobile home that has a toilet and a bathtub or shower. 
    Independent mobile home park shall mean a mobile home park for independent mobile homes only. 
    Independent mobile home space shall mean a mobile home space intended to accommodate an independent mobile home, but which may be used to accommodate a dependent mobile home; provided, that it shall be considered to be a dependent mobile home space when accommodating a dependent mobile home with respect to sections 37-72(4) and 37-73. 
    Inspector shall mean the director of inspection services of the city or his deputies and authorized representatives. 
    Mobile home shall mean any vehicle used or designed for use as a vehicle or conveyance upon the public highways and authorized to be licensed as such by the laws of the state and which is constructed in such a manner as to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling or sleeping place for one (1) or more persons. 
    Mobile home park shall mean any plot of ground upon which two (2) or more mobile homes occupied or designed to be used for dwelling or sleeping purposes are located, but not including a plot of ground used by a licensed motor vehicle dealer exclusively for the display and sale of mobile homes or other vehicles where such homes are not occupied or used for such purposes. 
    Mobile home space shall mean a plot of ground within a mobile home park designated and intended for the accommodation of one (1) mobile home. 
    Planning director shall mean the planning director of the city planning commission. 
    Service building shall mean a substantial permanent building providing toilet facilities for men and women and slop water closet and other facilities for use in common by the occupants of mobile home spaces. 
(Code 1965, § 36-1) 
Sec. 37-22. - Violation and penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be punished as provided by chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). Each day that a violation of any provision of this article shall occur or continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 36-35) 
Sec. 37-23. - Right of entry of inspector. 
    Upon presentation of proper credentials, the inspector may enter, at reasonable times, any building, structure or premises in the city to inspect the same for compliance with the requirements of this article and to perform any other duty imposed upon him thereby. 
(Code 1965, § 36-33) 
Sec. 37-24. - Applicability of city building, plumbing and electrical codes. 
    The provisions of the city building code, the city plumbing code and the city electrical code are applicable to all work coming within the purview thereof and done and performed upon a mobile home park. All work subject to any provisions thereof and done upon any mobile home park shall comply strictly with the provisions thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 36-7) 
Cross reference- Building code, § 11-1 et seq.; electrical code, § 19-1 et seq.; plumbing code, § 45-1 et seq. 
Sec. 37-25. - Use of mobile home spaces, etc., generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to accommodate, park or occupy an independent mobile home in or on a dependent mobile home space. It is unlawful for any person to accommodate, park or occupy a dependent mobile home in or on an independent mobile home space, unless such space shall be considered to be a dependent mobile home space when accommodating a dependent mobile home with respect to sections 37-72(4) and 37-73. It shall be unlawful for a person to rent, offer for rent, or continue to rent both a mobile home and a mobile home space to be used for dwelling or sleeping purposes unless the mobile home so rented, offered for rent or continued to be rented is maintained in such condition that it is fit and suitable for human habitation. 
(Code 1965, § 36-34) 
Secs. 37-26-37-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION PERMIT 

Sec. 37-41. - Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to construct, enlarge, alter, improve or convert any mobile home park or to improve any lands for use as a mobile home park or to cause the same to be done, unless such person holds a valid and existing permit issued for the performance of such work by the inspector. 
(Code 1965, § 36-2) 
Sec. 37-42. - Applicability-Procedures prescribed by building code applicable. 
    The procedures prescribed by the building code of the city, as amended from time to time, insofar as applicable and appropriate, are applicable to and shall be followed in applying for permits for the construction, alteration, enlargement, improvement, etc., of mobile home parks except as specifically otherwise provided in this article. 
(Code 1965, § 36-3) 
Sec. 37-43. - Same-Plot plan to be submitted with application; review, etc., of plot plan by planning director. 
    In addition to other matters required to be submitted with an application for a building permit for a mobile home park, there shall be submitted with the application therefor a complete plot plan drawn to scale which shall show the area and dimensions of the mobile home park; the number, location and size of all mobile home spaces; the location, width and arrangement of roadways and walkways; the location of service buildings and any other proposed structures; the location of water and sewer lines and the location and manner of protection for the playground area; the proposed plan for drainage of the property included in the mobile home park and the plans and specifications for the street to be constructed in such park. The inspector shall immediately transmit the plot plan to the planning director. The planning director shall promptly review the same, and if it shall appear therefrom that the plan complies with the provisions of this article and all other applicable ordinances and regulations, that the means provided for access from mobile home spaces, play areas and service buildings to roadways and public thoroughfares, and that the means of ingress and egress to and from public thoroughfares are so arranged as to make reasonable provisions for the safety of users, he shall endorse his approval thereon and return the same to the inspector. The planning director may also in his discretion submit recommendations for the improvement of such plot plan, which will improve the economy, convenience or efficiency of the use thereof, but such recommendation shall not be binding. If the planning director shall find that such plan does not comply with this article or other applicable ordinances and regulations or that the arrangement thereof does not provide for the safety and protection of the users, he shall disapprove such plan and return it to the inspector with a statement in writing as to his reasons for disapproval. No permit shall be issued if the planning director disapproves such plot plan. 
(Code 1965, § 36-4) 
Sec. 37-44. - Fee. 
    A fee for each mobile home park construction permit shall be paid to the inspector at the time of the filing of the application therefor. Such fee shall be in addition to all other building, electrical, plumbing and other fees required for work included in the construction. The fee shall be based upon the area included in the mobile home park and shall be computed at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) for the first five (5) or fraction thereof of mobile home spaces and one dollar fifty cents ($1.50) for each additional mobile home space. 
(Code 1965, § 36-5) 
Sec. 37-45. - Review by planning commission upon denial of permit. 
    Any person whose application for a permit under the provisions of this article has been denied by the inspector may have such denial reviewed by the planning commission upon filing with the inspector a written request therefor within ten (10) days after notice of such denial. Such written request shall specify with reasonable particularity the grounds on which the applicant relies for a reversal of the inspector's denial of the permit. The planning commission is authorized and directed from time to time to establish, promulgate, alter and amend administrative rules and regulations providing the procedure for the conduct upon the hearing upon such review. 
(Code 1965, § 36-6) 
Sec. 37-46. - Varying from approved plans and specifications prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to do any work in and about the construction, alteration, repair, improvement or enlargement of any mobile home park or any structure thereon for which a permit is required, which varies in any substantial particular from the approved plans and specifications submitted with the application for such permit and which were approved and on which the permit issued is or was based. 
(Code 1965, § 36-8) 
Secs. 37-47-37-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SITE, AREA AND AMENITY REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 37-51. - Site requirements generally. 
    It is unlawful to establish, build or construct any mobile home park in the city except on a well-drained site so located that drainage therefrom will not endanger any municipal culinary or domestic water supply. It is unlawful to establish, construct or build any mobile home park except in an area free from marshes, swamps and other potential breeding places for insects or rodents. 
(Code 1965, § 36-9) 
Editor's note- The city advises that mobile home parks are zoned R-3, but a special exception approved by both the board of adjustment and the planning commission is required in order to establish, build or construct any new mobile home parks. 
Sec. 37-52. - Size of site. 
    It is unlawful to establish, build or construct any mobile home park unless the same is large enough to accommodate: 
(1)  A designated number of mobile home spaces of the minimum size prescribed in this article; 
(2)  Necessary service streets, roadways and walkways; 
(3)  Parking spaces for motor vehicles as required by this article; and, 
(4)  Service areas and playgrounds as required by this article. 
(Code 1965, § 36-10) 
Sec. 37-53. - Minimum area, etc., for mobile home spaces. 
    Mobile home spaces shall meet the following minimum standards: 
(1)  Each dependent mobile home space shall contain a minimum of one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet and shall be at least thirty (30) feet wide. 
(2)  Each independent mobile home space shall contain a minimum of three thousand two hundred (3,200) square feet and shall be at least forty (40) feet wide. 
(3)  All mobile home spaces shall abut on a roadway or other clear area with unobstructed access to a public street and shall be of such size and arrangement as to permit parking of mobile homes therein in such manner that there shall be a minimum of fifteen (15) feet between mobile homes and a minimum of ten (10) feet from the exterior boundary of the mobile home park. The boundary of each mobile home space shall be clearly and permanently marked. 
(4)  The mobile home park shall include in its gross area not less than one-eighteenth of an acre for each dependent mobile home space and not less than one-eleventh of an acre for each independent mobile home space. 
(Code 1965, § 36-11) 
Sec. 37-54. - Access roads. 
    Access roads shall be provided to each mobile home space suitably graded, hard surfaced and properly drained. Each access road shall be so designed and constructed by means of loops or access to public streets at both ends as to be continuous so that vehicles may enter and leave without making a U-turn. Each such road shall connect with a public street. Each such road shall have a minimum width of twenty (20) feet adapted to vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1965, § 36-12) 
Sec. 37-55. - Parking areas. 
    In each mobile home park areas and facilities shall be provided for the parking of motor vehicles off the public streets and the mobile home park roadways. Such parking areas shall be so designed and constructed that they will reasonably accommodate at one time a number of vehicles not less than one hundred fifty (150) percent of the number of mobile home spaces provided in the mobile home park. 
(Code 1965, § 36-13) 
Sec. 37-56. - Playground areas. 
    Each mobile home park shall provide for the common use of the occupants of mobile home spaces therein one or more playground areas. No other use may be made of any area designated as a playground. Such playgrounds shall be protected from the public streets, from the mobile home park roadways and from parking areas by a suitable fence or wall not less than four (4) feet high. A minimum of one hundred fifty (150) square feet of playground per mobile home space shall be made available in one (1) or more places in the mobile home park. 
(Code 1965, § 36-14) 
Sec. 37-57. - Patios. 
    Each mobile home space shall be provided with a patio convenient to the entrance to the mobile home space it is designed to accommodate. Such patio shall have a minimum area of one hundred eighty (180) square feet and shall be surfaced with a rigid impervious pavement meeting the minimum standards and specifications prescribed for the installation of sidewalks by the city engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 36-15) 
Sec. 37-58. - Storage spaces. 
    Each mobile home park shall provide not less than ninety-six (96) cubic feet of substantially enclosed storage space in each mobile home space in the park. Such storage accommodations shall be so designed that all of the storage accommodations in a mobile home park shall present a uniform appearance, that they can be closed and locked, and each storage accommodation shall be made available for reasonably convenient access from the mobile home space it is intended to serve. 
(Code 1965, § 36-16) 
Secs. 37-59-37-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - UTILITY AND SANITARY SERVICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Garbage, Ch. 25; water and sewers, Ch. 53.5. 

Sec. 37-71. - Service buildings-Generally. 
    Each mobile home park shall be provided with one (1) or more service buildings and facilities meeting the minimum standards and requirements set out in sections 37-72 and 37-73. 
(Code 1965, § 36-17) 
Sec. 37-72. - Same-Minimum standards and facilities. 
    Service buildings required by this article shall comply with the following minimum standards and provide the following minimum facilities: 
(1)  Location. Each service building shall be located at least fifteen (15) feet from any mobile home space. 
(2)  Construction generally; lighting. Each such building shall be of permanent construction; the interior thereof and the exterior thereof shall be brightly lighted at all times. 
(3)  Construction materials. It shall be constructed of moisture resistant material which will permit frequent washings and cleaning and disinfecting as necessary without excessive deterioration. 
(4)  Toilet, lavatory and shower facilities. It shall provide not less than one (1) toilet for females, one (1) toilet for males, and one (1) lavatory and shower for each sex for each ten (10) dependent mobile home spaces in the park. In any event, it shall provide not less than two (2) toilets for females, one (1) toilet and one (1) urinal for males, and one (1) lavatory and shower for each sex. 
(5)  Laundry and clothes drying facilities. It shall provide not less than one (1) laundry tray and one (1) slop water closet with independent entrance, and not less than fifty (50) square feet of outside clothes drying space per mobile home space, with adequate poles and lines adjacent to the service building. Other clothes drying facilities of adequate capacity may be provided in the service building in lieu of outside drying space. 
(6)  Heating and hot water facilities. Service buildings shall have adequate heating facilities to maintain a temperature of seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit during cold weather and to supply a minimum of three (3) gallons of hot water per hour per trailer coach space during the time of peak demands. 
(7)  Ventilation and screening. All rooms therein shall be well ventilated and all openings shall be effectively screened. 
(Code 1965, § 36-18) 
Sec. 37-73. - Same-Locations. 
    At least one (1) service building providing minimum facilities as specified in section 37-72 shall be located within two hundred (200) feet of every dependent mobile home space. 
(Code 1965, § 36-19) 
Sec. 37-74. - Water supply-Generally. 
    There shall be provided in each mobile home park an accessible, adequate, safe and potable supply of water capable of furnishing a minimum of one hundred twenty-five (125) gallons of water per day per mobile home space. Where a public water supply of such quality is available, that source shall be used exclusively. No independent water supplies shall be developed or used unless, upon petition by the applicant, the county health department shall after investigation and hearing find and determine that the proposed source and the works for the production, transmission and distribution of such supply will produce water meeting minimum standards prescribed from time to time by the United States Public Health Service and shall grant special permission for the development and use of such independent water supply. 
(Code 1965, § 36-20) 
Sec. 37-75. - Same-Distribution system. 
    The water distribution system within the mobile home park shall comply with all minimum standards and specifications for the installation of public water distribution systems as established under the provisions of the city plumbing code. 
(Code 1965, § 36-21) 
Sec. 37-76. - Same-Service standards. 
    Individual water service shall be provided for all service buildings and all mobile home spaces. The mobile home park water system shall provide running water service of a pressure of not less than twenty (20) pounds per square inch at all outlets. Facilities and fittings for water service for direct use by mobile homes shall be so located and constructed that they will not be damaged in the movement of the mobile homes and other motor vehicles having access to the mobile home park. 
(Code 1965, § 36-22) 
Sec. 37-77. - Same-Cross connections. 
    It is unlawful for any person to make any connection between a water distribution system of a mobile home park and any nonpotable, questionable or unapproved water supply. 
(Code 1965, § 36-23) 
Sec. 37-78. - Same-Drinking fountains. 
    At least one (1) drinking fountain for each play area and one (1) drinking fountain in the immediate vicinity of each service building shall be provided for public use. 
(Code 1965, § 36-24) 
Sec. 37-79. - Sewage disposal-Generally. 
    Every mobile home park shall be provided with an adequate and suitable sewage collection system. Such sewage collection system shall meet the minimum standards and specifications provided for sewage collection systems as established under the city plumbing code. The sewage collection system shall discharge into a public sewer where one is available. 
(Code 1965, § 36-25) 
Sec. 37-80. - Same-Sewage treatment. 
    In the event no public sewer is available to which the mobile home park sewage collection system can be connected, a sewage treatment plant, or septic tank and drainfield, shall be provided. The design of such sewage treatment plant or other facility shall be based on the ultimate maximum capacity of the mobile home park. Sewage treatment plant effluents shall not be discharged into any waters of the state except with the prior approval of the appropriate state authority and of the county department of health. The sewage treatment plant or other sewage disposal facility shall be located in such a place that it will not create a nuisance or health hazard to the park or to the owners or occupants of any adjacent property. Plans and specifications for the sewage treatment plant or other sewage disposal facility shall be submitted to the inspector and reviewed and found to be adequate before any construction is begun. 
(Code 1965, § 36-26) 
Sec. 37-81. - Same-Individual connections. 
    Each mobile home space shall be provided with a sewer connection of at least three-inch pipe. The connection shall have suitable fittings so that a watertight connection can be made between the mobile home drain and the sewer connection. Each individual connection shall be so constructed that it can be closed when not linked to a mobile home drain and shall be trapped in such a manner as to maintain it in an odorfree condition. 
(Code 1965, § 36-27) 
Sec. 37-82. - Garbage and refuse containers and racks. 
    Tightly covered garbage containers shall be provided within a reasonable distance from all mobile home spaces. Racks or holders shall be provided for all garbage and other refuse containers. Such container racks or holders shall be so designed and constructed as to prevent containers from being tipped and to minimize spillage and container deterioration and to facilitate cleaning around them and such containers, racks or holders shall be so constructed as to be of a uniform appearance within the park. 
(Code 1965, § 36-28) 
Sec. 37-83. - Electrical service-Generally. 
    Standard electrical service shall be provided for each mobile home space and the outlets for such service shall be weatherproofed. 
(Code 1965, § 36-29) 
Sec. 37-84. - Same-Power lines. 
    In mobile home parks, no electrical power line shall be permitted to lie on the ground. No such power line shall be suspended less than eighteen (18) feet above the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1965, § 36-30) 
Sec. 37-85. - Fire protection-Fire hydrants, etc. 
    Where a public water system is available to the mobile home park, standard fire hydrants and fire service lines shall be installed in such manner that a fire hydrant shall be located within four hundred (400) feet of each mobile home space. 
(Code 1965, § 36-31) 
Sec. 37-86. - Same-Telephone facilities. 
    In every mobile home park suitable telephone facilities shall be installed and maintained in a convenient and readily accessible place prominently marked and designated and kept available for use in giving fire alarms at any time. 
(Code 1965, § 36-32) 
Chapter 38 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Police department and law enforcement, Ch. 46; duty of municipal clerk re poolrooms, § 47-2. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Establishment of municipal court. 
    There is hereby established a municipal court for the city pursuant to the provisions of Sections 12-17-94 through 12-17-114, Code of Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 1, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-2. - Jurisdiction. 
    The municipal court of the city shall have jurisdiction of all prosecutions for the breach of ordinances of the municipality within its corporate limits and police jurisdiction. This jurisdiction shall also extend to all prosecutions for violations of state misdemeanors committed within the corporate limits and police jurisdiction of the municipality where such offenses have been made offenses against the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 2, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-3. - Time and place of holding court. 
    The municipal court shall hold court at such time and place as the governing body may determine with the advice of the presiding municipal judge. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 3, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-4. - Procedure generally. 
    The procedure in the municipal court of the city shall, so far as not set out herein or otherwise declared by law, conform as nearly as practicable to that before justices of the peace in the state in analogous cases. 
(Code 1965, § 39-13) 
Sec. 38-5. - Judicial notice of ordinances. 
    The municipal court shall take judicial notice of the ordinances of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(J), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-6. - Oaths, subpoenas, etc. 
    Each municipal judge may administer oaths, compel the attendance of witnesses and compel the production of books and papers, punish any person found and adjudged to be in contempt of court by fine not exceeding fifty dollars ($50.00) and/or imprisonment not exceeding five (5) days) or the maximum punishment permitted under § 12-14-31, Code of Alabama, and shall have power coextensive with the jurisdiction of the district court to issue writs and other process, and to approve and declare bonds forfeited. The presiding municipal judge shall designate any other municipal officers who shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(I), 11-15-77; Ord. No. 01-018-2012, § 3, 7-10-12) 
Sec. 38-7. - Issuance of warrants. 
    Each municipal judge is authorized to issue arrest and search warrants upon affidavit for municipal ordinance violations returnable to the municipal court and for violations of state law returnable to any state court. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 9, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-8. - Execution of warrants. 
    The sheriff of the county and all law enforcement officers of the municipality shall obey the municipal judge having legal authority in faithfully executing the warrants and processes committed to them for service according to their mandates. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(K), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-9. - Appearance and appeal bond.
