    Each municipal judge shall have the power to admit to bail any person charged with the violation of any municipal ordinance by requiring an appearance bond, with good security, to be approved by the municipal judge in an amount not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or the maximum amount permitted under § 12-14-5, Code of Alabama, and may, in his discretion, admit to bail such persons on a personal recognizance bond conditioned on the appearance of such person before him on a day named therein to answer the charges preferred against him. The presiding judge shall designate any other municipal officer or officers who shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds. Such designee of the presiding judge shall have the same powers and privileges given the municipal judge in this section. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(A), 11-15-77; Ord. No. 01-018-2012, § 4, 7-10-12) 
Sec. 38-10. - Nonjury trial. 
    All cases in municipal court shall be tried by a municipal judge without a jury. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(G), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-11. - Penalty. 
    Each municipal judge shall have the authority to punish any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance in accordance with the punishment prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991); provided, however, that no fine or sentence of imprisonment shall exceed the maximum fine or sentence provided by the city ordinance violated nor shall the fine or sentence exceed the maximum fine and sentence provided for violation of a substantially similar offense under state law. The penalty imposed on a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(B), 11-15-77; Ord. No. 01-018-2012, § 5, 7-10-12) 
Cross reference- Penalty and enforcement procedures for Code, § 1-21 et seq. 
Sec. 38-12. - Forfeiture of bond upon conviction. 
    Upon conviction, the court may, upon a showing of inability to make immediate payment of fines and costs, accept defendant's bond with or without surety and with waiver of exemptions as to personalty payable within ninety (90) days, upon nonpayment of which execution may issue as upon judgments in state courts. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(E), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-13. - Working out judgment. 
    Each municipal judge in his judgment may provide that if a fine and costs are not paid within the time prescribed, the defendant, unless indigent, shall work out the amount of the judgment under the direction of the municipal authority allowing not less than ten dollars ($10.00) for each day's service. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(C), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-14. - Court costs. 
    Upon each conviction in municipal court for a violation of any ordinance of the city, there shall be taxed against the defendant as court costs the sum of ten dollars ($10.00), and there shall also be taxed as costs the additional costs and fees imposed by the statutes of the state, and the latter such costs and fees shall be remitted pursuant to the statutes. All costs taxed for the city, as hereinabove provided, shall be paid into the city treasury. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(D), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-15. - Judge's authority to continue cases, remit fines, etc. 
    Each municipal judge shall have the authority to continue the case from time to time to permit the fine and costs to be paid, remit fines, costs and fees, impose intermittent sentences, establish work release programs, require attendance of educational, corrective or rehabilitative programs, suspend driving privileges for such times and under such conditions as provided by law and order hearings to determine the competency of the defendant to stand trial; provided further, that the judge may enter an order authorizing the defendant to drive under the conditions set forth in the order. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(F), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-16. - Probation. 
    Each municipal judge may suspend execution of sentence and place a defendant on probation for varying periods of time, not to exceed two (2) years, under the procedures and conditions set out in Section 12-14-13, Code of Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(H), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-17. - Corporations-Affidavit to be docketed; notice to corporation. 
    When an affidavit is filed in the municipal court against a corporation doing business in the city or within its police jurisdiction, such affidavit shall be forthwith docketed in the court, and the clerk of the court, or the judge thereof, shall issue a notice thereof to the defendant corporation, accompanied by a certified copy of the affidavit. Such notice and copy may be served upon any officer or agent of the defendant corporation authorized by the laws of the state to receive service of summons or other civil process issuing against such corporation and upon the return of the same showing proper service, the cause shall stand for trial before the judge of the municipal court. 
(Code 1965, § 39-14) 
Sec. 38-18. - Same-Failure to appear. 
    If a defendant corporation fails to appear and plead to the affidavit filed against it, the judge of the municipal court shall cause a plea of not guilty to be entered for it and the trial shall proceed as if the corporation had appeared and pleaded not guilty but in such case proof must be made to the judge of the municipal court that the person upon whom the notice and copy of the affidavit was served, as provided in section 38-17, was an officer or agent of the corporation authorized by law to receive such service. 
(Code 1965, § 39-15) 
Sec. 38-19. - Same-Judgment; execution. 
    Upon the conviction of a corporation in the municipal court, judgment shall be rendered against it for the fine imposed, together with the costs of the prosecution, and execution thereon shall forthwith issue against the property of the corporation. Other executions may issue thereon until such judgment is satisfied. In case of appeal from such judgment, the execution thereof may be superseded by giving a supersedeas bond as in civil cases. 
(Code 1965, § 39-16) 
Sec. 38-20. - Remission of fines; commutation or reduction of sentence. 
(a)  The mayor may remit fines and such costs as payable to the municipality and commute sentences imposed by municipal judges of the court to which an appeal was taken for violations of municipal ordinances, and may grant pardons, after conviction, for violation of such ordinances; and he shall report his action to the governing body of the city at the first regular meeting thereof in the succeeding month with his reasons therefor in writing. 
(b)  The judge of the municipal court may reduce or remit any fine or sentence or may pardon any person convicted of violating any provision of this Code or other city ordinance, upon proper cause shown to him. 
(Code 1965, § 39-5; Ord. No. 39-110, § 7, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-21. - Control of courtroom. 
    The city courtroom shall be under the control and direction of the judge of the municipal court of city. 
(Code 1965, § 39-6) 
Sec. 38-22. - Reports. 
(a)  Each municipal judge shall report on the proceedings of the municipal court and of his proceedings as municipal judge as required by law or rule. 
(b)  The municipal judges shall be required to make a report to the governing body of the city on the operation of the municipal court every month. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, §§ 12, 13, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-23. - Additional court costs and fees. 
(a)  The Mobile Municipal Court, in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 584, which became effective May 4, 1994, is hereby authorized to levy additional court costs and fees on each case resulting in a conviction and adjudicated on or after the effective date of this ordinance in the Mobile Municipal Court up to an amount not to exceed those fees levied by the District Court of Mobile County, Alabama. Such additional court costs which may have been levied against any case by the Mobile Municipal Court shall not be waived unless all other costs associated with such case are waived. 
(b)  A special municipal fund designated as the "corrections fund" shall be established, and all such additional costs and fees collected by the Mobile Municipal Court, as provided by Act. No. 584, shall be paid into said special municipal fund, and used solely for the operation and maintenance of the Municipal Court Complex, the Mobile Metro Jail, or any other correctional and/or detention facilities, including juvenile detention facilities, as deemed appropriate by the city and in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 584. 
(c)  Additional funds, space and property sufficient to maintain and equip the Municipal Court Complex, the Mobile Metro Jail or any other correctional and/or detention facilities, including juvenile facilities, may be allocated by the governing body as deemed necessary or appropriate. The city may also receive gifts, grants and property for use by the Municipal Court Complex, the Metro Jail or any other correctional and/or detention facilities, including juvenile facilities, and may contract for services related to the construction, equipment and maintenance of such facilities. 
(d)  The city may, at its discretion, enter into a contract with other municipal governing bodies to provide for the implementatin of Act No. 584, for the construction, operation and maintenance of such joint municipal correctional and/or detention facilities, including juvenile facilities, or Municipal Court Complex, and may adopt such joint rules and regulations as may be applicable to the jurisidiction of each entity relative to correctional and/or detention facilities, including juvenile facilities, or court facilities. 
(f)  (1)  The municipal court, in accordance with the provisions of Act No. 584 and Ord. No. 38-088, which became effective May 4, 1994 and November 22, 1994 respectively, is hereby authorized to levy a warrant fee on all municipal court cases where an alias or capias warrant is issued, up to an amount not to exceed those charges levied by the district court of the county. 
(2)  All such additional warrant fees collected by the municipal court shall be paid into the corrections fund established by Act No. 584 (subsection (b) hereinabove) with the exception of two dollars ($2.00) now being collected for the DNA database fund. 
(Ord. No. 38-088, §§ 1-4, 11-22-94; Ord. No. 38-052, §§ 1, 2, 10-24-00) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 38-088, adopted November 22, 1994 did not specifically amend this Code, hence, inclusion of §§ 1-4 as § 38-23 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 38-24. - Property held by municipal court. 
    Property held by the municipal court is presumed abandoned and shall be deposited into the city general funds, if it is unclaimed by the apparent owner, one year after the property becomes distributable. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2009, 4-14-09) 
Secs. 38-25-38-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - JUDGES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, adopted May 23, 2006, amended the Code by repealing former art. II, §§ 38-41-38-46 and 38-48, and adding a new art. II, §§ 38-41-38-51. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 39-110, adopted November 15, 1977; and Ord. No. 39-016, adopted February 8, 1978. 

Sec. 38-41. - Number; term. 
    The municipal court shall consist of five (5) judges: Three (3) full time judges, and two (2) part-time judges. The full-time and part-time judges of the municipal court shall be appointed by the city council by a vote of the majority of its members. The term of office of each full-time municipal judge shall be for a term of four (4) years. The term of office of each part-time municipal judge shall be for a term of two (2) years. The term of either full-time or part-time municipal judges shall continue until a successor has been appointed and qualified. The municipal judges shall be eligible for reappointment upon the expiration of their terms. One (1) of the part-time judges shall be assigned to hold dockets at the Metro Jail. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06; Ord. No. 38-060-2008 § 1, 10-7-2008; Ord. No. 38-047-2015 , § 1, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 38-42. - Qualification; other employment. 
    Each municipal judge must be licensed to practice law in the state, and must be a qualified elector of the state. No judge shall be otherwise employed in any capacity by the city during his term of office. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-43. - Vacancy. 
    The office of a municipal judge shall be vacant if he or she dies, resigns, or is removed; and vacancies shall be filled by the city council in the same manner as original appointments are made. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-44. - Oath. 
    Each municipal judge shall, before assuming office, take and sign the oath provided by the constitution of the state, and a copy thereof shall be filed in the office of the secretary of state, the administrative director of courts, and the city clerk; provided, however, that failure to file as required by this section shall not render invalid any act, order, or judgment of said judge. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-45. - Presiding judge. 
(a)  One of the full-time municipal judges shall serve as presiding judge, who shall have primary responsibility for the administration of the municipal court, to include such duties as the scheduling of cases and such additional duties as may from time to time be provided by ordinance. The mayor shall designate which of the full-time judges shall serve as presiding judge. The presiding judge shall be entitled to receive such additional compensation as provided by ordinance. 
(b)  The presiding judge shall be the chief judicial officer of the municipal court and shall have the power and duty to supervise and direct the judicial and administrative functions of the court. It shall be the obligation of the presiding judge to see that the court docket is kept as current as is reasonably possible; and to such end the presiding judge shall establish a court calendar of cases and shall have the authority to set dockets and assign cases for trial and disposition before such municipal judges as shall be appointed. The presiding judge shall also prescribe and publish reasonable rules and regulations for the dispatch of the business of the court. 
(c)  The presiding judge, in order to maintain a current docket, shall have the authority to hold, or direct to be held, such sessions of court as shall be necessary. All sessions of court shall be presided over by the presiding judge or by a judge assigned by the presiding judge. 
(d)  The presiding judge shall designate any other municipal officers who shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds. 
(e)  The presiding judge shall make quarterly reports to the city council and mayor on the operation of the municipal court. The quarterly report shall include, at a minimum, information stating the number of new cases filed during the quarter, the number of cases still pending at the end of the quarter, the number of cases resolved or disposed of during the quarter, the number of cases that were appealed to the circuit court during the quarter, the presiding judge's recommendations for improving access to justice and the operations of the court, and any other information or statistics that the presiding judge determines to be pertinent. The information concerning the number of cases filed, pending, resolved or disposed of, and appealed shall be arranged to separately reflect the number of traffic offenses initiated by issuance of a uniform traffic ticket and complaint, the number of non-traffic offenses initiated by issuance of a uniform non-traffic citation and complaint, the number of offenses initiated by arrest, and any other categorization of offenses as the presiding judge shall deem necessary to fully and accurately report on the operations of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06; Ord. No. 38-047-2015 , § 2, 4-28-15; Ord. No. 38-074-2015 , § 1, 8-11-15) 
Sec. 38-46. - Disqualification on specific cases. 
    Each municipal judge shall be subject to all grounds of disqualification from hearing specific cases that are applicable to circuit court judges. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-47. - Full-time municipal judges not to engage in the practice of law. 
    No full-time municipal judge shall, during his or her continuance in office, engage in the practice of law or receive any remuneration for judicial service, except the salary and allowances authorized by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-48. - Acting municipal judge. 
    In the event of the absence from the city, death, disability or disqualification of a municipal judge, for any reason, the mayor shall have the authority to designate persons, licensed to practice law in the state and who are qualified electors of the state, not otherwise employed in any capacity by the city, to serve as acting municipal judges with all the power and authority of a duly appointed municipal judge. No such acting judge may serve for more than thirty (30) successive days or a total of sixty (60) days in any calendar year; provided, that when the duly appointed municipal judge is disqualified pursuant to the constitution, the time of service limitations for acting judges shall not apply during such disqualification. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-49. - Compensation. 
    The salary of the municipal judges shall be fixed by resolution of the council. This salary shall not be diminished during the judges' term of office. Any general increase in the compensation of all or substantially all city employees shall be applied proportionately to the salary of the municipal judges. The council may provide for the retirement of municipal judges, with such conditions, retirement benefits and pensions for them and their dependents as the council may prescribe by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-50. - Reports. 
    The presiding judge of the municipal court shall report on the proceedings of the municipal court as required by law or rule. 
    The presiding judge shall make a quarterly report to the city council on the operation of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06) 
Sec. 38-51. - Time and place of holding court. 
    The full-time municipal judges shall work five (5) days per week, Monday through Friday, from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., at Mobile Government Plaza or at such other places as may be convenient or necessary for the transaction of official court business. 
    The part-time judges shall preside over such dockets as may be assigned by the presiding judge, including dockets held at the county metro jail and at such other places as may be convenient or necessary for the transaction of official court business. One (1) of the part-time judges shall be assigned to hold dockets at the county metro jail. Part-time judges shall be assigned to work three (3) half-day dockets per week. 
(Ord. No. 38-018-2006, § 1, 5-23-06; Ord. No. 38-060-2008 § 2, 10-7-2008; Ord. No. 38-062-2008 § 1, 10-14-2008) 
Secs. 38-52-38-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OTHER PERSONNEL 

Sec. 38-61. - Magistrates. 
    The presiding municipal judge shall take steps to have a magistrate appointed for the city pursuant to Rule 18 of the Alabama Rules of Judicial Administration. The powers of the magistrate shall be limited to: 
(1)  Issuance of arrest warrants; 
(2)  Granting of bail in minor misdemeanor prosecutions; 
(3)  Receiving of pleas of guilty in minor misdemeanors where a schedule of fines has been prescribed by law or rule; 
(4)  Accountability to the municipal court for all uniform traffic tickets and complaints, moneys received and records of offenses; and 
(5)  Such other authority as may be granted by law. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 10, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-62. - Bailiff. 
    The presiding municipal judge may appoint a person to serve as bailiff of the municipal court and if such an appointment is made, the municipal governing body shall set the compensation of such bailiff. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 6(F), 11-15-77; Ord. No. 39-016, 2-8-78) 
Sec. 38-63. - Clerk and assistant clerks-Generally. 
    The mayor may appoint a person other than the judge of the municipal court to act as clerk of the municipal court, who shall keep the docket and perform all other necessary clerical duties connected with the municipal court, but the judge of the municipal court shall take all affidavits and sign all process, civil or criminal. The mayor may also appoint as many assistant clerks as may be necessary to assist the clerk of the municipal court in the performance of his duties, but in no case shall the mayor appoint a member of the police department to act as clerk or as assistant clerk of the municipal court. 
(Code 1965, § 39-7) 
Sec. 38-64. - Same-Bonds. 
    The clerk and assistant clerks of the municipal court and of the traffic violations bureau of the city shall be bonded in an amount not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and such other amounts to be determined by the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 39-8) 
Sec. 38-65. - Appointment of assistant judges, secretary to judge, etc. 
    The mayor may appoint one (1) or more persons to act as secretary to the judge of the municipal court, any assistant judges and the prosecutor or prosecutors of the municipal court. 
(Code 1965, § 39-10) 
Sec. 38-66. - Full time prosecutor-Appointment; duties. 
    The mayor may appoint a full time attorney to serve as prosecutor in the municipal court of the city. The person so appointed shall represent the city in all cases involving a violation of a provision of this Code or other city ordinance which may appear before the municipal court of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 39-11) 
Sec. 38-67. - Same-Official title. 
    The official title of the person performing the duties of prosecutor in the municipal court shall be prosecutor for the municipal court of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 39-12) 
Secs. 38-68-38-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROCEDURES 

Sec. 38-71. - Where appeals lie. 
    All appeals from judgments of the municipal court shall be to the circuit court of the circuit in which the violation occurred for trial de novo. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(A), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-72. - Invalid ordinance. 
    The municipality may appeal within sixty (60) days without bond from a judgment of the municipal court holding a municipal ordinance invalid. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(B), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-73. - Appeal bond. 
    A defendant may appeal in any case within fourteen (14) days from the entry of judgment by filing notice of appeal and giving bond with or without surety approved by the court or the clerk in an amount not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and costs, as fixed by the court, conditioned upon the defendant's appearance before the circuit court. The municipal court may waive appearance bond upon satisfactory showing that the defendant is indigent or otherwise unable to provide a surety bond. If an appeal bond is waived, a defendant sentenced to imprisonment shall not be released from custody, but may obtain release at any time by filing a bond approved by the municipal court. If the defendant is not released, the municipal court clerk shall notify the circuit clerk and the case shall be set for trial at the earliest practicable time. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(C), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-74. - Default by city. 
    When an appeal has been taken, the municipality shall file the notice and other documents in the court to which the appeal is taken within fifteen (15) days, failing which the municipality shall be deemed to have abandoned the prosecution, the defendant shall stand discharged and the bond shall be automatically terminated. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(D), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-75. - Sentence on appeal. 
    Upon trial or plea of guilty in the circuit court on appeal, the court may impose any penalty or sentence which the municipal court might have imposed. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(E), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-76. - Default by appellant. 
    Upon failure of an appellant to appear in circuit court when the case is called for trial, unless good cause for such default is shown, the court shall dismiss the appeal and enter judgment of default on the appeal bond, and may also issue a warrant for arrest of the appellant. A copy of the order shall be delivered by the circuit clerk to the clerk of the municipal court. The circuit court may on motion of defendant made within thirty (30) days of the order of dismissal, set aside the dismissal and other orders and reinstate the appeal on such terms as the court may prescribe for good cause shown by the defendant. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(F), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-77. - Arrest of defendant upon dismissal of appeal. 
    Upon receipt of notice of dismissal of an appeal, the municipal court may issue a warrant for arrest of the defendant, who may also be arrested without a warrant as an escapee. Upon arrest the defendant shall be delivered to the municipal authorities and punished in accordance with the judgment of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(G), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-78. - Remand of defendant. 
    If a judgment is entered against a defendant upon appeal, the circuit court shall remand the defendant to the municipal authorities for punishment in accordance with the judgment of the circuit court, unless, when the judgment is for fine and costs only, the judgment is paid or a judgment is conferred therefor in favor of the municipality with sureties or as otherwise provided for convictions under state law. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(H), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-79. - Disposition of fines and costs. 
    Upon receipt of payment of fines and costs upon appeals, the clerk of the circuit court shall within thirty (30) days pay ninety (90) percent of such fines and forfeitures, and ten (10) percent of the costs, to the treasurer of the municipality. The circuit clerk shall be liable on his bond for such fines and costs plus a penalty of five (5) percent per month for default in such payments. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(I), 11-15-77) 
Sec. 38-80. - Appeal to criminal court. 
    From the judgment of the circuit court, the municipality, in a case holding invalid an ordinance, or the defendant in any case, may appeal to the court of criminal appeals in like manner as in cases of appeals for convictions of violation of the criminal laws of the state. If the appeal is taken by the municipality, it shall not be required to give surety for the cost of the appeal. When taken by the defendant, he may give bail with sufficient sureties, conditioned that he will appear and abide by the judgment of the appellate court, and failing to give bail he must be committed to the municipal jail; but he may give such bail at any time pending the appeal. When an appeal is taken by the defendant and bail is given pending the appeal, and the judgment of conviction is affirmed or the appeal is dismissed, the defendant is bound by the undertaking of bail to surrender himself to the municipal authorities within fifteen (15) days from the date of such affirmance or dismissal, and if he shall fail to do so, the clerk of the circuit court from which the appeal is taken, upon motion of the municipality, must endorse the bail bond forfeited, and a writ or writs of arrest must be issued by the clerk to the sheriff. Upon arrest the defendant shall be delivered to the municipal authorities and the sentence must without delay be carried out as if no appeal has been taken. If bail is forfeited as herein provided, a conditional judgment must be rendered by the court in favor of the municipality and the same proceedings had thereon for the municipality as is authorized by law to be had in the name of the state in state cases. 
(Ord. No. 39-110, § 8(J), 11-15-77) 
Chapter 39 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- City declared bird sanctuary, § 7-1; offenses in cemeteries, §§ 12-13-12-16; offenses regarding library, §§ 15-53-15-55; gambling, Ch. 24; poolrooms, Ch. 47; offenses regarding the posting of house numbers, § 57-211 et seq.; weapons, Ch. 62. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 39-1. - State law misdemeanors, violations, etc. 
(a)  Any person or corporation committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city, or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a misdemeanor shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(b)  Any person or corporation committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, which is declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted, to be a violation shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(c)  Any person or corporation committing within the corporate limits of the city or within the police jurisdiction thereof, an offense as defined by section 13A-1-2 of the Alabama Criminal Code, which offense is not declared by a law or laws of the state now existing or hereafter enacted to be a felony, misdemeanor or violation, shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(d)  Any person found to be in violation of subsection (a), (b) or (c) shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). Any corporation found to be in violation of subsection (a), (b) or (c) shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed the limit prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(e)  Any person found to be in violation of section 32-5A-191, Code of Alabama, 1975, as amended, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and/or may be imprisoned or sentenced to hard labor for not more than one (1) year. 
(f)  Excepted from the provisions of this section are the provisions of Code of Alabama, sections 36-19-1 through 36-19-29, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 41-136, §§ 1-4, 12-18-79; Ord. No. 41-085, 9-20-83; Ord. No. 41-105, §§ 1-5, 11-8-83) 
Sec. 39-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 59-027-2010, § 1-108, adopted September 21, 2010, amended the Code by repealing former § 39-2. Former § 39-2 pertained to begging, and derived from the Code of 1965, § 41-66.16. 
Sec. 39-3. - Wandering abroad and sleeping in, etc., vacant barns, sheds, automobiles, railroad cars, vacant lots, etc. 
    Any person wandering abroad and occupying, lodging or sleeping in any vacant or unoccupied barn, garage, shed, shop or other building or structure, or in any automobile, truck, railroad car or other vehicle without owning the same or without permission of the owner or person entitled to the possession of the same, or sleeping in any vacant lot during the hours of darkness and not giving a satisfactory account of himself, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-66.15) 
Sec. 39-4. - Possession of burglary tools, etc. 
    Any person upon whose person or in whose possession shall be found any instrument, tool or other implement for picking locks or pockets, or any implement that is usually employed or that reasonably may be inferred to have been designed to be employed in the commission of any felony, misdemeanor or the violation of any ordinance, and who shall fail to account satisfactorily for the possession of the same, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-66.14) 
Sec. 39-5. - Keeping place where lost or stolen property is concealed. 
    Any person who keeps a place where lost or stolen property is concealed shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-66.21) 
Sec. 39-6. - Engaging in, etc., fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain money, etc. 
    Any person who shall engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain money or other valuable thing from others, or any person who aids or assists such trick, device or scheme, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-66.20) 
Sec. 39-7. - Applicability of section 39-90 to persons idle because of strikes or lockouts. 
    The provisions of section 39-90 shall not apply to persons who are idle because of strikes or lockouts. 
(Code 1965, § 41-68) 
Sec. 39-8. - Changing price tags. 
    A person shall be guilty of an offense against the city if he or she changes or alters or removes or attempts to change or alter or remove the price tag attached to a piece of merchandise or goods for sale in any retail or wholesale establishment with the intent of defrauding such establishment. 
(Ord. No. 41-033, § 1, 4-26-77) 
Sec. 39-9. - Unauthorized cable connections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to make, attempt to make or cause to be made an unauthorized connection to any cable television service or to any line or equipment conducting or regulating such service, or willfully to tamper with any line or instrument conducting such service, whether audio or video, with the intent to avoid or assist another in avoiding the payment of the lawful charge price or toll in whole or in part for such service. 
(b)  The adult occupant or occupants of premises in which a television set is located which has an unauthorized connection to any cable television service or to any line or equipment conducting or regulating such service shall be presumed to have made, or have had made, the unauthorized connection, which is made an unlawful act by subsection (a), above. 
(Ord. No. 41-064, §§ 1, 2, 7-1-80) 
Sec. 39-10. - Telephone calls using threatening, vulgar, etc., language. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to telephone any other person within the city or the police jurisdiction thereof for the purpose of harassment by the use of threatening, vulgar, indecent, obscene or immoral language. 
(Code 1965, § 41-63) 
Sec. 39-11. - Interference with radio, etc., reception. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to cause or permit any reasonably preventable electrical interference with radio or television reception in the city or its police jurisdiction through or by the operation of any machine, device, apparatus or instrument of any kind whatsoever located in the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(b)  Reasonably preventable electrical interference defined. Electrical interference with radio or television reception, caused by any machine, device, apparatus or instrument, shall be deemed reasonably preventable when such interference can be eliminated or materially minimized by equipping, at reasonable expense, such machine or device, or instrument with a device designed for the purpose of eliminating or minimizing electrical interference with radio or television reception and also when such electrical interference is otherwise reasonably preventable. 
(c)  Transmitting, broadcasting or receiving instrument, etc. Subsection (a) shall not be held or construed to embrace or cover the regulation of any transmitting, broadcasting or receiving instrument, apparatus or device used or useful in interstate commerce, the operation of which instrument, apparatus or device is licensed or authorized by or under the provisions of an act of the congress of the United States. 
(Code 1965, §§ 41-24-41-26) 
Sec. 39-12. - Use of window type exhaust fans restricted. 
    It is hereby declared to be a nuisance and unlawful and an offense against the city for the owner or lessee or occupant of any building within the city to place or cause to be placed or allow a window fan of the exhaust type to be operated in any window which is twelve (12) feet or closer to another building, unless such fan is provided with a deflector, or other device, to prevent the blowing of air against such other building. 
(Code 1965, § 41-7) 
Sec. 39-13. - Pedestrians, bicycles, etc., prohibited on certain interstate highways. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for pedestrians to be upon, or for any person to operate a bicycle, a nonmotorized vehicle or a motor driven cycle of less than ten (10) horsepower, on any part of Interstate Highway 10 and Interstate Highway 65, including the entrance roads thereto, at any place within the city and its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 41-26.1) 
Sec. 39-14. - Bow and arrow regulations. 
(a)  Prohibition. No person shall shoot or discharge in or upon any street, alley, public grounds or parks within the City of Mobile, any bow, spring gun or other similar device which is calculated or intended to propel or project an arrow or other projectile, nor in or upon any private grounds or building where the projectile propelled or discharged by the use of such bow or similar device endangers the life, limb or property of another, or will traverse any part of any street, alley, public grounds or parks; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prevent the shooting with or discharging of bows or implements used in the practice of archery or implements for propelling arrows in or upon such properly supervised public areas as may set aside and designated for that purpose by proper authority having jurisdiction and control over such public areas, or in or upon properly supervised private archery ranges constructed and maintained in such a manner as not to endanger life, limb or property, or to any shooting galleries using air rifles, when shooting galleries are constructed and maintained so as not to endanger life, limb or property. 
(b)  Confiscation. Any person violating the provisions of this section may have the bow and arrow confiscated by the police department of the City of Mobile regardless of whether or not a penalty or fine is imposed. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 39-054, §§ 1-3, 8-17-93; Ord. No. 39-060, §§ 1-3, 9-7-93) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 39-054, adopted August 17, 1993, as amended by Ord. No. 39-060, adopted September 7, 1993 did not specifically amend this Code, hence, inclusion of §§ 1-3 as § 39-14 was at this discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 39-15. - "Spray string," "snap pops," or similar matter or substances thereto prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to have in his/her possession, keep, store, use, manufacture, sell, offer for sale, give away or handle any "spray string," "snap pops," or other matter or substances similar thereto, within the city within its police jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 39-002, § 1, 1-4-94) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 39-002, adopted January 4, 1994, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 1 as § 39-15 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 39-16. - Laser lights, laser pointers or similar matter prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, a laser light or laser pointer shall be defined as any device that emits light amplified by stimulated emission of radiation that is visible to the human eye. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally, knowingly, or recklessly to direct the beam of a laser pointer at another person or animal while the laser pointer is emitting a laser beam under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The laser beam directly or indirectly causes bodily injury to the person or animal; 
(2)  The person at whom the laser beam is directed is a law enforcement officer acting in his official capacity or in uniform; 
(3)  The laser beam causes the other person to suffer intimidation, annoyance or alarm; 
(4)  The laser beam has the potential to cause any animal to become agitated, excited, injured or uncontrollable. 
(Ord. No. 39-015, § 1, 2-10-04) 
Sec. 39-17. - Unlawful to use or possess with intent to use, or to deliver or sell, drug paraphernalia. 
(a)  Definition of drug paraphernalia. As used in this section, the term "drug paraphernalia" means all equipment, products, and materials of any kind which are used, intended for use, or designed for use, in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, harvesting, manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, preparing, testing, analyzing, packaging, repackaging, storing, containing, concealing, injecting, ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the controlled substances laws of this state. It includes but is not limited to: 
(1)  Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use in planting, propagating, cultivating, growing, or harvesting of any species of plant which is a controlled substance or from which a controlled substance can be derived; 
(2)  Kits used, intended for use, or designed for use in manufacturing, compounding, converting, producing, processing, or preparing controlled substances; 
(3)  Isomerization devises used, intended for use, or designed for use in increasing the potency of any species of plant which is a controlled substance; 
(4)  Testing equipment used, intended for use, or designed for use in identifying, or in analyzing the strength, effectiveness, or purity of controlled substances; 
(5)  Scales and balances used, intended for use, or designed for use in weighing or measuring controlled substances; 
(6)  Dilutants and adulterants, such as quinine hydrochloride, mannitol, mannite, dextrose and lactose, used, intended for use, or designed for use in cutting controlled substances; 
(7)  Separation gins and sifters used, intended for use, or designed for use in removing twigs and seeds from, or in otherwise cleaning or refining, marihuana; 
(8)  Blenders, bowls, containers, spoons and mixing devices used, intended for use, or designed for use in compounding controlled substances; 
(9)  Capsules, balloons, envelopes and other containers used, intended for use, or designed for use in packaging small quantities of controlled substances; 
(10)  Containers and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in storing or concealing controlled substances; 
(11)  Hypodermic syringes, needles and other objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in parenterally injecting controlled substances into the human body; 
(12)  Objects used, intended for use, or designed for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marihuana, tetrahydro cannabinols, cocaine, hashish, or hashish oil into the human body, such as: 
a.  Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls; 
b.  Water pipes; 
c.  Carburetion tubes and devices; 
d.  Smoking and carburetion masks; 
e.  Roach clips: meaning objects used to hold burning material, such as a marihuana cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand; 
f.  Miniature cocaine spoons, and cocaine vials; 
g.  Chamber pipes; 
h.  Carburetor pipes; 
i.  Electric pipes; 
j.  Air-driven pipes; 
k.  Chillums; 
l.  Bongs; 
m.  Ice pipes or chillers. 
n.  Glass tubes which are hollow, cylindrical items made of glass which are smaller than three-quarters of an inch in diameter, shorter than twelve inches in length, and which are not sealed with glass at both ends. 
(b)  Factors in determining whether object is drug paraphernalia. In determining whether an object is drug paraphernalia, a court or other authority shall consider, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, the following: 
(1)  Statements by an owner or by anyone in control of the object concerning its use; 
(2)  Prior convictions, if any, of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, under any state or federal law relating to any controlled substance; 
(3)  The proximity of the object, in time and space, to a direct violation of this section or to a controlled substance; 
(4)  The existence of any residue of controlled substances on the object; 
(5)  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the intent of an owner, or of anyone in control of the object, to deliver it to persons whom he knows intend to use the object to facilitate a violation of the controlled substances laws of this state; the innocence of any owner, or of anyone in control of the object, as to a direct violation of such laws shall not prevent a finding that the object is intended for use, or designed for use as drug paraphernalia; 
(6)  Instructions, oral or written, provided with the object concerning its use; 
(7)  Descriptive materials accompanying the object which explain or depict its use; 
(8)  National and local advertising concerning its use; 
(9)  The manner in which the object is displayed for sale; 
(10)  Whether the owner, or anyone in control of the object, is a legitimate supplier of like or related items to the community, such as a licensed distributor or dealer of tobacco products; 
(11)  Direct or circumstantial evidence of the ratio of sales of the object or objects to the total sales of the business enterprise; 
(12)  The existence and scope of legitimate uses for the object in the community; 
(13)  Expert testimony concerning its use. 
(c)  Use or possession with intent to use. It shall be unlawful for any person to use, or to possess with intent to use, or to use to inject, ingest, inhale or otherwise introduce into the human body, drug paraphernalia to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain or conceal a controlled substance in violation of the controlled substances laws of this state. 
(d)  Delivery or sale. It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver or sell, possess with intent to deliver or sell, or manufacture with intent to deliver or sell drug paraphernalia, knowing that it will be used to plant, propagate, cultivate, grow, harvest, manufacture, compound, convert, produce, process, prepare, test, analyze, pack, repack, store, contain, conceal, inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce into the human body a controlled substance in violation of the controlled substances laws of this state. 
(e)  Penalties. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, of the Mobile City Code, 1991. 
(f)  Contraband; forfeiture. All drug paraphernalia used in violation of this section shall be contraband and subject to the forfeiture laws of the city and state and Code of Alabama section 20-2-93 as amended, in particular. 
(Ord. No. 39-022-2005, §§ I-VI, 3-15-05) 
Secs. 39-18-39-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC AUTHORITY 

Sec. 39-51. - Unauthorized destruction of records. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to destroy any public records of the city without proper authority to do so. 
(Ord. No. 02-058, § 5, 6-10-75) 
Sec. 39-52. - Subdivision platting and dedication of land for streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to plat any property for subdivision into lots in the city, for sale of lots in the property so platted, or to undertake to dedicate any property in the city for use as a street or avenue in such city until the proposed platting or dedication has been first submitted to and approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 41-61) 
Sec. 39-53. - Assisting officer. 
    Every person, when called on by any police officer, shall promptly aid and assist him in the execution of his duties. 
(Code 1965, § 47-8) 
Sec. 39-54. - Failing to obey direction of order of police officer. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to fail to obey the direction or order of a member of the police department of the city while such member is acting in an official capacity in carrying out his duties. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 47-6.1) 
Sec. 39-55. - Resisting or interfering with officer; assisting in escape. 
    If any person shall resist a police officer in the discharge of his duty or shall in any way interfere with or hinder or prevent him from discharging his duty as a police officer or offer or endeavor to do or assist any person in the custody of any policeman to escape or attempt to escape from such custody or rescue or attempt to rescue any person so in custody, he shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 47-7) 
Sec. 39-56. - Assaulting or throwing missile at police officer. 
    Any person who unlawfully assaults or throws any missile against or at any police officer shall upon conviction be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 14-14) 
Sec. 39-57. - Impersonating officer, etc. 
    If any person shall falsely personate any of the members of the police department or shall maliciously or with intent to deceive use or imitate any of the signs, signals, devices, uniforms or numbers adopted and used by the city policemen, he shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 47-9) 
Cross reference- Private detective impersonating state officer, § 48-23. 
Sec. 39-58. - Sale of police badges. 
    It is hereby prohibited and made unlawful for any person to sell and deliver in the city any official police badge for use to designate the wearer thereof either as a member of the city police force or a member of the sheriff's force of the county, except to a person who is in fact a member of one or the other of such forces. 
(Code 1965, § 47-11) 
Sec. 39-59. - Following up and answering police radio calls by certain persons prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle, other than city officers and police and fire department officers in the line of duty, to follow up and answer police radio calls or in any way to interfere with police officers answering such police radio calls. 
(Code 1965, § 47-17) 
Cross reference- Intercepting police radio wrecker communications, § 63-9. 
Sec. 39-60. - Use of information received over police radio system. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, to receive or assist in receiving any radio signal broadcast over the police radio system and use the same or any information therein contained for his own benefit or for the benefit of another. 
(Code 1965, § 47-19) 
Sec. 39-61. - Tampering with, etc., fire alarm or police patrol telegraph. 
(a)  Any person who shall cut, remove or otherwise tamper with the wires of the fire alarm or police system of telegraph of the city, without permission of the city electrician, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(b)  No person shall damage in any way any fire alarm or police patrol telegraph box, wire or pole or other fixture or part in use by the city or hinder the prompt use thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 41-10) 
Sec. 39-62. - False alarms. 
(a)  Findings. Due to the proliferation of security alarm systems throughout the City of Mobile (hereinafter "the city"), numerous instances of false alarms have occurred. Each false alarm causes useless expenditure of police time, risk associated with emergency response to police officers and to the public, and an inefficient allocation of available police patrol time. The cost to the public in unnecessary responses to false alarms is substantial. At current police officer's salaries and overhead rates, each false alarm costs the city approximately $50.00. In 1998 the Mobile police department responded to 35,734 false alarms (sixteen (16) percent of calls for service). These false alarm responses cost the city approximately $1,786,700.00. 
(b)  Purpose. To establish procedures to: (1) create a permitting system whereby security alarm systems within the city and its police jurisdiction will be required to obtain an annual permit for that system, and (2) create mechanisms for recording false security alarms and provide that the city be reimbursed for the cost incurred in responding to false security alarms. 
(c)  Definitions. 
(1)  False alarm means an alarm signal, whether monitored using the services of a monitoring company or not, which elicits a response by the police or any municipal emergency personnel, when a situation requiring a response by the police or other emergency personnel does not exist. False alarms do not include (1) an alarm signal caused by violent conditions of nature existing at the time of the alarm and verified by documentation from a weather service, (2) an alarm signal caused by testing of the alarm system, if advance notice of the test has been given to the Mobile police department, (3) alarms described in chapter 39, Article XII of the City Code, or (4) motor vehicle alarms. 
(2)  Alarm business means an economic enterprise conducted by an individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity which participates in selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, offering, replacing, moving, or installing any alarm system in or on any building, structure, or facility within the city or its police jurisdiction. An individual, partnership, or corporation, or other entity engaged in the activities in this section must produce, on demand, a license required by Act 97-711, Acts of the Alabama Legislature (1997) and Mobile Electrical Ordinance No. 19-957, Section 27:124(b). 
(3)  Alarm system means any assembly of equipment, mechanical or electrical, arranged to signal the occurrence of an illegal entry or an attempted illegal entry, robbery, or any other activity requiring urgent police attention, and to which the police are expected to respond. An automatic telephone-dialing device is an alarm system. 
(4)  Alarm user, or user means the person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure, or facility wherein an alarm system is used or maintained. 
(5)  Automatic telephone dialing device means an alarm system which is activated by a signal or message, and which automatically sends a prerecorded voice message or coded signal by microwave, telephone line, or other method of transmission directly to Mobile County 911 or directly to the city police department indicating an unauthorized entry or attempted unauthorized entry to which the police are expected to respond. An automatic telephone dialing device not connected to Mobile County 911 or to the police department emergency communications system is not governed by this section. 
(6)  Date of receipt means the third day after notice to an alarm user has been delivered to the U.S. Postal Service, properly addressed with the postage prepaid. When a notice is hand-delivered to an alarm user, the date of receipt shall be the date the notice was hand-delivered by a municipal employee. 
(7)  Premises means any structure in or on which an alarm is installed. If two or more alarm systems operate independently on a structure under common ownership, each system is a separate alarm system for the purposes of this section. 
(8)  False alarm report means the statement prepared by the police officer(s) responding to an alarm determined to be a false alarm. The false alarm report shall be filed with the alarm officer by the responding officer via normal police department administrative channels, with a copy left at the premises. If the copy left at the premises is not delivered by hand to the alarm user, a back-up copy will be sent to the alarm user by first-class mail. An officer hand delivering the false alarm report shall indicate on the false alarm report the date and time delivered, and identify the recipient. 
(9)  Bill for false alarm cost means the administrative assessment issued by the alarm officer, or his/her designee, to the alarm user to accompany the fourth, and all subsequent false alarm reports issued to an alarm user in any calendar year. 
(10)  Alarm officer means the city employee, designated by the mayor, who shall receive false alarm reports, consider appeals as defined in subsection (k) of this section, and when required, issue bills for false alarm cost. The alarm officer shall be responsible for the maintenance and custody of all business records required for the efficient and accurate administration of this section. 
(d)  Nothing contained in this section will be construed to create any duty or responsibility on the city to respond to a security alarm or determine the effectiveness of any alarm system. It also does not create any duty or responsibility for the failure of an alarm system to operate properly, or for any loss damages that may result as a proximate consequence of the inoperability of an alarm system, or for the timeliness of police response to prevent injuries to individuals or premises. 
(e)  Illegal acts. The following acts are declared illegal, and in violation of this section. Any person, firm, or corporation committing any of the acts set forth in this section shall, on conviction, be punished as provided in Chapter I, Article II, section 1-21. It is unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation to: 
(1)  Intentionally allow or cause a false alarm; 
(2)  Install, or cause to be installed, or operate, an audible alarm system which emits a sound substantially similar to an emergency vehicle's siren in the "wail" mode, or a Mobile County emergency management agency siren or warning device. An audible alarm emitting the "hi-lo" or "yelp" mode of an emergency vehicle's siren is permissible. 
(3)  Install, maintain, or operate an alarm system without an automatic reset device in the system to terminate the alarm within fifteen (15) minutes; 
(4)  Fail, or refuse to have a representative of the Alarm User respond to the premises where the alarm system has been activated within one (1) hour of the notification of the Alarm User of activation of the alarm; and 
(5)  Install an alarm other than in compliance with all state law and code requirements. The alarm business performing such installation shall be the responsible party under this Section. 
(f)  Determination of false alarm and payment of cost. 
(1)  A police officer responding to an activated alarm system shall inspect the premises to determine if there is evidence of an illegal entry or an attempted illegal entry, or other activity requiring urgent police response. Based on a reasonable inspection of the premises, and any other information that may be available to the officer at the site of the activated alarm, the officer shall make a determination if the alarm constituted a false alarm. If the officer determines that there was a false alarm, the officer shall make a false alarm report, indicating the date and times the officer(s), identified by name(s) and badge number(s), arrived at the premises and the reasons for determining that a false alarm has occurred. A copy of the false alarm report shall be given to the alarm user or representative, if present, or conspicuously attached to the premises. The responding officer shall return a copy of the false alarm report to the alarm officer. If the alarm user was not personally given the false alarm report by the responding officer at the premises, the alarm officer shall mail to the alarm user, by first class mail, the false alarm report. 
(2)  After receipt by an alarm user of the fourth, or any subsequent, false alarm report at any premises in one calendar year (January 1-December 31), and absent a determination that the alarm was not false, the alarm officer shall notify the alarm user that a billable false alarm has occurred at the premises. Multiple false alarms occurring within any given 24-hour period shall count as only one false alarm. With the fourth, or any subsequent false alarm report within one calendar year, a bill for false alarm cost shall be sent to the alarm user in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such occurrence. This bill for false alarm cost shall be paid by the alarm user within thirty (30) days of receipt of the bill for false alarm cost. Any such bills unpaid after ninety days from date of issuance may be grounds for the police department to suspend false alarm response service to that premises until all such unpaid bills have been paid. 
(g)  Permit required; application; fee; transferability; false statements. 
(1)  No alarm user shall operate, or cause to be operated, an alarm system at its alarm site without a valid permit issued by the alarm officer. A separate permit is required for each alarm site. Any person operating a non-registered alarm system (whether suspended, expired, or never acquired) will be subject to an assessment of $100.00 for each false alarm, and may be denied further police alarm response services if deemed appropriate by the police department, in consultation with the alarm officer. 
(2)  The annual fee for a permit, or permit renewal, for an alarm site shall be $25.00 for a residence and $50.00 for a business. No refund of a permit or renewal fee, permit transfer, or permit proration will be made. The initial annual registration fee must be submitted to the alarm officer within fifteen (15) days after the alarm installation or the transfer of ownership of an existing alarm system. 
(3)  Upon receipt of a completed application form and the permit fee, the alarm officer shall register the applicant unless the applicant has: 
a.  Failed to pay a bill, as assessed under subsection (e) of this section; or 
b.  Had an alarm permit for the alarm site suspended or revoked, and the violation causing the suspension or revocation has not been corrected. 
(4)  Each alarm permit application must include the following information: 
a.  The name, complete address (including apartment or suite number) and telephone numbers of the person who will be the permit holder and be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this section; 
b.  The classification of the alarm site as either residential (includes condo, mobile home, etc.), commercial or apartment; 
c.  Mailing address if different from the alarm site; 
d.  Any dangerous or special conditions present at the alarm site; 
e.  Name and telephone numbers of at least two individuals who are able and have agreed to receive notification of an alarm activation at any time; respond to the alarm site within thirty (30) minutes; and upon request can grant access to the alarm site and deactivate the alarm system if such becomes necessary; 
f.  Type of business (if applicable) conducted at the alarm site; 
g.  Signed certification from the alarm user stating; 
1.  The name, address, and phone number of the alarm company responsible for providing repair service to the alarm system; and 
2.  The phone number of the alarm company monitoring the alarm system if different from the repair service alarm company. 
(5)  Any false statement of a material fact made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining a permit shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a permit. 
(6)  All fees owed by an applicant must be paid before a permit may be issued or renewed. 
(h)  Permit duration and renewal. A permit shall expire one (1) year from the date of issuance, and must be renewed annually by submitting an updated application and permit renewal fee to the alarm officer. The alarm officer shall send notice by U.S. Mail, first-class postage prepaid, to the alarm user at the alarm user's most recent permit application address, information advising each alarm user of the need to renew thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the permit. It is the responsibility of the alarm user to submit an application prior to the permit expiration date. Failure to renew will be classified as use of a nonregistered alarm system, and fees as detailed in (f) shall be assessed without waiver. A fifteen dollar ($15.00) late fee shall be assessed if the renewal is more than thirty (30) days late. 
(i)  Suspension of response. 
(1)  The alarm officer, in consultation with the chief of police, may suspend alarm response at an alarm site if it is determined that: 
a.  The alarm user has ten (10) or more false alarms in one (1) year; or 
b.  There is a false statement of a material fact in the permit application; or 
c.  The alarm user has failed to make timely payment of a bill as assessed under subsections (e) or (f). 
(2)  Unless there is separate indication that there is a crime in progress, the police department may refuse law enforcement response to an alarm dispatch request at an alarm site for which the alarm permit is suspended. 
(j)  Reinstatement. 
(1)  Any person whose alarm response has been suspended may have alarm response reinstated by the alarm officer if the person has abided by one or more of the following: 
a.  Submits an updated application and permit fee; 
b.  Pays, or otherwise resolves, all outstanding bills; 
c.  In cases where service has been suspended for ten or more false alarms within a calendar year, proof that the alarm system has been inspected by a qualified alarm repair company and found to be in good working order, and that alarm users at the alarm site have received refresher training in alarm system operations and use. 
(k)  Enforcement. Enforcement of this section may be a civil action and/or by criminal prosecution as provided in chapter 1 for offenses under municipal law. 
(l)  Appeals. The alarm user may, within thirty (30) calendar days of the date of the false alarm report, or upon notification of suspension of alarm response service, contact the alarm officer and appeal the issuance of the false alarm report or the suspension of alarm response service. An appeal fee of $25.00 will accompany the appeal request of the alarm user. At the appeal, the alarm user may (1) present written evidence of violent conditions of nature, or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to the control of the alarm user causing the alarm to be activated, or (2) provide information to reasonably support the conclusion that an illegal entry, or an attempted illegal entry, or other activity occurred at the premises requiring urgent police attention did occur and activate the alarm, or (3) in the case of suspension of alarm response service, that substantial corrective action has been taken in accordance with the provisions of subsection (i) of this section. If the alarm officer is satisfied that the alarm was not a false alarm, or in the case of suspension of alarm response service, that the corrective elements in subsection (i) of this section have been satisfied, the alarm user shall be informed of this determination, the false alarm report will be cancelled, or service will be restored, and the alarm user's appeal fee of $25.00 will be refunded. 
(m)  Confidentiality. Information contained in the permit application and applications for appeals shall be held in confidence by all employees or representatives of the city, and by any third-party administrator or employees of a third-party administrator with access to such information. 
(n)  Government immunity. Requirements for permitting alarm systems are not intended to, nor will they create a contract, duty, or obligation, either expressed or implied, of response. Any and all liability and consequential damage resulting from the failure to respond to a notification is hereby disclaimed and governmental immunity as provided by law is retained. By permitting an alarm system, the alarm user acknowledges that police response may be based on factors such as: availability of police units, priority of calls, weather conditions, traffic conditions, emergency conditions, and staffing levels. 
(Code 1965, § 41-8; Ord. No. 39-067, §§ 1, 2, 4-7, 12-7-99; Ord. No. 34-014, §§ 1, 2, 4, 6-15, 3-20-01) 
Cross reference- False alarms with alarms connected to communications center, § 46-78. 
Sec. 39-63. - Malicious or frivolous prosecution; failure to prosecute. 
    Any person who frivolously or maliciously or without probable cause therefor procures, whether by complaint on oath or otherwise, the arrest of any person by any police officer of the city and any person who procures the arrest of another person by any police officer of the city and, without good excuse therefor, fails or refuses to appear and prosecute such person or to testify as a witness against him may, for each such offense, be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-28) 
Secs. 39-64-39-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY AND REAL PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses regarding fire prevention, §§ 22-17-22-19. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 39-71. - Trespass. 
(a)  No person shall enter without lawful authority upon the land or premises of another, or, being upon the land or premises of another, upon being notified to depart therefrom by the owner or occupant, or the agent or servant of either, without lawful authority shall neglect or refuse to depart therefrom. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this section shall be punished in accordance with the provisions of chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-64.1) 
Sec. 39-72. - Malicious injury to property. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person, personally or by agent or otherwise, maliciously or mischievously to deface, remove, damage, tear down or destroy any real or personal property of whatsoever kind or nature, whether publicly or privately owned, in the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 41-27) 
Cross reference- Defacing monuments in Magnolia Cemetery, § 12-63; injuring poles or wires, §§ 19-49, 19-50; offenses regarding fire prevention, §§ 22-17, 22-19; molesting garbage containers or contents, § 25-1; depredations in parks, § 41-3; injuring, defacing, etc., pipes, § 45-73. 
Sec. 39-73. - Throwing or propelling stones, rocks and other missiles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to throw, or to propel by any device, any stone, rock or any other missile upon or at any vehicle, building, or other public or private property, or upon or at any person in any public or private way or place, or enclosed or unenclosed ground. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of violating this section shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-60.1; Ord. No. 41-014, 1-4-72) 
Sec. 39-74. - Injuring, etc., show window, sign or newly painted work. 
    Any person who shall break or deface any show window or sign or newly painted work by maliciously cutting or scratching, the same shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-22) 
Sec. 39-75. - Injuring or carrying away fence, door, sign, etc., of another. 
    No person shall break down, destroy or carry away any fence, or any part thereof, or steps, blinds or doors of any house or injure any private bridge, curbing or pavement or deface, break or carry away any signboard or plate indicating the name, residence, occupation or business of any other person. 
(Code 1965, § 41-23) 
Sec. 39-76. - Spitting or throwing fruit skins, etc., on sidewalks, etc. 
    No person shall spit or throw fruit skins, parings or peelings upon any sidewalk in the city or upon the floor of any bus operated within the city or in any public elevator, public building, public theater or public hall or upon any walkway in any public park in the city. 
(Code 1965, § 41-58) 
Sec. 39-77. - Use, sale, etc., of confetti. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to have in possession, keep, store, use, manufacture, sell, offer for sale, give away or handle any non-biodegradable, plastic-based confetti, serpentine, or other substance or matters similar thereto within the city or within its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 41-3; Ord. No. 39-022-2018 , § 1, 8-7-18) 
Cross reference- Littering, § 25-31 et seq. 
Sec. 39-78. - Abandonment of refrigerators, iceboxes, etc., in places accessible to children. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain outside of any dwelling, building or other structure or within any unoccupied or abandoned building, dwelling or other structure under his control, in a place accessible to children, any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or other container which has an airtight door or lid, snap lock or other locking device which may not be released from the inside, without first removing such door or lid, snap lock or other locking device from the icebox, refrigerator or container. 
(Code 1965, § 41-52) 
Sec. 39-79. - Steel-jawed animal traps. 
    The use of steel-jawed animal traps for any purpose whatsoever within the city and its police jurisdiction is expressly prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 41-067, 3-4-86) 
Cross reference- Humane traps, § 7-31. 
Sec. 39-80. - Emission of dense smoke prohibited. 
(a)  The emission or discharge into the open air of dense smoke in such manner or in such quantities as to cause damage to the property, real or personal, of any person or as to be detrimental to the health or materially interfere with the comfort of persons within the city or its police jurisdiction is hereby prohibited and made unlawful. 
(b)  In any trial, suit or proceeding under or involving subsection (a), it shall be a good defense if the person charged with a violation of subsection (a) shall show to the court or jury trying the facts, with the necessary probative effect according to the rules of evidence under the laws of the state, that there was no known practical device, appliance, means, fuel, way or method by the application or use of which the emission or discharge of the dense smoke complained of could have been prevented. 
(Code 1965, §§ 41-54, 41-55) 
Sec. 39-81. - Stink or funk balls. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, dispose of, give away or use within the city or its police jurisdiction articles known as stink balls or funk balls or anything of like nature, by whatever name known or called, the purpose of which is to create disagreeable odors to the great discomfort of persons coming in contact therewith. 
(Code 1965, § 41-60) 
Sec. 39-82. - Washing in, tampering with, etc., fountains. 
    Any person who at any time washes his hands, face or feet in any of the fountains in the city or obstructs the flow of water into the same or in any manner tampers with or abuses such fountain or its fixtures shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-11) 
Sec. 39-83. - Reckless driving. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words and phrases shall, for the purposes of this section, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City shall mean the city and its police jurisdiction. 
    Private property shall mean property within the city owned or controlled by an individual, firm or corporation which has been designated and set aside for use by the general public as either pedestrian walkways or for the operation or parking of vehicles. 
    Public property shall mean all property owned by or in the possession of or under the control of the state, the county, the city or any other body politic or public corporation. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn; provided, that for the purposes of this section, a ridden animal shall be deemed a vehicle. 
(b)  Upon public property. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to drive any vehicle upon any public property within the city carelessly and heedlessly in wilful or wanton disregard to the rights or safety of others, or without due caution and circumspection and at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. 
(c)  Upon private property. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon private property carelessly or heedlessly in wilful or wanton disregard of the rights or safety of others, or without due caution and circumspection and at a speed or in a manner so as to endanger or be likely to endanger any person or property. 
(Code 1965, §§ 41-51.1-41-51.3) 
DIVISION 2. - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Curfew for minors, § 39-261 et seq. 

Sec. 39-84. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Civil emergency shall mean: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority by law. 
(2)  Any natural disaster or manmade calamity including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the city resulting in the death or injury of person or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew shall mean a prohibition against any one or more persons walking, running, loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the city, except persons officially designated to duty with reference to such civil emergency. 
(Code 1965, § 41-2.1; Ord. No. 14-032, 1968, § 1) 
Sec. 39-85. - Proclamation of mayor. 
    When in the judgment of the mayor a civil emergency as defined in section 39-84 is deemed to exist he shall forthwith proclaim in writing the existence of the same. 
(Code 1965, § 41-2.2; Ord. No. 14-032, 1968, § 2) 
Sec. 39-86. - General curfew. 
    After proclamation of a civil emergency by the mayor, he may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the city, or to the city as a whole, as he deems advisable, and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interest of the public safety and welfare. 
(Code 1965, § 41-2.3; Ord. No. 14-032, 1968, § 3) 
Sec. 39-87. - Curfew applicable to minors under seventeen. 
(a)  After proclamation of a civil emergency by the mayor, he may order a curfew applicable only to minors under the age of seventeen (17) years; and such curfew may be declared applicable to such geographical areas of the city, or to the city as a whole, as he deems advisable, and subject to such further conditions, limitations and exemptions as he deems necessary in the interest of public safety and welfare. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the parent, guardian or other adult person having the care and custody of a minor under the age of seventeen (17) years to knowingly permit such minor to violate the curfew ordered by the mayor under this section. 
(Code 1965, § 41-2.4; Ord. No. 14-110, 1968) 
Sec. 39-88. - Orders which may be issued by mayor.
