    After proclamation of a civil emergency, the mayor of the city may also in the interest of public safety and welfare make any or all of the following orders: 
(1)  Order the closing of all retail liquor stores; 
(2)  Order the closing of all beer taverns; 
(3)  Order the closing of all private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating liquor or beer is permitted; 
(4)  Order the discontinuance of the sale of beer; 
(5)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away of gasoline or other flammable liquid or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle; 
(6)  Order the closing of gasoline stations and other establishments, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution or dispensing of flammable liquid or combustible products; 
(7)  Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever; 
(8)  Order the closing of any or all establishments or portions thereof, the chief activity of which is the sale, distribution, dispensing or giving away of firearms or ammunition; 
(9)  Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
(Code 1965, § 41-2.5; Ord. No. 14-032, 1968, § 4) 
Sec. 39-89. - Violations and penalties. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this division, or any executive order issue by the mayor pursuant to the authority therein contained, shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished by a fine not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00), or may be imprisoned in the city jail or sentenced to hard labor for the city for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment or sentenced to hard labor, at the discretion of the judge trying the case. 
(Code 1965, § 41-2.6; Ord. No. 14-006, 1972, § 5) 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Offenses regarding public assemblies, §§ 49-1-49-3; unlawful assemblies, § 49-21; demonstrations on sidewalks, § 49-36. 

Sec. 39-90. - Loitering and prowling. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to loiter or prowl in a place, at a time or in a manner not usual for law abiding individuals, under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm or immediate concern is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstance makes it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting him to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer did not comply with this procedure or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person is true and, if believed by the officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to punishment as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 41-065, §§ 1-3, 9-3-85) 
Cross reference- Loitering in parks, § 41-5. 
Sec. 39-91. - Loitering for purposes of illegal drug activity. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Illegal drug activity means the sale, purchase or possession or attempted sale, purchase or possession of any illegal narcotic or drug or controlled substance as defined by any ordinance of the city or any statute of the state or of the United States of America. 
    Known drug activity location means any area within the city or its police jurisdiction which is within a one-half mile radius of the general location of at least five (5) drug seizures or arrests leading to convictions for illegal drug activity as defined in this section within the past year. 
    Known drug dealer or user means a person who, within five (5) years previous to the date of arrest for a violation of any of the provisions of this section, has, within the knowledge of the arresting officer, been convicted of violating any ordinance of the city or statute of the state or of the United States of America prohibiting and punishing any of the following or any similar act or acts: any illegal act relating to the sale, use or possession of any illegal narcotic or drug or controlled substance as defined by any ordinance of the city or statute of the state or of the United States of America. 
    Loitering, for purposes of this section, means remaining idle in essentially one (1) place and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing or walking about aimlessly. 
    Public place means a place to which the public or a substantial portion of the public has access, and includes but is not limited to highways, transportation facilities, schools, places of amusement, parks, playgrounds and hallways, lobbies and other portions of apartment houses not constituting rooms or apartments designed for actual residence, provided that no private dwelling and no place engaged for a private gathering is included within the meaning of public place with respect to any person specifically invited therein. 
    Transportation facility means any conveyance, premises or place used for or in connection with public passenger transportation, whether by air, railroad cars, buses, and air, boat, railroad and bus terminals and stations and all appurtenances thereto. 
Use of any term denoting male gender in this section shall include the female gender. 
(b)  Prohibited activities. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city: 
(1)  For any person to loiter or remain in a public place for the purpose of engaging in illegal drug activity. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purpose is manifested are that such person is in a known drug activity location plus any of the following circumstances are present: that such person is a known drug dealer or user; or that such person repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempt to stop, or engages motorists in a conversation; or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators or passengers by hailing, waving of arms or any other bodily gesture or any other means; or leans into or enters stopped vehicles; or exchanges money with motorists or pedestrians; or warns other persons in the area of the presence of law enforcement officers; or exchanges money or other items in return for packages or other items with motorists, passengers or pedestrians. 
(2)  For any person to engage in or attempt to engage in any illegal drug activity as defined in this section. 
(3)  For any person to solicit, induce, entice or procure another to engage in or attempt to engage in any illegal drug activity as defined in this section. 
(c)  Temporary detention. 
(1)  Whenever any law enforcement officer encounters any person under any circumstances which reasonably indicate that such person has committed, is committing, or is about to commit a violation of this section, the officer may temporarily detain such person for the purpose of ascertaining the identity of the person temporarily detained, and the circumstances surrounding his or her presence abroad which led the officer to believe that the person detained had committed, was committing, or was about to commit a violation of this section. 
(2)  No person shall be temporarily detained under the provisions of subsection (c) longer than is reasonably necessary to effect the purpose of paragraph (1). Such temporary detention shall not extend beyond the place where it was first effected or the immediate vicinity thereof. 
(3)  If at any time after the onset of the temporary detention authorized by subsection (c)(1), grounds for arrest of that person shall appear, the person may be arrested. 
(4)  Among the elements which may be considered by a police officer in determining that a person has committed, is committing, or is about to commit a violation of this ordinance are any of the elements listed in subsection (b)(1). 
(d)  Prior convictions. For the purposes of this section, a certified copy of the judgment of conviction shall be deemed prima facie evidence of each prior conviction; however other types of proof of prior convictions may be produced by the arresting officer. 
(e)  Cumulative effect. This section shall be cumulative, supplemental and in addition to any presently existing City Code provision or ordinance or any other law of any nature whatsoever which may have similar, like or overlapping provisions and which may be available for use by the city. 
(f)  Punishment. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 47-048, §§ 1-6, 6-27-89) 
Sec. 39-92. - Disorderly conduct. 
    A person commits the offense of disorderly conduct if, with the intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, he: 
(1)  Engages in fighting or in violent, tumultuous or threatening behavior; or 
(2)  Makes unreasonable noise; or 
(3)  In a public place uses abusive or obscene language or makes an obscene gesture; or 
(4)  Without lawful authority, disturbs any lawful assembly or meeting of persons; or 
(5)  Obstructs vehicular or pedestrian traffic, or transportation facility; or 
(6)  Congregates with other persons in a public place and refuses to comply with a lawful order of the police to disperse. 
(Code 1965, § 41-4.1; Ord. No. 41-057, 7-5-83) 
Sec. 39-93. - Fighting, etc. 
    No person shall be guilty of fighting, quarreling or any riotous, indecent or blasphemous language or disorderly conduct in the streets, houses or elsewhere in the city or its police jurisdiction or abusing, provoking or disturbing, either by word or action, any person on any street or public place. 
(Code 1965, § 41-9) 
Sec. 39-94. - Drunkenness. 
(a)  Any person found drunk in or about a street or any house or place of business where liquors of any kind are sold or in or about any house or place of business of a public nature within the city or its police jurisdiction shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(b)  Any person who, while intoxicated or drunk, appears in any public place or within the curtilage of any private residence, not his own, where one or more persons are present, and manifests a drunken condition by boisterous, noisy, disorderly or indecent conduct, or by rude and profane language, or by staggering, falling or sleeping, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-6; Ord. No. 41-159, 12-23-80) 
Sec. 39-95. - Intoxication in a motor vehicle. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Actual physical control of a motor vehicle means that a person is in actual physical possession of a motor vehicle as evidenced by the fact that, at the time of the offense, he or she is physically located inside the motor vehicle. This phrase shall not include someone who is only a passenger in the motor vehicle and who has no actual control of the vehicle. 
    Public place means any place, building or conveyance, to which the public has or is permitted to have access, and any highway, street, lane, park, parking lot, roadway median, roadway right-of-way, or place of public resort or amusement. 
(b)  Prohibited activities. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to be drunk or intoxicated in a motor vehicle while in actual physical control of the vehicle, and while the vehicle is located upon any public street or upon any other place to which the public has or is permitted to have access. It shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section: (1) If a person is found alone inside a motor vehicle in an intoxicated state; or (2) If a person is found lying or sitting behind the steering wheel of a motor vehicle in an intoxicated state. 
(c)  Cumulative effect. This section shall be cumulative, supplemental and in addition to any presently existing City Code provision or ordinance or any other law of any nature whatsoever which may have similar, like or overlapping provisions and which may be available for use by the city. 
(d)  Punishment. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this ordinance shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 29-066, §§ 1-4, 7-8-80) 
Cross reference- Intoxicating liquor, Ch. 30. 
Sec. 39-96. - Noise generally. 
(a)  Noise prohibited. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to play, use or operate, or permit to be played, used or operated, any radio, tape player, cassette player, compact disc player, or other machine or device for reproducing sound, in or on any public property, including any public street, road, building, sidewalk, or park, in such a manner that the sound generated is plainly audible at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet or more from the source of the sound. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to play, use or operate any radio, tape player, cassette player, compact disc player, or other machine or device for reproducing sound in any motor vehicle on a street or highway in such a manner that the sound generated is plainly audible at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet or more from the motor vehicle. 
(3)  Possession by a person or persons of any of the machines or devices enumerated above shall be prima facie evidence that that person operates or those persons operate the machine or device. 
(b)  Exceptions. The prohibition of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any athletic event, cultural event or concert authorized by the city. 
(2)  Any noises or sounds produced by radios, sirens, or other equipment attached to, or being operated by, any police, fire, rescue, or other emergency vehicles or personnel. 
(c)  Punishment. Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, division 2, Mobile City Code, with a fine of one hundred sixty dollars ($160.00) plus court costs, or by community service for a period not exceeding six (6) months, or by both fine and imprisonment, and/or community service at the discretion of the judge. 
(Code 1965, § 41-38; Ord. No. 39-045, § 1, 8-2-94; Ord. No. 39-028, 5-13-97; Ord. No. 39-007, §§ 2-4, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 39-015-2008, § 1, 3-18-08) 
Cross reference- Noisy public assemblies, §§ 49-31-49-33. 
Sec. 39-96.1. - Noise in residential districts. 
(a)  Intent. It is the intent of the city council of the city to endeavor to provide citizens an environment free from such excess sounds or noise in order to provide for the safety, preserve the health, promote the prosperity, and improve the morals, order, comfort and convenience of the inhabitants of the municipality. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section: 
(1)  Construction activities shall mean any and all activity incidental to the construction, erection, demolition, assembling, altering, installing or equipping of buildings, structures, roads or appurtenances thereto, including land clearing, grading, excavating and filling. 
(2)  Construction equipment shall mean construction activity utilizing any equipment or devices, such as but not limited to, pile drivers, power shovels, derricks, hoist tractors, loaders, rollers, concrete hauling motor vehicles, pavement breakers, bulldozers, crawler-tractors, rotatory drills and augers, cranes, ditcher, trenchers, scrapers, wagons, pumps, compressors, pneumatic power equipment, or other mechanical apparatus operated by fuel or electric power in the construction, repair or demolition of any building, structure, land, street, alley, waterways, or appurtenance thereto. 
(3)  db(a) shall mean a measure of sound pressure level in decibels on the A-weighted scale. 
(4)  Decibel meter shall mean an instrument to measure decibels which meets or exceeds American National Standards Institute (ANSI) Section 1.4, 1997 standards for type 2 special meters and is capable of measuring the equivalent continuous A-frequency weighted sound pressure level per ANSI S1.43-1997 paragraph 3.2. These devices will be rechecked once a year for accuracy. 
(5)  Domestic power equipment shall mean any equipment or device used for routine home or building repairs and grounds maintenance. 
(6)  Device shall mean any mechanism which is intended to produce or which actually produces sound when operated or handled. 
(7)  Person shall mean and include any individual, corporation, association, partnership or limited partnership. 
(8)  Property line. The boundary line distinguishing ownership or the common wall of a town house, condominium, or leased premises. 
(9)  Residential district shall have the same meaning as in the zoning ordinance of the city, including single-family residence districts (R-1), two-family residence districts (R-2), multi-family residence districts (R-3), and residential business districts (R-B), or as established by future zoning ordinances as residential. 
(10)  Sound shall mean that which is or can be heard, or particularly a temporal and spatial oscillation in pressure, or other physical quality, in a medium with internal forces that cause compression and rarefaction of that medium and which propagates at finite speed to distant points. 
(11)  Sound-amplifying equipment shall mean any machine or device for the amplification of the human voice, music, or any other sound or noise. 
(12)  Dumpster shall mean any container two (2) cubic yards or larger, that is used to hold construction and demolition material, garbage, trash, rubbish, recyclable materials, or any combination thereof. 
(c)  Noise in residential districts restricted. 
(1)  Generally. It shall be unlawful and a nuisance to make, continue or cause to be made or continued any loud or excessive noise that unreasonably interferes with the comfort, health, or safety of others within the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  In addition to the general prohibition set out above, it shall be unlawful, a nuisance and a violation of this section, for any person to: 
a.  Use, operate, or permit to be used or operated, any device, radio, musical instrument, television, phonograph, drum, sound amplifying equipment or device which produces or reproduces sound, either stationary or mobile, in such a manner that, during the hours from 6:00 am. to 10:00 p.m.: 
1.  It is plainly audible at a distance of fifty (50) feet or more from any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city; or 
2.  It creates any noise which exceeds eighty-five (85) db(a) at any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city. 
b.  Use, operate, or permit to be used or operated, any device, radio, musical instrument, television, phonograph, drum, sound amplifying equipment or device which produces or reproduces sound, either stationary or mobile, in such a manner that, during the hours from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 am.: 
1.  It is plainly audible at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet or more from any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city; or 
2.  It creates any noise which exceeds fifty (50) db(a) at any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city. 
c.  Loud or raucous sounds or noises-6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m. Willfully make or cause a noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any residential district and which during the hours from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.: 
1.  Is plainly audible at a distance of fifty (50) feet or more from any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city; or 
2.  Exceeds 85 db(a) at any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city. 
d.  Loud or raucous sounds or noises-10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. Willfully make or cause a noise which disturbs the peace or quiet of any residential district and which during the hours from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m.: 
1.  Is plainly audible at a distance of twenty-five (25) feet or more from any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city; or 
2.  Creates any noise which exceeds fifty (50) db(a) at any property line within a residential district or upon any public street or right-of-way within, or bordering upon, any residential district within the corporate limits of the city. 
e.  Any person creating any such sound or noise as described in this section and/or anyone permitting such a sound or noise to be created in, or emanate from, any premises under his care, custody or control, shall be presumed responsible for any such sound or noise. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person to empty any dumpster in any residential district zoned as R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-B, or within five hundred (500) feet of the property line of any property that is zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-B, during the hours from 10:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. 
(4)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deliver, pick up, or raise any dumpster, or any roll-off box or container, in any residential district zoned as R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-B, or within five hundred (500) feet of the property line of any property that is zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-B, during the hours from 10:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. 
(5)  It shall be unlawful for any person to pick up construction or demolition material, garbage, trash, rubbish, recyclable materials, or any combination thereof, with a truck which has a compactor or the capacity to raise, move, or empty any dumpster, or any roll-off box or container, in any residential district zoned as R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-B, or within five hundred (500) feet of the property line of any property that is zoned R-1, R-2, R-3, or R-B, during the hours from 10:00 p.m. until 6:00 a.m. 
(d)  Exceptions. 
(1)  Emergency and public work. Noise or sound created in the performance of public service by governmental agencies or their contractors; or emergency work engaged in by persons for the public safety, health or welfare; or to restore property to a safe condition following a public emergency; or work to restore essential public services, including construction activities directly related to the abatement of any emergency, shall not be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Noises from authorized activities. The prohibitions of this section shall not apply to air traffic at the Mobile Municipal Airport, or any activities of a temporary duration which are permitted by law and for which a license or permit has been granted by the city including but not limited to parades, sporting events, concerts, Greater Gulf State Fair and fireworks displays. 
(3)  Sirens, horns and whistles. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any siren, whistle, horn or bell used by emergency vehicles or civil defense or used by motor vehicles, trains and boats as warning devices to avoid collisions. 
(4)  Bells or chimes. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any bell or chimes, or any device for the production or reproduction of the sound thereof which are associated with a clock of time keeping device, a church or school. 
(5)  Burglar alarm. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any burglar alarm or security device, provided, however, no burglar alarm or security device shall sound for more than fifteen (15) minutes after being activated. 
(6)  Construction activity or equipment. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any construction activity or equipment operated between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(7)  Domestic power equipment. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any domestic power equipment operated between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(8)  Vessels. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the operation of any motor boat or vessel on any lake, river, stream or waterway. 
(9)  Motor vehicles and trains. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the normal and usual operation of motor vehicles and trains. 
(10)  Dumpsters. The provisions of this section relating to the emptying of dumpsters, and to the delivery, pick up, or raising of any dumpster, in or near residential areas between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., shall not apply in the following circumstances: 
a.  To the emptying, delivery, pick up, or raising of any dumpster that has a plastic or poly-material lid and plastic or poly-material side doors and that is situated on a minimum two-inch thick rubber pad; 
b.  To the emptying, delivery, pick up, or raising of any dumpster that is constructed of plastic or poly-materials; and, 
c.  To the emptying, delivery, pick up, or raising of any dumpster that has a plastic or poly-material lid and plastic or poly-material side doors by using a truck that is equipped with functioning automatic hydraulic deceleration valves that reduce the noise caused by emptying the dumpster by limiting the abrupt stops during the emptying cycle that occur: 
1.  At the end of the lifting portion of the cycle when the dumpster reaches a stop point over the truck; and 
2.  At the end of the lowering portion of the cycle when the dumpster is set back on the ground. 
(11)  The provisions of this section relating to the emptying, delivery, pick up, or raising of dumpsters and roll-off boxes or containers in or near residential areas between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. shall not apply to any dumpster or roll-off box or container located within the central business district or on any school or college property. For purposes of this section, the central business district is defined as the area bounded on the North by St. Anthony Street from the Mobile River to Claiborne, then by St. Michael Street from Claiborne Street to Washington Avenue; on the West by Washington Avenue; on the South by Government Street from Washington Avenue to Claiborne Street, then by Church Street to the Mobile River; and on the East by the Mobile River. 
(Ord. No. 39-015, §§ 1-4, 3-17-98; Ord. No. 39-014, § 1, 2-29-00; Ord. No. 39-017, § 1, 3-21-00; Ord. No. 39-011-2009, §§ 1-3, 3-19-09; Ord. No. 39-004-2015 , §§ 1-3, 2-18-15) 
Sec. 39-97. - Sound trucks, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, by agent or otherwise, to operate on or along the streets, sidewalks or other public places of the city or its police jurisdiction any vehicle with a loudspeaker, phonograph, radio or other instrument of like kind or nature in operation when the sound from such instrument can be heard in the buildings adjoining the street, sidewalk or other place along which the vehicle containing the instrument is traveling. 
(Code 1965, § 41-57) 
Sec. 39-98. - Disturbing religious worship. 
    Whoever shall disturb a congregation or assembly of any section or church met for religious worship in the city or its police jurisdiction, by making a noise or by rude or indecent behavior or profane discourse within the place of worship or on the street or elsewhere so near as to disturb the order and solemnity of the meeting, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-5) 
Sec. 39-99. - Dances near hospitals, etc. 
    It is declared a nuisance and is hereby prohibited for any person to conduct or participate in any dance or dancing within the city or its police jurisdiction within such distance from any hospital, sanitarium or infirmary as to annoy or disturb any of the patients or inmates of such hospital, sanitarium or infirmary. 
(Code 1965, § 41-4) 
Sec. 39-100. - Signs, writings, etc., tending to disturb peace, etc. 
(a)  No person shall show or expose in public any writing, sign, drawing, print, caricature, statue, burning cross or any other object which may excite scandal or has a tendency to disturb the public peace. 
(b)  No person shall show or expose on property owned or occupied by another any writing, sign, drawing, print, caricature, statue, burning cross or any other object which may excite scandal or has a tendency to disturb the public peace, or which may disturb the occupant of such property, unless such person shall have first obtained the consent of the owner or occupant of such property. 
(Code 1965, § 41-53) 
Sec. 39-101. - Golf prohibition. 
(a)  With the exception of city owned golf courses, it shall be unlawful for any individual to hit, chip, putt, or strike a golf ball in a city park, playground, right-of-way, median, or in any public area where such an activity might threaten public health, safety or welfare. 
(b)  Any person judged to be in violation of this section shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 43-004, 1-7-92) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 43-004, adopted 1-7-92, amended the code to provide for golf prohibition in chapter 41, regarding parks and playgrounds. Said ordinance has been included as § 39-101 for classification purposes at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 39-102-39-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES RELATING TO SEXUAL CONDUCT OR OBSCENITY[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Adult entertainment enterprises, § 64-4.I. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 39-111. - Indecent exposure-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to expose or exhibit, or to procure or cause another to expose or exhibit, his sexual organs or private parts in any public place or on the private premises of another, or so near thereto so as to be seen from such private premises, in a vulgar and indecent manner. 
(Code 1965, § 41-21) 
Sec. 39-112. - Same-Indecent dress, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to appear in any public place in a state of nudity or indecent or lewd dress, or make an indecent exposure of his person, or to perform or commit any indecent act. 
(Code 1965, § 41-21.1) 
Sec. 39-113. - Nude bathing, etc. 
    Any person who, while naked or insufficiently clothed to prevent indecent exposure of his person, shall bathe, wade, wash or swim in the Mobile River or in Mobile Bay or in any watercourse, pond, pool or ditch within the city or its police jurisdiction shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-39; Ord. No. 65-004, 1-17-89) 
Sec. 39-114. - Peeping Toms. 
    Any person who, without legal cause or good excuse, in the nighttime goes upon the premises of another and stares, gazes or peeps into any room, apartment or other place of abode, not his own or under his control, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-44) 
Secs. 39-115-39-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OBSCENITY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Obscene or immoral pictures on signs, § 54-12. 

Sec. 39-121. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    Licensee shall mean any person holding a city business license. 
    Obscene, obscenity. A thing is "obscene" if, by contemporary community standards, and considered as a whole, its predominant appeal is to prurient interest. As a matter of state and city public policy, obscenity is utterly without redeeming social importance and constitutes a public nuisance which should be abated. 
    Printed or written matter or material shall mean any book, pamphlet, magazine, periodical, newspaper, picture magazine, comic book, storybook, photograph, motion picture, negatives, or other printed or written matter, but does not include written or printed matter or material used by or in any religious, scientific or educational institution. 
(Code 1965, § 41-40) 
Sec. 39-122. - Preparation, sale, exhibition, distribution, etc. 
(a)  Every person who knowingly prepares, sells, exhibits or commercially distributes or gives away or offers to give away, or has in his possession with intent to sell or commercially distribute or to give away or offer to give away, any obscene, printed or written matter or material, shall be guilty of an offense against the city and shall be punished as provided by chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall apply and be effective in the city and its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 41-41) 
Sec. 39-123. - Posting obscene or vulgar picture, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to post or leave or cause to be posted or left an obscene or vulgar picture, placard, writing or printed matter about or near any church, dwelling, school, academy or public street or in any storehouse or public place. 
(Code 1965, § 41-42) 
Sec. 39-124. - Indecent, etc., plays. 
    Any person who shall exhibit or perform in any indecent, immoral or lewd play or other immodest representation shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 41-43) 
Secs. 39-125-39-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PROSTITUTION 

Sec. 39-131. - Definitions. 
    As used in this division, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
    Advance prostitution. A person "advances prostitution" if, acting other than as a prostitute or a patron of a prostitute, he knowingly causes or aids a person to commit or engage in prostitution, procures or solicits patrons for prostitution, provides persons or premises for prostitution purposes, operates or assists in the operation of a house of prostitution or a prostitution enterprise. 
    Known prostitute or panderer means a person who, within a year previous to the date of arrest for a violation of any of the provisions of this division, has within the knowledge of the arresting officer been convicted of violating any ordinance of the city or statute of the state prohibiting and punishing any of the following or any similar act or acts; engaging in prostitution; soliciting another to engage in an act of prostitution; advancing or profiting from prostitution; renting a room for the purpose of prostitution, to commit a crime against nature, or an immoral purpose; enticing or using females for the purpose of prostitution, committing a crime against nature, or for immoral purposes; any act prohibited by this division; or any act constituting sexual activity for hire. 
    Loitering for purposes of this division, means remaining idle in essentially one (1) place and shall include the concepts of spending time idly, loafing or walking about aimlessly. 
    Profit from prostitution. A person "profits from prostitution" if, acting other than as a prostitute receiving compensation for personally rendered prostitution services, he accepts or receives money or other property pursuant to a prior agreement with any person whereby he participates or is to participate in the proceeds of prostitution activity. 
    Prostitution means engaging or agreeing or offering to engage in sexual activity with another person in return for or payment of a fee, profit, compensation, or the promise of or agreement to pay or receive a fee, profit or compensation. 
    Public place means a place to which the public or a substantial portion of the public has access and includes but is not limited to highways, transportation facilities, schools, places of amusement, parks, playgrounds and hallways, lobbies and other portions of apartment houses not constituting rooms or apartments designed for actual residence; provided, that no private dwelling and no place engaged for a private gathering is included within the meaning of public place with respect to any person specifically invited therein. 
    Sexual activity for purposes of this division, means any type of sexual intercourse, sexual contact, crimes against nature, and shall include the acts of normal sexual intercourse, anal intercourse, oral sex acts; or the touching or fondling in any manner of female breasts, or male or female genitals. The above definition shall not be deemed to be all-inclusive. 
    Transportation facility means any conveyance, premises or place used for or in connection with public passenger transportation, whether by air, railroad cars, buses and air, boat, railroad and bus terminals and stations and all appurtenances thereto. 
    Use of any term denoting male gender in this division shall include the female gender. 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 1, 10-24-79) 
Sec. 39-132. - Penalty. 
    Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this division shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). In the event the fine and costs are not presently paid or judgment confessed therefor in favor of the city with good and sufficient sureties with a waiver of exemptions as to personalty, the defendant shall be required to work out the fine and costs under the direction of the city authorities, allowing one dollar ($1.00) for each day's service. No female shall be required to work on the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 41-108, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 39-133. - Prior convictions. 
    For the purposes of this division, a certified copy of the judgment of conviction shall be deemed prima facie evidence of each prior conviction. 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 7, 10-24-79) 
Sec. 39-134. - Sex of parties immaterial. 
    In any prosecution under this division, the sex of the parties to the illegal sexual activity or prohibited conduct is immaterial, and it is no defense that such persons were of the same sex. 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 2, 10-24-79) 
Sec. 39-135. - Prohibited activities. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city: 
(1)  For any person to loiter or remain in a public place for the purpose of engaging or soliciting another person to engage in an act of prostitution or sexual activity for hire. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purpose is manifested are: that such person is a known prostitute or panderer; that such person repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passersby in conversation; or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators or passengers by hailing, waving of arms or any other bodily gesture or by any other means. 
No arrest shall be made for a violation of this subsection unless the arresting officer, by direct demand, first affords such person an opportunity to explain such conduct. 
No person shall be convicted of a violation of this subsection if it appears at trial that the explanation tendered was true and disclosed a lawful purpose. 
(2)  For any person to engage in an act of prostitution. 
(3)  For any person to solicit, induce, entice or procure another to engage in an act of prostitution. 
(4)  For any person to advance prostitution or profit from prostitution. 
(5)  For any person to offer another or offer or agree to secure another for the purpose of prostitution. 
(6)  For any person to patronize a prostitute. An act of patronizing a prostitute shall be deemed complete when: 
a.  Pursuant to a prior understanding a person pays a fee to another person as compensation for such person or a third person having engaged in sexual activity with him; or 
b.  A person pays or agrees to pay a fee to another person pursuant to an understanding that in return therefor such person or a third person will engage in sexual activity with him; or 
c.  A person solicits or requests another person to engage in sexual activity with him in return for a fee. 
(7)  For any person to direct, take or transport or to offer or agree or request another to take or transport any person to any place, structure or building or to any other place with knowledge that the purpose of such directing, taking or transporting is prostitution. 
(8)  For any person to invite or entice any person to go with him to any place or to enter any room, house or building or enclosure for purposes of prostitution. 
(9)  For any person to keep, set up, maintain or operate any place, structure, building or conveyance for the purpose of prostitution, or to permit any person to remain there for such purpose. 
(10)  For any person to receive or offer or agree to receive any person into any place, structure, building or conveyance for the purpose of prostitution, or to permit any person to remain there for such purpose. 
(11)  For any person to reside in, enter into or remain in any place, structure, building or conveyance for the purpose of prostitution. 
(12)  For any person to rent or sublet any house, building or room or any enclosure, or to give lodging or shelter, for hire or otherwise, to any person for purposes of prostitution. 
(13)  For any person to aid, abet or participate in the doing of any of the activities prohibited in this section. 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 3, 10-24-79) 
Sec. 39-136. - Attempt. 
    Whoever attempts to commit an offense prohibited by this division and in such attempt does not act toward the commission of such offense, but fails in the perpetration or is intercepted or prevented in the execution of the same, commits the offense of criminal attempt and shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 4, 10-24-79) 
Sec. 39-137. - Temporary detention. 
(a)  Whenever any law enforcement officer encounters any person under any circumstances which reasonably indicates that such person has committed, is committing, or is about to commit a violation of this division, the officer may temporarily detain such person for the purpose of ascertaining the identity of the person temporarily detained, and the circumstances surrounding his or her presence abroad which lead the officer to believe that the person detained had committed, was committing, or was about to commit a violation of this division. 
(b)  No person shall be temporarily detained under the provisions of subsection (a) longer than is reasonably necessary to effect the purpose of subsection (a). Such temporary detention shall not extend beyond the place where it was first effected or the immediate vicinity thereof. 
(c)  If at any time after the onset of the temporary detention authorized by subsection (a), grounds for arrest of that person shall appear, the person may be arrested. If after an inquiry into the circumstances which prompted the temporary detention or arrest, no grounds for the arrest of the person shall appear, he or she shall be released. 
(d)  Among the elements which may be considered by a police officer in determining that a person has committed, is committing, or is about to commit a violation of this division are: 
(1)  That such person is a known prostitute or panderer. 
(2)  That such person repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passersby in conversation; or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators or passengers by hailing, waving of arms or any other bodily gesture or by any other means. 
(3)  That such activity as described above, when observed by a law enforcement officer, taken as a whole, led the officer to reasonably conclude that a violation of this division has been committed, is being committed, or is about to be committed. 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 6, 10-24-79) 
Sec. 39-138. - Revocation of license of hotel, rooming house, etc. 
(a)  The license of any hotel, rooming house, boarding house or lodging house which, in whole or in part, is devoted to the business of prostitution or housing prostitutes engaged in prostitution shall be and become vacated and void upon conviction of any person controlling or being concerned in the conduct, control, management or operation of any such hotel, rooming house, boarding house or lodging house of such activity. 
(b)  In case any application shall be made for the granting of a license to the person who operated or conducted any hotel, rooming house, boarding house or lodging house after any license has been revoked under subsection (a), the revenue department shall examine into and investigate the license and shall issue the same only where satisfied, after such examination, that the applicant is of good moral character. If the revenue department shall refuse the license, an appeal shall be allowed to the city council from this action and it may act and grant the license or sustain the action of the revenue department, as it may see fit. 
(Ord. No. 41-125, § 5, 10-24-79) 
Secs. 39-139-39-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MATERIALS HARMFUL TO MINORS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Minors and intoxicating liquors, § 30-31 et seq.; minors and junk dealers, § 53-131 et seq. 

Sec. 39-151. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    City shall mean the city and its police jurisdiction. 
    Display shall mean to exhibit in a manner which induces or persuades an inspection of that which is exhibited for sale or rent. 
    Harmful to minors means that quality of any description or representation, in whatever form, of nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement or sado-masochistic abuse, when it: 
(1)  Predominantly appeals to the prurient, shameful or morbid interest of minors, and 
(2)  Is patently offensive to prevailing standards in the adult community as a whole with respect to what is suitable material for minors, and 
(3)  Is utterly without redeeming social importance for minors. 
    Knowingly means having general knowledge of or reason to know, or a belief or ground for belief which warrants further inspection or inquiry of both: 
(1)  The character and content of any material described in this article which is reasonably susceptible of examination by the defendant, and, 
(2)  The age of the minor; provided, however, that an honest mistake shall constitute an excuse from liability under this article if the defendant made a reasonable bona fide attempt to ascertain the true age of such minor. 
    Minor shall mean any person under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
    Motion picture shall mean movies projected from any size film. 
    Nudity shall mean the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area or buttocks with less than a full opaque covering, of the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any portion thereof below the top of the areola, or the depiction of covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. 
    Sado-masochistic abuse shall mean flagellation or torture by or upon a person clad in undergarments, a mask or bizarre costume, or the condition of being fettered, bound or otherwise physically restrained on the part of one so clothed. 
    Sexual conduct shall mean acts of masturbation, homosexuality, sexual intercourse or physical contact with a person's clothed or unclothed genitals, pubic area, buttocks, or, if such person be a female, breast. 
    Sexual excitement shall mean the condition of human male or female genitals when in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.1) 
Sec. 39-152. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating any provision of this article shall be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). Each day any violation of any provision of this article shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.6; Ord. No. 41-015, 1-4-72) 
Sec. 39-153. - Applicability. 
    The acts forbidden by this article shall not apply to a parent or legally constituted guardian who does such an act with reference to his own child, or to any judge, jury or attache of a court or any attorney or any member of a legislative body, municipal, state or federal, when such act is connected with the prosecution or investigation of a violation or possible violation of this article or any other law, or the consideration of legislation or proposed legislation designed to eliminate or reduce obscenity in any form. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.8) 
Sec. 39-154. - Selling, displaying, giving to, etc., minors, certain pictures, books, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to sell, loan, display, furnish, give to or purchase for a minor: 
(1)  Any picture, photograph, drawing, sculpture, motion picture film or similar visual representation or image of a person or portion of the human body which depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sado-masochistic abuse and which is harmful to minors, or 
(2)  Any book, pamphlet, magazine, printed matter however reproduced, or sound recording which contains any matter enumerated in subsection (1) of this section, or explicit and detailed verbal descriptions or narrative accounts of sexual excitement, sexual conduct or sado-masochistic abuse and which taken as a whole, is harmful to minors. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.2) 
Sec. 39-155. - Exhibiting or admitting, etc., minors to certain motion pictures, shows, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to exhibit for a monetary consideration to a minor or knowingly to sell to a minor an admission ticket or pass or knowingly to admit a minor for a monetary consideration to premises whereon there is exhibited a motion picture, show or other presentation which, in whole or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sado-masochistic abuse and which is harmful to minors. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.3) 
Sec. 39-156. - Minors misrepresenting age-To purchase, etc., harmful pictures, books, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for a minor person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that he is not a minor or is not under eighteen (18) years of age, and by means of such false representation buy, receive or otherwise obtain, or attempt to buy, receive or otherwise obtain any matter enumerated in section 39-154. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.4) 
Sec. 39-157. - Same-To gain admittance, etc., to harmful motion pictures, shows, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for a minor person, directly or indirectly, to falsely represent that he is not a minor or is not under eighteen (18) years of age, and by means of such false representation buy, receive or otherwise obtain, or attempt to buy, receive or otherwise obtain an admission ticket or pass to or otherwise gain admittance onto premises whereon there is exhibited a motion picture, show or other representation which, in whole or in part, depicts nudity, sexual conduct or sado-masochistic abuse and which, taken as a whole, is harmful to minors. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.5) 
Sec. 39-158. - Revocation or suspension of business license. 
    In addition to any other penalties provided for a violation of this article, the business license of any licensee of the city shall be subject to revocation or suspension pursuant to the terms of the license code of the city, which revocation may be effected by the governing body of the city whether the licensee has been arrested for a violation of any provision of this article or has been convicted of violating any provision of such article. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.7) 
Secs. 39-159-39-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - MODEL GLUE 

Sec. 39-171. - Defined. 
    The term "model glue," as used in this article, shall mean any glue or cement of the type commonly used in the building of model airplanes, boats and automobiles, or any similar substance which contains one (1) or more of the following volatile solvents: 
(1)  Acetone; 
(2)  Amyl acetate; 
(3)  Benzol or benzene; 
(4)  Butyl acetate; 
(5)  Butyl alcohol; 
(6)  Carbon tetrachloride; 
(7)  Chloroform; 
(8)  Cyclohexanone; 
(9)  Ethanol or ethyl alcohol; 
(10)  Ethyl acetate; 
(11)  Hexane; 
(12)  Isopropanol or isopropyl alcohol; 
(13)  Isopropyl acetate; 
(14)  Methyl "cellosolve" acetate; 
(15)  Methyl ethyl ketone; 
(16)  Methyl isobutyl ketone; 
(17)  Toluol or toluene; 
(18)  Trichloroethylene; 
(19)  Tricresyl phosphate; 
(20)  Xylol or xylene; 
or any other solvent, material, substance or chemical, or combination thereof, having the property of releasing toxic vapors. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.9) 
Sec. 39-172. - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this article, shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Ord. No. 41-108, 11-15-77) 
Sec. 39-173. - Smelling or inhaling fumes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally to smell or inhale the fumes of any type of model glue, or to induce any other person to do so, for the purpose of causing a condition of, or inducing symptoms of, intoxication, elation, euphoria, dizziness, excitement, irrational behavior, exhilaration, paralysis, stupefaction or dulling of the senses or nervous system, or for the purpose of, in any manner, changing, distorting or disturbing the audio, visual or mental processes; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the inhalation of any anesthesia for medical or dental purposes. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.10) 
Sec. 39-174. - Possession, purchase, sale, etc., for prohibited purposes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person intentionally to possess any type of model glue for the purpose of using the same in the manner prohibited by section 39-173. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally possess, buy, sell or otherwise transfer any type of model glue for the purpose of inducing or aiding any other person to violate the provisions of section 39-173 or subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.11) 
Sec. 39-175. - Sale or transfer to minors under seventeen. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly and intentionally to sell or otherwise transfer possession of any type of model glue to any minor under the age of seventeen (17) years for any purpose whatsoever, unless at the time of the sale or transfer of possession such minor shall be accompanied by his parent or guardian, as the case may be, and the written consent to such sale or transfer of such minor's parent or guardian shall be signed by such parent or guardian in the presence of the person making the sale or transfer. 
(b)  In such cases, the seller or transferrer shall make a written record of such transaction, showing the name, address, sex and age of the minor, as well as the name and address of the consenting parent or guardian, which record shall be kept available for inspection by the department of police for a period of at least one (1) year from the date of such transfer; provided, that such records need not be kept if the seller or transferrer retains the consent letters where such letters contain all of the required information, as herein set forth. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to furnish any such consent letter which purports to be signed by a parent or guardian, which consent letter, or the signature signed thereto, is false in any respect. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.12) 
Sec. 39-176. - Sale, etc., by wholesalers to persons not bona fide retailers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any wholesaler of merchandise to sell or transfer any quantity of model glue to any person whatsoever, who is not, or does not represent, a recognized bona fide retail dealer in merchandise customarily handling such product in the ordinary course of his business at a fixed location. If any such prohibited sale is made by any wholesaler, it shall constitute prima facie evidence of an intent to violate the provisions of section 39-173 and subsection (a) of section 39-174. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36.13) 
Sec. 39-177. - Retail sales by persons other than bona fide dealers; sales of more than one tube, etc., to one customer within twenty-four-hour period; unlawful display, etc., by retail dealers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the retail sale of model glue unless such person is a recognized bona fide retail dealer (at a fixed location) in merchandise, customarily handling such product in the ordinary course of his business. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any bona fide recognized retail dealer, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, to sell more than one (1) tube, or other minimum sized container, of model glue to any one (1) customer within any twenty-four-hour period; provided, that the provisions of this subsection do not apply to the sale of model glue together with a hobby or model kit, and further the provisions of this subsection do not apply to the sale or transfer of any model glue in regular sale or transfer between a retail dealer or wholesaler and a bona fide user of such glue for industrial purposes. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any bona fide recognized retail dealer, as defined in subsection (a) of this section, to keep, maintain or prominently display in his business establishment any stock or supply of model glue in such manner or place as to make the same accessible to customers, or other members of the public, without actually receiving the same directly from the retailer or his bona fide authorized representative. 
(Code 1965, § 41-37) 
Secs. 39-178-39-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CERTAIN EXPLOSIVE CHEMICALS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, Ch. 22; hazardous materials, Ch. 26. 

Sec. 39-181. - Territorial applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply both within the corporate limits of the city and outside the corporate limits of the city but within the police jurisdiction thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 41-50) 
Sec. 39-182. - Physician's prescription. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be applicable to the sale of any phosphorus (P), sodium (Na) or potassium chlorate (KClO 3 ) made in the filling of any prescription signed and issued by a duly licensed and practicing physician. 
(Code 1965, § 41-49) 
Sec. 39-183. - Permit to purchase phosphorus, sodium and potassium chlorate. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to sell or give away any phosphorus (P), sodium (Na) or potassium chlorate (KClO 3 ) without the purchaser or donee having first obtained from the city clerk, in the manner provided by this article, a permit to receive or purchase such phosphorus (P), sodium (Na) or potassium chlorate (KClO 3 ). 
(Code 1965, § 41-45) 
Sec. 39-184. - Prerequisites to issuance of permit. 
    The city clerk shall issue a permit for the purchase or the receiving of phosphorus (P), sodium (Na) or potassium chlorate (KClO 3 ) if the applicant for the permit files with him the following documents: 
(1)  A certificate by the director of the crime laboratory of the city and county to the effect that the applicant for the permit has satisfied him that the substance is to be used for a legal and proper purpose and indicating the amount which may be purchased or received. 
(2)  A verified application giving the name and address of the applicant, the location of the applicant's place of business, the amount of the substance applied for in stock or on hand, the amount of substance needed and the purpose for which such substance is to be used. 
(Code 1965, § 41-47) 
Sec. 39-185. - Possession without permit unlawful. 
    It shall be an offense against the city for any person to have in his possession any phosphorus (P), sodium (Na) or potassium chlorate (KClO 3 ) without having obtained a permit to purchase or receive it. 
(Code 1965, § 41-46) 
Sec. 39-186. - Record to be made by seller, etc. 
    No phosphorus (P), sodium (Na) or potassium chlorate (KClO 3 ) shall be sold or given away without the seller or donor being furnished with the certificate required by section 39-184 and without the seller or donor making a record in a bound book of the date of the transfer, the name, address, place of business and nature of the business of the transferee, the use to which it is to be put, the amount of the substance then said to be possessed by the transferee and the amount sold or given to the transferee on the date in question. This permanent record shall at all times be open to the inspection of members of the United States Coast Guard, the director of the crime laboratory of the city and county and to the city clerk or his designated agent. 
(Code 1965, § 41-48) 
Secs. 39-187-39-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MASKS 

Sec. 39-191. - Prohibited generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to appear in a mask in any street or other public place within the city or its police jurisdiction. 
(Code 1965, § 41-32) 
Sec. 39-192. - Appearing in mask for advertising purposes. 
    The prohibitions of this article shall not apply to any person appearing in the streets or public places of the city, at times other than during the carnival celebration, in mask, for advertising purposes, if such person has a permit from the mayor to so appear. 
(Code 1965, § 41-36) 
Sec. 39-193. - Persons and societies permitted to appear and parade in masks during Mardi Gras. 
(a)  Permission of mayor required. During the Mardi Gras or carnival celebration, commencing fourteen (14) days before Mardi Gras day and continuing until midnight of Mardi Gras day, the following persons and societies may appear in masks in any such street or other public place and may parade in masks in any such street or other public place and may parade through the streets of the city: Emperor Felix and his escort, the Comic Cowboys, Knights of Revelry, Krewe of Columbus, Infant Mystics, Order of Myths and any other society or association regularly organized solely for participation in the Mardi Gras or carnival celebration; provided, that no such society or association shall be permitted to appear or parade in any such street or other public place unless it shall, at least five (5) days before such appearance or parading, file with the mayor of the city a written application for a permit to so appear and parade, stating in such application the time when such society or association desires so to appear or parade, the route through the streets to be taken by its parade and the names of the persons of such society or association who will be in such parading party. The mayor shall determine upon the filing of such application whether the good order of the city will be preserved by granting the application and, in cases of doubt, shall confer with the other members of the city council before acting on such application. It is hereby prohibited and shall be unlawful for any society or association or any member thereof to appear or parade in any of such streets or other public places, in masks, without first obtaining a written permit from the mayor to do so, to be granted only upon a written application therefor as above set forth. 
(b)  Hours permitted; establishing identity upon request of police officer. No individual shall appear in mask in any street or other public place within the city or its police jurisdiction, except on Mardi Gras Day, and the three (3) days immediately prior thereto, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., unless such individual so appears as a member of one of the societies or associations whose appearance is provided for by subsection 39-193(a). Any individual appearing in mask pursuant to this section shall on demand from any police officer of this city, remove such mask and furnish to such officer his name, place of employment, if any, and his place of residence, and shall furnish to such police officer any document which would establish his identity. It shall be unlawful for any such individual to furnish false information or untrue documentary evidence of his identity. 
(c)  Exhibition of permit on demand; name, residence, etc., to be given. Any society or association appearing in any street or other public place within the city or its police jurisdiction, in mask, shall, on demand from any police officer of the city, produce or be required to produce its permit from the mayor for so appearing and any person appearing in any such street or other public place as a member of any such society or association shall, on demand of any police officer of the city, furnish to such officer his name and place of residence and the name of the society or association of which he is a member. 
(Code 1965, §§ 41-33-41-35; Ord. No. 41-092, 10-18-77) 
Secs. 39-194-39-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - MARDI GRAS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Barricades during Mardi Gras, § 21-41 et seq.; fire prevention, Ch. 22; public assemblies, Ch. 49. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 39-201. - Fireworks during Mardi Gras. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  For purposes of this section, the term "fireworks" is deemed to mean any type of explosive or noisemaking device using explosive material of any nature, including fireworks as defined by any agency of the federal, state or local government, and including any type device which is known as common fireworks, including trick noisemakers, toy novelties, toy smoke devices, sparklers, smoke balls, smoke novelty items, snappers, poppers, snap-pops, bang snaps, caps or any other device which will explode and/or make noise when ignited by flame, or will explode or make noise upon the use of pressure or percussion. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, the period observed as Mardi Gras shall run from 12:01 a.m. on the fourteenth day prior to Ash Wednesday to 6:00 a.m. on Ash Wednesday. 
(3)  For purposes of this section, "public" shall be defined as an area open to all persons, maintained by or for the people at large, including but not limited to public streets, sidewalks, alleyways and buildings. 
(b)  Sale; purchase; use. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to sell, purchase or use any type of fireworks as defined in this section in public in the city or its police jurisdiction, during the period observed as Mardi Gras. 
(c)  Minors. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any parent to allow a minor child to purchase or use fireworks, as defined in this section, in public in the city or its police jurisdiction during the period observed as Mardi Gras. 
(Ord. No. 41-077, §§ 1-3, 9-24-85) 
Sec. 39-202. - Opened glass containers in public places during Mardi Gras. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  For the purpose of this section, the period observed as Mardi Gras shall run from 12:01 a.m. on the fourteenth day prior to Ash Wednesday to 6:00 a.m. on Ash Wednesday. 
(2)  For the purposes of this section, an "opened glass" container is defined as: 
a.  Any drinking vessel made of glass excluding wrapped or packaged drinking glasses or cups which are merely being transported from one place to another; or 
b.  Any container made of glass upon which the seal has been broken. 
(3)  For the purposes of this section, "public" shall be defined as an area open to all, maintained by or for the people at large. 
(b)  Carrying or drinking from. It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or drink from any opened glass container in public in the city during the period observed as Mardi Gras. 
(c)  Owner's responsibility. It shall be unlawful for owners or employees of establishments which sell beverages in glass containers in the city knowingly to allow any person to leave the premises of the establishment carrying an opened glass container. 
(Ord. No. 41-088, §§ 1-5, 10-4-83) 
Cross reference- Litter, § 25-31 et seq.; intoxicating liquor, ch. 30. 
Sec. 39-203. - Pets and other animals at Mardi Gras parades and activities prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Whenever used in this section, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context, "pet" shall mean any animal, fowl, reptile, or any other such usual, unusual or exotic pet kept or owned by any person or persons attending or participating in the Mardi Gras celebration and related activities on the streets of the city and along designated parade routes. 
(2)  For purposes of this section, the period observed as Mardi Gras, upon adoption of this section, shall be that period beginning February 1, 1996 and extending to February 23, 1996, and each succeeding year thereafter shall run from 12:01 a.m. on the twentieth day prior to Ash Wednesday' to 6:00 a.m. on the Friday following Ash Wednesday. 
(b)  Unlawful to have pets on city streets along parade routes during the Mardi Gras activities. During the period of time specified herein, observed as the Mardi Gras period, it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person or persons who own or keep a pet of any kind or nature whatsoever to bring or allow any such pet to be brought onto the streets of the city when and where such Mardi Gras parades and/or other activities are conducted, whether uncontained, contained on a leash or otherwise contained. 
(c)  Exemptions. This section shall not apply to horses and/or mules or other such animals ridden, used to pull floats. or otherwise determined to be a part of any Mardi Gras parade or related activity being conducted on the streets of the city. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person who violates this section shall be punished by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), not including court costs and fees. 
(Ord. No. 39-027-2015 , 3-3-15) 
Secs. 39-204-39-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARADES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Parades generally, § 49-41 et seq. 

Sec. 39-211. - Mystic societies parades generally. 
(a)  All Mardi Gras mystic societies and organizations shall be allowed to parade on the streets of the city only along those parade routes and only on the dates and times specifically approved by the mayor. 
(b)  During that period of time designated by the mayor for the presentation of a street parade by Mardi Gras mystic societies and organizations, the streets along such route shall be, and they hereby are, reserved only for Mardi Gras parade purposes and such street shall be used only by those taking part in such parade. During those periods of time any other persons shall not enter in, on or upon those portions, sections or parts of the city streets established by the mayor as the official parade routes. All persons other than those participating or taking part in the parades shall remain on the curbs and sidewalks or upon other portions, sections or parts of designated city streets along the parade routes, but are not a part thereof. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to officials, officers, agents or employees of the city, county, state or federal government in the course of performing their official duties. 
(Code 1965, § 41-30) 
Sec. 39-212. - Advertising or display float following parade generally. 
    During the annual Mardi Gras parades of mystic societies in the city, no vehicle or advertising or display float not belonging to the mystic society then parading shall follow the parade of such society on the streets at a closer distance than three (3) blocks from the rear of such parade. During the progress of such parade it shall be unlawful for the driver or person in charge or control of any vehicle or advertising or display float not belonging to the mystic society then parading to drive such vehicle or advertising or display float on the streets closer than three (3) blocks to the rear of the last float in the parade of such mystic society or, with such vehicle or advertising or display float, to follow the parade of any mystic society on the streets without keeping at least three (3) blocks to the rear of such parade. 
(Code 1965, § 41-31) 
Sec. 39-213. - Vehicles and floats propelled by mules or other animals. 
    No vehicle or float propelled by the use of mules or other animals shall be allowed to participate in any Mardi Gras parade; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to an emblem float. 
(Code 1965, § 41-31.2) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, ch. 7. 
Sec. 39-214. - Running, etc., upon or across right-of-way of street being used as parade route. 
(a)  During the period of time beginning one (1) hour prior to the commencement of a Mardi Gras parade and ending one (1) hour after the end of such Mardi Gras parade, it shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to run upon and across any portion of the right-of-way, including, but not limited to, the sidewalk and neutral ground thereon, of any street being used as the route of a Mardi Gras parade. 
(b)  It shall further be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person, during the period of time commencing one (1) hour before the beginning of a Mardi Gras parade and ending one (1) hour following the conclusion of such Mardi Gras parade, to walk at faster than a normal pace and in such manner as to interfere with the peace, comfort, safety and health of other spectators, upon any part of a street right-of-way designated as the route of such Mardi Gras parade. 
(c)  Any person found guilty of violating any provision of this section shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to officials, officers, agents or employees of the city, county, state or federal government in the course of performing their official duties. 
(Code 1965, § 41-30.1) 
Secs. 39-215-39-220. - Reserved.

Sec. 39-221. - False advertisements generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly use, or knowingly cause to be used, any advertisement on radio, television, handbills or media of any kind when such advertisement contains facts, figures, information, pictures, drawings and similar items which are false and tend to mislead, and where such person uses or causes to be used such advertisement with knowledge that it contains facts, figures, information, pictures, drawings and similar items which are false and tend to mislead.

Sec. 39-222. - Soliciting patronage at railway or bus station. 
    Every hackman, cabman, taxicab driver or the driver of any other vehicle shall, at and about railway stations and bus stations, remain with his vehicle; and no person shall solicit the patronage of any arriving or departing passenger at any railway station or bus station within the city for himself or for any other person nor solicit patronage in the streets adjacent to such railway station or bus station in a loud or boisterous manner. 
(Code 1965, § 41-56)

Sec. 39-223. - Escort service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or operate in the city or in its police jurisdiction the business commonly known as an escort service, whereby male or female escorts are provided upon request, upon payment of a fee or charge. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit dating services which are lawfully licensed where the individuals neither pay nor receive pay for sexual services. 
(Code 1965, § 41-6.1)
