ARTICLE XII. - FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 41-057, adopted September 7, 1993, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion as art. XII, §§ 39-231-39-263 was at the discretion of the editor. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 39-231. - Purposes. 
(a)  The main purpose of this article is to reduce or eliminate the incidents of false fire alarms in the City of Mobile, Alabama. While alarm systems provide a vital service to residents, businesses and the entire City of Mobile, false fire alarms pose a safety hazard. They divert municipal employees from useful duties, causing a waste of municipal manpower and services. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to encourage alarm users and alarm businesses (sales, installation, customer service and/or monitoring) to properly maintain and operate alarm systems within the city by limiting unnecessary municipal department responses to false fire alarms. 
(c)  This article governs local alarm systems by providing for penalties for violation of this article along with enforcement procedures. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. I, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-232. - Appeals. 
(a)  Within thirty (30) calendar days from the date of receipt by the alarm user of any M.O.T. for a false fire alarm from the fire department, the alarm user has the right to file an appeal with the municipal court clerk's office which shall consist of a written request for a hearing before the environmental court judge on the matter. The request for a hearing shall be accompanied by a filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) which will be refunded to the alarm user if the false fire alarm is determined to have been genuine or beyond the control of the alarm user. 
(b)  The city environmental court judge shall hold a hearing within sixty (60) calendar days from the date the alarm user files request for a hearing with the municipal court clerk's office. The alarm user shall be given notice of the hearing and shall have an opportunity to present evidence upon his or her behalf, to cross-examine any witnesses, and to be represented by counsel. 
(c)  The decision of the environmental court judge shall be final; however, the alarm user, pursuant to state law, shall have the right to appeal such final decision to the Circuit Court of Mobile County, etc. 
(Ord. No. 41-051, Art. III, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 39-233-39-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE ALARM REGULATIONS (FIRE DEPARTMENT) 

Sec. 39-241. - Definitions. 
    [For purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings acsribed to them:] 
    Automatic telephone dialing device or digital alarm communicator alarm system means an alarm system which is activated by a signal or message and which automatically sends a prerecorded voice message or coded signal by microwave, telephone lines, or other mode of transmittal directly to the county 911 line or directly to the police or fire department, indicating the existence of an emergency situation that the alarm system is designated to detect. 
    Calendar year means from January l to December 31 of the existing calendar year. 
    Date of receipt means, for a residential user, the date that the return receipt accompanying any certified mailing of the notice required to be sent to the alarm user's premises pursuant to section 39-245(d) is signed or the date that any such notice is delivered to the alarm user personally or to any person fifteen (15) years of age or older residing with the alarm user after informing the person of the contents of the notice. For business alarm users, the term means the date the return receipt accompanying any certified mailing of the notice required to be sent to the alarm user's premises pursuant to section 39-245(d) is signed or the day any such notice is delivered to an officer, a director, a general partner or the proprietor of the business, or to any employee if an officer, a director, a general partner, or the proprietor is not present on the premises, after notifying the employee of the contents of the notice. 
    False fire alarm means the activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligent or intentional misuse of the alarm system by the fire alarm user or an employee whereby the fire or medical emergency does not in fact exist. False fire alarm does not include an alarm signal caused by violent conditions of nature or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm business operator or alarm user. Alarms resulting from the following conditions are not considered false fire alarms: 
(1)  Earthquake causing structural damage to the protected premises. 
(2)  Flooding of the protected premises due to overflow or natural drainage. 
(3)  Lightning bolt causing physical damage to the protected premises. 
(4)  Telephone line malfunction verified in writing to the City of Mobile by at least a first line telephone company supervisor or by fire department personnel on the scene of an alarm. 
(5)  Notification of the fire department before a unit is dispatched to investigate; that the alarm does not require a response. 
(6)  An alarm call on the mistaken belief that a fire or medical emergency exists. 
    Fire alarm system means any mechanical, electrical or radio-controlled device which is arranged, designed, or used to signal the occurrence in the City of Mobile of a fire or medical emergency requiring urgent attention, and to which fire or emergency medical personnel are expected to respond. Fire alarm systems include those through which public safety personnel are notified directly of such signals through central monitoring stations or are notified indirectly by way of third persons who monitor the alarm systems and who report such signals to the fire department. Fire alarm systems also include those designed to register a signal which is so audible, visible, or in other ways perceptible outside of a protected building, structure or facility as to notify persons in the neighborhood beyond the zoning lot where the signal is located who in turn may notify the fire department of the signal. The term does not include smoke detectors connected to an alarm system that is a part of a single-family or two-family structure. 
    Fire alarm user means the individual, including but not limited to any person, firm, corporation, partnership or any other entity who purchases, leases, contracts for, or obtains a fire or medical alarm system. 
    Fire Department means the Fire Department of the City of Mobile, Alabama and the City of Mobile's jurisdiction, including, but not limited to its Fire Suppression Services and Medical Services divisions. 
    Fire official means the fire chief or any other employee of the fire department designated to enforce the provisions of this article. 
    Premises means any building or structure or portion thereof protected by an alarm system. In the case of two (2) or more buildings or structures or portions thereof on the same property under the same ownership protected by alarm systems that ar not connected to a single control system, each building or structure or portion thereof shall be deemed to be separate and distinct premises. 
    Same premises means at the same building or structure or portion thereof protected by an alarm systems, without regard to alterations therein, if the identity of the alarm user has not materially changed since the last false fire alarm report. For example, but without limiting the meaning of this definition, a bona fide sale of the premises or the business therein to a third party or the replacement of a tenant by a different tenant shall be deemed a material change of the identity of the alarm user. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 1, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-242. - Liability of city. 
    The city and any of its agents and employees shall have no liability or responsibility for the operation or effectiveness of any alarm system and shall not be subject to any claims, demands or actions which may arise out of or in connection with the failure to respond to any alarm. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 2, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-243. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  False fire alarms are expressly prohibited in the City of Mobile, Alabama, pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(b)  No person shall install or operate an audible alarm system which emits a sound which is similar to that of an emergency siren or civil defense warning system. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to install or maintain an automatic telephone dialing device or digital alarm communicator alarm system within the city. 
(d)  Upon activation of an alarm system and a request for assistance by the fire department no fire alarm user or other person listed with the fire department, pursuant to section 39-248, (Required equipment/information), paragraph (3)a., shall fail or refuse to respond to the premises where the alarm occurred after being requested to do so by the City of Mobile Central Dispatch. Any failure to respond to the premises within thirty (30) minutes after requested to do so shall be deemed a failure to respond. Failure to respond shall be in violation of this article and shall subject the individual(s) responsible for responding to a municipal fine in the amount of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(e)  It shall be unlawful to install or maintain an alarm system that does not have an auxiliary power supply that activates in the event of a power failure or electrical outage. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 3, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-244. - Penalty. 
(a)  If any fire alarm user produces a false fire alarm in any calendar year, the fire official shall provide a written courtesy notice of this fact, by certified mail or hand delivery to the individual. Said notice letter may request the false fire alarm user to take corrective action in regard to the false fire alarm, additionally the letter shall inform the false fire alarm user of the city's fine schedule for false fire alarms. 
(b)  Upon receiving the fourth false fire alarm during a calendar year, the fire official shall issue a municipal offense ticket (M. O. T.), as provided in chapter 1, article II of the City Code of Mobile; however, a M.O.T. could be issued after the first false fire alarm at the discretion of the fire official based upon safety considerations. 
(c)  Any subsequent violation of this section within the same calendar year of the issuance of the first municipal offense ticket shall be considered a separate violation of this section, and shall result in a second separate municipal offense ticket being issued, thereby mandating environmental court prosecution. In such event the mandatory M.O.T. fine for violation of this article shall not be less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). This article provides for quasi-civil violations of this municipal ordinance to be punished with the issuance of a municipal offense ticket, pursuant to chapter 1, article II of the City Code of Mobile, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 4, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-245. - Response to false fire alarms; issuance of courtesy warnings and citations. 
(a)  Whenever an alarm system is activated within the city's jurisdiction, thereby requiring a response to the premises, the fire official on the scene shall inspect the premises, investigate the cause for the alarm, and determine whether or not the response was in fact required. 
(b)  If the fire official determines the fire alarm to have been false, the fire official shall prepare a false fire alarm report and written notice shall be issued to the fire alarm user by certified mail or hand delivery. 
(c)  Also, if the fire department determines a fire alarm to have been false, the fire official may, if a safety threat exists, require the fire alarm user to obtain written certification from a licensed alarm company that the company has inspected the system and that any defects of design, installation or operation of the alarm system, which are identifiable as the cause of the false fire alarm, have been corrected. 
(d)  The issuance of a courtesy letter of warning to the alarm user is not intended to create any rights of the alarm user. The city has the authority to issue a M.O.T. citation rather than a letter of warning after the first false fire alarm response to premises. The issuance of a letter of warning is merely a courtesy offered by the fire department to induce the alarm user to take corrective actions to prevent future false fire alarms. 
(e)  The fire official shall have the right to inspect any alarm system upon request, to determine whether the alarm system is in proper working order and in compliance with this article. 
(f)  If fire officials respond to the same premises more than once during any twenty-four-hour period, only one (1) false fire alarm shall be charged against the alarm user, unless evidence exists that the alarm user is purposely harassing the fire department with false fire alarm calls; in such circumstance each false fire alarm call is a separate violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 5, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-246. - Permit/registration required; expiration; fees. 
(a)  Every fire/medical alarm installation company shall: 
(1)  Obtain an installation permit, fee fifty dollars ($50.00), from the fire department for all alarm systems required by the Fire Code of the City of Mobile. 
(2)  Supply the fire department with evidence of a City of Mobile business license. 
(3)  Supply the fire department with evidence of insurance in the comprehensive amount of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) per occurrence. 
(4)  Every required alarm system must have installation plans approved by the fire department. 
a.  Plans and specifications for automatic or manual fire alarm systems indicating the location and number of all sending stations including automatic detection devices and signals with specifications of the type, construction, and operation of the system shall be submitted for approval prior to installation of equipment or wiring. Plans shall include location of the annunciator panel with appropriate zoning nomenclature. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 6, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-247. - Adequate instructions; copies of regulations. 
(a)  Every alarm business selling, leasing, or furnishing to any user of an alarm system which is installed on the premises located in the area subject to this article shall furnish the user with instructions that provide information to allow the user to operate the alarm system properly, and to obtain proper service with the alarm system at any time. 
(b)  The fire department shall have copies of this article available for review at the central station of the fire department, 701 St. Francis Street, upon request. 
(Ord. No. 41-057, Art. II, § 7, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-248. - Required equipment/information. 
(a)  Any newly acquired fire alarm system, or any existing fire alarm system which requires updating or modification following the date of the passage of this article, shall be required to: 
(1)  Be installed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association standards currently adopted as the Fire Code of the City of Mobile. 
(2)  To have an automatic audible alarm system cutoff within fifteen (15) minutes of activation for those systems using an audible alarm. 
(3)  Provide emergency access to the protected facility pursuant to one (1) of the three (3) listed criteria, as follows: 
a.  User must provide to the central station or answering service the names and telephone numbers of at least three (3) persons who can respond to the premises where the alarm occurred within thirty (30) minutes of being notified at any time with the keys to the premises and the alarm system. This list of names and telephone numbers shall be kept current at all times. The same information shall be supplied to the fire department upon request. Any user of a system other than a fire department central alarm station must supply the same information to the fire department upon request. 
1.  Failure to respond within thirty (30) minutes after the Mobile fire department attempts to notify key holder shall be a violation of the article and shall subject the individual responsible to a fine in the amount of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) by the issuance of a municipal offense ticket and prosecution in the environmental division of the city's municipal court. 
b.  If the alarm company agrees, it must have one (1) of its representatives respond to the premises where the alarm occurred at any time, with the keys to the premises and alarm system. 
1.  Under this alternative it is still ultimately the owner of the alarm systems responsibility to have keys available within thirty (30) minutes after attempted notification by the Mobile Fire Department. Failure to do so shall be a violation of the article and shall subject the individual responsible to a fine in the amount of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00) by the issuance of a municipal offense ticket and prosecution in the environmental division of the city's municipal court. 
c.  The user shall install on the outside of the premises a lock box that only the fire department has a key to, which has also been approved by the fire official. This box must contain the keys to the premises and the alarm system. 
1.  If the alarm owner chooses the third option of installing a secured lock box and the Mobile Fire Department responds to an alarm; then the Mobile Fire Department will immediately notify the alarm owner and advise him of entry and apparent cause of alarm, such as fire or false fire alarm. In the event of a false fire alarm, the Mobile Fire Department will leave the building secured and the owner will be responsible to reset all alarms as soon as possible. 
(4)  All audible alarm systems shall have a sign or notice posted on or near the audible device with the name and telephone number of the person/or persons responsible for service and maintenance of the system. The notice shall be conspicuously posted and readable from ground level. 
(5)  Tools and keys required to reset alarm system shall be maintained on premises. 
(6)  Any alarm system with a zone display panel must have a diagram posted near alarm panel describing location of zones. 
(7)  Every newly installed required alarm system shall be approved by the fire official and the installer shall furnish to the fire department a fire alarm system certification as described in the Fire Code of the City of Mobile (NFPA 72). 
(Ord. No. 39-057, Art. II, § 8, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-249. - Response to alarms. 
(a)  Whenever a fire alarm is activated in the City of Mobile thereby requiring an emergency response to the location by the fire department, the fire department personnel at the scene of the activated fire alarm system shall inspect the area protected by the system and shall determine whether the emergency response was in fact required as indicated by the alarm system or whether the alarm signal was a false fire alarm pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(b)  If the fire department personnel at the scene of the activated fire alarm system determines the alarm to have been false, said personnel shall make a written report of the false fire alarm, a notification of which shall be certified mailed or hand delivered to the alarm user pursuant to the terms of this article, advising the fire alarm user of the occurrence of a false fire alarm a date, time and location specified in the notice. 
(c)  The fire official or duly authorized designee shall have the right to inspect any alarm system on the premises to which a response has been made at the time of the activation of the fire alarm or he may cause an inspection of such system to be made at any reasonable time thereafter, by appointment, with the owner of the property. The fire official shall notify the fire alarm user and any alarm company involved so a representative may be present at the time of inspection. 
(Ord. No. 39-057, Art. II, § 9, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-250. - Notification of alarms. 
(a)  Alarm signals initiated by manual fire alarm boxes, automatic fire detectors, waterflow from the automatic sprinkler system, actuation of other extinguishing, fire or medical emergency alerting systems shall be treated as emergency fire alarms for the purposes of this article. 
(b)  Any monitored, proprietary or central, fire alarm system shall: 
(1)  Within ninety (90) seconds retransmit such an alarm signal to the City of Mobile's central dispatch through approved non-E-911 telephone lines so the proper emergency equipment may be dispatched. 
(2)  Notify the fire alarm user, by a method listed in subsection (a) of this section, in the quickest possible manner. 
(c)  Trouble signals: 
(1)  Monitored alarms: 
a.  Monitoring companies shall immediately dispatch a runner to investigate trouble signal and notify the owner of alarm of the status of the situation. 
b.  The equipment owner shall contact an alarm service or maintenance company and have the trouble with the alarm system cleared within seventy-two (72) hours. 
(2)  Unmonitored fire alarm: 
a.  Owner shall immediately investigate cause of the trouble signal, and shall have an alarm system maintenance company repair the system, as soon as possible, but in no event shall the repair of the system take longer than seventy-two (72) hours. 
(3)  Trouble signals shall not be treated as a fire alarm requiring emergency response by the Mobile Fire Department, pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 39-057, Art. II, § 10, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 39-251. - Grace period; new installations. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any new installation or modification of alarm systems for the first thirty (30) days following completion of the installation or system modification. Users installing a new system or making substantial modifications to an existing system shall be entitled to a grace period during which false fire alarms generated by such system shall be deemed non-false fire alarms. This grace period shall cease thirty (30) days after installation or modification of an alarm system. 
(Ord. No. 39-057, Art. II, § 11, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 39-252-39-260. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - CURFEW FOR MINORS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 39-045-2011, §§ I-V and VII, adopted October 4, 2011, have been treated as repealing former art. XIII, §§ 39-261-39-264, and adding a new art. XIII. Former art. XIII pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 39-039, adopted May 21, 2002. 
Cross reference- Civil emergencies, § 39-84 et seq. 

Sec. 39-261. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the following meanings: 
    Curfew center means a place to temporarily maintain custody of a minor prior to release to a parent, legal guardian or legal custodian or, if appropriate, to the Strickland Youth Center or such other place designated by the juvenile court. The curfew center shall be located at the Crisis Center at the Strickland Youth Center unless and until a more suitable location is proposed by the mayor and approved by the council. 
    Curfew hours means: 
(1)  Nighttime curfew hours: 
a.  For all areas of the city except that area defined as the "downtown entertainment district": 
1.  11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday until 6:00 a.m. of the following day; 
2.  12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. on any Saturday or Sunday. Provided, that regardless of the day of the week upon which it falls, on each holiday recognized by the city, the evening curfew hours for the night before the holiday and the morning curfew hours for the holiday shall both begin at 12:00 a.m. (midnight) and shall extend until 6:00 a.m.; 
b.  For that area defined as the "downtown entertainment district": 10:00 p.m. on any day until 5:00 a.m. on the following day. The curfew applicable to the downtown entertainment district shall not apply on New Year's Eve, during "Bayfest," and during Mardi Gras. 
(2)  Daytime curfew hours: 9:00 a.m. until 2:30 p.m. on any Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday or Friday during which Mobile County Public Schools are in session. 
    Downtown entertainment district means the area located in downtown Mobile and bounded as follows: on the south by Government Street from its intersection with Water Street to its intersection with Dearborn Street, thence by Dearborn Street from its intersection with Government Street to its intersection with Conti Street, thence by Conti Street from its intersection with Dearborn Street to its intersection with Washington Avenue; on the east by Water Street from its intersection with Government Street to its intersection with St. Joseph Street; on the north by St. Joseph Street from its intersection with Water Street to its intersection with St. Louis Street, thence by St. Louis Street from its intersection with St. Joseph Street to its intersection with Washington Avenue; and on the west by Washington Avenue from its intersection with St. Louis Street to its intersection with Conti Street. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means a privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. 
    Guardian means: 
(1)  A natural person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  A public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
    In session means the status of a school during the fall or spring term when students are required to attend the school. A school is not in session during its summer break, during any holiday or any other scheduled general student vacation day or part of a day observed by the school. 
    Minor means any person who has not yet reached his or her eighteenth birthday (or for purposes of the daytime curfew hours, his or her seventeenth birthday), who has not been emancipated under state law. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership or corporation operating, managing or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  A natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of another person; or 
(2)  At least eighteen (18) years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
    Public place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to streets, highways and the common areas of school, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities and shops. 
    Remain means to: 
(1)  Linger or stay; or 
(2)  Fail to leave when requested to do so by a police officer or owner, or operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
Provided, however, that law enforcement officers shall have discretion as to whether to request a minor to leave a public place prior to commencing an enforcement action under this section without making such a request. 
    Serious bodily injury means physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, permanent disfigurement, or the protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(Ord. No. 39-045-2011, § I, 10-4-11; Ord. No. 39-036-2012, § 1, 11-6-12) 
Sec. 39-262. - Offenses. 
(a)  Minors. A minor commits an offense if he or she is in or remains in a public place during curfew hours. A minor or any other "child" as defined in the Code of Alabama 1975 § 12-15-102 subject to the exclusive jurisdiction of the juvenile court who is adjudicated by the juvenile court as having violated this section shall be subject to the maximum penalties, if any, provided by state law for status offenses by juveniles, and shall be subject to the orders, care, and rehabilitation authority of the juvenile court. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, the juvenile court is authorized in its discretion to order payment of a fine of up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) and to order any other disposition authorized by the Code of Alabama 1975, § 12-15-215 or otherwise provided by state law. 
(b)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he or she intentionally, recklessly, knowingly or negligently permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the city during curfew hours, in violation of this article. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he or she knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours, in violation of this article. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall apply to minors who are suspended or expelled from school, unless they are emancipated under state law. 
(e)  A minor who is taught by a certified teacher pursuant to § 16-28-5; or enrolled in a church school as defined in § 16-28-1(2); or who is exempt from attending public school under § 16-28-6; or who is otherwise exempted from the public and private school systems in compliance with state law, and the minor's parent or guardian, are not in violation of the daytime curfew hours if the minor is in or remains in a public place with the permission of the parent or guardian. 
(f)  A minor who is engaged in interstate travel is not in violation of this article. 
(g)  A minor who is exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly is not in violation of this article. 
(h)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 39-045-2011, § II, 10-4-11) 
Sec. 39-263. - Defenses. 
(a)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 39-262, that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
(2)  On a lawful errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any unnecessary detour or stop; 
(3)  Engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, by a direct route without any unnecessary detour or stop; 
(4)  Involved in an emergency; 
(5)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence, except that this defense does not apply to a violation of the daytime curfew hours; 
(6)  Attending an official school activity, religious activity, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, by a direct route without any unnecessary detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the city, a civic organization, or another similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(7)  Married or had been married; 
(8)  Attending a bona fide work-study program recognized by the United States Department of Education or any public school system, or going to or returning home from such a program by a direct route without any unnecessary detour or stop and within one (1) hour of the commencement or termination of the work-study activity; 
(9)  A student enrolled in a bona fide college, university, or other institution of higher education, or a student enrolled in a bona fide vocational, technical, or other similar school intended to prepare the student for employment; 
(10)  Involved in receiving health care services, or traveling to or from locations where health care services are provided within one (1) hour of the commencement or termination of such health care services. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under section 39-262(c) of this article that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present on the premises of an establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under this article for a violation of the daytime curfew hours that: 
(1)  The school in which the minor was enrolled or otherwise required to attend was not in session; 
(2)  The minor was on the premises of the school in which the minor was enrolled or otherwise required to attend; 
(3)  The minor was participating in a school-approved work study program, or was going to the work study program or returning to home or school from the work-study program without any unnecessary detour or stop; 
(4)  The minor was on a lunch break from a school that permits an off campus lunch program; 
(5)  The minor was on an excused absence from the school in which the minor was enrolled or otherwise required to attend and had permission from a school official; or 
(6)  The minor was a high school graduate or had received a high school equivalency certificate. 
(Ord. No. 39-045-2011, § III, 10-4-11) 
Sec. 39-264. - Enforcement, procedures and reporting. 
(a)  Before taking any enforcement action under this section, a law enforcement officer shall have the discretionary authority to make inquiry of the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place, for the purposes of determining probable cause and whether any defense applies. A law enforcement officer shall have all discretion provided by state or federal law to determine whether to do any of the following: 
(1)  Issue a verbal warning and release the minor; 
(2)  Release the minor to a parent, guardian, legal custodian of the minor or other suitable person able to provide supervision and care for the minor and issue verbal counsel and warning as may be appropriate; 
(3)  Transport the minor to the curfew center; or 
(4)  Take such other discretionary, lawful action which will in the judgment of the law enforcement officer protect the best interests of the minor. 
(b)  When a minor has been transported to the curfew center, reasonable attempts shall be made to notify the minor's parent or legal guardian as soon as possible to report to the curfew center to pick up the minor. At the curfew center, a law enforcement officer will make a reasonable attempt to do one (1) or more of the following within three (3) hours of the minor's detention at the curfew center: 
(1)  Issue a verbal warning and release the minor; 
(2)  Release the minor to a parent, guardian, legal custodian of the minor or other suitable person able to provide supervision and care for the minor and issue verbal counsel and warning as may be appropriate; 
(3)  Refer and transport the minor to the Strickland Youth Center; 
(4)  File an appropriate petition in juvenile court for violation of this article; 
(5)  File an appropriate request with the state department of human resources to conduct an investigation; or 
(6)  Take such other discretionary, lawful action which will in the judgment of the law enforcement officer protect the best interests of the minor. 
(c)  Enforcement of this article against a minor shall be made by petition filed in juvenile court. Enforcement of this article against a parent, guardian or against an owner, operator or employee of a business establishment shall be by issuing a uniform nontraffic citation and complaint ("UNTCC") enforceable in municipal court. When more than one (1) minor under the control of the same parent or guardian is found in violation of the provisions of this section in the same act or incident, that parent or custodian shall be issued no more than one (1) citation for that particular occurrence. 
(d)  This section shall not be interpreted in a manner which would affect or diminish the immunity or discretionary authority, conferred by the state and federal law on law enforcement officers and cities. 
(Ord. No. 39-045-2011, § IV, 10-4-11) 
Sec. 39-265. - Penalties. 
(a)  Violation by a minor. A violation by a minor is subject to the jurisdiction of the juvenile court and penalties are set forth in subsection 39-262(a) of this article. 
(b)  Other violations. 
(1)  The uniform nontraffic citation and complaint ("UNTCC") shall be the charging instrument for a violation of subsection 39-262(b) or (c) of this article. 
(2)  The first violation shall be punishable by a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(3)  The second violation within one (1) year and all subsequent violations thereafter shall be punishable by a fine of up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment of up to six (6) months or by both fine and imprisonment. 
(4)  In sentencing violations of this article, the municipal court may consider a suspended sentence, probation, community service, or, in lieu of or in addition to any penalty that may be imposed, ordering the violator to obtain counseling or attend classes to improve parenting and child raising skills. 
(Ord. No. 39-045-2011, § V, 10-4-11) 
Sec. 39-266. - Effective date, sunset, and extension. 
    This article shall be in full force and effect from and after its adoption and publication as required by law, as follows: 
(1)  The night time curfew hours applicable to the "downtown entertainment district" shall be effective immediately, and shall remain in effect unless and until changed by the council; 
(2)  The night time curfew hours applicable to all areas except the "downtown entertainment district" shall be effective from and after 11:00 p.m. on November 1, 2011, and shall remain in effect until 12:00 a.m. on December 31, 2014, unless extended thereafter by ordinance duly adopted by the council; 
(3)  The day time curfew hours shall be effective from and after 12:00 a.m. on January 1, 2012, and shall remain in effect until 12:00 a.m. on December 31, 2014, unless extended thereafter by ordinance duly adopted by the council. 
(Ord. No. 39-045-2011, § VII, 10-4-11; Ord. No. 39-035-2012, 11-6-12) 
Chapter 40 - PARKING LOTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Off-street parking and off-street truck loading, § 64-6. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 40-1. - Lighting requirements for commercial lots. 
(a)  Every commercial parking lot within the city, where vehicles are permitted to park in the lot for a fee charged and where one (1) or more persons are in attendance and on duty on the lot during business hours of the lot, shall be equipped with lights so that the average footcandle level of the entire overall surface area of such parking lot shall be not less than two (2) footcandles and so that the lowest footcandle value at any point on the surface of the parking lot shall not be less than one-half of one (1) footcandle. 
(b)  Every commercial parking lot within the city, where vehicles are permitted to park in the lot for a fee charged, which is unattended during business hours (or is operated by mechanical means with no person in attendance), shall be equipped with lights so that the average footcandle level of the entire overall surface area of such parking lot shall be not less than one (1) footcandle and so that the lowest footcandle value at any point on the surface of the parking lot shall not be less than one-fourth of one (1) footcandle. 
(Code 1965, § 42-1; Ord. No. 42-061, 6-24-80) 
Cross reference- Illumination of uses, § 64-4. 
Sec. 40-2. - Duty of operators and employees to move vehicles to lighted portion of parking lot. 
    Every parking lot operator within the city, and all employees in every parking lot within the city, shall, prior to leaving such lot unattended at the close of each business day, move all motor vehicles then located in such parking lot to that portion of the parking lot which is in a well-lighted condition. 
(Code 1965, § 42-2) 
Secs. 40-3-40-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PAVING, RESURFACING OR CHANGING GRADE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Land disturbing activities, § 17-121 et seq; Parking lots, § 64-4. 

Sec. 40-21. - Permit required. 
    Any person, firm or corporation desiring to pave, resurface or otherwise change an existing grade elevation for the purpose of creating a vehicular parking lot, or lay in connection with the parking lot any underground rainwater drainage pipe not in or under a building, may do so after first obtaining a permit from the inspection services department of the city for this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 1, 2-16-72) 
Sec. 40-22. - Permit fees. 
    The fee for issuance of such permits shall be as follows: 
Parking areas not to exceed 10,000 feet ..... $ 75.00 
Parking areas from 10,000 to 50,000 feet ..... 100.00 
Parking areas in excess of 50,000 feet ..... 200.00 
Underground drainage only ..... 75.00 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 7, 2-16-71; Ord. No. 42-062, 5-11-82) 
Sec. 40-23. - Certain lots exempt. 
    Vehicular parking lots attendant to sites occupied by one- or two-family residential houses are hereby exempt from this article. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 2, 2-16-72) 
Sec. 40-24. - Plot plan-Required. 
    The director of the inspection services department shall not issue a permit for the paving of any parking area until the applicant has submitted a plot plan showing original and final elevations, including provisions for underground drainage, and driveway entrances and exits, to abutting streets. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 3, 2-16-72) 
Sec. 40-25. - Same-Criteria. 
    Such plot plan shall be approved by the city engineer to allow for adaptations to and efficient operation of the city's pre-existing storm drainage system and to attempt to attenuate damages occurring to adjacent properties attendant to drainage variations. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 4, 2-16-72) 
Sec. 40-26. - Waiver of certain property owners; when required. 
    Graded or paved areas shall be so constructed that rainwater will not flow across or on public rights-of-way, or adjoining properties, unless written waivers signed by and binding the affected adjacent property owners and their successors and releasing the applicant from possible damages due to changes in the storm drainage resulting from the parking lot area put on record in the probate court of the county. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 5, 2-16-72) 
Sec. 40-27. - Underground drainage. 
    Underground drainage shall be required where city system storm drains are available or as found necessary by the city engineer and shall be of sufficient size and installed in a proper manner to carry off anticipated rainwater, and such drainage shall be provided before hard surfacing materials are permanently placed on the site. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 5, 2-16-72) 
Cross reference- Drainage and flood control, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 40-28. - Inspection of site. 
    The city engineer or the inspection services department shall check each site for which a permit has been issued to ensure that grading, drainage and paving are in compliance with the approved plot plan. 
(Ord. No. 42-038, § 6, 2-16-72) 
Chapter 41 - PARKS AND PLAYGROUNDS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Cultural facilities, ch. 15. 

Sec. 41-1. - Duty of superintendent, etc. 
    It is the duty of the parks superintendent and the employees under his supervision to protect the grounds and the trees, shrubs, flowers, ornaments, curbing, seats and other appendages from depredation, to cut the grass as needed, to keep the avenues clean and to maintain good order in all of the parks and playgrounds of the city. 
(Code 1965, § 43-1) 
Sec. 41-2. - Police to maintain order, etc. 
    The police of the city shall maintain order and decorum in the public parks and public places of the city and prevent tramps, loafers and disreputable persons from remaining therein. The police are hereby invested with the power and authority to order any person to vacate and leave such park or public place whenever, in the judgment of the chief of police or the policeman on duty at that time, it is necessary or proper for such order to be given. 
(Code 1965, § 43-2) 
Sec. 41-3. - Depredations. 
    Any depredation in any square, park or public place, upon a monument, fence, gate, tree, shrub, flowers, seat or other appendage or appurtenance thereof, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 43-3) 
Cross reference- Malicious injury to property, § 39-72. 
Sec. 41-4. - Burning grass, etc. 
    Any person who burns or sets fire to the grass, shrubbery or undergrowth in any park or public place in the city shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(Code 1965, § 43-4) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 41-5. - Loitering or congregating in parks or playgrounds. 
    It shall be unlawful for persons to loiter in the parks or playgrounds of the city or to congregate in numbers therein when the object of such loitering or congregating is patently for the purpose of doing mischief by creating unnecessary noises, using obscene language, telling indecent stories or using the parks and playgrounds contrary to the use for which they were intended. 
(Code 1965, § 43-5) 
Cross reference- Loitering and prowling, § 39-90. 
Sec. 41-6. - Vehicles. 
    Automobiles, motorcycles and other vehicles shall not be operated in any public park of the city except on streets or roadways maintained therein for such purpose. 
(Code 1965, § 43-6) 
Sec. 41-7. - Development or redevelopment of park property. 
    Upon recommendation by the mayor, his duly authorized representative, or the parks superintendent, the city council shall consider the development of any undeveloped park property, or anticipated changes in the use of developed parks, or a portion thereof, and approve or disapprove of the development or redevelopment after a public hearing. The city shall post with conspicuous signs the area of the park to be affected. The signs shall indicate the future use of the property and shall remain on the subject property for a period of not less than two (2) weeks prior to a public hearing held to consider the development or change of use. Not less than two (2) weeks prior to the public hearing, reasonable efforts will be made to notify by mail property owners abutting the park property affected by development or change of use and property owners whose property will be directly affected. The signs placed on the subject property, and the notices mailed to the property owners, will, in addition to stating the nature of the proposed development or changes of use of the subject park property, state the date of the public hearing. At the public hearing the council shall receive comment from the city parks superintendent, or his duly authorized representative, and from members of the public in favor of and opposed to the development or change of use; and after concluding the public hearing the council shall adopt a resolution either approving or disapproving the development or change of use. This section does not modify, supersede or rescind the requirement of any other ordinance, the requirements of which must be complied with before initiating demolition or construction on park property. 
(Ord. No. 43-020, 3-19-91) 
Cross reference- Planning and development, Ch. 44; zoning, Ch. 64. 
Sec. 41-8. - Disabled. 
    All parks, playground and picnic area requirements set forth in the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 shall be observed by all city departments. 
(Ord. No. 01-044, § 1, 7-6-93) 
Sec. 41-9. - Mobile tennis center advisory board. 
(a)  There is hereby created the "Mobile tennis center advisory board." 
(b)  The Mobile tennis center advisory board shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the city council. The term of each member shall be for three (3) years. Members shall serve at the pleasure of the city council, and may be removed as members of the board by the city council at any time with or without cause. 
(c)  The director of the city's parks and recreation department, the director of the Copeland-Cox Tennis Center, and the director of tennis and tournament promotion shall be ex officio members of the board, and shall have the authority to attend all meetings of the board and be recognized and enter into all discussions on matters before the board; however, such ex officio members shall not vote on any matters considered by the board. 
(d)  Members of the Mobile tennis center advisory board shall serve without compensation. 
(e)  The Mobile tennis center advisory board shall act in an advisory capacity to the city council in connection with the operation of the city's three (3) tennis centers (the Copeland-Cox Tennis Center on Gaillard Drive, the Cottage Hill Tennis Center in Medal of Honor Park, and the Lyons Park Tennis Center in Lyons Park), and shall have the power and authority to: 
(1)  Observe the operation, management, affairs, condition, and business transactions of the tennis centers and all appurtenant facilities; to report said operations to the city council; and to make recommendations to the city council for the orderly and efficient operation and maintenance of the tennis centers. 
(2)  Receive and review reports of tennis center activities, anticipated activities, and finances. 
(3)  The Mobile tennis center advisory board and its members shall have no authority, direct or indirect, to engage in the management or operation of the tennis centers. 
(4)  The Mobile tennis center advisory board and its members shall have no authority, direct or indirect, to give orders to any employees of the city. 
(f)  The board shall elect as its officers a chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary. A quorum of the board shall consist of four (4) members. 
(g)  The board shall meet quarterly, and at such other times as may be necessary and convenient. All meetings of the board shall be held at the Copeland - Cox Tennis Center, and shall be conducted in accordance with the Alabama Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 15-031-2011, §§ 1-7, 6-21-11) 
Sec. 41-10. - Citizens' parks and recreation advisory committee. 
(a)  There is hereby established a committee known as the citizens' parks and recreation advisory committee. 
(b)  The citizens' parks and recreation advisory committee shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city council on issues related to the acquisition, development, improvement, maintenance, and operation of the city's parks and recreation facilities. The committee is tasked with the mission of meeting with interested citizens and organizations to receive public input on parks and recreation facilities. The committee shall serve as a central point of communications between the council and all citizens and organizations that have an interest in the acquisition, development, improvement, maintenance, and operation of the city's parks and recreation facilities. The committee shall promote public participation by meeting with interested citizens and organizations, and after consideration of the input received from interested citizens and organizations, the committee shall make recommendations to the council for the improvement and enhancement of the city's parks and recreation facilities. 
(c)  The committee will be composed of: 
(1)  Seven (7) members appointed by the city council; 
(2)  One (1) student member from an area secondary school appointed by the council; and 
(3)  One (1) senior citizen member appointed by the council. 
All nominees shall be placed on the council agenda for approval. Since this committee is being created to advise the council, no member of the council shall be appointed to or shall serve on this committee in any capacity. 
(d)  Members of the committee must have the following qualifications: 
(1)  They must be resident citizens of the city. 
(2)  They must have an interest in parks and recreation, and a commitment to the vital role that parks and recreation services play in the quality of life of area residents and visitors. 
(3)  They must have a commitment to seek input from neighborhoods, organizations, and citizens and to apply this information to improve and enhance parks and recreation services. 
(4)  They may not be employed by the city. 
(5)  They may not have any direct financial interest in city business, and may not be officers or directors of any organization that receives funding from the city or that has a performance contract with the city. 
(e)  The members of the committee first appointed shall serve a term that will expire on November 1, 2015. Thereafter, members of the committee shall serve for terms of two (2) years, except for the student member and the senior citizen member who shall be appointed to serve for terms of one (1) year. A member of the committee may be removed with or without cause by the council. 
Vacancies for any reason shall be filled in the same manner as their appointment, and such appointments shall be for the unexpired term of the member replaced. 
The city's director of parks and recreation shall be an ex officio, non-voting member of the committee. 
(f)  Members of the committee shall serve without compensation. 
(g)  The committee shall elect a chair and a vice-chair from among the members of the committee. Such officers shall be elected for a term of one (1) year. The chair shall preside over meetings of the committee, shall represent the committee before the city council, and shall otherwise serve to facilitate the business of the committee. The chair shall use Roberts Rules of Order as a guide for the conduct of all meetings of the committee. The chair shall have a vote on all matters coming before the committee. 
The vice-chair shall exercise such duties in the absence of the chair. 
(h)  All meetings of the committee shall be open to the public, and the committee shall conduct its meetings in accordance with the Alabama Open Meetings Act. 
(i)  A majority of the total membership of the committee shall constitute a quorum, and a quorum shall be required in order for the committee to conduct business. 
( Ord. No. 41-023-2014, §§ 1-9, 7-1-14 ) 
Chapter 44 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1]

ARTICLE II. - REGIONAL PLANNING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, Ch. 64. 
State Law reference- Regional planning, Code of Ala., § 11-52-1 et seq., as amended. 

Sec. 44-31. - Definitions. 
    The words and terms "governmental unit," "governing body," "municipality," "region," "advisory planning" and "comprehensive advisory planning," where used in this article shall have the meaning assigned to such words or terms by the provisions of Section 11-85-20 of the Code of Alabama, as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 2-53) 
Sec. 44-32. - Region established; composition. 
    Pursuant to the authority contained in Sections 11-85-20 through 11-85-23 of the Code of Alabama, as amended, there is hereby created and established a region for advisory planning purposes, which region shall include all the geographical area contained within the aggregate territorial limits of all governmental units, the governing body of which shall adopt this article. 
(Code 1965, § 2-54) 
Sec. 44-33. - Regional planning commission-Created, etc. 
    Pursuant to the authority contained in Sections 11-85-20 through 11-85-23 of the Code of Alabama, as amended, there is hereby created and established a regional planning commission, the membership of which shall be as provided by such sections and whose members shall be appointed for the terms and in the manner prescribed by such sections. 
(Code 1965, § 2-55) 
Sec. 44-34. - Same-Powers, etc. 
    The regional planning commission created and established in this article is hereby authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and to do all things authorized by the provisions of Sections 11-85-20 through 11-85-23 of the Code of Alabama, as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 2-56) 
Secs. 44-35-44-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PLANNING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Planning commission, § 64-8.C. 

Sec. 44-51. - Creation; composition. 
    Pursuant to the authority contained in Code of Alabama, Section 11-52-2, as amended, there is hereby created the city planning commission to consist of nine (9) members who are to be appointed for the terms and in the manner prescribed by Code of Alabama, Section 11-52-3, as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 2-4) 
Sec. 44-52. - Powers. 
    The planning commission is hereby authorized and empowered to exercise all powers and to do all things authorized by Code of Alabama, Section 11-52-1 et seq., as amended. 
(Code 1965, § 2-5) 
Secs. 44-53-44-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HISTORIC DEVELOPMENT[4]
