    The city may acquire and redevelop properties within a redevelopment project area for residential, commercial, institutional, recreational and/or industrial uses through voluntary donation, purchase, mortgage foreclosure, and/or eminent domain; however, use of eminent domain authority is limited according to sections 52-152 and 52-153 of this article. 
(1)  The city may accept the donation of properties or may purchase properties and the improvements thereon from private owners or from institutional owners, including the state, for reuse or redevelopment after approval by the governing body. 
(2)  Disposition for "nominal consideration" results from the city's having mitigated all blighting conditions on individual properties, rendering them suitable for redevelopment or re-use, including, if necessary, mitigation of environmental contamination. The amount of the nominal consideration to be received in the disposition of the property and improvements thereon must be approved by the governing body in advance of execution. 
(Ord. No. 65-048-2017 , § 6, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 52-158. - Tax status of project lands sold or leased to private individuals or corporations for redevelopment. 
    Any property which the city leases to private individuals or corporations for development under a redevelopment project area plan shall have the same tax status as if such leased property were owned by such private individuals or corporations. 
(Ord. No. 65-048-2017 , § 6, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 52-159. - Federal financial aid. 
    The city may borrow money or accept contributions from the federal government to assist in its undertaking of redevelopment projects and may do any and all things necessary or desirable to secure such financial aid, including obligating itself in any contract with the federal government for annual contributions to convey to the federal government the project to which said contract relates, upon the occurrence of a substantial default thereunder, in the same manner as it may do to secure such aid in connection with slum clearance and housing projects under the provisions of this title. 
(Ord. No. 65-048-2017 , § 6, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 52-160. - Investment by the city in bonds issued by housing authorities. 
    Bonds or other obligations issued by the city in connection with a redevelopment project pursuant to this chapter, shall be security for public deposits and legal investments to the same extent and for the same persons, institutions, associations, corporations, and other bodies and officers as bonds or other obligations issued pursuant to this title in connection with the development of slum clearance and housing projects. 
(Ord. No. 65-048-2017 , § 6, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 52-161. - Redevelopment project areas. 
    For the purposes of this chapter and as identified on the official census maps, the following tracts and block groups are hereby determined to constitute the established redevelopment project area: 
Tract Block Group Location Description 4 1 The Campground/MLK Heritage Neighborhood 4 2 Fisher/Owens 5 Lafayette Heights/MLK Heritage Neighborhood 7 1 and 2 Toulminville 26 Crichton, north of Spring Hill Ave 27 Crichton, south of Spring Hill Ave 39 1 and 2 Trinity Gardens 13 2 Oakdale 14 Oakdale and Maysville 15 1 and 2 Maysville and RV Taylor 23 1 Riviera 22 Navco 19 2 McVoy/Gill Road 64 2 Mobile Terrace  
(Ord. No. 65-048-2017 , § 6, 12-5-17) 
Secs. 52-162-52-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 52-181. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and cited as the inoperable motor vehicle ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 1, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-182. - Authorization. 
    This article is authorized and enacted pursuant to Alabama Act No. 2018-197. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 2, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-183. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to: 
(1)  Carry into effect the powers and duties conferred by Alabama Act No. 2018-197. 
(2)  Provide for, promote and protect the safety, health, and general welfare of the residents and property owners of the city. 
(3)  Limit the outdoor storage of junked and inoperable motor vehicles for the purpose of promoting and protecting property values and the general appearance of residential neighborhoods and the city as a whole. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 3, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-184. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the following meaning: 
(1)  The term "inoperable motor vehicle" means any motor vehicle, trailer, recreational vehicle, camper, or semi-trailer that has remained on private property and in view of the general public for thirty (30) days or more and is inoperable in that one (1) or more of its major mechanical components, including, but not limited to, engine, transmission, drive train, or wheels, are missing or are not functional, or the vehicle otherwise constitutes a nuisance. 
(2)  The term "official" means the city's code official, a municipal law enforcement officer, a municipal enforcement officer, or any other municipal employee designated by the mayor to exercise the authority and perform the duties provided in this article. 
(3)  The term "city" means the City of Mobile, Alabama. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 4, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-185. - Declaration of public nuisance. 
    Inoperable motor vehicles are hereby declared to be public nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 5, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-186. - Exceptions. 
    An inoperable motor vehicle shall not be deemed a public nuisance, and therefore the abatement procedures established by this article do not apply, under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  The motor vehicle has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations, provided that the motor vehicle has a valid and current license tag displayed thereon in accordance with state law provided that the motor vehicle has a valid and current license tag displayed thereon in accordance with state law, and provided further that no such motor vehicle may remain on private property for a period not to exceed an aggregate total of thirty (30) days. 
(2)  The motor vehicle is on the premises of a place of business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles or primarily engaged in the storage and sale of damaged or theft-recovered vehicles for insurers, provided that such place of business has a duly-issued and current city business license. 
(3)  The motor vehicle is kept in an enclosed building completely shielded from the view of individuals on the adjoining properties. Covering inoperable motor vehicles with tarps or car covers does not meet the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 6, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-187. - Procedures and enforcement. 
(a)  Whenever an official shall find an inoperable motor vehicle as is defined herein, the official shall cause a notice of violation to be issued by placing a notice on the vehicle and by providing written notice to the owner of record of the property on which the vehicle is located and, in cases where the vehicle is in such a condition that identification numbers are available to determine ownership, to the last registered owner of record of the vehicle and to any secured party or other holder of a recorded or registered security interest or lien on the motor vehicle. 
(b)  The notice of violation shall state the following: 
(1)  That the vehicle has been determined to be a public nuisance; 
(2)  That the owner of the vehicle is given thirty (30) days from the date the notice is received to either cause the vehicle to be removed from said property or to cause the vehicle to be stored in an enclosed building completely shielded from the view of individuals on the adjoining properties; 
(3)  That if the vehicle is not removed or stored in an enclosed building within that period of time the city will cause its removal; 
(4)  That all expenses incurred in removing the vehicle from the property will be assessed against the registered owner of the vehicle if the identity of the owner can be determined, or against the owner of the property on which the vehicle is located; and, 
(5)  That a hearing before the city council on the question of abatement and removal of the inoperable motor vehicle as a public nuisance may be requested in writing by the owner of the vehicle, any secured party or the property owner within the thirty-day period, and that if no hearing is requested in writing then the vehicle will be removed by the city. 
(c)  Request for hearing. 
(1)  If a written request for a hearing is received by the designated code official at 205 Government Street, Mobile, Alabama 36602 within the thirty-day period, the city council shall schedule the hearing to be held at a regularly scheduled meeting within fourteen (14) days after the request has been received. Notice giving the time, location, and date of the hearing on the question of abatement and removal of the inoperable motor vehicle as a public nuisance shall be mailed by certified mail, with a five-day return receipt requested, to the owner of the land as shown on the last equalized assessment roll, to the last registered owner of record of the vehicle, and to any registered or recorded secured party or lienholder unless the vehicle is in such a condition that identification numbers are not available to determine ownership. 
(2)  The owner of the land on which the vehicle is located may appear in person at the hearing or present a written statement in time for consideration at the hearing, and deny responsibility for the presence of the vehicle on the land or otherwise show his or her plans to abate the nuisance. No cost of the administration or removal of the vehicle shall be assessed against the landowner if it is determined at the hearing that the vehicle was placed on the land without the consent of the landowner and that he or she has not subsequently acquiesced in its presence. 
(3)  The registered owner of the vehicle may appear in person at the hearing and present any reason why such vehicle should not be determined to be a public nuisance, why removal should not occur, or why the cost of abatement should not be assessed against said owner, or may present a plan for abatement of said vehicle within a set period of time. 
(4)  Any secured party may appear at the hearing and present a plan for removal of the vehicle or may present reasons why the vehicle should not be removed and sold by the city. 
(5)  The council shall consider the information presented at the meeting at which it is presented unless the council shall affirmatively find that the information or evidence submitted raises issues which require additional investigation, in which case the matter may be passed to a meeting no later than the second regularly scheduled meeting subsequent to the meeting at which the matter is initially presented, at which time the council shall act on the matter. The council may: 
(d)  Deny any requested relief and order the abatement of the vehicle and its disposal to proceed. 
(e)  Declare that the property owner on whose property the vehicle is located is not responsible for the vehicle due to the vehicle having been placed on the land without the consent of the landowner and that the landowner has not subsequently acquiesced in its presence. 
(f)  Determine that the vehicle is not a public nuisance and that removal is not required. 
(g)  Accept an adequate plan for removal of the vehicle presented by the property owner or owner of the vehicle, set a date certain by which time the vehicle shall be removed and direct that in the event the vehicle is not removed by the date set, the vehicle shall be immediately abated by the city and all costs assessed against the party presenting the plan for removal. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 7, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-188. - Removal by owner. 
    The owner of the land on which the vehicle is located, any secured party, or the registered owner of the vehicle may remove the vehicle at his or her own expense prior to the removal of the vehicle by the city. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 8, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-189. - List of providers of vehicle removal services. 
    The city will maintain a list of names of persons or private contractors, or both, who perform vehicle removal services. Any company or individual providing such service may request to be added to this list. The city will not recommend any particular individual or company but will, upon request of the registered owner of the vehicle, secured party or property owner, provide them with a copy of the list. The registered owner of the vehicle, secured party or property owner shall not be required to utilize the services of any company or individual listed, but may use any lawful means to cause the removal of the vehicle and may utilize the services of any individual or company for said removal. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 9, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-190. - Removal by city. 
    After the expiration of thirty (30) days from the date the notice of violation is issued, if the vehicle has not been removed from the property or moved to an enclosed building completely shielded from the view of individuals on the adjoining properties, and if a request for hearing before the city council has not been made, then the city shall cause the vehicle to be removed. If a written request is made for a hearing before the city council and the city council determines that the vehicle is a public nuisance and that removal should proceed, and the property owner, vehicle owner or holder of the security interest has not removed the vehicle or moved it to an enclosed building completely shielded from the view of individuals on the adjoining properties within five (5) days from the date of the decision of the city council, then the city shall cause the vehicle to be removed. If a plan for removal of the vehicle had been presented to the city council and accepted and removal has not been accomplished by the date set, then the city shall cause the immediate removal of the vehicle. 
    Any private contractors used by the city for removal of inoperable motor vehicles shall be selected on a rotation schedule among the contractors providing vehicle removal services in the city. 
    Inoperable motor vehicles removed by the city pursuant to the provisions of this article will be towed and stored at the city impound lot. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 10, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-191. - Disposal of vehicles. 
(a)  Inoperable motor vehicles that have been stored at the city impound lot for sixty (60) days without anyone having made claim thereto may be sold at public auction. 
(b)  Notice of the date, time, and place of the sale and a description of the vehicle to be sold, including the year, make, model, and vehicle identification number, shall be given by publication once a week for two (2) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation. 
(c)  Written notice of the date, time, and place of the sale, a description of the vehicle to be sold, including the year, make, model, and vehicle identification number, and the approximate amount of the costs of towing and storage, shall be given to the registered owner, any secured party or lienholder, and the property owner no less than ten (10) days before the scheduled date of the public auction. 
(d)  The proceeds of any such sale shall first be applied toward the payment of any and all costs incurred by the city. Any excess funds from the sale, minus the costs of removal and administration, shall be returned to the owner. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 11, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-192. - Notice to the department of revenue. 
    The city shall notify the department of revenue of the sale or disposition of the inoperable motor vehicle on a form supplied by the department. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 12, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-193. - Assessment of costs. 
    Costs of removal, including towing and storage charges, may be assessed against the registered owner of the vehicle if the identity of the owner can be determined, or may be assessed against the owner of the property on which the vehicle was stored. No cost of the administration or removal of the vehicle shall be assessed against the landowner if it is determined by the city council that the vehicle was placed on the land without the consent of the landowner and that he or she had not subsequently acquiesced in its presence. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 13, 5-22-18) 
Sec. 52-194. - Supplemental authority. 
    The provisions of this article are supplemental and shall not be construed as limiting or restricting any power or authority the city may now have or possess under any other provision of law or to repeal any other ordinance or law except to the extent of any conflict, in which case the provisions of this article shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 52-010 2018 , § 14, 5-22-18) 
Chapter 57 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Moving buildings, § 11-41 et seq.; obstructing streets or gutters in cemetery, § 12-58; poles and wires, § 19-31 et seq.; lying prone on street, § 49-35; obstructing public ways through charitable solicitation, § 55-43; traffic, ch. 61. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 57-1. - Walking or riding on neutral ground. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to walk or to ride a vehicle over, along or across that portion of a sidewalk lying between the paved portion thereof or the regularly traveled portion thereof and the curbing or ditch of the adjacent street, except at regular sidewalk crossings and except at crossings commonly used in front of residences and places of business to pass from such residences and places of business to vehicles parked on the adjacent street immediately in front of them. 
(Code 1965, § 55-35) 
Sec. 57-2. - Cost of removal of obstruction or repair by city. 
    In case removing any obstruction or repairing any injury to the street or sidewalk is necessary, the city shall so remove or repair the same, at the cost of the person in fault. 
(Code 1965, § 55-13) 
Sec. 57-3. - Removal and disposition of articles obstructing sidewalk or street. 
    When any article, other than a motor vehicle, is found obstructing or encumbering a sidewalk or street, and the owner is unknown, any police officer shall, under the direction of the mayor, cause such obstruction to be taken to some place of safety, to be held five (5) days. At the expiration of that time it shall be sold, after giving three (3) days' notice, by publication, of the time and place of sale. The proceeds shall be paid to the city finance director after deducting the expenses and costs, and, if not called for by the owner within sixteen (16) days, shall be forfeited to the city. 
(Code 1965, § 55-14) 
Sec. 57-4. - Water from roofs of buildings. 
    Owners of buildings shall so construct pipes and gutters leading from the roofs that water therefrom shall not fall on the streets or sidewalks but shall be conducted to the street gutters by continuous pipes. 
(Code 1965, § 55-3) 
Cross reference- Drainage and flood control, ch. 17. 
Sec. 57-5. - Protection of asphalt paving from oils, etc. 
    All persons dealing in transporting or peddling by conveyance or otherwise any bituminous substance, such as petroleum, naphtha, gasoline or the like, or transporting by conveyance or pipe lines or otherwise crude or other oil, gas or similar product, shall provide for the delivery of such material or substance in such manner as to prevent leaks or drips upon any asphalt pavement within the city. 
(Code 1965, § 55-37) 
Sec. 57-6. - Repair of injury to sidewalk, curb or gutter. 
    Every person who shall injure any sidewalk, curb or gutter shall cause the same to be repaired within twenty-four (24) hours thereafter and shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). If the injury or damage be committed by a minor, a parent or guardian shall cause the repairs to be made. 
(Code 1965, § 55-40; Ord. No. 65-004, 1-17-89) 
Sec. 57-7. - Use of street or sidewalk under construction, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon or walk, ride or drive upon or over or place or carry anything upon or lead any animal upon or cause any vehicle to cross over or upon any portion of any street or sidewalk being paved, repaved, oiled, tarred or repaired, where any barrier or warning sign has been placed indicating that such street or sidewalk, or a portion thereof, is closed to traffic and passage. 
(Code 1965, § 55-36) 
Sec. 57-8. - Removing earth from street, etc. 
    No person shall dig, haul or carry away earth or material of any kind from any street, ditch or other public place without the consent or order of the street superintendent and for use for street improvement only. 
(Code 1965, § 55-9) 
Cross reference- Drainage and flood control, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 57-9. - Removal of granite curbing, cobblestones or red paving brick. 
(a)  Any person performing construction work or excavation in any public ground or public way or street in the city, where the nature of such work requires the removal of any granite curbing, cobblestones or red paving brick, shall immediately notify the city engineering department and shall not continue with such construction or excavation work until the city engineering department has had an opportunity to arrange for the safe removal of such construction materials or has given a written permit to such person allowing him to proceed with such construction or excavation work. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to perform construction work or excavation work on any public ground or public street right-of-way in the city in such manner as to cause damage or destruction to any granite curb, cobblestones or red paving brick, without having first obtained a written permit to do so from the city engineering department. 
(Code 1965, § 55-19.1) 
Sec. 57-10. - Paving right-of-way between back of curb and property line. 
(a)  Whenever it is proposed to place paving on the right-of-way of the city between the back of the street curbs and the property line of adjacent property owners, it shall be unlawful for anyone to place pavement in one (1) continuous section exceeding more than thirty (30) inches from the back of the curb line to the first paving joint, which shall be provided with a felt or other pavement divider. This restriction shall not apply to any paving reaching to the curb line which is not in excess of ten (10) feet in width. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be also required to remove any pavement placed in violation of this section and replace the same in compliance herewith. 
(Code 1965, § 55-20) 
Sec. 57-11. - Permission required before filling drainage ditch. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to fill up any drainage ditch alongside or crossing any of the public streets, alleys, sidewalks or other public places of the city without first obtaining permission from the city engineer, even though the ditch is being filled for the purpose of covering a drain pipe and to beautify the parkway or lawn or to eliminate a bridge or other crossing of a ditch. The city engineer shall issue permission for the filling of a ditch whenever it is no longer needed for drainage purposes or whenever the drain pipe to be placed in the ditch by the applicant is of a size large enough to carry the water which would normally pass along the ditch and when the pipe is laid at a level and in a manner which will conform to the general plans of the city engineer for the drainage of the district where the ditch in question is located. 
(Code 1965, § 55-7) 
Cross reference- Drainage and flood control, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 57-12. - Manholes. 
(a)  Protection required. All persons owning and operating pipelines, conduits or other like underground mains and services within the city, requiring the use of manholes, shall keep such manholes properly protected. 
(b)  How protected. Whenever the necessity arises for opening any manhole, during the entire time such manhole remains uncovered it shall be surrounded by a substantial metal frame, exhibiting a conspicuous red flag. The frame shall be so constructed as to fully enclose three (3) sides about such manhole opening and the entire design of such frame shall be submitted to and be approved, in writing, by the city engineer. 
(c)  Watchman. Whenever any manhole is located at any place where the frame described in subsection (b) cannot be used, a watchman shall be provided by the owner of such manhole, for the purpose of giving timely warning to persons using the street. 
(Code 1965, §§ 55-32-55-34) 
Sec. 57-13. - Bridges over gutters, etc. 
(a)  Generally. All street bridges, curbs, bulkheads and retaining walls of ditches or drains shall be so built that the upright supports, if any, shall be behind the bulkheads and the walls shall present a smooth surface on the drain side. This shall apply to all repairs or reconstruction as well as to erection of new ones, whether made by the city, a contractor, a property owner or others. 
(b)  Not to obstruct drainage. In construction of new bridges over street drains or gutters and in the reconstruction of old ones, by the city or by others, such bridges shall be so built that they shall, on the sidewalk end, rest on the top of the curb and be levelled down to allow easy access. They shall at the other end rest on a foundation or support at substantially the same level as the top of the curb. No portion of the bridge shall project below this level and no support or part shall be in the gutter or in any way obstruct drainage. 
(c)  Removal of nonconforming bridges. The superintendent of public works shall, on notice from the city engineer, remove any bridge which does not conform to the above requirements and obstructs the flow of drainage water. 
(d)  Metal sleepers; hinges. The city engineer is authorized to direct the use of metal sleepers or crosspieces where the gutter is too shallow to admit the use of wooden sleepers. Where a bridge over a street gutter is more than six (6) feet long, at least two (2) feet of it for its full length over the main part of the gutter shall be so provided with hinges that it can be thrown back for proper cleaning of the gutter beneath. This section applies to city and private bridges alike. 
(Code 1965, §§ 55-42, 55-43) 
Sec. 57-14. - Adoption of state highway department standards-Specifications for highways and bridges. 
    The current edition of the Alabama State Highway Department Standard Specifications for Highways and Bridges, as amended from time to time by the state is adopted as the City of Mobile Standard Specifications for Highways and Bridges and is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1965, § 55-43.1; Ord. No. 65-004, 1-17-89) 
Sec. 57-15. - Same-Accommodating utilities on highway rights-of-way. 
    The city council hereby formally adopts the State of Alabama Highway Department Standards for Accommodating Utilities on Highway Rights- of-Way as standards (as written and future amendments thereto) for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city on those roads and streets which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
(Code 1965, § 55-43.2) 
Sec. 57-16. - Procedure for street renaming. 
(a)  Any person or persons desiring to rename a street shall file a written petition with the city clerk. Such petition must be initiated and signed by ninety (90) percent or more of the owners of the recorded parcels of land fronting on any such street. Such petition must include the following: 
(1)  The current name of the street; 
(2)  The proposed name of the street; 
(3)  A statement documenting the significance of the current name of the street; and 
(4)  A statement documenting the significance of the proposed name of the street. If the petition proposes to change a street name to that of a particular individual, the petition must include a biographical sketch of that individual. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a petition seeking to rename a street filed as provided above, the city clerk will transmit a copy to: 
(1)  The city council: 
(2)  The mayor; 
(3)  The city engineer; 
(4)  The city traffic engineer; 
(5)  The director of urban development and planning; 
(6)  The United States Postmaster for the City; 
(7)  The chief of police; 
(8)  The chief of the fire rescue department; 
(9)  The chairman of the planning commission; 
(10)  The director of the emergency management agency; 
(11)  The director of the emergency 911 communications board; and, 
(12)  The historic preservation commission for review of whether there is any historical significance associated with the existing street name. 
(c)  After waiting a minimum of thirty (30) days for any comments from the persons or organizations to whom the petition is sent for review, the city clerk will place a resolution on the council's agenda for consideration of the petition. In considering a petition for a proposed street name change, the council may take into consideration the recommendations and comments, if any, from the persons and organizations to whom the petition was sent for review. 
(d)  Upon the city council's adoption of a resolution changing the name of a street, the city clerk will provide written notice of the name change to each of the persons and organizations identified in paragraph (b). 
(Ord. No. 57-030-2015 , § 1, 3-10-15) 
Sec. 57-17. - Fees for the vacation of easements and public rights-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be the policy of the city to require abutting landowners who will benefit directly from the vacation of an easement or a public right-of-way for a road, street, alley, or other dedicated public way, open or unopen, to pay to the city a fee in accordance with code of ala., § 11-49-6. 
(b)  At the time that a written petition requesting the vacation of an easement or a public right-of-way for a road, street, alley, or other dedicated public way, open or unopen, is submitted, the person(s) who submitted the petition shall provide the following information to the city clerk: 
(1)  The correct legal description of the area sought to be vacated; 
(2)  A plat or survey that clearly shows in detail: 
a.  The area sought to be vacated; 
b.  The location of all lots or tracts that abut the area sought to be vacated; 
c.  The square footage of the area sought to be vacated; and 
d.  The square footage of each subdivision lot or tract that abuts the area sought to be vacated; and, 
(3)  The current year assessed value, as determined by the county revenue commissioner, of all subdivision lots or tracts that abut the easement or right-of-way sought to be vacated. 
(c)  The fee shall be equal to the fair market value of the land which will be added to the holdings of the abutting landowners who will directly benefit from the vacation, as determined in accordance with Code of Ala., § 11-49-6. 
(d)  If the aggregate fee for all lots or tracts of abutting landowners who will directly benefit from the vacation, as determined in accordance with Code of Ala., § 11-49-6, is less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), then no fee shall be required. 
(e)  If the aggregate fee for all lots or tracts of abutting landowners who will directly benefit from the vacation, as determined in accordance with Code of Ala., § 11-49-6, is equal to or greater than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), then the fee shall be finally determined and assessed by the city council after a public hearing, notice of which shall be published and mailed in accordance with the requirements of Code of Ala., § 11-49-6. 
(f)  The council may, in its discretion, waive any fee as it determines to be justified or warranted under the circumstances presented. 
(g)  Once all fee(s) and cost(s) have been paid, and any other conditions of the vacation have been met, the person(s) who submitted the written petition shall receive a certified copy of the council's resolution to be filed by them with the declaration of vacation in the probate records of the county. 
(Ord. No. 57-070-2015 , §§ 1-7, 7-28-15) 
Secs. 57-18-57-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 57-31. - Approval of subdivision plats upon compliance with certain street width requirements. 
    The city engineer is instructed and directed to approve subdivision plats or maps only when the plat shows that the width of the street rights-of-way therein complies with the major street plan of the city adopted by the planning commission of the city, but in no event where a street right-of-way is less than fifty (50) feet; provided, that one (1) of the following conditions is met: 
(1)  That the streets located in the subdivision have been improved in strict compliance with the minimum requirements of the city as set forth in an ordinance adopted by the board of commissioners of the city on September 30, 1958, and entitled "An Ordinance Regulating the Improvement of Streets in the Corporate Limits of the City of Mobile." 
(2)  In lieu of completion of the streets as set forth in subsection (1) above, and when in the opinion of the city council the public rights shall be fully protected, that the subdivider has filed a bond in an amount and with sureties to be approved by the city council, such bond to be approved as to form by the city attorney and conditioned upon the actual construction of the streets in such subdivision according to the requirements set forth in subsection (1) above. 
(3)  In lieu of compliance with the provisions of subsection (1) or (2) above, that the subdivider shall have filed with the city engineer's office an instrument, approved as to form by the city attorney, whereby the subdivider has placed a lien upon all lots in the proposed subdivision, such lien running to the city and being conditioned upon the completion of all streets in such subdivision in strict compliance with the provisions of subsection (1) above, in which event such lien shall be cancelled by the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 55-1) 
Editor's note- The ordinance referred to above is not set out in this volume but was saved from repeal and will be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 57-32. - Duty as to street lines. 
    It shall be the duty of the city engineer to define, establish, rectify and permanently mark the center lines of all public streets of the city; to mark the points of intersecting cross street lines or changes of direction with iron or copper bolts; and, at all angles, points or changes of direction in street lines the bolts shall be protected with cast-iron cylinders fitted with covers. Upon long, straight lines of streets the bolts shall be protected every five (5) blocks in a similar manner. It shall be his duty also to measure accurately the distance between the bolts marking the street line intersections, and the angles at the intersections, to plat the same to a large scale into the ward books of the present records of the city, to record upon the maps the field notes of these measurements and such other reference notes to permanent walls of buildings as may be necessary to secure the establishment of the street lines, so far as not already done and preserved. 
(Code 1965, § 2-31) 
Sec. 57-33. - Line of street to be obtained before building, etc. 
    No person shall erect, rebuild or enlarge any house, building or fence fronting on any street, construct a curbing or pave a sidewalk in the city unless he shall have obtained from the city engineer the line of the street. 
(Code 1965, § 55-4) 
Sec. 57-34. - Encroachment declared nuisance; removal. 
    Any house, building, fence or support thereof which may be placed so that it encroaches upon a public right-of-way, street or easement is a nuisance and shall be moved back to the proper property line. In case no owner or agent can be found, the nuisance may be removed or abated by the director of inspection services. The cost of such removal or abatement shall be the responsibility of the owner of record of the property. 
(Code 1965, § 55-5; Ord. No. 65-004, 1-17-89) 
Sec. 57-35. - Removal of obstructions closing streets, etc. 
    If any person shall obstruct, impede or close any street, alley or extension of the same or any part thereof, whether in use or dedicated only, he shall open the same and move the obstruction or impediment, immediately after notice is served upon him by the police. This notice shall issue upon such representation to the city engineer as shall induce him to believe that such obstruction or impediment has been made. Any person failing to remove such impediment or obstruction, within five (5) days after such notice, shall be punished as provided in section 1-21. It is hereby made the special duty of the chief of police, all policemen, the public works superintendent and the city engineer to report to the council infractions of this section. 
(Code 1965, § 55-2) 
Sec. 57-36. - Trash, etc., in streets. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this Code, no person shall obstruct or encumber any street or public place in any way, or throw, leave or deposit in any street, gutter, ditch, drain or public place any cotton, lumber, firewood, cart, dray, wagon, hay, dung, ashes, kitchen stuff, cans, broken glass, parings, leather, paper, cloth, shavings, chips, brush, leaves or any kind of filth or trash or any other article whatever; provided, however, that the provisions hereof shall not apply to the throwing of trinkets, candy or biodegradable, non-plastic based, confetti or serpentine during Mardi Gras of each year. 
(Code 1965, § 55-6; Ord. No. 57-023-2018 , § 1, 8-7-18) 
Cross reference- Littering from a vehicle, § 25-43. 
Sec. 57-37. - Filling holes in dirt streets. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person to fill any hole in any dirt street in the city or its police jurisdiction with sawdust, shavings, straw, leaves, small branches from trees and shrubbery or material of like kind or nature. 
(Code 1965, § 55-8) 
Sec. 57-38. - Loads touching or dragging on street. 
    No person shall haul, carry or transport through a street any timber, lumber or any other article in such manner that any part thereof shall touch or drag upon the street. 
(Code 1965, § 55-41) 
Sec. 57-39. - Street signs. 
(a)  Erection and maintenance at intersections. Signs bearing the names of the streets shall be put up and maintained at all street intersections in the city. 
(b)  Supervision and direction of city traffic engineering director; where erected. Street signs shall be put up under the immediate supervision and direction of the city traffic engineering director but under the general direction of the mayor. They shall be put up at street corners in such manner as, in the judgment of the city engineer, will be most convenient and conspicuous and best adapted to carry out the purpose of this chapter. 
(c)  Injuring, molesting etc. Any person who shall unlawfully pull down, pull off, deface, obliterate or otherwise in any manner injure any street sign put up under this section or under any other authority of the city or any board or plate indicating the name of any street or place shall be punished as provided in section 1-21. 
(d)  Naming of streets. It shall be the responsibility of the city traffic engineering director to name streets within the city upon receiving approval or direction by the city council. 
(Code 1965, §§ 55-23-55-25) 
Cross reference- Signs, Ch. 54. 
Secs. 57-40-57-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[2] 

Footnotes:

Secs. 57-51-57-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 57-71. - Sidewalks to be kept free of grass, weeds and other obstructions. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person or tenant occupying property within the city to fail to keep the sidewalk in front thereof free from grass, weeds, bushes, trees or any other object which would obstruct the use of the sidewalk by pedestrians. It shall further be unlawful for such person or tenant occupying such piece of property to fail to keep the sidewalk area in front of such property free from obstructions to a height of not less than seven (7) feet and to a width of not less than four (4) feet. 
(Code 1965, § 55-38) 
Sec. 57-72. - Sweeping sidewalks. 
    All tenants of houses, yards, lots or grounds fronting on any street shall sweep and clean or cause to be swept and cleaned that part of the sidewalk that lies before the respective premises every day before 10:00 a.m. 
(Code 1965, § 55-39) 
Sec. 57-73. - Obstructions on sidewalks-Generally. 
    No person shall obstruct, embarrass or encumber any sidewalk with cotton, lumber, firewood, carts, drays, wagons, goods, wares, merchandise or any article; ride or drive any horse, cart, dray, truck, carriage, wheelbarrow, automobile or other vehicle, however propelled, over any sidewalk, except at driveways; expose for public sale on any sidewalk any goods, wares or merchandise; erect gates to open outwardly on the street, or permit them so to remain when erected, or otherwise to obstruct any sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 55-10) 
Cross reference- Obstructing free passage of streets, § 49-1. 
Sec. 57-74. - Same-During improvement or repair of sidewalk. 
    In paving or otherwise improving any part of a sidewalk or in repairing the same, the owner of the abutting lot or his contractor may, when necessary, enclose the part of the sidewalk being improved or repaired with wire fencing or any other safe and suitable barrier for such length of time as shall be necessary to complete the improvement of the sidewalk or to repair the same but, when necessary for the safety of the public, such owner or such contractor shall maintain, at night, on such fencing or other barrier, suitable lights to give warning of the obstruction. 
(Code 1965, § 55-11) 
Secs. 57-75-57-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 

Sec. 57-91. - Abutting owner may pave. 
    The owner or agent of property may pave the sidewalk in front thereof but shall conform to the grade and use material approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 55-44) 
Sec. 57-92. - Conformity to lines and grades fixed by city engineer. 
    All sidewalks constructed within the city shall conform to the lines and grades fixed or to be fixed by the city engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 55-45) 
Sec. 57-93. - Duty of abutting owner to construct, etc., after notice. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner of real property abutting any sidewalk within the city, within thirty (30) days after receiving notice from the city council requiring the construction, reconstruction, renewal, extension, readjustment or repair of any sidewalk, to do or to have done the work prescribed in such notice. All such work shall be done under and in accordance with the rules and regulations now or hereafter prescribed by the city council. 
(Code 1965, § 55-46) 
Sec. 57-94. - Notice to nonresident or unknown owner. 
    Notice may, in the case of a nonresident or unknown owner, be executed by service upon his agent when known and, when there is no resident agent ascertainable, by publication in some newspaper published in the city once a week for three (3) weeks. The council shall thereupon proceed as after personal service. 
(Code 1965, § 55-47) 
Sec. 57-95. - Permit required to lay or relay sidewalk. 
    Any person desiring to lay or relay any sidewalk within any section of the city shall first secure a permit therefor from the city council or its authorized representative, to be issued upon the condition that the work proposed to be done shall be done within sixty (60) days from the date of issuance of such permit and according to the rules and regulations of the council. 
(Code 1965, § 55-48) 
Sec. 57-96. - Slope of pavement. 
    The pavement of all sidewalks shall be laid with a slope towards the street at a grade not exceeding one (1) inch in three (3) feet in such a way that the water shall not remain thereon. 
(Code 1965, § 55-49) 
Sec. 57-97. - Lot drainage. 
    Drainage from lots shall be through covered gutters or pipes laid across the sidewalks below the surface thereof. 
(Code 1965, § 55-50) 
Cross reference- Drainage and flood prevention, Ch. 17. 
Sec. 57-98. - Lien of city for cost of construction or repair. 
    The cost of construction or repair of sidewalks by the city is hereby assessed against the abutting owner, and the city shall have a lien therefor upon the adjacent and abutting property of such owner. The cost shall be certified to the assessments department of the city by the council and shall be collected in the manner provided by law for the collection of special taxes due the city. 
(Code 1965, § 55-51) 
Cross reference- Enforcing liens, § 50-21 et seq. 
Sec. 57-99. - Duty of abutting owner to keep sidewalk in repair. 
    All the sidewalks in the city shall be put and kept in repair by the owners of the property abutting thereon and any person who shall be injured in person or property through the failure of any such owner to put or keep the abutting sidewalk in repair shall have a right of action against such owner. 
(Code 1965, § 55-52) 
Sec. 57-100. - Notice to abutting owner to repair; repair by city. 
(a)  If any sidewalk is out of repair, the city engineer shall give notice to the owner of the property abutting thereon to repair the same within ten (10) days. If the same shall not be repaired by such owner within ten (10) days from the giving of the notice, the same shall be repaired by the city at the expense of such owner and the amount expended for such repairs shall be a lien upon the property abutting such sidewalk and, with interest, shall be collected as special taxes are collectible. 
(b)  The remedy provided by the preceding paragraph for the collection of the expense incurred by the city in repairing any sidewalk shall not be exclusive but such expense may be collected in the manner there stated or any other manner permitted by the laws of the state. 
(Code 1965, § 55-53) 
Sec. 57-101. - Failure to put or keep sidewalk in repair unlawful. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property in the city to fail to put or keep the sidewalks abutting his property in repair. 
(Code 1965, § 55-54) 
Secs. 57-102-57-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 57-121. - Permit to build or maintain required. 
    No one shall build or maintain a driveway across the curb or sidewalk without obtaining a permit from the city engineer. 
(Code 1965, § 55-55) 
Sec. 57-122. - Specifications. 
    All construction work on driveways across the curb or sidewalk shall be done in conformity with the city standard specifications for sidewalks and driveways prepared by the city engineer, which standard specifications are as follows: 
(1)  Permit for construction of a sidewalk or driveway shall be secured from the city engineer's office before work is started and the work shall be done in conformity to the direction of the authorized assistant of the city engineer. Minimum widths of sidewalks shall be four (4) feet and minimum depths three and three-quarters (33/4) inches. (The city reserves the right to alter specifications to meet unusual physical conditions that may be encountered.) 
(2)  All walks shall be placed adjoining property lines and on the grades established by the city and shall be sloped one-quarter inch to the foot. The subgrade shall be thoroughly compacted and have a slope in conformity with the finished surface. 
(3)  Concrete shall be a mixture of 
1.00 part cement 
2.25 parts sand 
3.25 parts gravel 
using not over six (6) gallons of water to each bag of cement. 
(4)  All forms shall be rigid and straight. 
(5)  After the concrete has been placed and tamped, it shall be brought to the established grade by means of a strike board. It will then be worked with a wood float in a manner which will thoroughly compact it and provide a surface free from depression or irregularities of any kind. In no case shall dry cement and sand be sprinkled on the surface. 
(6)  The surface edges of all slopes shall be rounded to a radius of one-half inch. The pavement shall be divided into blocks approximately the same width as the walk by means of a jointer or groover. 
(7)  Transverse expansion joints shall be made at intervals of about thirty (30) feet and shall extend from the surface to the bottom of the sidewalk and shall be one-half inch in width and filled with joint filler. All protruding expansion joints shall be cut flush with the sidewalk. 
(8)  After floating has been completed, the surface shall be lightly brushed transversely with a soft brush or preferably finished with a cork float so as to leave a nonskid surface. 
(9)  As soon as the finished work has hardened sufficiently to prevent damage, the surface of the walk shall be sprinkled with clean water and kept wet for at least seventy-two (72) hours. Curing by application of chemicals or some other method may be used upon the approval of the engineer or his authorized assistant. 
(10)  Work shall be protected by the erection and maintenance of suitable barricades to protect the walk from traffic and shall not be opened to traffic until the prescribed curing period has expired. 
(11)  All driveway entrances shall be constructed in conformity in all respects to the above specifications and shall have a minimum radius of at least three (3) feet at the curb, and the depth of the paving of the driveway apron and walk joining the entrance apron shall have a minimum depth of at least five (5) inches. 
(12)  All provisions of this Code and other ordinances as to barricading, lighting, etc., shall be strictly obeyed. 
(13)  If the work is done by contract, the contractor shall have a city sidewalk contract license. 
(Code 1965, § 55-56) 
Sec. 57-123. - Maximum width. 
    No driveway shall exceed forty (40) feet at the outer or street edge of the sidewalk. 
(Code 1965, § 55-57) 
Sec. 57-124. - Cutting curbing beyond property line. 
    In the construction of a driveway, no street curbing shall be cut beyond any property line as projected except when consented to, in writing, by the adjoining property owner involved. 
(Code 1965, § 55-58) 
Sec. 57-125. - Safety island for adjoining driveways. 
    Where two (2) or more adjoining driveways are provided for the same property, a safety island of not less than twenty (20) feet at the outer edge of the sidewalk shall be provided by the construction of a concrete curb with a radius of not less than three (3) feet on either side. 
(Code 1965, § 55-59) 
Sec. 57-126. - Apron. 
    No driveway apron shall extend out into the street further than the face of the curb nor into the gutter area. The street edge of the driveway apron shall project at least three-quarters of an inch vertically above the surface of the gutter. 
(Code 1965, § 55-60) 
Sec. 57-127. - Setting back safety island or street corner. 
    A safety island or a street corner may be set back from the original curb line; provided, that a three and one-half (31/2) inch vertical exposure is maintained. 
(Code 1965, § 55-61) 
Sec. 57-128. - Sidewalk grade. 
    The sidewalk grade of each driveway shall not exceed a one-half inch rise for each foot. 
(Code 1965, § 55-62) 
Secs. 57-129-57-140. - Reserved.
