A)  Asphalt driveways affected by the construction project shall be replaced from the right-of-way line to the curb or edge of road. 
B)  Construction of asphalt driveways will comply with Alabama Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, current edition, section 429. 
7.1.2.  Concrete. 
A)  Construction of concrete driveways affected by the construction project shall be replaced to the nearest control joint. 
B)  Construction of concrete driveways will comply with Alabama Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, current edition, section 618. 
7.2.  Concrete sidewalks. 
A)  Concrete sidewalks affected by the construction project will be replaced to the nearest control joint in the affected construction area. Joints will be sawed unless at an expansion joint. 
B)  Construction of sidewalks will comply with Alabama Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, current edition, Section 618; provided however, that in any historic district, the city engineer may authorize the use of such materials other than concrete as may be recommended by the architectural review board of the city. 
7.3.  Curb and gutter. 
A)  Concrete curb and gutter, affected by the construction project, will be replaced from joint to joint in the affected area. 
B)  Construction will comply with Alabama Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Highway Construction, current edition, section 623. 
7.4.  Miscellaneous structures. 
A)  All walls, steps and other miscellaneous structures, affected by the construction, will be replaced as required by the city engineer. 
7.5.  Drainage systems and structures. 
A)  All disturbed drainage channels, structures, and pipe systems will be replaced as required by the city engineer. 
7.6.  Unpaved areas. 
A)  All established lawn areas, affected by the construction project, will be replaced with similar type landscape materials which were existing prior to the project. Other areas will be restored with approved topsoil and seeding. 
(Ord. No. 57-022-2006, 6-20-06; Ord. No. 57-026-2017 , § 8, 12-12-17) 
Chapter 60 - THEATERS 

Sec. 60-1. - Sitting or standing in aisles prohibited. 
    During any performance in any theater, no person shall sit or stand in any aisle therein. 
(Code 1965, § 59-1) 
Sec. 60-2. - Smoking. 
    No person shall smoke in any part of any theater while the same is occupied by any audience. 
(Code 1965, § 59-2) 
Cross reference- Smoking, § 27-61 et seq. 
Sec. 60-3. - Duty of manager to enforce two preceding sections. 
    It is the duty of the manager or lessee of every theater to enforce the provisions of the two (2) preceding sections and any failure upon his part to do so shall be held to be a violation thereof and be punishable as such. 
(Code 1965, § 59-3) 
Chapter 61 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The city's traffic regulations are also published separately in handbook form. The notation "T" in the history note denotes derivation from the city's 1964 Traffic Code. 
Cross reference- Ambulance to obey traffic laws, § 6-45; vehicles hauling garbage, § 25-6; escape of load from uncovered vehicle, § 25-44; pedestrians, bicycles, etc., prohibited on certain interstate highways, § 39-13; reckless driving, § 39-83; intoxication in a motor vehicle, § 39-95; Mardi Gras parades, § 39-211 et seq.; vehicles in parks, § 41-6; parades, § 49-41 et seq.; railroads, Ch. 51; rollerskates and skateboards, Ch. 52; attaching advertisement to automobile, § 54-6; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 57; traffic requirements at excavations, § 57-150; vehicular restrictions on certain streets, § 57-191 et seq.; wreckers, Ch. 63. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 61-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be known and cited as the Traffic Code. 
(T.C., § 25-4) 
Sec. 61-2. - Punishment. 
    Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this chapter known as the Traffic Code of the City of Mobile, Alabama, 1964, shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). 
(T.C., §§ 19-1, 25-6; Ord. No. 37-032, adopted 1972) 
Sec. 61-3. - Schedule of fines for traffic infractions. 
    Pursuant to the rules of judicial administration, there is established the following schedule of fines for the summary disposition of traffic offenses: 
Offense      Fine 
Stopping on highway ..... $30.00 
Driving on wrong side of road ..... 30.00 
Failure to dim ..... 10.00 
Failure to stop at railroad crossing ..... 10.00 
Failure to yield right-of-way ..... 20.00 
Following too closely ..... 20.00 
Improper brakes ..... 20.00 
Improper lights ..... 20.00 
Improper mufflers ..... 10.00 
Improper passing ..... 20.00 
Improper signal ..... 10.00 
Improper tag ..... 25.00 
Improper turn ..... 20.00 
No helmet (motorcycle rider) ..... 10.00 
Running red light ..... 20.00 
Running stop sign ..... 20.00 
Speeding (unaggravated cases-less than 25 miles per hour over limit) ..... 20.00 
Failure to leave safe distance when passing bicycle ..... 20.00 
(Ord. No. 41-068, 8-28-84; Ord. No. 61-048-2011, § 1, 10-25-11) 
Sec. 61-4. - Effect of chapter. 
    If any part or parts of this chapter are for any reason held to be invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(T.C., § 25-1) 
Sec. 61-5. - Repeal. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with or inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter are hereby repealed, except that this repeal shall not affect or prevent the prosecution or punishment of any person for any act done or committed in violation of any ordinance hereby repealed prior to the taking effect of this chapter. 
(T.C., § 25-2) 
Sec. 61-6. - Words and phrases defined. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this chapter shall for the purpose of this chapter have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. 
    Alley or alleyway shall mean a street or highway intended to provide access to the rear or side of lots or buildings in urban districts and not intended for the purpose of through vehicular traffic. 
    Authorized emergency vehicle shall mean vehicles of the fire department (fire patrol), police vehicles and such ambulances and emergency vehicles of municipal departments or public service corporations as are designated or authorized by the director of public safety or the chief of police. 
    Bicycle shall mean every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels either of which is more than twenty (20) inches in diameter. 
    Bus shall mean every motor vehicle designed for carrying more than seven (7) passengers and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle, other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Business district shall mean the territory contiguous to a highway when fifty (50) percent or more of the frontage thereon for the distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is occupied by buildings in use for business. 
    Central business (or traffic) district shall mean all streets and portions of streets within the area described as follows: All that area bounded by Broad Street on the west, Water Street on the east, St. Louis Street on the north, Church Street on the south. 
    Commercial vehicle shall mean every vehicle designed, maintained, or used primarily for the transportation of property. 
    Controlled or limited access highway shall mean every highway, street or roadway in respect to which owners or occupants of abutting lands and other persons have no legal right of access to or from the same except at such points only and in such manner as may be determined by the public authority having jurisdiction over such highway, street or roadway. 
    Crosswalk shall mean: 
(1)  That part of a roadway at an intersection included within the connections of the lateral lines of the sidewalks on opposite sides of the highway measured from the curbs, or in the absence of curbs from the edges of the traversable roadway. 
(2)  Any portion of a roadway at an intersection or elsewhere distinctly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Curb loading zone shall mean a space adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Driver shall mean every person who drives or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
    Highway shall mean every way or place of whatever nature open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel. The term "highway" shall include the full width of the right-of-way of any public road, street, avenue, alley, or boulevard, bridge, viaduct or trestle and the approaches thereto, within the limits of the state. The term "highway" shall not be deemed to include a roadway or driveway upon grounds owned by private persons. 
    Intersection shall mean: 
(1)  The area embraced within the prolongation or connection of the lateral curb lines, or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of the roadways of two (2) highways which join one another at, or approximately at, right angles, or the area within which vehicles travelling upon different highways joining at any other angle may come in conflict. 
(2)  Where a highway includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of each roadway of such divided highway by an intersecting highway shall be regarded as a separate intersection. In the event such intersecting highway also includes two (2) roadways thirty (30) feet or more apart, then every crossing of two (2) roadways of such highways shall be regarded as a separate intersection. 
    Laned roadway shall mean a roadway which is divided into two (2) or more clearly marked lanes for vehicular traffic. 
    Median means that property, not designated for vehicular use, which is located in the center of any street or highway and which separates the traffic lanes of the street or highway, and which is owned, controlled, or regulated by the city. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean every vehicle which is self-propelled and every vehicle which is propelled by electric power obtained from overhead trolley wires, but not operated upon rails. 
    Motorcycle shall mean every motor vehicle designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor. 
    Official time standard shall mean that whenever certain hours are named herein, the time standard referred to shall mean standard or daylight-saving time as may be in current use in this city. 
    Official traffic control devices shall mean all signs, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected by authority of a public body or official having jurisdiction, for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic. 
    Park or parking shall mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
    Parking space shall mean a space or section of the street adjacent to the curbing bounded and indicated by appropriate markings. 
    Passenger curb loading zone shall mean a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Pedestrian shall mean any person afoot. 
    Persons shall include individuals, partnerships, associations, trusts and corporations, and the receivers, assignees or agents or any of them. 
    Planting strip is that property, not designated for vehicular use, which is in the nature of a median or right-of-way, but which separates two (2) streets or a street and a highway from each other, and which is owned, controlled or regulated by the city; for example, property separating a highway and a service road. 
    Police officer shall mean every officer of the municipal police department or any officer authorized to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violations of traffic regulations. 
    Private road or driveway shall mean every road or driveway not open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel. 
    Railroad shall mean a carrier of persons or property upon cars, other than streetcars, operated upon stationary rails. 
    Railroad train shall mean a steam engine, electric or other motor, with or without cars coupled thereto, operated upon rails, except streetcars. 
    Residence district shall mean the territory contiguous to a highway not comprising a business district when the frontage on such highway for a distance of three hundred (300) feet or more is mainly occupied by dwellings, not more than two hundred (200) feet apart, or by dwellings and buildings in use for residence. 
    Right-of-way shall mean the privilege of the immediate use of the roadway, or any property immediately adjacent to a street or highway, not designated for vehicular use, which is owned, controlled, or regulated by the city, as the context requires. 
    Roadway shall mean that portion of a highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, exclusive of the berm or shoulder. In the event a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway separately but not to all such roadways collectively. 
    Safety zone shall mean the area or space officially set apart within a roadway for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is protected or is so marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    Sidewalk shall mean that portion of a street between the curb lines, or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines, intended for use of pedestrians. 
    Stop shall, when required, mean complete cessation from movement. 
    Stop or stopping or standing or parking shall, when prohibited, mean any halting even momentarily of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal. 
    Streetcar shall mean a car other than a railroad train for transporting persons or property and operated upon rails principally within a municipality. 
    Through highway shall mean every highway or portion thereof on which vehicular traffic is given preferential right-of-way, and at the entrances to which vehicular traffic from intersecting highways is required by law to yield right-of-way to vehicles on such through highway in obedience to either a stop sign or a yield sign, when such signs are erected as provided in this chapter. 
    Traffic shall mean pedestrians, ridden or herded animals, vehicles, streetcars and other conveyances either singly or together while using any highway for purposes of travel. 
    Traffic control signal shall mean any device, whether manually, electrically or mechanically operated, by which traffic is alternately directed to stop and to proceed. 
    Traffic division shall mean the traffic division of the Mobile police department. 
    Vehicle shall mean every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, excepting devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(T.C., §§ 1-1-1-42) 
Sec. 61-7. - Required obedience to traffic chapter. 
    It is an offense against the city for any person to do any act forbidden, or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. 
(T.C., § 3-2) 
Sec. 61-8. - Obedience to duly authorized city employees. 
    No person shall willfully fail or refuse to comply with any lawful order or direction of a duly authorized city employee. 
(T.C., § 3-3) 
Sec. 61-9. - Persons propelling push carts or riding animals to obey traffic regulations. 
    Every person propelling any push cart or riding an animal upon a roadway, and every person driving any animal-drawn vehicle, shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to the driver of any vehicle, except those provisions of this chapter which by their very nature have no application. 
(T.C., § 3-4) 
Sec. 61-10. - Public employees to obey traffic regulations. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the driver of any vehicle owned by or used in the service of the United States Government, the state, the county or the city, and it shall be unlawful for any such driver to violate any of the provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise permitted in this chapter or by state statute. 
(T.C., § 3-6) 
Sec. 61-11. - Unattended motor vehicle. 
    No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand unattended without first stopping the engine, locking the ignition, removing the key, and effectively setting the brake thereon and, when standing upon any grade turning the front wheels to the curb or side of the highway. 
(T.C., § 9-25) 
Sec. 61-12. - Opening and closing vehicle doors. 
    No person shall open the door of a motor vehicle on the side available to moving traffic unless and until it is reasonably safe to do so, nor shall any person leave a door open on the side of a motor vehicle available to moving traffic for a period of time longer than necessary to load or unload passengers. 
(T.C., § 9-9) 
Sec. 61-13. - Boarding or alighting from streetcars or vehicles. 
    No person shall board or alight from any streetcar or vehicle while such streetcar or vehicle is in motion. 
(T.C., § 10-1) 
Sec. 61-14. - Clinging to vehicles. 
    No person riding upon any bicycle, coaster, roller skates, sled or toy vehicle shall attach the same or himself to any streetcar or vehicle upon a roadway. 
(T.C., § 9-11) 
Sec. 61-15. - Unlawful riding. 
    No person shall ride on any streetcar or vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(T.C., § 10-2) 
Sec. 61-16. - Use of coasters, roller skates and similar devices restricted. 
    No person upon roller skates, or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle, or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a street on a crosswalk; and when so crossing, such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(T.C., § 3-5) 
Sec. 61-17. - Cleaning or repairing automobiles on streets or sidewalks. 
    No person shall clean or cause to be cleaned an automobile or other motor vehicle upon any street or sidewalk of the city nor shall any person repair or cause to be repaired any automobile or other motor vehicle upon any street or sidewalk of the city, except that where an automobile or other motor vehicle while in the course of a trip or journey and upon a street of the city becomes injured, so that it cannot, without further injury, proceed upon its journey or to a suitable place of repair or storage not upon a street or sidewalk of the city, then a person may make or cause to be made such temporary or minor repairs upon such automobile or other motor vehicle while it is upon a street in the city as will enable the automobile or other motor vehicle to proceed, without injury, upon its journey or to a suitable place of repair or storage not upon a street or sidewalk of the city. 
(T.C., § 22-10) 
Sec. 61-18. - Glass, etc., on street, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, place or deposit or leave or cause to be thrown, placed, deposited or left in any street, alley, public place or square, or in any private place or premises any glass, broken or unbroken, or metal, stone or earthenware, tacks, cinders, planks, shingles, or other substances of a nature likely to cause injury to travelers or pedestrians, or to automobiles, bicycles or other vehicles or likely to cause injury to any horse or animal or which might cut or puncture any pneumatic tire. 
(T.C., § 22-11) 
Sec. 61-19. - Shrubs, trees, etc., at intersections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, grow or maintain within thirty (30) feet of a street corner, any bush, shrub or flower, which exceeds three (3) feet in height. It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, grow or maintain within thirty (30) feet of any street corner any tree, any of the limbs of which are nearer than eight (8) feet to the ground. The purpose of this section is to provide a clear vision, in a space beginning three (3) feet about the ground and ending eight (8) feet above the ground and extending back in each direction from street corners for a distance of thirty (30) feet, to persons operating vehicles along the streets of the city. 
(b)  Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of subsection (a) shall be punished as provided in chapter 1, article II, City Code (1991). It shall be the duty of the judge of the municipal court, when trying a case under the provisions of subsection (a), to render an order directing the person convicted hereunder to either trim or remove the bush, shrub, flower, plant or tree, grown, planted or maintained, in violation of subsection (a) within five (5) days of the date of the conviction. If such order is not complied with within five (5) days of the date of the conviction, the court shall render an order directing the captain of police in charge of traffic to cause such bush, shrub, flower, plant or tree to be removed or trimmed. The captain and the officers acting under his direction shall have the right to enter on the property involved for the purpose of carrying out such order. If it becomes necessary for such officer to cause such bush, shrub, flower, plant or tree to be trimmed or removed, there shall be taxed as costs against the person convicted a further sum equal to the reasonable cost of the labor expended in such trimming or removal. 
(T.C., §§ 22-12, 22-13) 
Cross reference- Minimum landscape requirements, § 64-4.E. 
Sec. 61-20. - Tinting of windshields of vehicles. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts the following in compliance with Section 32-5-215(a) and Chapter 5C, Sections 32-5C, Sections 32-5C-1 et seq., Code of Alabama, 1975: 
(1)  No vehicle operated on the streets of the city shall have applied or affixed to the front windshield any material or glazing which reduces light transmission through the front windshield. 
(2)  No vehicle operated on the streets of the city shall have applied or affixed to the rear windshield or the side or door windows any material or glazing which reduces light transmission through the rear windshield or side windows to less than thirty-two (32) percent or increases light reflectance to more than twenty (20) percent, with a measurement tolerance of at least three (3) percent. The light transmission shall be measured with a device or instrument capable of measuring light transmission before a person may be charged with a violation of this section, and the officer shall be equipped with such a meter before stopping the driver. 
(b)  Exceptions to the provisions of subsection (a) hereinabove shall be those exceptions as set out in § 32-5C-3, Code of Alabama, 1975. 
(c)  Upon application to the Department of Public Safety of the State of Alabama from a person required for medical reasons to be shielded from the direct rays of the sun, an exemption may be issued by the state from the provisions and requirements of Chapter 5, §§ 32-5C-1 et seq., 1975 Code of Alabama, for any motor vehicle owned by the person or in which such person is a habitual passenger. The application shall be supported by a written statement of fact from a physician licensed to practice medicine in the State of Alabama. The exemption may be issued with the conditions and limitations prescribed by the Department of Public Safety. Any exemption so issued by the state likewise exempt such vehicle from the provisions and requirements of this section. 
(d)  Any motor vehicle which has material and glazing applied or affixed to the windows or rear windshield of a vehicle, which material and glazing have reduced the light transmission through the window or windshield or increased the light reflectance of the window or windshield, shall display a label visible from the outside of the vehicle indicating that the windows or windshield are in compliance with the light transmission and light reflectance requirements as provided herein. No person shall knowingly install any material upon the windshield or windows of any motor vehicle, the installation of which would result in a reduction of light transmission or an increase in light reflection in violation of the provisions herein. 
(e)  Any person found in violation of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and for a first conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ten (10) days, or by both fine and imprisonment; for a second conviction for an offense committed within one (1) year after the date of the first offense, the person shall be punished by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00), or by imprisonment for not more than thirty (30) days, or by both fine and imprisonment; and for a third conviction for a subsequent offense committed within one (1) year after the date of the first offense, the person shall be punished by a fine not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than three (3) months, or by both fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 61-068, §§ 1-5, 10-1-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 61-068, §§ 1-5, adopted October 1, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 61-20 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 61-21-61-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 61-41. - Authority of police and fire department officials. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police to enforce all street traffic laws of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in this city. 
(b)  Officers of the police department or such officers as are assigned by the chief of police are hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand, or signal in conformance with the traffic laws, provided that, in the event of a fire or other emergency or to expedite traffic or to safeguard pedestrians, officers of the police department may direct traffic as conditions may require notwithstanding the provisions of the traffic laws. 
(c)  Officers of the fire department, when at the scene of a fire, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. 
(T.C., § 3-1) 
Sec. 61-42. - Police administration of traffic division. 
    There is hereby established in the police department of this city a traffic division to be under the control of an officer of police. 
(T.C., § 2-1) 
Sec. 61-43. - Duty of traffic division. 
    It shall be the duty of the traffic division with such aid as may be rendered by other duly authorized city employees to enforce the street traffic regulations of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in this city, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents and to cooperate with the city traffic engineer and other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties specially imposed upon the division by this chapter and the traffic ordinances of this city. 
(T.C., § 2-2) 
Sec. 61-44. - Records of traffic violations. 
(a)  The traffic division of the police department, or any other city employee duly authorized for such by the mayor, shall keep a record of all violations of the traffic ordinances of this city or of the state vehicle laws of which any person had been chargedtogether with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Said record shall accumulate during at least a five-year period and from that time on the record shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent five-year period. 
(b)  All forms for records of violations and notices of violations shall be serially numbered. For each month and year a written record shall be kept available to the public showing the disposal of all such forms. All such records and reports shall be public records. 
(T.C., § 2-3) 
Sec. 61-45. - Record of traffic cases; report of convictions to state. 
(a)  Every magistrate or judge of a court shall keep or cause to be kept a record of every traffic complaint, traffic citation, or other legal form of traffic charge deposited with or presented to said court, and shall keep a record of every official action by said court or its clerk in reference thereto, including but not limited to a record of every conviction, forfeiture of bail, judgment of acquittal, and the amount of fine or forfeiture resulting from every said traffic complaint or citation deposited with or presented to said court or traffic violations bureau. 
(b)  Within ten (10) days after the conviction or forfeiture of bail of a person upon a charge of violating any provision of this act or other law regulating the operation of vehicles on highways every magistrate of the court or clerk of the court of record in which such conviction was had or bail was forfeited shall prepare and immediately forward to the state department of public safety an abstract of the record of said court covering the case in which the person was so convicted or forfeited bail, which abstract must be certified by the person so required to prepare the same to be true and correct. Report need not be made of any conviction involving the illegal parking or standing of a vehicle. 
(c)  The abstract must be made upon a form furnished by the state department of public safety and shall include the name and address of the party charged, the number, if any, of his operator's or chauffeur's license, the registration number of the vehicle involved, the nature of the offense, the date of hearing, the plea, the judgment, or whether bail was forfeited, and the amount of the fine and forfeiture as the case may be. 
(d)  Every court shall, also, forward a like report to the state department of public safety upon the conviction of any person of manslaughter or other felony in the commission of which a vehicle was used. 
(e)  The failure, refusal or neglect of any such judicial officer to comply with any of the requirements of this section shall constitute misconduct in office and shall be grounds for removal therefrom. 
(T.C., § 19-13) 
Sec. 61-46. - Driver files to be maintained. 
(a)  The police department or the record division therefor shall maintain a suitable record of all traffic accidents, warnings, arrests, convictions and complaints reported for each driver, which shall be filed alphabetically under the name of the driver concerned. 
(b)  The division shall study the cases of all the drivers charged with frequent or serious violations of the traffic laws or involved in frequent traffic accidents or any serious accident, and shall attempt to discover the reasons therefor, and shall take whatever steps are lawful and reasonable to prevent the same or to have the licenses of such persons suspended or revoked. 
(T.C., § 2-7) 
Sec. 61-47. - Record division to submit annual traffic-safety report. 
    The record division shall annually prepare a traffic report which shall be filed with the mayor. Such report shall contain information on traffic matters in this city as follows: 
(1)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the number of persons injured and other pertinent traffic accident data; 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the police; 
(3)  The plans and recommendations of the division for future traffic safety activities. 
(T.C., § 2-8) 
Sec. 61-48. - City traffic engineer. 
(a)  The office of city traffic engineer is hereby established. The city traffic engineer shall be a qualified engineer and shall be appointed under civil service and he shall exercise the powers and duties as provided in this chapter and in the traffic ordinances of this city. 
(b)  It shall be the general duty of the city traffic engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic control devices, to conduct engineering analyses of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering investigation of traffic conditions, to plan the operation of traffic on the streets and highways of this city, and to cooperate with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and duties imposed by ordinances of this city. 
(T.C., § 2-10) 
Sec. 61-49. - Emergency and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The chief of police by and with the approval of the city traffic engineer is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of the traffic ordinances of this city and to make and enforce temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. No such temporary or experimental regulation shall remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. 
(b)  The city traffic engineer may test traffic control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(T.C., § 2-11) 
Sec. 61-50. - City traffic engineer to designate crosswalks and establish safety zones. 
    The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized: 
(1)  To designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway, and at such other places as he may deem necessary; 
(2)  To establish safety zones of such kind and character and at such places as he may deem necessary for the protection of pedestrians. 
(T.C., § 4-12) 
Sec. 61-51. - Traffic lanes. 
(a)  The city traffic engineer is hereby authorized to mark traffic lanes upon the roadway of any street or highway where a regular alignment of traffic is necessary. 
(b)  Where such traffic lanes have been marked, it shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to fail or refuse to keep such vehicle within the boundaries of any such lane, except when lawfully passing another vehicle or preparatory to making a lawful turning movement. 
(T.C., § 4-13) 
Sec. 61-52. - Traffic division to designate method of identifying funeral processions. 
    The traffic division shall designate a type of pennant or other identifying insignia to be displayed upon, or other method to be employed to identify the vehicles in funeral processions. 
(T.C., § 2-9) 
Sec. 61-53. - Fines to be specified. 
    The magistrate or magistrates who hear traffic cases shall designate the specified offenses under the traffic ordinances of the city and the traffic laws of the state in respect to which payments of fines may be accepted by the clerk of the municipal court, in satisfaction thereof, and shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of such fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided such fines are within the limits declared by law and ordinance, and shall further specify what number of such offenses shall require appearance before the magistrate. 
(T.C., § 18-1) 
Sec. 61-54. - When person charged may elect to appear before magistrate. 
(a)  Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may be made to the clerk of the municipal court shall have the option of paying such fine within the time specified in the notice of arrest at the office of the clerk of the municipal court upon entering a plea of guilty and upon waiving appearance in court; or may have the option of depositing required lawful bail, and upon a plea of not guilty shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. 
(b)  The payment of a fine to the clerk of the municipal court shall be deemed an acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged offense, and, upon accepting the prescribed fine, the violator shall be issued a receipt as acknowledgment of payment thereof. 
(T.C., § 18-2) 
Sec. 61-55. - Duties of clerk under sections 61-53 and 61-54. 
    The following duties are hereby imposed upon the clerk of the municipal court, in reference to traffic offenses: 
(1)  He shall accept designated fines, issue receipts and represent in court such violators as are permitted and desire to plead guilty, waive court appearance, and give power of attorney. 
(2)  He shall receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time of their appearance on the court docket, and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be present. 
(3)  He shall make available to the court the record of all violations of which each person has been convicted within the city and its police jurisdiction. 
(T.C., § 18-3) 
Sec. 61-56. - Clerk of the municipal court to keep records. 
    The clerk of the municipal court shall keep records and submit summarized monthly reports to the city council of all notices issued and arrests made for violations of the traffic laws and ordinances in the city and of all the fines collected by the traffic violations bureau or the court, and of the final disposition or present status of every case of violation of the provisions of said laws and ordinances. Such records shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the totals of each. The records shall be public records. 
(T.C., § 18-4) 
Sec. 61-57. - Chemical breath analysis for blood alcohol content. 
    The city in compliance with Section 32-5-192 of the Code of Alabama, 1975, as amended, does hereby designate the chemical analysis of the breath by use of the photoelectric intoximeter as the test to be administered by its officers approved by the state department of health pursuant to Section 32-5A-194 to determine the alcoholic content of the blood of any person lawfully arrested for any offense arising out of acts alleged to have been committed while the person was driving a motor vehicle on the public highways of the state while under the influence of intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. No. 29-006, § 1, 1-28-75) 
Sec. 61-58. - Inspection of vehicles in violation of minor safety infractions. 
    In the event of a minor vehicle equipment violation, the ticketed person shall have seventy-two (72) hours in which to repair or have the equipment repaired, excluding Sundays and legal holidays. The ticketed person may present the ticket and the repaired vehicle to any police officer at a city police department police precinct for a vehicle inspection. Upon confirmation of the completed repair, the officer shall complete the proper portion of the uniform traffic complaint. The officer shall return this ticket to municipal court through established police channels for the court to nol-pros. The officer shall also collect a reinspection fee of ten dollars ($10.00) from the ticketed person, issuing that individual a numbered receipt for the payment. The city police department shall collect and account for these funds using applicable established city cash management procedures. These funds will be forwarded to the city's comptroller for deposit in a special fund earmarked for public safety/policing projects not covered within the police department's regular general fund budget. Once a year, by August 1, the police department shall report to the mayor the total funds accumulated in this account, and the manner in which these funds have been expended. 
(Ord. 61-018, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Secs. 61-59-61-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - TRAFFIC CONTROL 

Sec. 61-70. - Standard Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices Code adopted. 
    The Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as provided by the U.S. Department of Transportation, Federal Highway Administration, Publication No. FHWA-SA-89-006, HTO-21/2-89(15M)P, as amended, has been on file in the office of the city clerk of the City of Mobile, Alabama, pursuant to a resolution adopted by the city council on April 16, 1996, is hereby adopted as the "Standard Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices Code" of the city. 
(Ord. No. 61-028, § 1, 5-15-96) 
Sec. 61-71. - Authority to install traffic control devices. 
    The city traffic engineer shall place and maintain or cause to be placed and maintained, traffic control signs, signals and devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of the ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional traffic control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the traffic ordinances of this city or under state law or to guide or warn traffic. 
(T.C., § 4-1) 
Sec. 61-72. - Obedience to official traffic control devices. 
    The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic control device applicable thereto, placed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise directed by a traffic or police officer, subject to the exceptions granted the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle. 
(T.C., § 4-3) 
Sec. 61-73. - Obedience to signals and signs at intersections. 
(a)  At every street intersection in the city where the signal system of red and green lights is in use and being operated, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian or the operator of a vehicle to make the crossing at such intersection in the face of the danger signal of the red light; provided, that if such movement across the street is commenced toward the green light, the movement may be continued across the street in the event the light is changed after the movement in and across the street is commenced. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating any vehicle through or across any street intersection in the city to turn such vehicle to the left where there is a traffic sign attached to the traffic light or on a post or standard at the intersection in plain view of the operator stating that no such turn is permitted and it shall also be unlawful for any such person to make any right turn at any such intersection where there is such a traffic sign stating that no right turn is permitted. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person operating any vehicle to cut through private or public property to avoid any traffic control device. 
(T.C., § 3-12) 
Sec. 61-74. - Signals to be in accordance with manual and specification for traffic control devices. 
    All signs and signals required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the city. All traffic control devices so erected and not inconsistent with the provisions of the laws of the state or this chapter shall be official traffic control devices. 
(T.C., § 4-2) 
Sec. 61-75. - Manual on traffic control devices adopted. 
    The Alabama Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices, as may be amended from time to time by the Alabama Highway Department, is hereby adopted as the manual on traffic control devices for the city. 
(Ord. No. 37-098, § 1, 8-7-79) 
Sec. 61-76. - When traffic signs required for enforcement purposes. 
    No provisions of this chapter for which signs are required shall be enforced against an alleged violator if at the time and place of the alleged violation an official sign is not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person. Whenever a particular section does not state that signs are required, such section shall be effective even though no signs are erected or in place. 
(T.C., § 4-4) 
Sec. 61-77. - Notice to public where signs, etc. are required. 
    Wherever notice to public is required under the terms of this chapter any of the approved methods of giving such notice as set out in the current Alabama Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways shall be sufficient to give notice to the public as required by this chapter. 
(T.C., § 9-33) 
Sec. 61-78. - Traffic control signal legend. 
(a)  Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic control signals exhibiting different colored lights or colored lighted arrows successively, one at a time, or in any combination, only the colors green, red and yellow shall be used except for special pedestrian signals carrying a word or symbol legend and the lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(1)  Green indication: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing a circular green signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left, unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn. But vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited. 
b.  Vehicular traffic facing a green arrow signal shown alone or in combination with another indication may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow or such other movement as is permitted by other indications shown at the same time. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
c.  Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal as provided in section 61-79, pedestrians facing any green signal except when the sole green signal is a turn arrow may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(2)  Steady yellow indication: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular yellow or yellow arrow signal is thereby warned that the related green movement is being terminated or that a red indication will be exhibited immediately thereafter. 
b.  Pedestrians facing a steady circular yellow or yellow arrow signal unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal as provided in section 61-79 are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway before a red indication is shown, and no pedestrian shall then start to cross the roadway. 
(3)  Steady red indication: 
a.  Vehicular traffic facing a steady circular red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, if none, then before entering the intersection and shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown except as provided in subdivision (3)b. 
b.  Except when a sign is in place prohibiting a turn, vehicular traffic facing any steady red signal may cautiously enter the intersection to turn right or to turn left from a oneway street into a oneway street after stopping as required by subdivision (3)a. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
c.  Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian control signal as provided in section 61-79, pedestrians facing a steady circular red signal alone shall not enter the roadway. 
(b)  In the event an official traffic control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this section shall be applicable except as to those provisions which by their nature can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any such signal or marking the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(T.C., § 4-5) 
Sec. 61-79. - Pedestrian control signals. 
    Whenever special pedestrian control signals exhibiting the words or symbols "Walk" or "Don't Walk" are in place, such signals shall indicate as follows: 
(1)  Walk. Pedestrians facing such signal may proceed across the roadway in the direction of the signal and shall be given the right-of-way by the drivers of all vehicles. 
(2)  Don't Walk. No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the walk signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the "don't walk" signal is showing. 
(3)  Don't Walk (flashing). No pedestrian shall start to cross the roadway in the direction of such signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the "walk" signal shall proceed to a sidewalk or safety island while the "don't walk" signal is flashing. 
(T.C., § 4-6) 
Sec. 61-80. - Flashing signals. 
(a)  Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic sign or signal it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop) signal. When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop before entering the nearest crosswalk at an intersection or at a limit line when marked, of if none, then before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution) signal. When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through the intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(b)  This section shall not apply at railroad grade crossings. Conduct of drivers of vehicles approaching railroad grade crossings shall be governed by the rules as set forth in section 61-393. 
(T.C., § 4-7) 
Sec. 61-80.1. - Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markings. 
(a)  No person shall place, maintain or display upon or in view of any highway, an unauthorized sign, signal, marking or device which purports to be or is an imitation of or resembles an official traffic control device or railroad signal or sign, or which attempts to direct the movement of traffic, or which hides from view or interferes with the effectiveness of any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal. 
(b)  No person shall place or maintain nor shall any public authority permit upon any highway any traffic sign or signal bearing thereon any commercial advertising, except with permission of the city. 
(c)  This section shall not be deemed to prohibit the erection upon private property adjacent to highways of signs giving useful directional information and of a type that cannot be mistaken for official signs. 
(d)  Every such prohibited sign, signal or marking is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and the authority having jurisdiction over the highway is hereby empowered to remove the same or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(T.C., § 4-8) 
Sec. 61-80.2. - Interference with official traffic control devices or railroad signs or signals. 
    No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic control device or any railroad sign or signal or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or any other part thereof. 
(T.C., § 4-9) 
DIVISION 3. - CITATIONS 

Sec. 61-81. - Failure to obey citation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate his written promise to appear given to an officer upon the issuance of a traffic citation regardless of the disposition of the charge for which such citation was originally issued. 
(T.C., § 19-8) 
Sec. 61-82. - Procedure of police officers. 
    Except when authorized or directed under the laws of the state to immediately take a person before a magistrate for the violation of any traffic laws, a police officer who halts a person for such violation other than for the purpose of giving him a warning or warning notice and does not take such person into custody under arrest, shall take the name, address and operator's license number of the person, the registered number of the motor vehicle involved and such other pertinent information as may be necessary, and shall issue to him in writing on a form provided by the city, a traffic citation containing a notice to answer to the charge against him in the municipal court of the city at a time at least five (5) days after such alleged violation to be specified in the citation. The officer, upon receiving the written promise of the alleged violator to answer as specified in the citation, shall release the person from custody. 
(T.C., § 19-3) 
Sec. 61-83. - Disposition and records of traffic citations, warrants and complaints. 
(a)  Every police officer upon issuing a traffic citation to an alleged violator of any provision of the motor vehicle laws of the state or the traffic ordinances of the city shall deposit the original citation with his immediate superior, who shall cause the same to be delivered to the clerk of the municipal court. 
(b)  Upon the filing of such citation in the office of the clerk of municipal court of this city as aforesaid, the citation may be disposed of only by trial in the court or by other official action by a judge of the court, including forfeiture of bail or by payment of a fine, except before a warrant of arrest has been issued for a person for failing to appear as provided by section 61-82, the chief of police with the approval of the executive director of public safety or the mayor, or the executive director of public safety or the mayor personally may excuse or void a traffic citation for good cause. 
(c)  The chief of police shall require the return to him of each traffic citation and all copies thereof, which has been spoiled or upon which any entry has been made and has not been issued to an alleged violator. 
(d)  The chief of police shall also maintain or cause to be maintained in connection with every traffic citation issued by a member of the police department a record of the disposition of the charge by the municipal court or its traffic violations bureau. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful and official misconduct for any member of the police department or other officer or public employee to dispose of, alter, or deface a traffic citation or any copy thereof, or the record of the issuance or disposition of any traffic citation, complaint or warrant, in a manner other than as required in this section. 
(T.C., § 19-4) 
Sec. 61-84. - Illegal cancellation of traffic citations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cancel or solicit the cancellation of any traffic citation in any manner other than as provided by proper authority. 
(T.C., § 19-5) 
Sec. 61-85. - Audit of records and reports. 
(a)  Every record of traffic citation, complaints thereon, and warrants issued therefor required in this article shall be audited at least annually and a report of such audit together with a summary thereof submitted to the city council. Such reports shall be public records. 
(b)  The clerk of the municipal court shall publish or cause to be published a monthly summary of all traffic citations issued by members of the police department, the disposition of the complaints thereon, and the issuance and disposition of all warrants issued therefor. 
(c)  For the purpose of this article, the city or its duly authorized representatives shall have access at all times to all necessary records, files and papers of the municipal court of the city, its traffic bureau and the police department. 
(T.C., § 19-6) 
Sec. 61-86. - When copy of citation shall be deemed a lawful complaint. 
    In the event the form of citation provided under section 61-91 includes information and is sworn to as required under the general laws of the state in respect to a complaint charging commission of the offense alleged in the citation to have been committed, then such citation when filed with a court having jurisdiction shall be deemed to be a lawful complaint for the purpose of prosecution under this chapter. 
(T.C., § 19-7) 
Sec. 61-87. - Citation on illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of the city or by state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic citation, on a form provided by the city, for the driver to answer to the charge against him within five (5) days, during the hours and at a place specified in the citation. 
(T.C., § 19-9) 
Sec. 61-88. - Failure to comply with traffic citation attached to parked vehicle. 
    If a violator of the restriction on stopping, standing or parking under the traffic laws or ordinances does not appear in response to a traffic citation affixed to such motor vehicle within a period of five (5) days, the clerk of the municipal court shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the traffic citation was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that in the event such letter is disregarded for a period of five (5) additional days a warrant of arrest will be issued. 
(T.C., § 19-10) 
Sec. 61-89. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. 
(a)  In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(b)  The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the prosecution as prescribed in sections 61-81 and 61-86 has been followed. 
(T.C., § 19-11) 
Sec. 61-90. - When warrant to be issued. 
    In the event any person fails to comply with a traffic citation given to such person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the municipal court, the clerk of the municipal court shall secure and issue a warrant for his arrest. 
(T.C., § 19-12) 
Sec. 61-91. - Forms and records of traffic citations and arrests. 
(a)  The city shall provide books to include traffic citation forms for notifying alleged violators to appear and answer to charges of violating traffic laws and ordinances in the municipal court of the city. The books shall include serially numbered sets of citations in duplicate in the form prescribed. 
(b)  The city shall issue such books to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent and shall maintain a record of every book so issued and shall require a written receipt for every such book. 
(c)  The chief of police shall be responsible for the issuance of such books to individual members of the police department. The chief of police shall require a written receipt for every book so issued and shall maintain a record of every such book and each set of citations contained therein. 
(T.C., § 19-2) 
Sec. 61-92. - Commercial motor vehicles-Citation for multiple violations. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to provide for issuance of a single citation for common, multiple violations existing in and on commercial motor vehicles, to designate the charge for multiple violations and to set the fine for violations thereunder. 
(b)  Applicability. This section shall apply to every commercial motor vehicle engaging in interstate or intrastate commerce, and more particularly described and defined as set out in the U.S. Department of Transportation Regulations, Federal Highway Administration. 
(c)  Charge for multiple violations. Section 396.3 of the Department of Transportation Regulations, CFR Manual 49, provides that all motor carriers shall systematically inspect, repair, and maintain, or cause to be systematically inspected, repaired, and maintained, all motor vehicles subject to their control. In order to better assure compliance with guidelines established by the Department of Transportation, and to provide for a more equitable means of enforcement, a fine of one hundred eighteen dollars ($118.00) is herewith established, for multiple violations found in and on commercial motor vehicles, under Code Section 396.3, Inspection, Repair and Maintenance (Department of Transportation Regulations, CFR Manual 49), and a single citation shall be issued for such multiple violations, citing the charge 396.3, Failure to Inspect, Repair and Maintain, with each violation found to be set out separately on such citation. (See Exhibit A, which is not set out herein but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk.) In the event a single violation occurs, a citation shall be written for the single charge, in accordance with the existing schedule of fines for such violation. (See Exhibit A). 
(Ord. No. 61-069, §§ 1-3, 10-1-96) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 61-069, §§ 1-3, adopted October 1, 1996, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as § 61-92 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 61-93-61-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 61-101. - When to be impounded. 
(a)  City police officers and other duly authorized city employees are hereby authorized to have removed from the streets, sidewalks, alleys or other public places in the city or its police jurisdiction, any vehicle left thereon in violation of any municipal traffic or parking law or ordinance. In addition thereto, but not in limitation thereof, members of the police department and other duly authorized city employees are authorized to have vehicles immobilized and/or removed from the streets, or other public places, under the following alphabetized circumstances: 
(1)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon any bridge, viaduct or causeway or any tube or tunnel where such vehicle constitutes an obstruction to traffic. 
(2)  When a vehicle upon a street is so disabled as to constitute an obstruction to traffic and the person in charge of the vehicle is by reason of physical injury incapacitated to such an extent as to be unable to provide for its custody or removal. 
(3)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street and is so parked illegally as to constitute a definite hazard or obstruction to the normal movement of traffic or is parked in violation of any parking ordinance governing the parking of vehicles on the streets. 
(4)  When any vehicle is left unattended upon a street which has been designated by the city as on the route of a Mardi Gras parade, during the period commencing two (2) hours immediately prior to the beginning of the Mardi Gras parade and during the time of such parade. 
(5)  Whenever there is found any motor vehicle parked upon the streets or public areas of the city which has previously received one or more traffic or parking citations which are unpaid or otherwise unsettled. 
(b)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street as authorized in this section and the officer knows or is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle, the name and address of the owner thereof, such officer shall immediately give or cause to be given notice in writing to such owner of the fact of such removal and the reasons therefor and of the place to which such vehicle has been removed. In the event any such vehicle is stored in a public garage, a copy of such notice shall be given to the proprietor of such garage. 
(c)  Whenever an officer removes a vehicle from a street under this section and does not know and is not able to ascertain the name of the owner, or for any other reason is unable to give the notice to the owner as hereinbefore provided, and in the event the vehicle is not returned to the owner within a period of three (3) days, then and in the event the officer shall immediately send or cause to be sent a written report of such removal by mail to the state department of public safety, whose duty it is to register motor vehicles, and shall file a copy of such notice with the proprietor of any public garage in which the vehicle may be stored. Such notice shall include a complete description of the vehicle, the date, time and place from which removed, the reasons for such removal, and the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored. 
(T.C., §§ 19-14, 23-1; Ord. No. 37-062, § 1, 8-27-91) 
Sec. 61-102. - Immobilization and towing for outstanding traffic fines. 
(a)  Authorized. Whenever an automobile or other motor vehicle is left parked or standing illegally, and such automobile or motor vehicle is or has been identified by license number or vehicle identification number to be registered within this state, and the municipal court for the city or other court of jurisdiction has on file a record of failure to appear or failure to pay any municipal parking or traffic fines on the registered owner of the vehicle, any police officer or duly authorized agent of the chief of police and the police department shall have authority to immobilize and/or tow such motor vehicle to a garage or other storage area designated or maintained by the police department or the city. A motor vehicle immobilized or towed under this section shall not be released or returned to its registered owner until all fines are paid to the municipal court clerk's office, or such other court as may be applicable. 
(b)  Special immobilization provisions. Any vehicle identified as a public nuisance, because it is found by a city police officer or other duly authorized city employee to be parked upon a city street or public highway, even though it has previously received one or more municipal traffic or parking citations which remain unpaid or otherwise unsettled, may be immobilized, towed and/or impounded pursuant to the provision of this chapter. If the immobilization option is chosen by the city police officer, or any other duly authorized city employee, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Immobilization shall be at the direction of a city police officer or other city employee charged with such responsibility. 
(2)  Upon immobilization the officer or employee shall place upon the vehicle a notice sufficient to warn the owner or driver that the vehicle has been immobilized and any attempt to move or drive it may result in damage; such notice shall also inform the owner or driver of the reason for immobilization. 
(3)  Immobilization shall remain in place for forty-eight (48) hours unless sooner released in accordance with 61-104 herein. If compliance with section 61-104 has not occurred within forty-eight (48) hours, the vehicle shall be towed and impounded, as per the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Burden of proof on owner of vehicle illegally parked. The presence of an unattended automobile or other motor vehicle left parked or standing illegally shall raise a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the automobile or other motor vehicle committed or authorized the parking violation, and the burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise. 
(d)  Applicable to owners only. This section shall not apply to an automobile or other motor vehicle unless the failure to appear or municipal traffic or policy fines were incurred by the registered owner thereof. If such automobile or motor vehicle has been identified by license number or vehicle identification number or be registered within this state, any other state or territory of the United States, and the municipal court for the city or other court of jurisdiction has on file a record of failure to appear or pay any municipal traffic or parking fines, there shall be prima facie presumption that such failure to appear or fines were incurred by the registered owner thereof, and the burden of proof shall be upon the registered owner to show otherwise. 
(e)  Release of wrongly impounded vehicles. For the purpose of this section, any such vehicles immobilized and/or towed by the police department, or any other duly authorized city employee or agent, under the circumstances described in subsection (d) i.e., when the registered owner shows proof that he did not incur the fines, shall be immediately released to registered owner thereof; and the Mobile police department, its authorized agents, servants and employees, shall not be liable for the wrongful repossession, detention, immobilization or towing of such vehicle, or any damages resulting therefrom, if done in good faith. 
(Ord. No. 47-085, §§ 1-4, 10-23-84; Ord. No. 37-062, § 2, 8-27-91) 
Sec. 61-103. - Storage of immobilized and impounded vehicle; notice to owner; notice to state department registering vehicles. 
    Whenever any police officer or other duly authorized city employee causes a vehicle to be removed from a street as authorized by this division, he shall direct that the vehicle be placed in storage in a place of safety designated for such storage by the city and he shall immediately report such action to the chief of police, who will cause to be maintained permanent records showing the date of removal of such vehicle, the place where such vehicle was found and a description of such vehicle. If the chief of police is able to ascertain from the registration records in the vehicle or from the license tags on the vehicle, the name and address of the owner of such vehicle, then he shall immediately notify such owner of the fact of such removal and the reason therefor. In the event the owner of such vehicle does not appear and take possession of such vehicle within a period of three (3) days from its removal from a street, then the chief of police shall send a written report of such removal and storage to the state department having charge of automobile registrations setting forth the date, time and place of such removal, the name of the garage or place where the vehicle is stored, and a complete description of such vehicle. 
(T.C., § 23-2; Ord. No. 37-062, § 3, 8-27-91) 
Sec. 61-104. - Redemption of immobilized and impounded vehicles by owner. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle has been immobilized or impounded pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, the owner thereof may redeem the same by paying the fine imposed for such municipal traffic or parking violation plus the reasonable cost of having such vehicle immobilized or removed from the streets, which amount shall be one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00), plus the cost of having such vehicle stored, if applicable, after it has been immobilized or impounded for a period of twenty-four (24) hours, such additional cost shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) for each day such vehicle is impounded after the expiration of the first twenty-four (24) hours following the impounding thereof. However, if the vehicle has already been advertised for sale, the owner must pay for the expense thereof before he may redeem his vehicle. 
(T.C., § 23-3; Ord. No. 37-062, § 4, 8-27-91; Ord. No. 61-043-2007, § 1, 10-23-07) 
Sec. 61-105. - Reclaiming immobilized and impounded vehicles. 
(a)  When a motor vehicle is immobilized, towed and/or impounded by the police department or any other duly authorized city employee, for any reason, the owner or other person claiming to be the owner or reasonably believed to be lawfully entitled to possession of the motor vehicle shall be notified by the police department of two (2) options available: 
(1)  The owner or other person lawfully entitled to possession of the motor vehicle may, upon a showing of satisfactory proof of ownership or entitlement of possession to the proper members of the police department, pay the immobilization, towing and storage fees, recover the vehicle and, if it is desirable, may demand a hearing in the municipal court at a later date on the question of responsibility for the immobilization, towing and storage fees. If any member of the police department feels that it is necessary to hold the motor vehicle and not release it under this option, then the owner or other person lawfully entitled to possession of the motor vehicle may proceed under option (2) as provided herein; or, 
(2)  The owner or other person claiming to be the owner or claiming to be lawfully entitled to possession of the motor vehicle may demand a hearing in the municipal court on the questions of immediate possession of the vehicle and the payment of any immobilization, towing and storage fees. If reasonably practical, a hearing will be held at the same time on any alleged violation of law pertaining to the immobilization or towing of the vehicle. The hearing on the questions of immediate possession of the vehicle and the payment of any immobilization, towing and storage fees as provided for in this option must be held within twenty-four (24) hours (excluding holidays and weekends) from the time that the owner or other person claiming to be the owner or claiming to be lawfully entitled to possession of the motor vehicle notifies the clerk of the municipal court of the demand for a hearing. 
(b)  In the event that the owner or other person claiming to be the owner or claiming to be lawfully entitled to possession of the vehicle chooses option (1) in paragraph (a) above, and the judge presiding at any hearing provided for in option (1) finds that this person shall not be responsible for the payment of the immobilization, towing and storage fees, then the clerk of the municipal court shall supply the person with proof of the finding and he may submit this, along with a request for a refund of his immobilization, towing and storage fees, to the legal department of the city, which will then process the refund. 
(c)  In the event that the owner or other person claiming to be the owner of claiming to be lawfully entitled to possession of a immobilized or towed vehicle chooses option (2) in paragraph (a) above, and the judge presiding at the hearing finds that the person should be entitled to immediate possession of the vehicle (either with or without the payment of immobilization, towing or storage fees) and the vehicle is in storage on the day of the aforementioned hearing, upon receipt of proof of the finding supplied by the clerk of the municipal court, the person, firm or corporation holding the towed vehicle shall immediately release it to the owner or other person found to be lawfully entitled to possession, provided that the person pays any immobilization, towing and storage fees which he is found to be responsible for at the aforementioned hearing. 
(d)  All demands for a hearing under this section shall be made to the clerk of the municipal court. 
(e)  It shall be the responsibility of the Mobile police officer causing any motor vehicle to be immobilized or towed to see that the owner or person claiming to be the owner or claiming to be lawfully entitled to possession is notified of the immobilization and/or towing, and also of the options available under this section. The officer may satisfy this requirement by supplying necessary information to the police operator and requesting that the operator make the required notification. The police operator will then make every reasonable effort, including the use of telephones or use of the mails if necessary, to make the required notification as soon as possible. The operator shall notify the requesting officer when such notification has been made. After attempting notification every five (5) days for a period of fifteen (15) consecutive days without success, the operator shall notify the requesting officer of the lack of notification, whereupon the officer shall notify the proper official within the police department of the circumstances so that proper disposition of the motor vehicle may be made. It shall be the responsibility of the requesting officer to follow up on the request and insure that the request is carried out by the police operator. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of the clerk of the municipal court to notify the proper members of the police department of any hearing which is to be held pursuant to this section. 
(g)  In those cases where pursuant to the authority or paragraph (c) above, an immobilized and/or towed vehicle is released to the owner or other person found to be lawfully entitled to possession thereof without the person being responsible for any immobilization, towing or storage fees, then the city shall bear the expense of immobilization, towing and storage. However, said storage fee shall not exceed seventy-two (72) hours storage; provided, that the city shall bear any additional storage fees caused by any delay which is found to be the fault of the city including any delay caused by weekends or holidays. The owner, person lawfully entitled to possession, or the person in possession of the motor vehicle at the time that it was immobilized or towed shall be responsible for any additional storage fees beyond seventy-two (72) hours storage if the delay was not due to the fault of the city or due to a weekend or holiday. 
(h)  In those cases where a refund is warranted under paragraph (b) above, the city shall refund the immobilization, towing and storage fees up to seventy-two (72) hours storage, provided that the city shall bear any additional storage fees caused by any delay which is found to be the fault of the city including any delay caused by weekends or holidays. The owner, person lawfully entitled to possession, or the person in possession of the motor vehicle at the time that it was towed shall be responsible for any additional storage fees beyond seventy-two (72) hours storage if the delay was not due to the fault of the City or due to a weekend or holiday. 
(i)  It shall be duty of the clerk of the municipal court to furnish the chief of police an account of the final disposition of any case heard under the hearing procedure set forth in this section within twenty-four (24) hours after disposition thereof. 
(j)  The following notice shall be posted conspicuously in all places to which members of the public may reasonably be expected to come to recover immobilized and/or towed motor vehicles and in all police precincts. The property section of the police department shall be responsible for making the notices and posting them according to this section: 
Attention:
